title: Ranking-Based Neural Query Expansion for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely on effective query representation to retrieve relevant documents. This paper proposes a ranking-based neural query expansion approach, 'RQE-Net', which leverages a neural ranking model to identify informative terms for query expansion. Our approach involves training a neural network to predict the relevance of each term in the query context, and then using the top-ranked terms to expand the original query. Experimental results on several ad-hoc retrieval benchmarks demonstrate that RQE-Net outperforms existing query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sensor Fusion in Industrial Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) systems often rely on multi-modal sensors to monitor equipment health. However, integrating data from diverse sources poses significant challenges. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for multi-modal sensor fusion in industrial anomaly detection. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model complex relationships between sensors and attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities. Experimental results on a real-world industrial dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in detecting anomalies, while providing interpretability of sensor contributions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is crucial in many applications, but existing methods often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that detects anomalies while providing explanations for the detected outliers. Our approach consists of a hierarchical encoder that captures both local and global temporal patterns, followed by an attention-based anomaly scorer that highlights the most relevant features contributing to the anomaly. We evaluate HAN on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating improved detection performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to optimize queries by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on execution times. Our experiments on a real-world graph dataset show that our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Efficient Document Ranking in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: Modern search engines face the challenge of efficiently ranking documents from vast indexes. This paper presents a novel hybrid retrieval model, 'HRM', which combines the strengths of sparse and dense representations. HRM leverages a sparse term-frequency-based approach for initial retrieval and then refines the ranking using a dense neural network-based re-ranker. We propose a two-stage training strategy, where the sparse model is trained using a listwise loss function, and the dense model is fine-tuned using a pairwise loss function. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate that HRM significantly outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models in terms of both effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, where the goal is to reformulate the user's query to better capture their search intent. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks. Our method, called DeepQE, leverages a transformer-based architecture to learn a dense representation of the query and its context. We demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, such as pseudo-relevance feedback and term weighting, on several benchmark datasets. Furthermore, we show that our approach is robust to varying query lengths and can be adapted to different domains with minimal fine-tuning.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In distributed database systems, query optimization is critical to minimize response times and improve system scalability. Traditional optimization techniques rely on heuristics or exhaustive search, which may not adapt well to dynamic workloads or complex query patterns. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans. Our method, called 'RL-QOpt', uses a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy for query optimization, considering factors such as data distribution, network latency, and resource utilization. Experiments on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that RL-QOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Investigation of Cultural and Linguistic Biases
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their ability to understand and respond to diverse user populations is often limited by cultural and linguistic biases. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the impact of cultural and linguistic backgrounds on the effectiveness of voice assistants. We analyze the performance of three popular voice assistants across six languages and six cultural contexts, revealing significant disparities in response accuracy and user satisfaction. We propose a set of design recommendations for more inclusive voice assistants, including culturally sensitive language models, adaptive response generation, and user-centered feedback mechanisms.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture for multi-agent reinforcement learning. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex interactions between agents and their environment. Our approach enables agents to learn hierarchical representations of their observations, facilitating more effective exploration and exploitation in cooperative and competitive scenarios. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of learning efficiency and task performance.

title: Concurrent Transactional Support in Distributed In-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: In-memory database systems have gained popularity due to their high performance and low latency. However, they often lack robust support for concurrent transactions, leading to inconsistencies and performance degradation. This paper proposes a novel concurrency control protocol, 'TransAct', designed for distributed in-memory database systems. TransAct leverages a combination of optimistic concurrency control and multiversion concurrency control to ensure serializability and high performance. Our experimental evaluation using the TPC-C benchmark demonstrates that TransAct outperforms existing concurrency control protocols in terms of throughput and response time, while maintaining high transactional consistency.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities and preferences need to form coalitions to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a decentralized coalition formation protocol, 'AgentCoal', which leverages graph-based modeling and distributed constraint optimization techniques. AgentCoal enables agents to autonomously form coalitions, negotiate task assignments, and adapt to dynamic changes in the environment. Experimental results demonstrate that AgentCoal outperforms existing centralized approaches in terms of task completion rate, coalition stability, and agent satisfaction.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of cloud-based Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms, optimizing query performance for multiple tenants has become a pressing concern. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MultiTenOpt', which leverages machine learning-based query plan prediction and adaptive resource allocation to minimize query latency and resource contention. We develop a probabilistic model to estimate query execution times and resource utilization, and propose a dynamic scheduling algorithm to allocate resources efficiently. Experimental results on a real-world DBaaS platform demonstrate that MultiTenOpt reduces average query latency by up to 30% and improves resource utilization by 25% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Enhanced Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-Hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component of ad-hoc information retrieval systems, as it aims to refine user queries to better match relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel QE approach leveraging deep neural networks, specifically designed to capture semantic relationships between query terms and document content. Our model, dubbed 'NeuroQE', incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to weight query term importance and a graph convolutional network to model document structure. Experimental results on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness over state-of-the-art QE methods, particularly for ambiguous and under-specified queries.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to decentralized task allocation for multi-agent systems using graph convolutional networks (GCNs). Our method, called DAGAT, leverages the graph structure of the agent communication network to learn efficient task allocation policies. We formulate the task allocation problem as a graph optimization problem and use GCNs to learn a decentralized policy that minimizes the total latency and improves the overall system throughput. Experimental results on a simulated multi-agent system demonstrate that DAGAT outperforms existing decentralized task allocation methods, achieving an average latency reduction of 23% and a 17% increase in system throughput.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) rely on reinforcement learning (RL) to make critical decisions, but the lack of transparency in RL models poses significant safety concerns. This paper proposes an explainable RL framework, 'XRL', that integrates model-based and model-free RL with attention mechanisms to generate visual explanations for AV decision-making. We evaluate XRL on a real-world driving dataset and demonstrate improved interpretability and safety compared to state-of-the-art RL methods. Our approach has significant implications for the development of trustworthy and accountable AV systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Modern Column-Oriented Databases
paper_abstract: Column-oriented databases have gained popularity in recent years due to their improved storage efficiency and query performance. However, optimizing queries for these databases remains a challenging task. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning techniques to predict the most efficient query plan. Our approach, called 'ColOpt', utilizes a combination of feature extraction and reinforcement learning to adapt to changing workload patterns and database schema. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColOpt outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 35% in terms of query execution time.

title: Holistic Data Profiling for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Data profiling is a crucial step in data integration and data quality assessment. However, existing profiling techniques are often limited to centralized databases, neglecting the complexities of distributed database systems. This paper presents 'D-Profiler', a novel, holistic data profiling framework designed for distributed databases. D-Profiler leverages a hierarchical clustering algorithm to identify correlated data fragments across nodes, and applies a probabilistic estimation approach to efficiently compute statistical summaries. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate that D-Profiler outperforms state-of-the-art profiling methods in terms of accuracy and scalability.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Improving Retrieval Effectiveness
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems to improve the retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach using deep reinforcement learning, which learns to select the most informative terms to add to the original query. Our approach, called DRL-QE, uses a deep Q-network to learn the policy of selecting expansion terms based on their expected reward, which is defined as the relevance of the expanded query to the user's information need. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that DRL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, including those based on pseudo-relevance feedback and word embeddings.

title: Indexing Schemes for Efficient Query Optimization in Time-Series Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential growth in time-series data, making query optimization in such databases a pressing concern. This paper presents a novel indexing scheme, TSIndex, which leverages the temporal and spatial correlations inherent in time-series data. TSIndex uses a hybrid approach combining a partitioned B-tree index with a compact, matrix-based representation of time-series data. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that TSIndex outperforms existing indexing schemes by up to 30% in terms of query response time and storage efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) to understand how agents make decisions. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for MARL, which incorporates attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions. Our approach enables the identification of influential agents and the attribution of rewards to individual agents' actions, leading to more interpretable policies. We evaluate HAN on a suite of cooperative and competitive MARL benchmarks, demonstrating improved explainability and robustness compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Dimensional Data Warehouses using Genetic Algorithms
paper_abstract: Optimizing query performance is crucial in data warehousing, especially when dealing with large, multi-dimensional datasets. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using genetic algorithms (GAs). We propose a chromosome representation that encodes query execution plans and develop a custom crossover operator that leverages query plan similarities. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that our GA-based optimizer outperforms traditional rule-based and cost-based optimizers, achieving an average query execution time reduction of 23.4%. Our approach is particularly effective for complex queries involving multiple joins and aggregations.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A User-Centered Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive voice assistants, focusing on the accessibility and usability challenges faced by older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants aged 65+, identifying key pain points and areas for improvement. Our findings inform the development of a novel voice assistant prototype, 'ElderVoice', which incorporates features such as natural language processing for cognitive support, personalized feedback, and multimodal output. A usability evaluation with 20 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Hierarchical Neural Topic Models
paper_abstract: Neural topic models have shown promising results in document ranking tasks, but their computational complexity often limits their applicability to large-scale datasets. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural topic model, 'HiNTM', which leverages a tree-structured architecture to efficiently capture topic hierarchies in documents. Our approach enables fast and accurate document ranking by learning to focus on relevant topics and ignoring irrelevant ones. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HiNTM in retrieving relevant documents, outperforming state-of-the-art neural ranking models while reducing computational costs.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but designing effective user interfaces remains a significant challenge. This paper investigates the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user experience in VR. We propose a novel framework, 'AvatarGen', which generates customized avatars based on user preferences and behavior. Our user study involving 50 participants shows that personalized avatars lead to increased user engagement, reduced cognitive load, and improved overall satisfaction. We also identify key factors influencing avatar design and provide guidelines for VR developers.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking for Conversational Search using Hierarchical Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to engage users in natural language dialogues, but often struggle to accurately re-rank relevant documents. This paper presents a novel approach, 'ConverseRank', which leverages hierarchical neural networks to adaptively re-rank search results based on conversational context. We propose a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes ranking, intent detection, and response generation tasks. Experimental results on a large-scale conversational search dataset demonstrate significant improvement in ranking accuracy and user satisfaction over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) aims to identify sentiment expressed through multiple modalities, such as text, images, and audio. Existing approaches often rely on early or late fusion, neglecting the complex interactions between modalities. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for MSA, which learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and their interactions at multiple levels. Our HAN model comprises modality-specific attention modules and a cross-modal fusion layer, enabling the model to capture both intra- and inter-modality relationships. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of our approach over state-of-the-art methods, achieving improved accuracy and robustness in MSA tasks.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Query Expansion on Neural Retrieval Models for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown promising results in ad-hoc search tasks, but their performance can be sensitive to the choice of query representation. In this paper, we investigate the effectiveness of query expansion techniques in improving the retrieval performance of neural models. We propose a novel query expansion framework that leverages both local and global context information to generate expanded queries. Our experiments on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly improves the retrieval performance of state-of-the-art neural models, particularly for difficult queries. We also provide insights into the characteristics of queries that benefit most from query expansion.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its adoption is hindered by a lack of accessibility features for users with disabilities. This paper presents a novel, inclusive VR design framework that incorporates insights from disability studies and human-computer interaction. We conducted a participatory design study with 20 users with diverse abilities and developed a set of guidelines for designing accessible VR experiences. Our evaluation of a prototype VR application demonstrates significant improvements in usability and user engagement for users with disabilities. The proposed framework has implications for promoting digital inclusion and enhancing the overall VR experience.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years, as they provide transparency and accountability in decision-making processes. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) model, which incorporates both item and user-level attention mechanisms to generate personalized explanations for recommendations. We leverage graph neural networks to model complex relationships between users, items, and features, and introduce a hierarchical attention framework to selectively focus on relevant information. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art ERS models in terms of both recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: EyeGazeAuth: A Machine Learning Approach to Secure Authentication Using Eye Movement Patterns
paper_abstract: Traditional authentication methods, such as passwords and biometrics, are vulnerable to various attacks. This paper proposes EyeGazeAuth, a novel authentication system that leverages machine learning to analyze eye movement patterns. We collect eye-tracking data from 100 participants and train a convolutional neural network to distinguish between genuine and impostor users. Our approach achieves an accuracy of 97.5% and outperforms existing authentication methods in resisting shoulder-surfing and replay attacks. We also conduct a user study to evaluate the usability and perceived security of EyeGazeAuth, demonstrating its potential for high-security applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Explainability is a crucial aspect of multi-agent decision-making, particularly in real-world applications like autonomous vehicles and smart grids. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to generate interpretable explanations for joint agent decisions. Our approach leverages agent-specific attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant features and interactions, enabling the identification of key contributing factors to the collective decision. Experimental results on a suite of multi-agent benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in improving both decision quality and explainability, outperforming existing baselines.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In distributed multi-agent systems, task allocation is a fundamental problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper presents a novel decentralized approach based on distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) to allocate tasks to agents in a robust and efficient manner. Our method leverages the agents' local knowledge and communication capabilities to iteratively refine task assignments, ensuring that global constraints are satisfied. Experiments on a simulated rescue scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized algorithms in terms of solution quality and communication overhead.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Traffic signal control is a complex problem that requires coordinating multiple agents to optimize traffic flow. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MARL) framework, 'TrafficCoor', which enables agents to learn coordinated policies for traffic signal control. We introduce a graph-based attention mechanism that allows agents to share information and adapt to dynamic traffic conditions. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulation platform demonstrate that TrafficCoor outperforms traditional traffic signal control methods, reducing congestion and travel times by up to 20%.

title: Designing Augmented Reality Interfaces for Elderly Users with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) technology has the potential to enhance the daily lives of elderly individuals with cognitive impairments, but existing AR interfaces often neglect their specific needs. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create accessible and usable AR interfaces for this population. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with elderly participants and caregivers to identify key design requirements, such as simplicity, clear guidance, and error tolerance. Our prototype, 'EasyAR', incorporates these principles and is evaluated through a usability study, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to commercial AR systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Robot Learning
paper_abstract: Robots operating in complex environments require interpretable decision-making models to ensure safety and efficiency. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture for robot learning, which integrates attention mechanisms and graph neural networks to learn hierarchical representations of robot states and environments. By leveraging attention weights, our approach provides explainable policies for robot navigation and manipulation tasks. Experimental results on a robotic grasping benchmark demonstrate improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for coordinating traffic signal control in urban transportation networks. We model the problem as a Markov game, where each agent represents a traffic signal and learns to optimize its control policy based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Our proposed algorithm, 'MAST', incorporates a novel attention mechanism to focus on critical intersections and adapt to changing traffic patterns. Simulation results on a large-scale traffic network demonstrate that MAST outperforms traditional optimization methods and state-of-the-art reinforcement learning baselines, reducing congestion and travel times by up to 25%.

title: Evaluating Embodiment Effects on Social Presence in Virtual Reality-based Remote Collaboration
paper_abstract: As remote collaboration becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding the role of embodiment in social presence is crucial. This study investigates how varying levels of embodiment in Virtual Reality (VR) affect user experience and social presence in remote collaboration. We conducted a within-subjects experiment with 30 participants, utilizing a custom-built VR platform with three conditions: (1) low embodiment (text-based chat), (2) moderate embodiment ( avatar-based interaction), and (3) high embodiment (full-body tracking). Results show that higher levels of embodiment significantly enhance social presence, trust, and collaboration quality, but also increase cognitive load and simulator sickness. Our findings inform the design of VR-based remote collaboration systems that balance embodiment, usability, and user experience.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to bridge the semantic gap between user queries and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel approach, 'DeepQL', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize query expansion. We formulate query expansion as a Markov decision process, where the agent learns to select expansion terms that maximize the expected retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Temporal Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has shown remarkable success in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks in DRL using temporal graph convolutional networks (T-GCNs). Our method, dubbed 'T-Guard', leverages the graph structure of DRL policies to identify abnormal behavior patterns indicative of attacks. We demonstrate the effectiveness of T-Guard in detecting various types of attacks, including poisoning and evasion attacks, on a range of DRL benchmarks. Our results show that T-Guard outperforms state-of-the-art detection methods, achieving an average detection accuracy of 92.5%.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing Cognitive Load for Elderly Users
paper_abstract: This study investigates the potential of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in alleviating cognitive load for elderly users when interacting with complex digital systems. We designed an ECA-based interface for a medication reminder system and evaluated its effectiveness through a user study with 30 elderly participants. Our results show that the ECA-based interface significantly reduced cognitive load, improved user experience, and enhanced task performance compared to a traditional text-based interface. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of accessible and user-centered HCI systems for older adults.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hyperbolic Geometry for Scalable AI Systems
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) is a crucial component of many AI systems, but existing methods struggle to scale to large graphs. We propose a novel KGE approach, HyperKG, which leverages the properties of hyperbolic geometry to efficiently represent complex relationships in knowledge graphs. By exploiting the hierarchical structure of hyperbolic spaces, HyperKG achieves state-of-the-art performance on benchmark datasets while reducing computational costs by up to 70%. We demonstrate the scalability of HyperKG on a massive knowledge graph with millions of entities and relationships, paving the way for its adoption in real-world AI applications.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatar-Based Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Learning Environments
paper_abstract: As online learning platforms proliferate, optimizing user engagement has become a crucial concern. This study investigates the effectiveness of personalized avatar-based feedback in virtual learning environments. We designed an immersive virtual reality interface that provides learners with a customized avatar, which offers real-time guidance and encouragement. Our mixed-methods approach combines gesture recognition, sentiment analysis, and user surveys to quantify the impact of avatar-based feedback on learner motivation, self-efficacy, and knowledge retention. Results indicate that personalized avatars significantly enhance user engagement, particularly among novice learners, and improve overall learning outcomes.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) to recognize emotions from multi-modal data. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention modules that learn to focus on relevant features and a hierarchical fusion module that integrates the outputs from each modality. We also introduce a novel explainability technique, called Emotion Attribution, to provide insights into the decision-making process of our model. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of emotion recognition accuracy and provides meaningful explanations for the predicted emotions.

title: Indexing Techniques for Efficient Query Processing in Distributed Document-Oriented Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed document-oriented databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large collections of semi-structured data. However, query processing in these systems remains a significant performance bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'DocIndex', which leverages the inherent structure of document data to accelerate query execution. Our approach combines a hierarchical indexing scheme with a distributed caching mechanism to minimize query latency and improve overall system throughput. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DocIndex outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 3x in query response time while maintaining a low storage overhead.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Older Adults: A Participatory Approach
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to enhance the lives of older adults, but existing VR systems often neglect their unique needs and abilities. This paper presents a participatory design approach to creating inclusive VR experiences for older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and HCI experts to identify key accessibility barriers and opportunities for innovation. Our findings inform the development of a novel VR system that incorporates adaptive interfaces, personalized feedback, and social features to support older adults' cognitive, physical, and emotional well-being. A user study with 20 older adults demonstrates the feasibility and effectiveness of our approach.

title: Efficient Indexing for High-Dimensional Data Using Learned Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: High-dimensional data indexing is a crucial problem in various applications, including similarity search and nearest neighbor retrieval. Bloom filters have been widely used for this purpose, but their performance degrades significantly with increasing dimensionality. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'Learned Bloom', which leverages machine learning techniques to optimize the construction of Bloom filters for high-dimensional data. Our method uses a neural network to learn a compact representation of the data, which is then used to construct a Bloom filter that minimizes false positives. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that Learned Bloom outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques, achieving up to 3x faster query times and 2x better accuracy.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Dense Retrieval
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents for answer extraction. This paper introduces Hierarchical Dense Retrieval (HDR), a novel approach that leverages dense passage representations and hierarchical clustering to reduce the search space. HDR achieves a significant reduction in retrieval latency while maintaining or improving retrieval accuracy compared to state-of-the-art dense retrieval methods. We evaluate HDR on several ODQA benchmarks, demonstrating its effectiveness in retrieving relevant passages and improving end-to-end QA performance.

title: EmoReact: A Multimodal Emotion Recognition Framework for Enhanced Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction (HCI), enabling systems to respond empathetically to user needs. This paper presents EmoReact, a novel multimodal emotion recognition framework that integrates computer vision, speech processing, and natural language processing to analyze user emotions. EmoReact employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to fuse features from different modalities, achieving improved recognition accuracy compared to unimodal approaches. We evaluate EmoReact on a large, publicly available dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in enhancing user experience in various HCI applications, including virtual assistants and affective gaming.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Diverse Documents using Hierarchical Clustering and Topic Modeling
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems often struggle to provide diverse and relevant search results, particularly for ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages hierarchical clustering and topic modeling to retrieve a diverse set of documents. Our method, dubbed 'DivTR', first applies hierarchical clustering to group similar documents based on their semantic features. Then, it employs topic modeling to identify the underlying topics in each cluster and rank documents according to their topic relevance. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that DivTR outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval diversity and precision.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on handcrafted features and heuristics. This paper explores the application of deep neural networks to learn query expansion models from large-scale datasets. We propose a novel architecture, 'QNCE', which integrates query and document representations using a neural cross-encoder. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain. We also analyze the learned query expansion strategies and demonstrate their interpretability.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Multi-Agent Systems in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel planning framework for multi-agent systems operating in dynamic environments. We propose a hierarchical task network (HTN) planning approach that integrates symbolic planning with geometric reasoning to generate feasible plans for multiple agents. Our framework can handle complex tasks, such as search and rescue operations, by decomposing them into sub-tasks and allocating them to individual agents. We evaluate our approach in simulated scenarios and demonstrate its effectiveness in adapting to changing environmental conditions. The results show significant improvements in plan efficiency and robustness compared to flat planning methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data, but existing methods struggle to scale to large graphs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages a hierarchical clustering of nodes to reduce computational complexity. HGAT adaptively selects relevant node features and attention weights at each level, enabling efficient processing of massive graphs. Experimentally, we demonstrate HGAT's state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, outperforming existing methods by up to 15% in terms of node classification accuracy.

title: Query Expansion using Attention-based Neural Re-ranking for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural retrieval models often require computationally expensive re-ranking of large document collections. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'AttentiveXP', which leverages attention mechanisms to selectively incorporate relevant terms from the top-ranked documents into the query representation. Our method reduces the number of documents to be re-ranked while preserving retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on the TREC-COVID dataset demonstrate that AttentiveXP achieves significant speedups over state-of-the-art neural models while maintaining comparable retrieval performance.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to enhance the lives of older adults with cognitive impairments, but existing VR interfaces often present accessibility barriers. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating accessible VR interfaces tailored to the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 20 participants, combining interviews, surveys, and usability testing. Our findings inform the development of a novel VR interface framework, 'CARE', which incorporates cognitive support features, tactile feedback, and simplified navigation. A pilot study demonstrates the efficacy of CARE in improving user experience and reducing cognitive load.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often lack interpretability and may not generalize well to unseen scenarios. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates visual, acoustic, and linguistic features for emotion recognition. Our HAN model employs a top-down attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant modalities and regions, allowing for decomposition of the recognition process and improved explainability. Experimental results on the EmoReact dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal fusion methods and provides insightful visualizations of the decision-making process.

title: Unsupervised Query Intent Identification using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Query intent identification is a crucial task in information retrieval, as it enables search engines to provide more relevant results. Existing methods rely on annotated datasets, which are time-consuming and expensive to create. This paper proposes a novel unsupervised approach, HiGAT, which leverages hierarchical graph attention networks to model the complex relationships between query terms and their context. We evaluate HiGAT on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in intent identification accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods. Furthermore, we show that HiGAT can be easily adapted to different domains and languages, making it a versatile solution for real-world search applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal inputs (e.g., text, audio, and vision) is a challenging task due to the complexity and diversity of human emotions. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that captures both intra-modality and inter-modality relationships. Our HAN model consists of three stages: (1) modality-specific feature extraction, (2) attention-based feature fusion, and (3) hierarchical attention for emotion classification. Experimental results on the Multimodal Emotion Recognition (MER) benchmark dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods by 12.5% in terms of weighted F1-score.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Biomedical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Biomedical information retrieval (BIR) often requires precise query formulation to retrieve relevant documents. This paper proposes a neural query expansion framework, 'BioQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to generate semantically enriched query embeddings. By incorporating domain-specific ontologies and relevance feedback, BioQE significantly improves retrieval performance on benchmark biomedical datasets. Our experiments demonstrate that BioQE outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision and a 20% increase in recall.

title: Autonomous Agent Coordination for Efficient Resource Allocation in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed systems often face the challenge of efficient resource allocation, which can be exacerbated by the lack of coordination among autonomous agents. This paper presents a novel decentralized coordination framework, 'Agent Harmony', that enables agents to dynamically adjust their resource allocation strategies based on real-time system conditions. Our approach leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning and graph-based modeling to optimize resource utilization. Experimental results on a simulated cloud computing environment demonstrate that Agent Harmony outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods, achieving up to 25% improvement in resource efficiency and 30% reduction in latency.

title: Scalable and Interpretable Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks, but their scalability and interpretability remain significant challenges. This paper proposes 'GraphExplainer', a novel GNN framework that leverages attention mechanisms and graph signal processing techniques to improve both scalability and interpretability. We introduce a hierarchical graph pooling strategy that reduces the computational complexity of GNNs while preserving node representations. Furthermore, we develop a feature importance metric that provides insights into the decision-making process of GraphExplainer. Experimental results on multiple real-world graph datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our approach.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages graph structural properties and machine learning-based cost estimation to reduce query latency and improve system throughput. We evaluate GraphOpt on a suite of real-world graph datasets and demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art query optimizers.

title: Efficient Indexing for High-Dimensional Data using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: High-dimensional data indexing is a crucial task in many data-intensive applications, but existing methods suffer from scalability issues and poor performance. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach, 'DeepIndex', which leverages the power of deep neural networks to efficiently index high-dimensional data. By learning a compact representation of the data using a hierarchical neural network, DeepIndex achieves significant improvements in query performance and storage efficiency compared to traditional indexing methods. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DeepIndex on various real-world datasets, showcasing its potential in accelerating query processing for modern data analytics.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Task-Oriented Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: We propose a decentralized coalition formation framework for task-oriented multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities and interests need to form coalitions to accomplish complex tasks. Our approach leverages distributed constraint optimization and machine learning-based negotiation protocols to enable agents to self-organize and form efficient coalitions. We evaluate our approach through extensive simulations, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving task completion rates and reducing communication overhead compared to centralized coalition formation methods.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Mixed-Methods Study
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces, such as voice assistants and chatbots, have become increasingly prevalent in daily life. However, older adults often face difficulties using these systems due to cognitive, sensory, and motor impairments. This paper presents a mixed-methods study that combines user research, usability testing, and design prototyping to develop accessible conversational interfaces tailored to the needs of older adults. Our findings highlight the importance of designing for simplicity, clarity, and flexibility, and provide recommendations for improving the accessibility of conversational interfaces for this population.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for explainable multi-agent decision making. Our approach enables agents to selectively focus on relevant communication messages and reasoning patterns, leading to improved decision-making outcomes and increased transparency. We evaluate our HAN framework on a benchmark multi-agent cooperative navigation task and demonstrate significant performance gains over existing state-of-the-art methods. Furthermore, we provide visualizations of attention weights to facilitate understanding of the agents' decision-making processes.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Graph-based Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their performance and security. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks in deep neural networks using graph-based anomaly detection techniques. We model the neural network's activation patterns as a graph and utilize graph-based metrics to identify anomalies indicative of adversarial attacks. Our approach is evaluated on several benchmark datasets and demonstrates improved detection accuracy compared to existing methods. We further analyze the robustness of our approach against various types of attacks and provide insights into the vulnerability of different neural network architectures.

title: Designing Adaptive Visualizations for Enhancing Cognitive Load Management in Intelligent Tutoring Systems
paper_abstract: Intelligent tutoring systems (ITS) often rely on visualizations to convey complex information to learners. However, poorly designed visualizations can lead to cognitive overload, negatively impacting learning outcomes. This paper presents a novel approach to adaptive visualization in ITS, which dynamically adjusts visualization complexity based on real-time learner cognitive load assessment. Our approach leverages machine learning-based cognitive load modeling and real-time visualization adaptation using a cognitive load-aware visual encoding scheme. A user study with 120 participants demonstrates that our approach significantly improves learning outcomes and reduces cognitive load compared to traditional visualization designs.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale network data. However, optimizing query performance for real-time analytics on distributed graph databases remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'GraphOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages graph structural properties and statistical models to predict query execution times. GraphOpt utilizes a cost-based optimization approach, incorporating distributed query planning and adaptive result caching to minimize query latency. Experimental results on a real-world social network dataset demonstrate that GraphOpt reduces query execution times by up to 5x compared to existing state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments. However, existing VR systems often neglect the unique needs and abilities of this population. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive VR experiences for older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and caregivers to identify key design requirements. Our VR system incorporates cognitive support features, such as simplified interfaces and personalized navigation, to facilitate engagement and independence. A pilot study with 20 participants demonstrates improved usability and enjoyment compared to existing VR systems.

title: Hierarchical Neural Ranking for Efficient Document Retrieval in Enterprise Search
paper_abstract: Enterprise search systems require efficient and accurate document retrieval to meet the information needs of users. This paper presents a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HNR-ES', which leverages a combination of dense passage retrieval and hierarchical attention mechanisms to improve retrieval efficiency and effectiveness. Our approach reduces the candidate set of documents through a coarse-grained retrieval stage, followed by a fine-grained ranking stage that incorporates semantic and structural features of the documents. Experimental results on a large-scale enterprise search dataset demonstrate that HNR-ES outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models in terms of recall, precision, and latency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that selectively focuses on relevant modalities and emotion cues to improve recognition accuracy. Our HAN model consists of a multi-modal fusion layer, a modality attention module, and an emotion attention module. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recognition accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Ranking Model Adaptation for Cold Start Problem in Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Cold start problem in recommendation systems occurs when there is limited user interaction data for new items or users. This paper proposes a novel ranking model adaptation approach, 'CRA', which leverages transfer learning and meta-learning to adapt a pre-trained ranking model to the cold start scenario. CRA learns to extract relevant features from the limited data and adapts the model to the new distribution. Experimental results on multiple real-world datasets demonstrate that CRA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in addressing the cold start problem, achieving up to 25% improvement in recommendation accuracy.

title: Improving Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems are critical for handling large-scale data queries. However, existing DIR systems suffer from high query latency and poor efficiency. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach, called HiDir, which leverages the principles of distributed hash tables and peer-to-peer networks to enable efficient query routing and document retrieval. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that HiDir reduces query latency by up to 40% and improves query throughput by up to 25% compared to state-of-the-art DIR systems.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Augmented Reality Interfaces for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) technology has the potential to revolutionize the way people interact with digital information. However, users with motor impairments, such as those with spinal cord injuries or Parkinson's disease, face significant challenges in interacting with AR interfaces. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system, 'GazeAR', which leverages eye-tracking technology to enable users to select and manipulate virtual objects in AR environments. We evaluate GazeAR with a user study involving 15 participants with motor impairments and demonstrate improved interaction accuracy and efficiency compared to traditional gaze-based systems.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction. However, user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user experience in VR. We conducted a user study with 100 participants, using a novel avatar customization system that incorporates facial recognition and machine learning-based personality inference. Our results show that personalized avatars lead to increased user satisfaction, reduced cognitive load, and improved task performance. We also identify key design factors that influence user avatar attachment and discuss implications for VR interface design.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Reasoning for Real-world Multi-Hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-hop question answering (MHQA) requires models to perform complex reasoning across multiple sentences. While transformer-based architectures have shown promising results, they often lack interpretability and transparency. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Reasoning (HAER) framework that integrates attention mechanisms with symbolic reasoning to generate interpretable explanations for MHQA tasks. Our approach leverages graph-based attention to identify relevant sentences and entities, and then applies a hierarchical reasoning module to generate step-by-step explanations. Experimental results on the HotPotQA dataset demonstrate that HAER outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Efficient Transfer Learning for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often struggle to effectively fuse information from disparate modalities. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) framework for MSA, which leverages transfer learning to adapt to new modalities. Our approach integrates graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between modalities and adaptively weights their contributions to sentiment prediction. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average improvement of 4.2% in accuracy and 3.5% in F1-score.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms have become increasingly popular, but optimizing queries in these environments remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'TenantAware', which leverages tenant-specific workload patterns and resource utilization to minimize query latency and improve overall system efficiency. We propose a hybrid approach that combines traditional query optimization techniques with machine learning-based models to accurately predict query execution times and optimize resource allocation. Experimental results on a real-world DBaaS platform demonstrate that TenantAware achieves an average query latency reduction of 30% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Indexing Techniques for Efficient Query Processing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular, but query processing remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'Distributed Hash Index' (DHI), which enables efficient query processing in distributed database systems. DHI leverages a combination of hash-based indexing and distributed data partitioning to minimize query latency and improve system throughput. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DHI outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 30% in terms of query response time and 25% in terms of system throughput.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation for autonomous agents using multi-agent reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'AgentQ', where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their individual capabilities and environmental observations. AgentQ utilizes a hierarchical graph neural network to model inter-agent dependencies and a distributed Q-learning algorithm to optimize task assignments. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse scenario demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require efficient task allocation to achieve complex goals. However, the combinatorial nature of task allocation problems makes them challenging to solve, especially in distributed settings. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to allocate tasks in multi-agent systems. Our method, called 'Distributed Task Allocator' (DTA), uses a decentralized actor-critic framework to learn task allocation policies that maximize system performance. We evaluate DTA in a simulated environment and demonstrate its ability to adapt to changing task requirements and agent availability. The results show that DTA outperforms traditional task allocation algorithms in terms of task completion time and system utility.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Empirical Study on User Experience with Synthetic Speech
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their user experience is often limited by the quality of synthetic speech. This paper presents an empirical study on the impact of synthetic speech on user experience, focusing on users with disabilities. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants, using a custom-built voice assistant with varying levels of speech naturalness. Our results show that users with disabilities prefer more natural speech, but also value customizability and adaptability in voice assistants. We propose a set of design recommendations for creating more inclusive voice assistants, emphasizing the need for user-centered design and speech personalization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Semantic Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, aiming to reformulate user queries to better capture their intent. We propose a novel QE approach, NeuroQE, which leverages neural semantic embeddings to model the relationships between query terms and their expansions. By incorporating a graph-based attention mechanism, NeuroQE can effectively capture the context and semantic nuances of the query, leading to improved retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art QE techniques, achieving significant gains in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot node classification is a challenging task in graph-structured data, where only a limited number of labeled nodes are available for training. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages self-supervised learning to learn node representations from unlabeled data. HGAT consists of a hierarchical clustering module that recursively partitions the graph into smaller clusters, followed by a graph attention module that aggregates node features within each cluster. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot node classification tasks, achieving an average accuracy improvement of 12.5%.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Intent Detection in Conversational AI
paper_abstract: Conversational AI systems rely on accurate intent detection to provide relevant responses. Existing approaches often struggle with complex, multi-turn dialogues and contextual dependencies. We propose a novel hierarchical attention graph neural network (HAGNN) architecture that models conversation structures and captures subtle intent cues. HAGNN leverages graph attention mechanisms to identify salient context nodes and hierarchical attention to integrate information across turns. Experimental results on a large-scale conversational dataset demonstrate significant improvements in intent detection accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art models.

title: Meta-Learning based Few-Shot Learning for Time Series Classification
paper_abstract: Time series classification (TSC) is a ubiquitous problem in many applications, but it often suffers from the scarcity of labeled data. Few-shot learning (FSL) has shown promise in addressing this challenge, but existing methods are typically designed for image or text data. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning approach, MetaTSC, which adapts to new TSC tasks with only a few labeled examples. We introduce a task-agnostic metric learning module that captures the underlying patterns in time series data, and a task-specific adaptation module that fine-tunes the model for each new task. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of MetaTSC in achieving state-of-the-art performance with minimal labeled data.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is crucial in various applications, including IoT, finance, and healthcare. However, most existing methods lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand the underlying causes of anomalies. This paper proposes Hierarchical Attention Networks (HAN) for explainable time-series anomaly detection. HAN leverages self-attention mechanisms to capture complex patterns and relationships in time-series data. We introduce a novel hierarchical architecture that combines local and global attention to identify anomalous segments and their contributing features. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in detecting anomalies and providing interpretable explanations.

title: Explainable AI for Human-Robot Collaboration: A Cognitive Architecture
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly collaborate with humans in complex tasks, it is essential to develop Explainable AI (XAI) techniques that provide insights into the robot's decision-making process. This paper presents a novel cognitive architecture, 'CogXAI', that integrates XAI with cognitive models of human-robot collaboration. CogXAI uses attention-based neural networks to generate explanations for the robot's actions, which are then validated through user studies. Our results show that CogXAI improves trust and understanding between humans and robots, leading to more effective collaboration in tasks such as assembly and search-and-rescue.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: An Exploration of Gesture-Based Interaction Design
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed human-computer interaction, but the design of intuitive interfaces remains an open challenge. This paper investigates the role of embodied cognition in VR, focusing on gesture-based interaction design. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants, analyzing their gestures and brain activity while performing tasks in a custom-built VR environment. Our results show that gestures grounded in real-world experience enhance user performance and reduce cognitive load. We present a set of design guidelines for VR interface designers, emphasizing the importance of incorporating embodied cognition principles to create more natural and immersive interactions.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating heterogeneous multi-agent systems (MAS) is a challenging problem, particularly in scenarios involving agents with diverse capabilities and objectives. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to learn effective coordination strategies for MAS. We introduce a hierarchical DRL framework, 'CoMA', which consists of a high-level planning module and a low-level control module. The planning module learns to assign tasks to agents based on their capabilities and the control module learns to execute the assigned tasks. We evaluate CoMA in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario and demonstrate its ability to adapt to changing environmental conditions and agent failures.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification in graphs is a fundamental task in many applications, but existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity and poor scalability. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages graph attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and subgraphs. By hierarchically applying attention at multiple scales, HGAT reduces the number of parameters and computations required, achieving state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while being orders of magnitude faster than existing methods.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Proactive Task Reallocation for Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, autonomous agents often face unexpected task failures or changes in priority. This paper introduces a novel framework, 'Proactive Reallocation of Tasks' (PART), which enables agents to proactively reallocate tasks and adapt to changing circumstances. PART combines a predictive model with a distributed constraint optimization algorithm to identify and resolve potential task conflicts. Our experimental results demonstrate that PART significantly improves task completion rates and reduces idle time in simulated disaster response scenarios, compared to traditional reactive reallocation approaches.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Learned Indexes
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems are increasingly popular in cloud-based data management. However, optimizing queries for diverse workloads and tenants remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages learned indexes to improve query performance in multi-tenant environments. We propose a hierarchical indexing framework, 'MT-LIX', which combines traditional B+-tree indexing with machine learning-based index selection. Our approach adapts to changing workload patterns and tenant characteristics, achieving up to 3x query speedup compared to traditional indexing methods. Experimental results on a real-world cloud database workload demonstrate the efficacy of MT-LIX in reducing query latency and improving system scalability.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular in modern data storage and processing. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task due to the complexity of data distribution and network communication. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. Our method, called QOptRL, learns to select the optimal query plan based on the database's current state and the query's characteristics. We demonstrate that QOptRL outperforms traditional query optimizers in terms of query execution time and resource utilization, making it a promising solution for large-scale distributed databases.

title: Neural Query Expansion using Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it helps to disambiguate user queries and improve retrieval accuracy. However, traditional query expansion methods rely on manual feature engineering and suffer from scalability issues. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion framework, 'GraphQE', which leverages graph attention networks to model complex relationships between query terms and documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Inclusive Accessibility
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have transformed human-computer interaction, but their performance varies significantly across individuals, particularly those with motor impairments. This paper presents 'Adapta Gesture', a novel framework that leverages machine learning and computer vision to develop adaptive gesture recognition systems. Our approach combines a deep learning-based gesture recognition model with a user modeling component that dynamically adjusts to an individual's abilities and preferences. We conduct a user study with 25 participants, including 10 with motor impairments, and demonstrate improved recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing state-of-the-art systems.

title: Designing Adaptive Gestural Interfaces for Virtual Reality using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on pre-defined gestural interfaces, which can be limiting and frustrating for users. This paper presents a novel approach to designing adaptive gestural interfaces for VR using machine learning. We propose a framework that leverages user behavior data and gesture recognition algorithms to dynamically adapt the interface to individual users' preferences and abilities. Our evaluation shows that the proposed approach improves user experience and task performance in VR applications. We also discuss the implications of our findings for designing more accessible and user-centered VR systems.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Learning-based Contextual Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle with query ambiguity and limited context. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'ConEx', which leverages deep learning-based contextual embeddings to model complex relationships between query terms and relevant documents. Our method incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to weigh the importance of contextual clues and a graph-based algorithm to efficiently expand the query. Experimental results on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for queries with ambiguous meanings.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. Traditional query optimizers rely on heuristics and rules, which can lead to suboptimal plans. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'RL-QOpt', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans. We design a custom environment to model the query optimization problem and employ a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy. Experimental results on the TPC-H benchmark demonstrate that RL-QOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers, achieving an average speedup of 2.5x on complex queries.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user experience and engagement in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 50 participants, using a custom-built VR platform that incorporates real-time facial expression tracking and personalized avatar rendering. Our results show that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, measured through self-reported satisfaction and objective metrics such as session duration and interaction frequency. We also identify key factors influencing user preference for personalized avatars, including facial similarity and customization options.

title: Hybrid Attentional Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) aim to provide transparent and trustworthy suggestions to users. This paper introduces a novel hybrid approach, 'HAGN', which combines graph neural networks (GNNs) with attentional mechanisms to model complex user-item relationships. HAGN leverages graph structure to capture latent patterns and attention to emphasize relevant features, generating interpretable explanations for top-N recommendations. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGN in improving recommendation accuracy and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art ERS methods.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Embeddings and Hierarchical Clustering
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a fundamental task in natural language processing and information retrieval, but existing approaches often struggle with scalability and accuracy.
