This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach, 'GEDHIC', which leverages hierarchical clustering to efficiently disambiguate entities in large-scale knowledge graphs. By learning graph-based embeddings and incorporating semantic context, GEDHIC achieves state-of-the-art performance on multiple benchmark datasets, outperforming traditional machine learning-based methods. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GEDHIC in a real-world application, improving entity linking accuracy by 23% on a large Wikipedia dataset.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing in Cloud-Native Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Cloud-native relational databases have revolutionized data management, but query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents a novel adaptive indexing approach, 'Aurora', which leverages machine learning to dynamically optimize index structures based on workload patterns. Aurora integrates a lightweight, online index advisor with a hierarchical indexing framework, enabling real-time adaptation to changing query distributions. Our experimental evaluation on a cloud-based database instance shows that Aurora achieves an average query performance improvement of 35% compared to traditional, statically configured indexing schemes.

title: Embodiment and Agency in Virtual Reality: A Study on User Experience and Presence
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has made significant strides in recent years, but understanding the factors that influence user experience and presence remains an open challenge. This paper investigates the role of embodiment and agency in VR, exploring how users' sense of body ownership and control affect their feeling of immersion and engagement. We conducted a user study with 40 participants, utilizing a custom-built VR environment with varying levels of embodiment and agency. Our results show that users who experienced higher levels of embodiment and agency reported increased presence and enjoyment, and were more likely to exhibit exploratory behavior. These findings have implications for the design of VR systems that aim to enhance user experience and immersion.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decision-making often relies on complex interactions between agents. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant agent interactions to improve decision-making. By incorporating attention mechanisms at both local and global levels, HGAT provides interpretable insights into agent decision-making processes. We evaluate HGAT on a real-world autonomous driving dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in decision accuracy and explainability compared to existing graph-based methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to coordinate to achieve a common goal. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework, 'RL-TA', that leverages reinforcement learning to learn optimal task assignment policies. Our approach utilizes a decentralized Markov decision process to model the task allocation problem, and trains agents to make decisions based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate that RL-TA outperforms existing decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of task completion time and agent utility.

title: Exploiting Hierarchical Query Graphs for Efficient Semantic Search
paper_abstract: Semantic search has become a crucial component in various information retrieval systems, but its computational complexity hinders its widespread adoption. This paper proposes a novel approach to semantic search by exploiting the hierarchical structure of query graphs. We introduce a graph-based indexing technique that leverages the hierarchical relationships between entities to prune the search space, thereby reducing the number of candidate entities to be ranked. Our experiments on a large-scale knowledge graph demonstrate that our approach achieves significant improvements in query response time while maintaining the accuracy of the search results.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous task allocation in multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. Our proposed method, 'AdaTA', allows agents to learn task allocation policies through self-play and adapt to changing task requirements and agent capabilities. We evaluate AdaTA in a simulated environment and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion efficiency and agent utilization compared to traditional manual allocation and decentralized greedy approaches. The results have implications for real-world applications such as autonomous warehouse management and disaster response.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Approach
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need to design interfaces that are accessible and usable by older adults. This paper presents a novel multimodal interaction approach for conversational interfaces that combines speech, gesture, and gaze-based input. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults and found that our approach significantly improves interaction accuracy and reduces cognitive load compared to traditional speech-only interfaces. Our results also highlight the importance of personalized feedback and adaptive difficulty adjustment in promoting user engagement and confidence.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Social Presence in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding the factors that influence social presence in VR is crucial. This study investigates the role of embodiment in fostering social presence in VR. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, examining the effects of embodiment on social presence, self-report measures, and behavioral responses. Our results show that embodiment significantly enhances social presence, particularly when users can control their virtual bodies. We discuss the implications of our findings for VR-based social interactions and provide recommendations for designers and developers.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Relation Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot relation classification remains a challenging task in natural language processing, particularly when dealing with limited labeled data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that leverages both entity and relation graphs to capture complex semantic relationships. Our approach consists of two stages: (1) entity graph attention, which selectively focuses on relevant entities, and (2) relation graph attention, which models relationships between entities. Experimental results on the FewRel benchmark demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average accuracy improvement of 4.5% on 1-shot and 2.5% on 5-shot settings.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings via Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings (KGEs) have become a crucial component in various AI applications. However, existing methods suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) for efficient KGEs. HGAN leverages a hierarchical graph structure to adaptively focus on relevant entities and relationships, reducing the computational complexity of attention mechanisms. Experimental results on popular benchmarks demonstrate that HGAN achieves state-of-the-art performance in link prediction and entity classification tasks while requiring significantly fewer parameters and computations.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. However, most existing methods lack interpretability, making it challenging to identify the root cause of anomalies. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) for explainable time series anomaly detection. Our approach leverages a multi-scale attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant segments and features, providing insights into the anomaly detection process. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in detecting anomalies while offering improved interpretability and robustness to noise and concept drift.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Improving Search Result Diversity
paper_abstract: The proliferation of online information has made it increasingly challenging for search engines to provide diverse and relevant search results. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion approach, which incorporates user search history and preferences to generate expanded queries that capture the nuances of the original query intent. Our approach leverages a graph-based representation of the query context and employs a reinforcement learning-based ranking model to optimize the diversity of search results. Experimental results on a large-scale search engine dataset demonstrate significant improvements in search result diversity and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval typically relies on query expansion techniques to improve retrieval effectiveness. However, traditional methods often rely on simplistic weighting schemes and neglect the semantic relationships between query terms. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'NeuroExpander', which leverages deep neural networks to learn context-aware term representations. By incorporating these representations into a probabilistic retrieval model, NeuroExpander achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness over state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets. We also demonstrate the robustness of our approach to varying query lengths and domains.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and availability need to be assigned to tasks with different priorities and deadlines. We propose a decentralized approach using reinforcement learning, where each agent learns to make allocation decisions based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Our algorithm, called MARL-TA, uses a distributed Q-network to learn the optimal allocation policy, which is shown to outperform traditional centralized and heuristic-based methods in simulations with varying task and agent dynamics.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Relevant Code Snippets using Hierarchical Neural Network-based Embeddings
paper_abstract: Code search and retrieval play a crucial role in software development, but existing techniques often struggle to capture the semantic relationships between code snippets. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages hierarchical neural network-based embeddings to model the syntax and semantics of code. Our method, called HiCoDe, learns a hierarchical representation of code snippets by recursively applying a neural network to capture both local and global patterns. Experiments on a large-scale code dataset demonstrate that HiCoDe outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph-based Anomaly Detection for Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their performance and reliability. This paper proposes a novel approach for detecting adversarial attacks using graph-based anomaly detection. We represent the neural network's output as a graph, where nodes correspond to neurons and edges represent the flow of activations. By analyzing the graph structure, we can identify anomalies indicative of adversarial attacks. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting a wide range of attacks, including those using advanced techniques such as gradient masking. Our method can be easily integrated into existing neural network architectures, providing an additional layer of security against adversarial threats.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various applications, including IoT, finance, and healthcare. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational costs and limited interpretability. This paper presents 'HATN', a novel hierarchical attention network that detects anomalies in time-series data with improved efficiency and explainability. HATN leverages a multi-scale attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant time-series segments, reducing the computational complexity of anomaly detection. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HATN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and speed, while providing intuitive visualizations of anomaly patterns.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities need to be assigned to tasks to maximize overall efficiency. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn distributed task allocation policies. We model the agent-task interaction as a graph and employ a GNN to learn the node representations, which are then used to predict the task assignments. Our approach is fully decentralized, scalable, and robust to changes in the agent or task sets. Experimental results on a variety of scenarios demonstrate significant improvements over traditional optimization-based methods, particularly in dynamic environments.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Hierarchical Prototypical Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification has garnered significant attention in recent years, but most existing methods rely on complex meta-learning algorithms or large-scale datasets. This paper proposes a novel approach, Hierarchical Prototypical Networks (HPN), which leverages a hierarchical representation of prototypes to improve few-shot classification accuracy. We demonstrate that HPN can adapt to new classes with only a few examples, outperforming state-of-the-art methods on benchmark datasets such as mini-ImageNet and tiered-ImageNet. Furthermore, we show that HPN can be seamlessly integrated with existing meta-learning frameworks, enhancing their performance in low-data regimes.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Hierarchical Graph Decomposition
paper_abstract: Pathfinding is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, but existing algorithms struggle with large-scale graphs. This paper presents a novel approach, 'HiMAP', which leverages hierarchical graph decomposition to reduce the search space. By recursively applying a clustering-based decomposition scheme, HiMAP efficiently identifies and resolves conflicts between agents in a distributed manner. Experimental results on synthetic and real-world benchmarks demonstrate that HiMAP outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of scalability, solution quality, and runtime, making it suitable for real-time applications in domains like autonomous vehicles and robotics.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Neural Embeddings for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a critical task in intellectual property search, where query expansion (QE) is a key technique to improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel QE approach that leverages neural embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms and patents. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weighs the importance of different terms in the query, and incorporate a patent-specific embedding space to better capture domain knowledge. Experimental results on a large patent corpus demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms traditional QE methods and achieves state-of-the-art performance in patent retrieval.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting models often lack transparency, making it challenging to understand their predictions. This paper presents 'HATSF', a hierarchical attention network that integrates interpretable components for explainable forecasting. Our approach encodes temporal dependencies using a novel hierarchical attention mechanism, allowing the model to selectively focus on relevant segments of the input sequence. We evaluate HATSF on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its ability to provide accurate forecasts while offering insights into the decision-making process. Experimental results show that HATSF outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of forecasting accuracy and interpretability.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Decentralized Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems in complex, dynamic environments is a challenging problem. This paper proposes a decentralized approach to solving partially observable Markov decision processes (POMDPs) in multi-agent systems. We introduce a novel method for learning decentralized policies using a combination of deep reinforcement learning and communication protocols. Our approach allows agents to share information and coordinate their actions in real-time, even in the presence of partial observability and uncertainty. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a variety of multi-agent scenarios, including robotic soccer and disaster response.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel approach to cooperative task allocation using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP). Our algorithm, called CATS, leverages a hybrid search strategy that combines constraint propagation with stochastic optimization to efficiently explore the vast solution space. We evaluate CATS on a range of benchmark problems and demonstrate its effectiveness in achieving near-optimal task allocations while minimizing communication overhead. The results show that CATS outperforms existing DCOP-based approaches in terms of solution quality and scalability.

title: Diversified Query Expansion for Domain-Specific Search Engines
paper_abstract: Domain-specific search engines often struggle to provide relevant results due to the limited scope of their indexed data. This paper proposes a novel diversified query expansion approach, 'DQE-DS', which incorporates both semantic and syntactic features to generate high-quality expansion terms. Our approach leverages a combination of word embeddings, named entity recognition, and part-of-speech tagging to identify context-specific keywords. Experimental results on a dataset of domain-specific searches demonstrate that DQE-DS outperforms existing query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval effectiveness and diversity of search results.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex, dynamic environments is a challenging problem in Artificial Intelligence. While recent advances in deep reinforcement learning have shown promise, they often lack transparency and interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that enables explainable multi-agent cooperation. By incorporating attention mechanisms at both the agent-level and team-level, HANs can selectively focus on relevant communication channels and task-oriented features, leading to improved cooperation and decision-making. We evaluate our approach on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, demonstrating significant performance gains and providing insights into the coordination strategies learned by the HAN.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval faces the challenge of effectively capturing query intent, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel graph-based embedding approach, 'GraphQE', which leverages the semantic relationships between query terms to generate informative expansions. By representing queries as graphs and applying a hierarchical attention mechanism, GraphQE identifies salient concepts and relationships, resulting in more accurate and diverse expansions. Experimental results on the TREC-8 Ad-Hoc Retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Knowledge Graph Embedding with Contrastive Learning for Multi-Modal AI Systems
paper_abstract: Integrating multiple modalities (e.g., vision, language, and audio) in AI systems often relies on knowledge graphs (KGs) to capture complex relationships. However, existing KG embedding methods struggle with heterogeneous data and noisy annotations. This paper proposes a novel contrastive learning framework, 'MultiModalCE', which jointly learns KG embeddings and modality-specific representations. By leveraging large-scale, unlabeled datasets and a carefully designed contrastive loss, MultiModalCE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both link prediction and entity classification tasks on several benchmark datasets.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become ubiquitous in modern data management, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We formulate the problem as a Markov decision process, where the agent learns to select optimal query plans based on runtime statistics and database state. Our experiments on a real-world distributed database show that our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, as it can significantly impact the relevance and ranking of retrieved documents. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages semantic relationships between query terms and documents to generate effective expansion terms. We employ a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture both local and global context, enabling the model to adapt to diverse query styles and document collections. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Enhancing Passage Retrieval in Conversational Search
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems rely on passage retrieval to provide relevant answers to user queries. However, the retrieval process often suffers from incomplete or noisy context, leading to suboptimal results. This paper presents a novel query-driven document expansion approach, 'QDE', which selectively incorporates relevant sentences from the top-retrieved documents to augment the original query. We propose a neural ranking model that leverages both local and global context to identify the most informative expansion sentences. Experimental results on the TREC Conversational Assistance Track dataset demonstrate that QDE significantly improves passage retrieval accuracy and relevance, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for adaptive traffic signal control. Our approach, called 'TrafficMA', leverages real-time traffic data to train a coalition of agents, each responsible for controlling a traffic signal in a network. By employing a decentralized, communication-based strategy, TrafficMA adapts to dynamic traffic patterns, reducing congestion and travel times. We evaluate TrafficMA using real-world traffic data from Pittsburgh, demonstrating improved performance compared to traditional, fixed-timing signal control methods.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Planning with Hierarchical Task Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent planning has become increasingly important in real-world applications, but scaling to large numbers of agents remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to multi-agent planning using hierarchical task networks (HTNs). Our method, 'MA-Plan', decomposes complex tasks into smaller sub-tasks and assigns them to individual agents based on their capabilities and availability. We introduce a hierarchical planning framework that iteratively refines task assignments and generates executable plans. Experimental results on a suite of benchmark problems demonstrate that MA-Plan outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of scalability, plan quality, and execution time.

title: Neural Architecture Search for Explainable Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Explainable time-series forecasting is crucial in many real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel neural architecture search (NAS) framework, 'TS-EXPLAIN', that automatically discovers interpretable and accurate time-series forecasting models. TS-EXPLAIN uses a reinforcement learning-based search strategy to identify the optimal neural architecture, incorporating a novel explainability metric that rewards models with transparent and coherent feature importance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of TS-EXPLAIN over state-of-the-art time-series forecasting models, achieving improved accuracy and explainability.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Medical Image Classification
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in medical image classification tasks, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and adoption in clinical practice. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that provides explainable and interpretable results. We design a multi-level attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant regions and features, generating attention maps that highlight diagnostic cues. Our experiments on a large dataset of chest X-rays demonstrate that HAN outperforms existing models while providing insights into the decision-making process, facilitating improved diagnosis and treatment.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various information retrieval tasks. However, their effectiveness often relies on the quality of the input queries. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion using pseudo-relevance feedback, which leverages the relevance signals from top-ranked documents to iteratively refine the query representation. We propose a neural architecture that incorporates a feedback module, which adaptively weights the importance of each feedback document to generate a more informative query expansion. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly improves the retrieval performance of neural models, outperforming existing query expansion techniques.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Label Node Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-label node classification is a fundamental problem in graph-structured data, where each node can belong to multiple classes. Existing approaches suffer from scalability issues and fail to capture complex relationships between labels. We propose a hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that learns to recursively aggregate node features and attentional weights at multiple scales. HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in F1-score and AUC-ROC. Additionally, we provide theoretical insights into the expressive power of HGAT and its robustness to label noise.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive conversational interfaces for this population. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 20 older adults with cognitive impairments, identifying key challenges and preferences in interacting with conversational agents. Our findings inform the development of a novel interface framework, 'CARE', which incorporates cognitive support strategies, such as explicit turn-taking cues and simplified language processing. A pilot study with 15 participants demonstrates CARE's effectiveness in improving user experience and reducing cognitive load.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction for Cognitive Load Reduction
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown great potential in enhancing learning experiences, but cognitive load remains a significant bottleneck. This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles in VR to reduce cognitive load. We designed a gesture-based interaction system, 'EmbodimentVR', which leverages users' bodily experiences to facilitate intuitive information processing. In a user study, we found that EmbodimentVR significantly reduced cognitive load and improved learning outcomes compared to traditional controller-based interactions. Our results suggest that embodied cognition can be an effective design principle for VR-based learning systems.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Conversational Search
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to retrieve relevant documents by simulating human-like interactions. However, existing methods suffer from information scarcity and semantic mismatch between queries and documents. This paper presents a novel query-driven document expansion approach, 'QDE', which selectively injects relevant context into documents to enhance their retrieval likelihood. Our method leverages a combination of lexical, syntactic, and semantic features to identify expansion candidates and incorporates a reinforcement learning framework to optimize the expansion policy. Experimental results on a large-scale conversational search dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance and efficiency using QDE.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, enabling more empathetic and personalized systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates multi-modal inputs from facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals. Our HAN model learns to focus on relevant input modalities and temporal segments, improving emotion recognition accuracy in the presence of noisy or missing data. Experimental results on a large, publicly available dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art performance for multi-modal emotion recognition tasks.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model agent interactions and task relationships. Our approach, dubbed 'GNN-TA', uses a distributed GNN architecture to learn a task allocation policy that minimizes communication overhead and maximizes system utility. We evaluate GNN-TA on a variety of synthetic and real-world scenarios, demonstrating its scalability and robustness in the presence of agent failures and dynamic task arrivals.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents through Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Urban traffic management is a complex problem that requires efficient coordination of autonomous agents to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for coordinating autonomous agents in urban traffic management. Our approach consists of two levels: a high-level planner that allocates agents to different regions of the city and a low-level controller that determines the optimal actions for each agent. We evaluate our approach using a simulated urban traffic environment and demonstrate significant improvements in traffic flow and travel times compared to traditional approaches.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-World Robotics
paper_abstract: Hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) has shown promise in solving complex robotics tasks, but its application to real-world scenarios remains limited due to high sample complexity. This paper proposes a novel efficient HRL framework, 'EHR', which leverages a hierarchical policy decomposition and a state-abstraction mechanism to reduce the exploration burden. We demonstrate EHR's effectiveness on a range of robotics tasks, including robotic grasping and manipulation, and show significant improvements in learning efficiency and task success rates compared to flat RL methods. Our results pave the way for the deployment of HRL in real-world robotics applications.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization in DDS remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of query execution plans and the dynamic nature of data distribution. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the DDS environment and receiving rewards based on query execution time. Our experimental results on a real-world dataset show that the proposed approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient assignment of tasks to agents with varying capabilities. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn a decentralized task allocation policy. Our method, called GTA-Net, represents the agent-task graph as a neural network and uses graph attention mechanisms to learn the relationships between agents and tasks. We evaluate GTA-Net on a set of benchmark problems and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Optimization
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic optimization is a complex problem that requires coordinating the actions of multiple agents in a dynamic environment. This paper proposes a novel scalable multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'SMART', which leverages decentralized learning and graph neural networks to optimize traffic signal control in real-time. We evaluate SMART on a large-scale traffic simulation platform and demonstrate significant improvements in traffic flow and reduced congestion times compared to traditional optimization methods.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking Models for Conversational Search
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems require efficient and effective ranking models to retrieve relevant documents in response to user queries. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'ConverseR', which leverages pre-trained language models and incorporates contextualized query representations. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures both local and global dependencies between query terms and document content. Experimental results on the TREC Conversational Assistance Track dataset demonstrate that ConverseR outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of ranking accuracy and query response time.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities and constraints need to be assigned tasks to maximize overall system performance. We formulate the task allocation problem as a Markov decision process and propose a reinforcement learning approach to learn the optimal allocation policy. Our approach utilizes a novel attention mechanism to model the complex interactions between agents and tasks, and is shown to outperform traditional optimization-based methods in simulation experiments involving robotic search and rescue scenarios.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for RDF Graph Databases using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Resource Description Framework (RDF) graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, optimizing query processing for RDF graph databases remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to learn query patterns and optimize query processing. Our approach, called 'RDF-GCN', uses GCNs to learn a compact representation of RDF graphs and then uses this representation to optimize query execution. Experimental results on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate that RDF-GCN outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion for Short Text Retrieval using Deep Semantic Embeddings
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique for improving short text retrieval performance. However, traditional methods often rely on shallow lexical features, neglecting the rich semantic relationships between words. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'SemExpand', which leverages pre-trained language models to generate dense semantic embeddings for query terms. By incorporating these embeddings into a probabilistic query expansion framework, we demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness on several benchmark datasets. Our results show that SemExpand outperforms state-of-the-art methods, particularly for short queries, and provides a new direction for integrating deep learning into information retrieval systems.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Neural Query Graphs for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely on effective document ranking to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. This paper proposes a novel neural query graph (NQG) model that leverages the query-document interaction to improve ranking performance. Our approach represents the query as a graph, which is learned jointly with the document representations to capture complex semantic relationships. We evaluate our NQG model on several TREC benchmarks and demonstrate significant improvements in ranking accuracy compared to state-of-the-art neural ranking models. Furthermore, we analyze the interpretability of our model, showing that the learned query graphs provide meaningful insights into the query-document relationships.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using machine learning techniques. We develop a query optimizer that leverages a graph neural network to model the database schema and predict the optimal execution plan for a given query. Our experimental results show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Designing scalable recommendation systems that can handle large user-item graphs is a critical challenge in modern e-commerce. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages both local and global graph structures to generate personalized recommendations. Our approach employs a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively selects relevant user and item features at multiple scales, enabling efficient processing of large graphs. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recommendation accuracy, computational efficiency, and scalability.

title: Eliciting User Preferences in Conversational Interfaces using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but understanding user preferences remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach using reinforcement learning to elicit user preferences in conversational systems. We introduce a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that learns to ask context-dependent questions to users, iteratively refining the understanding of their preferences. Our evaluation on a large-scale conversational dataset demonstrates that our approach significantly outperforms existing methods in terms of preference accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multimodal Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) tasks require models to integrate information from both images and natural language. While existing approaches focus on learning complex multimodal representations, they often overlook the hierarchical structure of visual and linguistic data. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant regions in images and sentences. Our experiments on popular VQA benchmarks demonstrate that HAN achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational costs by up to 30%. We also provide insights into the learned attention patterns, revealing the importance of object-centric reasoning in VQA.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern homes, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a participatory design approach to create inclusive voice assistants for this demographic. We conducted co-design workshops with 20 older adults to identify key challenges and preferences. Our findings indicate that existing voice assistants lack intuitive interfaces, clear feedback, and personalized support. We propose a set of design guidelines and a prototype voice assistant, 'ElderAssist', which incorporates these requirements. A user study with 15 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in usability, accessibility, and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Dimensional Data in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing queries for multi-dimensional data in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization, called 'Distributed Cube', which leverages the concept of data cubing to efficiently process range queries. We develop a probabilistic cost model that accurately estimates the cost of query execution and propose a heuristic-based optimization algorithm that minimizes the total query response time. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query response time and resource utilization.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Patterns and Error Recovery
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but their usability for older adults remains a concern. This study investigates the speech patterns of older adults interacting with voice assistants and identifies common error scenarios. We conducted a user study with 30 participants aged 65-85, analyzing their speech rates, pausality, and error recovery strategies. Our findings inform the design of an inclusive voice assistant prototype, which incorporates adaptive speech recognition, personalized feedback, and error recovery mechanisms. Results show significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction for older adults using our prototype compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis from multi-modal data (e.g., text, images, and audio) has become increasingly important in various applications. However, existing methods typically focus on a single modality or rely on early fusion, which may lead to suboptimal performance. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that leverages both intra- and inter-modal attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between modalities. Our experiments on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in sentiment analysis tasks, achieving a significant improvement in accuracy and F1-score.

title: Real-time Object Detection using YOLOv5 with Transfer Learning for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on accurate object detection to navigate complex urban environments. This paper presents a real-time object detection system using YOLOv5, leveraging transfer learning to adapt to diverse scenarios. We fine-tune the pre-trained YOLOv5 model on the KITTI dataset, incorporating domain adaptation techniques to improve performance on unseen environments. Experimental results demonstrate our approach achieves state-of-the-art accuracy (>95%) and speed (>30 FPS) on a NVIDIA Jetson Xavier NX platform, making it suitable for real-world autonomous vehicle applications.

title: Gaze-Based Error Detection for Intelligent Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) are increasingly prevalent, but their error-prone nature can lead to user frustration. We propose a novel gaze-based error detection mechanism for intelligent VAs, which leverages eye-tracking data to identify potential errors in VA responses. Our approach uses machine learning to classify gaze patterns indicative of user confusion or disagreement, triggering VA-initiated clarification or correction. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates a 35% reduction in errors and a significant improvement in user satisfaction when using our gaze-based error detection system.

title: EyeMovementPatterns: A Novel Gaze-Based Interface for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized the way we interact with digital environments. However, traditional interfaces often rely on manual input, which can be cumbersome and detract from the immersive experience. This paper presents EyeMovementPatterns, a novel gaze-based interface that leverages machine learning to infer user intent from eye movement patterns. Our approach combines convolutional neural networks with transfer learning to recognize gaze patterns, enabling users to navigate and interact with virtual objects using only their gaze. We conducted a user study to evaluate the usability and effectiveness of EyeMovementPatterns, demonstrating significant improvements in user experience and interaction efficiency.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies with Multi-Agent Interactions
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, including multi-agent systems. However, the vulnerability of DRL policies to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper investigates the adversarial robustness of DRL policies in the presence of multi-agent interactions. We propose a novel framework, 'MARL-ROBUST', which incorporates adversarial training and attention mechanisms to enhance the robustness of DRL policies. Experimental results demonstrate that MARL-ROBUST significantly improves the robustness of DRL policies against various types of adversarial attacks, while maintaining competitive performance in complex multi-agent environments.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Adaptive Routing
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems face challenges in efficiently routing queries to relevant nodes. This paper proposes an adaptive routing framework, 'ARIA', which leverages node expertise and query characteristics to optimize query routing. ARIA incorporates a probabilistic modeling approach to estimate node expertise and adaptively adjusts routing decisions based on query feedback. Experimental results on a large-scale DIR system demonstrate that ARIA reduces average query latency by 37% and improves retrieval accuracy by 12% compared to state-of-the-art routing methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Relational Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Relational knowledge graphs (RKGs) are a crucial component of many AI applications. However, existing graph neural networks (GNNs) struggle to effectively capture the complex relational structures present in RKGs. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) framework that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant relational paths during embedding. Our experiments on the WN18RR and FB15K-237 datasets demonstrate significant improvements in link prediction and triple classification tasks compared to state-of-the-art GNN-based methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework, 'GraphAgent', which leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model agent interactions and task dependencies. GraphAgent enables agents to learn distributed representations of tasks and allocate them in a decentralized manner, without relying on a centralized controller. Our experiments demonstrate that GraphAgent outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time and overall system efficiency, while adapting to dynamic changes in the environment.

title: Optimizing Subquery Execution in Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems often struggle with optimizing subquery execution, leading to poor performance and increased latency. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to dynamically adjust subquery execution plans. Our method, 'RL-SQE', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal subquery execution strategy based on the current system workload and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system show that RL-SQE outperforms traditional cost-based optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time, while maintaining comparable accuracy.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper proposes a decentralized auction-based mechanism for task allocation, which leverages the concept of virtual currencies to facilitate agent-to-agent negotiations. Our approach, called DTA-MAS, enables agents to bid for tasks based on their capabilities and availability, and allocates tasks to the winning agents. We prove the convergence and optimality of DTA-MAS under various settings and evaluate its performance using simulations, demonstrating improved task allocation efficiency and reduced communication overhead compared to existing centralized approaches.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems Using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems using graph neural networks (GNNs). Our approach, called HetMAL, learns to represent agents and tasks as nodes in a graph, and uses GNNs to capture complex dependencies between them. HetMAL outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of allocation efficiency, adaptability to changing task requirements, and robustness to agent failures. We evaluate HetMAL on a variety of scenarios, including search and rescue, and surveillance, demonstrating its effectiveness in real-world applications.

title: Deep Transfer Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Adaptive Prototype Refinement
paper_abstract: Deep transfer learning has become a dominant paradigm for few-shot image classification tasks. However, existing methods often rely on fixed prototype representations, which can be suboptimal for novel classes. This paper proposes an adaptive prototype refinement (APR) framework, which dynamically updates prototype representations based on the support set. Our APR approach leverages a meta-learning strategy to learn a robust prototype refinement function, which is then applied to the target classes. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming existing few-shot learning approaches by a significant margin.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have become increasingly prevalent in modern computing, but individuals with motor impairments often face significant barriers to accessing these systems. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive gesture-based interfaces that accommodate the needs of users with motor impairments. We conducted a comprehensive study involving 30 participants with varying motor abilities, and identified key design principles for reducing error rates and improving user experience. Our proposed framework incorporates a machine learning-based gesture recognition system that adaptively adjusts to individual users' abilities, and has been evaluated in a real-world scenario with promising results.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial technique for improving the effectiveness of ad-hoc retrieval systems. However, traditional QE methods often rely on manual feature engineering and suffer from lexical mismatch issues. This paper proposes a novel neural QE approach, 'NeuroQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to learn dense embeddings for query terms and documents. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively selects and weights relevant expansion terms based on their semantic relationships with the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: As multi-agent systems become increasingly pervasive, understanding the decision-making processes of AI agents is crucial. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for explainable multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our approach enables agents to selectively focus on relevant information from other agents and the environment, leading to improved cooperation and task performance. We evaluate our method on a set of challenging multi-agent environments, demonstrating significant gains in interpretability and adaptability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Agent-Based Task Allocation for Dynamic IoT Environments
paper_abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has created a need for efficient task allocation mechanisms that can adapt to dynamic environments. This paper presents a novel agent-based framework, 'DynaTA', which leverages decentralized decision-making to allocate tasks to IoT devices. We propose a hybrid approach that combines multi-agent systems with graph-based optimization techniques to minimize latency and energy consumption. Simulation results show that DynaTA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of scalability, flexibility, and robustness, making it suitable for real-world IoT applications.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular, but optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn efficient query plans. We model the database schema and query workload as a graph and train a GNN to predict the optimal query plan. Our experiments on a real-world dataset show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of execution time. We also explore the trade-offs between query optimization and data freshness in real-time analytics applications.

title: A Hybrid Approach to Query Expansion using Word Embeddings and Dependency Parsing for Improved Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it helps to alleviate the vocabulary mismatch problem between users' queries and relevant documents. In this paper, we propose a hybrid QE approach that leverages both word embeddings and dependency parsing to generate more effective expansion terms. Our approach, dubbed 'Hyb QE', first uses word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and candidate expansion terms. Then, it utilizes dependency parsing to identify the most informative expansion terms based on their syntactic roles in the query context. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that Hyb QE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, particularly for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Enhancing Gesture Recognition with Multimodal Fusion and Uncertainty Modeling
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition has numerous applications in human-computer interaction, but existing systems often struggle with variability in user gestures and sensor noise. This paper presents a novel approach that combines computer vision, electromyography, and inertial measurement unit data to recognize gestures. We propose a Bayesian neural network that models uncertainty in the fusion process, enabling the system to adapt to individual users and contexts. Our experiments on a large-scale gesture dataset demonstrate improved recognition accuracy and robustness to sensor noise, paving the way for more reliable and personalized HCI systems.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Conversational UIs in Reducing Cognitive Load for Older Adults
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, it is essential to design user interfaces that cater to the needs of older adults. This study investigates the effectiveness of conversational UIs in reducing cognitive load for older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment with 40 participants, comparing a conversational UI with a traditional GUI for completing everyday tasks. Our results show that the conversational UI significantly reduced cognitive load, improved task completion times, and enhanced user satisfaction. We identify key design recommendations for developers to create more accessible and usable conversational interfaces for older adults.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning and Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial step in database systems, but it remains a challenging problem due to the exponential search space of possible query plans. This paper presents 'GraphOpt', a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning and graph embeddings to accelerate query optimization. By modeling the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process, we use deep Q-networks to learn an effective query plan generator. We also propose a graph embedding technique to capture the structural dependencies between query operators, allowing the model to generalize to unseen queries. Experimental results on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of optimization time and achieves comparable plan quality.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Developing dialogue systems that can effectively engage with humans requires understanding the nuances of multi-modal input, including speech, text, and vision. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and contextual information to generate more accurate and explainable responses. We also introduce a new explanation module that provides insights into the model's decision-making process, improving transparency and trust in human-machine interactions. Experiments on a large-scale multi-modal dialogue dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art results in response accuracy and human likeness.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed systems often suffer from inefficient resource allocation, leading to underutilization and decreased performance. This paper presents an autonomous agent-based framework, 'ARA', that dynamically allocates resources to tasks based on real-time system conditions. Our approach leverages multi-agent systems theory to model interactions between tasks, resources, and agents, enabling decentralized decision-making and adaptability to changing system states. Experimental results on a cloud-based testbed demonstrate that ARA achieves significant improvements in resource utilization, task completion time, and system scalability compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Swarm Intelligence
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that can significantly impact the overall system performance. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework, 'SwarmAllocate', which leverages swarm intelligence principles to efficiently allocate tasks among agents. SwarmAllocate uses a novel pheromone-based communication mechanism to facilitate agent coordination, enabling the system to adapt to dynamic task arrivals and agent failures. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that SwarmAllocate outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion time and system robustness.

title: Self-Modifying Neural Networks for Adaptive Edge AI
paper_abstract: Edge AI applications require efficient and adaptable neural networks to operate in dynamic environments. This paper introduces SelfModNet, a novel neural architecture that enables self-modification of its weights and structure based on runtime feedback. SelfModNet leverages a meta-learning approach to adapt to changing input distributions, noise patterns, and resource constraints. Our experiments on edge AI benchmarks demonstrate significant improvements in accuracy, latency, and energy efficiency compared to traditional static neural networks. We also explore the potential of SelfModNet for real-world applications, including autonomous vehicles and smart surveillance systems.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Edge Computing
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized autonomous agent-based approach for resource allocation in edge computing environments. Our proposed framework, 'EdgeAgent', employs a multi-agent system to dynamically allocate resources among edge nodes, ensuring efficient task execution and minimized latency. We model the problem as a decentralized Markov decision process and develop a deep reinforcement learning-based solution for each agent to learn optimal resource allocation policies. Experimental results demonstrate that EdgeAgent outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of resource utilization and application performance.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Adaptive Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive solutions. This paper presents a novel distributed task allocation framework based on adaptive coalition formation. Our approach enables agents to form coalitions dynamically, taking into account their capabilities, task requirements, and environmental constraints. We introduce a decentralized optimization algorithm that leverages local information exchange and negotiation protocols to achieve near-optimal task allocations. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving task completion rates and reducing communication overhead.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning-based Index Selection
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are increasingly used to handle large-scale data storage and querying. However, optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to index selection using machine learning techniques. We develop a framework that leverages query workload patterns and data distribution characteristics to predict optimal index configurations. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional rule-based index selection methods, reducing query latency by up to 35%. We also explore the applicability of our framework to various distributed database systems.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Semantically Similar Documents using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems rely on keyword-based matching, which often fails to capture semantic relationships between documents. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'HierGNN-IR', that leverages hierarchical graph neural networks to learn document representations. By modeling documents as nodes in a graph, we can capture complex semantic relationships and retrieve documents that are semantically similar to a query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierGNN-IR outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Graph-based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a crucial technique for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational overhead and limited exploration capabilities. To address these limitations, we propose a novel NAS framework, 'GraphNAS', which leverages graph-based reinforcement learning to efficiently explore the architecture space. Our approach represents neural architectures as graphs and utilizes a reinforcement learning agent to search for optimal architectures. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphNAS achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing the search time by up to 50% compared to existing methods.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems have advanced significantly, but the role of haptic feedback in enhancing user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of the effects of haptic feedback on user engagement, spatial awareness, and task performance in VR. We designed a series of experiments using a custom-built VR platform with three haptic feedback conditions: vibration, force feedback, and texture simulation. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly improves user experience, particularly in tasks requiring spatial manipulation and exploration. We also identify key factors influencing the effectiveness of haptic feedback, including individual differences in haptic perception and task complexity.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Resource allocation in cloud computing is a complex, dynamic problem that requires efficient decision-making. This paper proposes a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning (DHRL) framework, 'CloudOpt', which learns to optimize resource allocation in cloud environments. CloudOpt incorporates a hierarchical architecture that decomposes the problem into sub-tasks, allowing the agent to focus on specific resource allocation decisions. Experimental results on a real-world cloud dataset demonstrate that CloudOpt achieves significant improvements in resource utilization and reduces energy consumption compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for multimodal fusion in visual question answering (VQA). Unlike existing approaches that flatten visual and textual features, our HAN hierarchically fuses them using attention mechanisms at multiple scales. This enables our model to capture complex contextual relationships between images and questions. We demonstrate improved performance on the VQA-CP v2 benchmark, achieving state-of-the-art results on the 'number' and 'other' question types. Our ablation study shows that the hierarchical attention mechanism is crucial for capturing nuanced multimodal interactions.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: As database systems continue to scale, query optimization becomes increasingly complex. Traditional approaches rely on heuristics and rule-based systems, which often fail to capture the nuances of modern distributed databases. This paper explores the application of deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to query optimization. We propose a novel DRL framework, 'QOptRL', which learns to optimize queries by interacting with a simulated database environment. Our experiments demonstrate that QOptRL outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of execution time and plan quality, particularly for complex queries and large-scale datasets.

title: In-Memory Indexing for Real-Time Aggregation in Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Column-store databases have become increasingly popular for analytical workloads, but their query performance is often bottlenecked by disk-based indexing. This paper proposes an in-memory indexing framework, 'MemAgg', which leverages the memory hierarchy to accelerate real-time aggregation queries. We introduce a novel cache-aware indexing technique that integrates with the database's query optimizer to minimize memory traffic and optimize query plans. Experimental results on a TPC-H benchmark dataset demonstrate that MemAgg achieves up to 5x query performance improvements compared to state-of-the-art disk-based indexing methods.

title: Adversarial Robustness in Deep Learning Models through Bayesian Neural Network Ensembles
paper_abstract: Deep learning models are increasingly vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can have catastrophic consequences in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to improve the robustness of deep learning models by leveraging Bayesian neural network ensembles. Our method, called 'BayesRobust', combines the outputs of multiple Bayesian neural networks to generate an ensemble prediction that is more resistant to adversarial perturbations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of BayesRobust on several benchmark datasets, showing improved robustness to state-of-the-art attacks while maintaining competitive performance on clean data.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Gestural Interfaces in Virtual Reality for Users with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to provide immersive and engaging experiences for users with motor disabilities. However, traditional controllers can be challenging for individuals with limited dexterity or mobility. This study investigates the usability and accessibility of gestural interfaces in VR for users with motor disabilities. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, comparing a gestural interface to traditional controller-based interaction. Results show that gestural interfaces can significantly reduce interaction time and improve user satisfaction, especially for users with severe motor impairments. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of inclusive VR experiences.

title: Designing Inclusive Chatbots: A Study on Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults
paper_abstract: This paper explores the design of conversational interfaces for older adults, with a focus on promoting inclusivity and accessibility. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, examining their interactions with existing chatbots and identifying pain points. Our findings highlight the importance of simplifying language, providing explicit feedback, and accommodating cognitive and motor impairments. We propose a set of guidelines for designing inclusive chatbots and demonstrate their efficacy through a prototype system. Our work contributes to the development of more accessible and usable conversational interfaces for older adults, enhancing their overall user experience.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Distributed Reinforcement Learning for Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach for coordinating multi-agent systems in complex, dynamic environments. We propose a distributed reinforcement learning framework that allows agents to learn cooperative policies for resource allocation tasks. Our method, called 'MARL-RA', leverages Graph Neural Networks to model agent interactions and incorporates a decentralized trust mechanism to ensure robustness against malicious agents. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid scenario demonstrate that MARL-RA outperforms traditional centralized optimization methods and achieves near-optimal resource allocation while adapting to changing environmental conditions.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents using Decentralized Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
paper_abstract: Coordinating autonomous agents in complex, dynamic environments is a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach using decentralized partially observable Markov decision processes (Dec-POMDPs) to model and solve the coordination problem. We introduce a decentralized planning algorithm that allows agents to learn and adapt to their local observations and communicate with each other to achieve a common goal. Experimental results in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving coordination and reducing collisions among agents.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Learned Indexes
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data analytics workloads. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of distributed data storage and retrieval. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using learned indexes, which leverages machine learning techniques to predict the optimal query plan. Our approach, called 'LQE', uses a graph neural network to model the database schema and learn the relationships between tables, indexes, and queries. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that LQE outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time and reduces optimization time by up to 5x.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing Cognitive Load for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have been increasingly used to support older adults in various tasks, but their impact on cognitive load is not well understood. This study investigates the effectiveness of ECAs in reducing cognitive load for older adults during a task-oriented conversation. We designed an ECA system that uses multimodal inputs and outputs to engage users in a conversational interface. Our results show that the ECA system significantly reduced cognitive load compared to a text-based interface, with participants reporting higher levels of trust and satisfaction. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of accessible and user-centered interfaces for older adults.

title: Towards Adaptive Agent Coordination in Dynamic Task Environments
paper_abstract: In dynamic task environments, agents must adapt to changing conditions and coordinate with each other to achieve common goals. This paper presents a novel framework for adaptive agent coordination, which leverages reinforcement learning to learn effective coordination strategies in real-time. Our approach, dubbed 'AdaCoor', integrates a task-oriented attention mechanism with a graph neural network to model inter-agent dependencies and optimize collective performance.
