Experimental results on a variety of benchmark scenarios demonstrate the robustness and scalability of AdaCoor in the face of unexpected environmental changes and agent failures.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Interpretable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the heterogeneity of modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that captures intra- and inter-modal relationships to recognize emotions more accurately. Our HAN model incorporates a hierarchical fusion mechanism that adaptively weights modalities based on their contributions to emotion recognition. Experimental results on the CMU-MultimodalSDK dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of emotion recognition accuracy and provides interpretable results through attention visualization.

title: Designing Adaptive Visualizations for Inclusive Decision-Making in Multimodal Interfaces
paper_abstract: Multimodal interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their complexity can lead to cognitive overload and exclusion of users with diverse abilities. This paper presents a novel visualization framework, 'VisInclu', which adaptively generates visual representations of multimodal data to support inclusive decision-making. VisInclu integrates machine learning-driven prediction models with participatory design principles to dynamically adjust visualization complexity, color schemes, and interaction modalities based on user preferences and abilities. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates that VisInclu significantly improves decision-making accuracy and user satisfaction for individuals with visual impairments, dyslexia, and aging-related cognitive decline.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Adaptive Trust Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, trust between agents is crucial for effective coordination. This paper introduces a novel adaptive trust network (ATN) framework that enables agents to dynamically adjust their trust relationships based on observed behavior and communication patterns. We propose a graph neural network-based approach to model trust propagation and demonstrate its effectiveness in enhancing cooperation and mitigating the impact of malicious agents. Experimental results on a variety of scenarios show that ATN outperforms existing trust mechanisms in terms of system performance and robustness.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommendation systems have become increasingly important in various applications, but their scalability remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages the hierarchical structure of user-item interactions to improve recommendation accuracy and efficiency. Our HGAT model employs a dual-attention mechanism that captures both local and global dependencies in the graph, allowing it to effectively model complex relationships between users and items. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recommendation accuracy, while reducing computational costs by up to 60%.

title: Multi-Modal Fusion for Explainable Decision-Making in Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: As autonomous systems become increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for explainable decision-making to ensure transparency and accountability. This paper presents a novel multi-modal fusion framework, 'EXPLAIN', which integrates visual, textual, and auditory features to provide interpretable explanations for autonomous decision-making. We leverage attention-based neural networks to selectively weigh and fuse modality-specific features, generating comprehensive explanations for complex decisions. Experimental results on a real-world autonomous driving dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of EXPLAIN in improving decision transparency and user trust.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: This paper explores the concept of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) and its impact on user experience. We designed a gesture-based interaction system that leverages the user's bodily gestures to control virtual objects. Our user study involving 30 participants revealed that embodied interaction enhances spatial awareness, memory recall, and overall user satisfaction. We also found that users exhibited more exploratory behavior and reported higher levels of engagement and immersion. The results have implications for the design of VR interfaces and suggest that embodied cognition can be a valuable design principle for creating more intuitive and engaging user experiences.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Neural Re-ranking with Query-dependent Contextualized Embeddings
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel neural re-ranking approach for efficient document ranking in information retrieval. We introduce query-dependent contextualized embeddings, which capture the semantic relationships between queries and documents more effectively. Our method, dubbed QRN, leverages a deep neural network to learn a ranking function that incorporates these embeddings. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QRN outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of ranking accuracy and query processing efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs, such as speech, text, and vision, has numerous applications in human-computer interaction. However, existing approaches often suffer from high computational complexity and neglect hierarchical relationships between modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages self-attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. Our experiments on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that HAN achieves state-of-the-art performance in multi-modal emotion recognition while reducing computational overhead by 30% compared to existing approaches.

title: Efficient Indexing for High-Dimensional Data using Hierarchical k-Means Trees
paper_abstract: High-dimensional data indexing is a crucial task in various applications, including data mining and machine learning. This paper proposes a novel indexing method based on hierarchical k-means trees, which reduces the computational cost of similarity searches and improves query performance. Our approach leverages a multi-resolution representation of the data, where each level of the hierarchy corresponds to a different granularity of the k-means clustering. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method through extensive experiments on real-world datasets, showcasing significant improvements in query efficiency and accuracy compared to existing state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Participatory Design Approach
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a participatory design approach to create inclusive conversational interfaces for this demographic. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults to identify design principles and requirements. Our findings highlight the importance of simplicity, clarity, and empathy in conversational interfaces. We propose a novel framework, 'ElderChat', which incorporates these principles and provides personalized support for older adults. A pilot study demonstrates ElderChat's effectiveness in improving user experience and reducing cognitive load.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of autonomous vehicles (AVs) on public roads demands efficient coordination strategies to ensure safety and traffic flow. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'AV-Coord', which enables AVs to learn cooperative behaviors in real-time. Our approach integrates graph neural networks with deep Q-networks to model complex interactions between AVs and their environment. Experimental results in a simulated urban scenario demonstrate that AV-Coord reduces congestion, minimizes collisions, and improves overall traffic efficiency compared to traditional rule-based approaches.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Evolutionary Game Theory
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel distributed task allocation framework for multi-agent systems using evolutionary game theory. Our approach, called EvoAllocate, models the task allocation problem as a repeated game among self-interested agents, where each agent aims to maximize its utility by selecting the most profitable tasks. We introduce a decentralized evolution strategy that allows agents to adapt their bidding strategies over time, leading to a Nash equilibrium. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that EvoAllocate outperforms existing algorithms in terms of system efficiency and fairness.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, aiming to enrich the original query to better capture the user's information need. While traditional QE methods rely on term co-occurrence analysis, we propose a novel approach that leverages semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between terms. Our method, 'SemQE', represents queries and documents as dense vectors and incorporates a novel attention mechanism to selectively weigh term importance. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval benchmark demonstrate that SemQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT using Graph-based Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Industrial IoT systems generate vast amounts of sensor data, making anomaly detection a critical task for ensuring operational reliability. This paper presents a novel graph-based deep learning approach, 'GraphAD', which leverages the inherent graph structure of IoT sensor networks to identify anomalies more efficiently. GraphAD combines graph attention layers with a contrastive learning objective to learn robust representations of normal sensor behavior, enabling accurate detection of anomalies. Experimental results on a real-world industrial dataset demonstrate that GraphAD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents using multi-agent deep reinforcement learning. Our approach, called MATRA, enables agents to learn to allocate tasks efficiently in a distributed manner, without relying on a centralized controller. We use a novel combination of graph neural networks and deep Q-networks to model the task allocation problem as a decentralized Markov decision process. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate that MATRA outperforms traditional decentralized allocation strategies, achieving improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead.

title: Personalized Gesture Recognition using Transfer Learning and Domain Adaptation for Wearable Devices
paper_abstract: Wearable devices have enabled various applications, including gesture recognition, which is crucial for human-computer interaction. However, existing methods suffer from limited generalizability across different users and environments. This paper proposes a novel approach that combines transfer learning and domain adaptation to develop a personalized gesture recognition system. Our method leverages a large-scale gesture dataset to pre-train a deep neural network, which is then fine-tuned on a small amount of user-specific data using adversarial domain adaptation. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recognition accuracy and robustness, while requiring minimal user calibration data.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have become increasingly popular in cloud computing, but optimizing queries for diverse workloads and tenants remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans for multi-tenant databases. Our proposed framework, 'RL-Optimizer', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan selection policy based on various performance metrics and tenant-specific characteristics. Experimental results on a real-world cloud database workload demonstrate that RL-Optimizer outperforms traditional heuristics-based optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query response time and resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems via Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, leveraging graph neural networks (GNNs) to efficiently allocate tasks among agents. Our approach, called GNN-TA, represents the agent-task interaction as a graph and employs a GNN to learn a distributed allocation policy. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GNN-TA in various scenarios, showing significant improvements in task completion time and agent utility compared to traditional centralized and decentralized approaches. Furthermore, we analyze the robustness of GNN-TA to agent failures and communication disruptions.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale graph data, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. In this paper, we propose a novel query optimization approach using reinforcement learning. Our method, called GraphQLearner, learns to select efficient query execution plans by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query latency. We evaluate GraphQLearner on three real-world graph datasets and demonstrate significant performance improvements compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers. Our results show that reinforcement learning can be effectively applied to distributed graph databases, leading to better query performance and scalability.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing gesture recognition systems that adapt to the unique needs of individuals with motor impairments. Our proposed system, 'Adapta Gesture', employs a machine learning-based framework that learns to recognize and compensate for the variability in gesture patterns exhibited by individuals with motor impairments. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, demonstrating that Adapta Gesture achieves an average recognition accuracy of 92.5%, outperforming existing gesture recognition systems. Our findings have significant implications for the development of accessible HCI systems that can be used by individuals with motor impairments.

title: Efficient Explainability for Transformer-based Models using Attention-based Saliency Maps
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of transformer-based models in AI applications has raised concerns about their lack of transparency. This paper proposes a novel approach to explainability, dubbed 'TransformerLens', which leverages attention mechanisms to generate saliency maps that highlight input features contributing to the model's predictions. Our method outperforms existing techniques in terms of attribution quality and computational efficiency, as demonstrated on a range of NLP benchmarks. We also provide a user study that shows the effectiveness of TransformerLens in improving human understanding and trust in AI-driven decision-making systems.

title: Gaze-Based Intention Detection for Human-Computer Interaction using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Gaze-based intention detection is a critical component of human-computer interaction (HCI) systems, enabling machines to anticipate and respond to user goals. This paper presents a novel deep learning framework, 'GazeIntentionNet', which leverages convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to detect user intentions from raw gaze data. We collect a large-scale dataset of gaze patterns and corresponding user goals, and demonstrate that GazeIntentionNet outperforms state-of-the-art methods in intention detection accuracy. Our system has applications in intelligent tutoring systems, assistive technologies, and human-robot collaboration.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Efficient Anomaly Detection in Multivariate Time Series
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in multivariate time series data is a crucial task in various applications, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational costs, limited scalability, and inferior performance. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Contrastive Learning (HCL) framework, which leverages the strengths of self-supervised learning and hierarchical representations to detect anomalies efficiently. HCL learns a hierarchical representation of the time series data by minimizing a contrastive loss between positive and negative samples at multiple scales. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that HCL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in sentiment analysis, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and adoption. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs), a novel explainable AI framework that leverages attention mechanisms to identify salient features and phrases contributing to sentiment predictions. We propose a hierarchical architecture that captures both local and global contextual dependencies, enabling the model to provide interpretable explanations for its predictions. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HANs outperform existing explainable methods while maintaining competitive sentiment analysis performance.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for adaptive traffic signal control. Our approach utilizes a novel agent architecture that integrates both local and global state information to optimize traffic signal timing. We evaluate our method on a realistic simulation platform, demonstrating significant reductions in average travel time and congestion levels compared to traditional fixed-timing and decentralized reinforcement learning baselines. Furthermore, we provide theoretical analysis on the convergence properties of our algorithm in decentralized settings.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents to achieve common goals is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems. While deep reinforcement learning has shown promise, interpretability remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that learns to represent agent interactions and intentions in a explainable manner. By aggregating local graph attention mechanisms, HGAT captures hierarchical relationships between agents and their environment. We evaluate HGAT on a range of cooperative tasks, demonstrating improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have become a crucial component in various AI applications, but their interpretability remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) for learning explainable knowledge graph embeddings. HGAN leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant entities and relationships, enabling the model to provide interpretable explanations for its predictions. We evaluate HGAN on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving embedding quality and interpretability. Furthermore, we provide a thorough analysis of the learned attention weights, revealing insightful patterns in the knowledge graph structure.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Graph-based Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks poses a significant threat to its deployment. This paper introduces a novel graph-based anomaly detection (GAD) approach to detect adversarial attacks in DRL. Our method represents the agent's policy as a graph and utilizes graph-based metrics to identify anomalous patterns indicative of attacks. We evaluate our approach on several DRL benchmarks and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting various types of attacks, including poisoning and evasion attacks. Our results show that GAD outperforms existing detection methods and provides a promising direction for securing DRL systems.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Uncertainty-based Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can lead to misclassification and security breaches. This paper proposes a novel approach for detecting adversarial attacks in DNNs using uncertainty-based anomaly detection. Our method, called 'UADEX', leverages the uncertainty estimates of DNNs to identify anomalous input samples that are likely to be adversarial. We demonstrate the effectiveness of UADEX on multiple benchmark datasets, achieving a detection rate of 95.2% with a false positive rate of 2.5%. Our approach outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods and provides a robust defense mechanism against adversarial attacks.

title: Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Efficient Retrieval in Large-Scale Document Collections
paper_abstract: With the rapid growth of digital documents, efficient and effective retrieval has become a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to document retrieval using hierarchical document embeddings (HDE). HDE leverages the hierarchical structure of documents to learn a dense representation, enabling fast and accurate retrieval in large-scale document collections. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HDE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval efficiency and effectiveness, while requiring significantly less computational resources.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommendation systems often rely on complex models that are difficult to interpret, hindering user trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) architecture that generates explanations for recommendations. HAGNN incorporates node-level, graph-level, and hierarchical attention mechanisms to capture complex item relationships and user preferences. We evaluate our approach on several real-world datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in recommendation accuracy and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Embodied Cognition Approach to Improving Conversational Understanding
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their conversational understanding is often limited by a lack of embodiment and social context. This paper presents an embodied cognition approach to designing more inclusive voice assistants, focusing on the role of multimodal cues and social priming in shaping conversational understanding. We conducted a series of user studies to investigate how users' mental models of voice assistants influence their interaction behaviors and perceived understanding. Our findings inform the design of a novel voice assistant framework that incorporates embodied cognition principles, demonstrating improved conversational understanding and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: Ranked retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various Information Retrieval (IR) tasks. However, their computational cost and memory requirements can be prohibitive for large-scale document collections. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HiRank', which leverages a multi-resolution document representation to reduce the number of neural network evaluations. Our approach combines a coarse-grained ranking stage with a fine-grained re-ranking stage, resulting in significant speedups and memory savings while maintaining retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate the efficacy of HiRank in terms of precision, recall, and query processing time.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have transformed human-computer interaction, but existing systems often fail to accommodate the unique needs and abilities of older adults. This paper presents a participatory design approach to develop an inclusive gesture recognition system, tailored to the motor and cognitive abilities of older adults. Our user-centered design process involved co-design workshops with 20 older adults, resulting in a novel gesture set that reduces error rates by 35% compared to commercial systems. We also propose a machine learning-based classifier that incorporates age-related factors, achieving an accuracy of 92.5% in recognizing gestures from older adults.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in conversational agents is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that leverages multi-modal inputs (text, speech, and vision) to recognize emotions in human-agent conversations. Our HAN model uses a hierarchical framework to capture intra-modal and inter-modal relationships, allowing it to better distinguish between subtle emotional cues. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset of human-agent conversations demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in emotion recognition accuracy, especially in scenarios with noisy or incomplete input data.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting has numerous applications in finance, healthcare, and climate modeling. However, the lack of transparency in black-box models hinders their adoption in high-stakes domains. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant temporal and feature-wise dependencies in multivariate time series data. Our approach yields state-of-the-art forecasting performance while providing inherent interpretability through attention weights. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN on several benchmarks, including stock prices, weather patterns, and disease prevalence, and show that it outperforms existing explainable models.

title: Query Optimization for IoT-Generated Time Series Data in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosion of time series data, posing significant challenges for query optimization in distributed database systems. This paper presents a novel approach, 'TSQR', which leverages a combination of indexing, caching, and parallel processing to accelerate query execution. TSQR employs a hierarchical clustering algorithm to identify correlated time series segments and reorders query execution to minimize disk I/O and network communication. Our experimental evaluation on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrates that TSQR outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time and 2x in terms of system throughput.

title: EyeGazeAssist: A Gaze-Based Assistive System for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant challenges in interacting with digital systems. This paper presents EyeGazeAssist, a novel gaze-based assistive system that enables users to navigate and select on-screen items using only their eye movements. Our approach leverages a deep learning-based gaze estimation model, which is trained on a large dataset of eye tracking recordings. We also introduce a novel 'gaze dwell-time' based selection mechanism that adapts to the user's gaze pattern, reducing the need for explicit dwell-time settings. A user study with 20 participants with motor impairments demonstrates the effectiveness of EyeGazeAssist in improving interaction speed and accuracy.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Databases Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly common, but optimizing query execution remains a challenging problem. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using deep reinforcement learning. We formulate the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and train a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy. Our approach, called 'DROPS', is able to adapt to changing workload patterns and database configurations. Experimental results on a realistic distributed database benchmark show that DROPS outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of execution time and resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In heterogeneous multi-agent systems, task allocation is a challenging problem due to varying agent capabilities and dynamic environment conditions. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments. Our approach, called DRL-TA, utilizes a graph neural network to model agent interactions and a deep Q-network to learn a task allocation policy. We evaluate DRL-TA in a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Entity Retrieval using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Entity retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant entities from a large knowledge graph given a query. However, the query representation often lacks context, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'KG-Expan', which leverages knowledge graph embeddings to enrich the query representation. We develop a graph-based attention mechanism to select the most informative entities and expand the query with their related concepts. Experiments on the Wikidata and YAGO datasets demonstrate that KG-Expan significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Modern distributed database systems face significant challenges in optimizing complex queries. This paper presents a novel framework, 'DistroOpt', which leverages machine learning and data partitioning to improve query performance. We introduce a probabilistic cost model that accurately estimates query execution times and a novel data placement strategy that minimizes data transfer between nodes. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DistroOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of execution time and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: EyeGazeExplorer: A Deep Learning Framework for Inferring User Intent from Eye Movements in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: In virtual reality (VR) environments, understanding user intent is crucial for providing personalized experiences. This paper presents EyeGazeExplorer, a deep learning framework that leverages eye movement data to infer user intent. Our approach combines convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to analyze gaze patterns and predict user goals. We evaluate EyeGazeExplorer on a large-scale VR dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving user experience and reducing interaction latency. Our framework has implications for various HCI applications, including virtual shopping, gaming, and education.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing queries in such systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to select the optimal query execution plan based on the system's current workload and resource utilization. Our experiments on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms traditional rule-based optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Adaptive Batch Normalization for Robust Deep Learning with Noisy Labels
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are prone to overfitting when trained on noisy labels. This paper presents an adaptive batch normalization (AdaBN) technique that selectively adjusts the normalization statistics based on label confidence. We develop a probabilistic framework to estimate label noise and dynamically adjust the batch normalization layer to mitigate its impact. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdaBN improves the robustness of deep models to noisy labels, achieving state-of-the-art performance on noisy CIFAR-10 and Clothing1M.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In heterogeneous multi-agent systems, tasks with varying complexities and requirements need to be allocated efficiently to agents with diverse capabilities. This paper presents a novel approach to coordinated task allocation using reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'CoMAC', where each agent learns to select optimal tasks based on its own capabilities, task priorities, and interactions with other agents. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that CoMAC outperforms traditional rule-based allocation methods, achieving higher task completion rates and reduced overall system latency.

title: Leveraging Passage Retrieval and Graph-Based Neural Ranking for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) has seen significant progress with the advent of neural models. However, most existing approaches rely on retrieving passages using traditional IR methods, which can be suboptimal. This paper proposes a novel ODQA framework, 'GraphRetriever', that integrates passage retrieval and neural ranking using graph-based neural networks. Our approach leverages entity relationships and contextualized embeddings to refine passage retrieval and improve answer extraction. Experimental results on the Natural Questions benchmark demonstrate that GraphRetriever outperforms state-of-the-art ODQA models, achieving an absolute gain of 3.2% in exact match score.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) face significant challenges in optimizing query performance, particularly in the presence of dynamic workloads and varying data distributions. This paper proposes an adaptive indexing framework, 'AdaptIx', which dynamically adjusts index structures based on real-time query patterns and system resource utilization. Our approach leverages machine learning-driven cost models to predict optimal indexing configurations, resulting in improved query latency and reduced resource consumption. Experimental evaluations on a large-scale DDS testbed demonstrate AdaptIx's effectiveness in achieving up to 3x query performance improvements over traditional static indexing approaches.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Design Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent in smart homes, but their usability and accessibility for older adults remain understudied. This paper presents a participatory design approach to designing voice assistants that cater to the needs of older adults. We conducted co-design workshops with 15 older adults and 10 caregivers to identify key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our findings highlight the importance of intuitiveness, feedback, and customization in voice assistant design. We propose a set of design guidelines and a prototype system that incorporates these principles, demonstrating significant improvements in usability and user experience for older adults.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments. However, existing VR interfaces often neglect the unique needs and abilities of this population. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating inclusive VR interfaces for older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with caregivers and older adults to identify design requirements and developed a set of interface design guidelines. A prototype VR system was implemented and evaluated with 20 older adults, demonstrating improved usability and engagement compared to traditional interfaces.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval (IR) due to the complexity of user queries and the vastness of the document space. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using reinforcement learning (RL). Our method, 'RL-Expander', learns to select the most informative expansion terms by interacting with the retrieval environment and receiving rewards based on the relevance of the retrieved documents. We evaluate RL-Expander on several standard IR datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This study examines the effect of personalized avatars on user experience and engagement in virtual reality (VR) environments. We designed an immersive VR game with customizable avatars and recruited 120 participants for a within-subjects experiment. Our results show that participants who used personalized avatars exhibited higher levels of engagement, measured by time spent in the game and self-reported enjoyment, compared to those using non-personalized avatars. We also found that personalization increased the sense of presence and embodiment in the virtual environment. The implications of these findings are discussed in the context of VR-based training, education, and entertainment applications.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their accessibility for older adults with cognitive impairments remains a significant concern. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create accessible conversational interfaces tailored to the needs of this population. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults with cognitive impairments, identifying key challenges and design recommendations. Our proposed interface, 'CARE', incorporates simplification, visualization, and contextual support to facilitate comprehension and interaction. A usability evaluation with 20 participants showed significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing conversational interfaces.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) are increasingly used in complex domains, such as smart cities and autonomous vehicles, where dynamic task allocation is crucial. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for coordinating MAS. Our approach combines a high-level task allocator with low-level agent controllers, enabling efficient adaptation to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. We evaluate our framework on a simulated urban surveillance scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced agent collisions compared to traditional decentralized approaches.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to task allocation for autonomous agents in decentralized environments. We formulate the task allocation problem as a distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) problem and propose a decentralized algorithm, called DACO, that allows agents to negotiate and allocate tasks without a central authority. DACO leverages a combination of constraint propagation and message-passing to efficiently allocate tasks while respecting agent capabilities and constraints. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that DACO outperforms existing decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of task completion rate and agent utility.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommender Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems are widely used in various applications, but their black-box nature hinders user trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) model that provides explainable recommendations by capturing complex item relationships and user preferences. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to identify influential items and users, and generates personalized explanations for each recommendation. Our experiments on multiple datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality, while providing insights into the decision-making process.

title: Hierarchical Few-Shot Learning with Adaptive Task Embeddings for Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has seen significant progress in recent years, but most approaches focus on a single task or dataset. In real-world scenarios, models often need to adapt to new tasks with limited data. This paper proposes a hierarchical few-shot learning framework, 'HATTE', which leverages adaptive task embeddings to facilitate knowledge transfer across tasks. Our approach uses a meta-learning strategy to learn task-specific embeddings that capture the underlying structure of each task. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HATTE on several benchmark image classification datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in few-shot and zero-shot settings.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Deep Neural Language Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on simplistic term co-occurrence statistics. This paper proposes a novel QE approach that leverages pre-trained deep neural language models (DLMs) to capture nuanced semantic relationships between terms. We fine-tune a BERT-based DLM on a large corpus of text and use its contextualized embeddings to generate expanded queries. Experimental results on several TREC datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for short and vague queries, compared to state-of-the-art QE methods.

title: Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face significant challenges in optimizing query execution plans. Traditional optimization techniques rely on heuristics and rule-based systems, which often fail to adapt to dynamic workloads and complex query patterns. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans in distributed database systems. We design a customized reinforcement learning framework that incorporates query semantics, system workload, and resource utilization to optimize query plans. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems have seen significant advancements with the integration of multi-modal inputs, such as text, speech, and vision. However, processing and fusing these modalities efficiently remains a challenge. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages attention mechanisms at multiple scales to selectively focus on relevant modalities and context. Our experiments on the Multi-Modal Dialogue Dataset (M2DD) demonstrate improved response generation quality and reduced computational overhead compared to existing state-of-the-art models.

title: Decentralized Agent Coordination for Dynamic Task Allocation in Multi-Robot Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized agent coordination framework for dynamic task allocation in multi-robot systems. Our approach, called DACTAR, leverages a combination of distributed constraint optimization and machine learning to enable autonomous robots to adaptively allocate tasks in real-time. We formulate the task allocation problem as a decentralized constraint satisfaction problem and propose a neural network-based solver that can be executed on each robot's onboard computer. Experimental results show that DACTAR outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion time and robustness to robot failures, while also providing improved flexibility and scalability.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Effective task allocation is crucial in multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities and constraints need to collaborate to achieve complex goals. This paper proposes a novel approach based on deep reinforcement learning, which learns to allocate tasks to agents by modeling their interactions and optimizing a global reward function. We introduce a hierarchical framework that combines a centralized planner with decentralized agent controllers, enabling efficient and adaptive task allocation in dynamic environments. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of our approach over traditional methods in various scenarios, including robotic search and rescue missions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in dynamic environments is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables explainable cooperation among agents. Our approach leverages a hierarchical representation of the environment, allowing agents to selectively focus on relevant features and communicate with each other through a learned attention mechanism. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate and interpretability of agent decisions.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in modern computing, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach using reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in distributed database systems. We formulate the query optimization problem as a Markov Decision Process and train a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy for query plan selection. Our experiments on a real-world database show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of execution time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization with Gaussian Processes
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have revolutionized various applications, but their performance heavily relies on careful hyperparameter tuning. This process is often time-consuming and computationally expensive. We propose a Bayesian optimization approach using Gaussian processes to efficiently search for optimal hyperparameters. Our method, 'GP-BO', leverages the uncertainty estimates of Gaussian processes to adaptively select the most informative hyperparameter settings. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GP-BO achieves comparable or better performance than state-of-the-art methods while reducing the number of evaluations by up to 50%. We also provide theoretical guarantees on the convergence of our algorithm.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Task Learning in Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning (MTL) has shown promise in computer vision, but existing methods often suffer from increased computational complexity and decreased performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that efficiently learns shared representations across multiple tasks. Our approach leverages task-specific attention weights to selectively focus on relevant features, reducing the impact of negative transfer. We demonstrate improved performance and reduced computation time on several benchmark datasets, including Cityscapes and COCO, and provide insights into the learned attention patterns.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality: A Study on User Experience and Eye Movement
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology advances, there is a growing need for intuitive and natural interaction methods. This paper presents a gaze-based interaction framework for AR applications, which leverages eye-tracking data to infer user intentions. We conduct a user study to evaluate the usability and effectiveness of our approach, focusing on the correlation between eye movement patterns and user experience. Our results show that gaze-based interaction can significantly reduce user frustration and improve task completion time in AR environments. We also identify key eye movement metrics that can inform the design of future AR interfaces.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection for Real-time Object Detection Systems using Explainable AI
paper_abstract: Object detection systems have become ubiquitous in various applications, including surveillance, autonomous vehicles, and healthcare. However, these systems are vulnerable to adversarial attacks that can compromise their performance. This paper proposes an Explainable AI (XAI) framework to detect adversarial attacks on real-time object detection systems. Our approach leverages a novel attention-based mechanism that identifies suspicious patterns in the input data, which are then analyzed using SHAP values to explain the model's predictions. Experimental results on popular object detection benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting adversarial attacks, even in the presence of noise and occlusion.

title: Cooperative Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Distributed resource allocation is a complex problem that arises in many real-world applications, such as cloud computing, smart grids, and logistics. This paper proposes a cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'CoRAL', that enables agents to learn optimal resource allocation strategies in a decentralized manner. We introduce a novel distributed Q-learning algorithm that incorporates communication and coordination mechanisms among agents, allowing them to adapt to changing environmental conditions and optimize overall system performance. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that CoRAL outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of efficiency, fairness, and robustness.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Event Extraction
paper_abstract: Event extraction from multi-modal data sources has become a crucial task in various applications. However, existing methods struggle to capture complex relationships between entities and events. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that integrates graph neural networks with hierarchical attention mechanisms. HGAT learns to represent events as graph structures and attends to relevant entities and modalities (e.g., text, images) at multiple scales. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in event extraction accuracy and robustness to noise.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodied Cognition on Gesture-based Interaction in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interaction in virtual reality (VR) has gained popularity, but the role of embodied cognition in shaping user experience remains understudied. We investigate how embodied cognition influences users' gestures, sense of agency, and overall performance in VR tasks. Our study employs a mixed-methods approach, combining behavioral data from a gesture-tracking experiment with qualitative insights from think-aloud protocols. Results show that users who exhibit stronger embodied cognition traits tend to perform better in VR tasks and exhibit more intuitive gestures. We discuss implications for the design of more effective and engaging gesture-based interfaces in VR.

title: Unsupervised Query Term Weighting for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional query term weighting methods in information retrieval rely heavily on manually curated resources, such as thesauri or dictionaries. This paper presents an unsupervised approach to query term weighting, leveraging the underlying semantics of the document collection. Our proposed method, 'TermForge', employs a graph-based representation of the document term relationships, which is then utilized to derive a weighted query representation. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that TermForge outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval efficiency and effectiveness, particularly in scenarios with limited domain knowledge.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Relation Extraction
paper_abstract: Few-shot relation extraction (FSRE) aims to identify relationships between entities in text with limited supervision. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture complex dependencies between entities and their context. Our approach involves hierarchical graph construction, entity-level attention, and relation-specific attention to infer relationships. Experimental results on standard FSRE benchmarks demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models, achieving significant improvements in both few-shot and zero-shot settings.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to decentralized task allocation in multi-agent systems using graph neural networks (GNNs). We propose a distributed algorithm that enables agents to learn a joint task allocation policy through local communication and observation of their neighbors' actions. Our approach leverages the expressive power of GNNs to model complex agent interactions and adapt to dynamic task environments. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in achieving near-optimal solutions while maintaining scalability and robustness.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., audio, video, text) is a challenging task due to the inherent complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that effectively fuses and selectively focuses on relevant modalities to improve emotion recognition. Our HAN model employs a hierarchical structure to capture intra-modality and inter-modality relationships, and incorporates attention mechanisms to dynamically weight the importance of each modality. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs.

title: Deep Adaptive Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) requires effective fusion of features from diverse modalities such as text, images, and audio. This paper presents a novel deep learning framework, 'MAAN', which leverages adaptive attention mechanisms to dynamically weigh and integrate modality-specific features. MAAN incorporates a hierarchical attention structure that captures both local and global dependencies across modalities, leading to improved sentiment prediction accuracy. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of MAAN over state-of-the-art MSA methods, particularly in scenarios with noisy or missing modality data.

title: Deep Hierarchical Neural Networks for Entity Disambiguation in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation in knowledge graphs is a challenging task due to the exponential growth of entities and their relationships. This paper proposes a novel deep hierarchical neural network, 'HDNet', that leverages the hierarchical structure of knowledge graphs to disambiguate entities. HDNet employs a multi-level attention mechanism to capture both local and global contextual information, outperforming state-of-the-art models on benchmark datasets. Experimental results demonstrate that HDNet achieves a 12.5% improvement in F1-score on the YAGO dataset and a 9.2% improvement on the DBpedia dataset.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has shown promise in various applications, but existing methods often neglect the hierarchical structure inherent in many knowledge graphs. We propose a novel KGE approach, 'HAT-KGE', which leverages hierarchical attention networks to capture complex relationships between entities and their attributes. Our experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAT-KGE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in link prediction and entity classification tasks, while reducing computational complexity. We further show that HAT-KGE can be easily integrated with popular AI frameworks for real-world applications.

title: Improving Explainability of Deep Reinforcement Learning using Attention-based Feature Importance
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but the lack of transparency in decision-making processes hinders its widespread adoption. This paper presents a novel approach to improving the explainability of DRL agents by incorporating attention-based feature importance. We propose a model-agnostic technique that generates feature importance scores, enabling the identification of crucial state features contributing to the agent's policy. Experimental results on Atari games and a real-world robotics dataset demonstrate that our approach provides meaningful insights into the decision-making process, improving the trustworthiness and accountability of DRL systems.

title: Hierarchical Document Retrieval with Neural Query Graphs
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems rely on exact keyword matching, which often fails to capture the nuanced relationships between query terms. We propose a novel neural approach, Hierarchical Query Graphs (HQRG), which represents queries as hierarchical graphs and documents as dense vectors. By leveraging these graph-structured queries, our model can effectively capture entity relationships, synonyms, and contextual dependencies. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HQRG outperforms state-of-the-art neural IR models, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Skeleton-Based Human Action Recognition
paper_abstract: Skeleton-based human action recognition has garnered significant attention in recent years, owing to its applications in fields like healthcare, surveillance, and human-computer interaction. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture for skeleton-based action recognition. HGAT integrates graph attention mechanisms at multiple scales to effectively capture spatiotemporal dependencies in human skeleton data. Experimental results on the NTU-RGB+D and Kinetics-Skeleton datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving improved recognition accuracy and robustness to noise and occlusion.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In large-scale multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture, called AgentAllocator, which enables agents to selectively focus on relevant tasks and teammates. By learning to represent tasks and agents as hierarchical embeddings, AgentAllocator outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate, communication overhead, and adaptability to changing environments. We evaluate our approach using a realistic simulation framework and demonstrate its applicability to various multi-agent domains.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have become increasingly popular in cloud computing, but optimizing queries for multiple tenants remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'MTQO', which leverages machine learning to predict query performance and optimize resource allocation. MTQO introduces a tenant-aware cost model that considers both query complexity and resource contention, resulting in significant improvements in query response times and system throughput. Experimental results on a real-world cloud database show that MTQO outperforms existing optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of average query latency.

title: Deep Query Reformulation for Efficient Document Retrieval in Specialized Search Engines
paper_abstract: Specialized search engines, such as those used in patent or academic databases, often require precise query formulation to retrieve relevant documents. This paper proposes a deep learning-based approach for query reformulation, which leverages a combination of natural language processing and information retrieval techniques. Our model, called 'DeepRef', learns to identify ambiguous or underspecified query terms and generates alternative formulations that improve retrieval performance. Experimental results on a large patent database demonstrate that DeepRef outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 23% increase in mean average precision and a 30% reduction in query latency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Word Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have gained popularity due to their ability to capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. However, they often suffer from the vocabulary mismatch problem, where the query and document vocabularies differ. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'EmbedExpan', which leverages word embeddings to generate context-aware expansion terms. We demonstrate that EmbedExpan outperforms traditional query expansion methods, such as Rocchio and latent semantic analysis, in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency. Experiments on several benchmark datasets show that our approach achieves significant improvements in precision and recall, while reducing the computational overhead of query expansion.

title: Intelligent Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Large-Scale IoT Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing number of devices in IoT systems demands efficient resource allocation to ensure scalability and performance. This paper proposes an intelligent agent-based framework for resource allocation, which leverages decentralized decision-making and learning capabilities. Our approach, 'AgentIoT', enables agents to adapt to dynamic IoT environments, optimize resource utilization, and improve overall system efficiency. We evaluate AgentIoT through simulations on a real-world IoT dataset, demonstrating significant improvements in resource allocation and system performance compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: EmoReact: A Multimodal Affective Computing Framework for Real-time Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Accurate emotion recognition is crucial for developing empathetic human-computer interfaces. This paper presents EmoReact, a novel multimodal affective computing framework that integrates computer vision, natural language processing, and physiological signal processing for real-time emotion recognition. EmoReact utilizes a convolutional neural network to extract facial features, a recurrent neural network to analyze linguistic cues, and a signal processing module to extract physiological features from wearable devices. We evaluate EmoReact on a large-scale multimodal dataset and demonstrate its superior performance compared to existing approaches, achieving an average F1-score of 0.92 across six emotions.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Adaptive Contextualized Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in Information Retrieval (IR) systems to improve search results. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach using adaptive contextualized embeddings, dubbed ACE-QE. ACE-QE leverages pre-trained language models to generate context-aware embeddings for query terms and documents. Our method adaptively adjusts the embedding dimensions and weights based on the query complexity and document relevance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ACE-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of precision and recall, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Cooperative Multi-Agent Planning with Incomplete Information using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent planning is a challenging problem, especially when agents have incomplete information about their environment. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning approach to tackle this issue. We propose a decentralized framework where agents learn to share information and coordinate their actions to achieve a common goal. Our method utilizes a graph neural network to represent the agent's observation and a deep Q-network to learn the optimal policy. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms existing methods in various multi-agent planning scenarios, including robotic soccer and autonomous driving.

title: Efficient Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection for High-Dimensional Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Real-world time series data often exhibit complex patterns and anomalies, making detection challenging. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'TS-Anom', which leverages a hybrid convolutional-recurrent neural network (CNN-RNN) architecture to identify anomalies in high-dimensional time series data. TS-Anom incorporates a novel attention mechanism that adaptively focuses on relevant feature subsets, reducing computational complexity and improving detection accuracy. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that TS-Anom outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 12.5% with a 3x speedup.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Smart Traffic Management
paper_abstract: As urban populations grow, intelligent traffic management systems are crucial to alleviate congestion and reduce travel times. This paper presents a novel framework for coordinating autonomous agents in smart traffic management using hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL). Our approach, called 'SmartTraffic', employs a two-level hierarchy of agents: high-level agents optimize traffic signal control, while low-level agents adapt to local traffic conditions. We demonstrate the efficacy of SmartTraffic in a simulated urban network, achieving a 23% reduction in average travel time and a 17% decrease in congestion compared to traditional fixed-time traffic signal control.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that effectively integrates and attends to relevant features from different modalities. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention layers that learn to weigh the importance of each modality and a hierarchical fusion layer that combines the attended features. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs, achieving an average F1-score of 0.853.

title: Adaptive Document Ranking with Hierarchical Embeddings for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in information retrieval rely on lexical matching, which can be limited by the vocabulary gap between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel adaptive ranking approach that leverages hierarchical embeddings to capture semantic relationships between queries and documents. Our method, HierRank, integrates a graph-based neural network with a probabilistic relevance model to estimate document relevance. Experimental results on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate that HierRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models in terms of ranking accuracy and efficiency, particularly for long-tail queries.

title: Query Expansion via Deep Neural Networks for Effective Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a critical task in intellectual property search, but traditional keyword-based approaches often suffer from limited query representation. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based query expansion method, dubbed 'PatentBERT', which leverages pre-trained language models to capture contextual relationships between query terms and patent documents. Our experiments on a large patent corpus demonstrate that PatentBERT significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval precision and recall, particularly for complex patent queries.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: As distributed database systems continue to grow in scale and complexity, query optimization remains a critical challenge. This paper presents a novel graph-based indexing approach that leverages the structural properties of query graphs to optimize query execution plans. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphQO', constructs a compact graph index that captures the relationships between query predicates and data distributions. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that GraphQO reduces query latency by up to 40% and improves resource utilization by 25% compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Document Indexing with Neural Hashing for Scalable Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Information retrieval systems rely on efficient document indexing to facilitate rapid query processing. This paper presents a novel neural hashing approach, 'NeuroIndex', which learns compact binary representations of documents to enable fast similarity search. By incorporating a graph-based attention mechanism, NeuroIndex captures semantic relationships between documents and outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods in terms of both query performance and storage efficiency. Experimental results on large-scale document collections demonstrate the scalability and effectiveness of NeuroIndex in real-world IR applications.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-time Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Optimizing resource allocation in cloud computing is crucial for efficient service delivery. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach, 'CloudAllocator', which learns to dynamically allocate resources in real-time. CloudAllocator leverages a multi-agent framework, where each agent represents a cloud resource, and utilizes a graph neural network (GNN) to capture complex dependencies between resources. Experimental results on a real-world cloud dataset demonstrate that CloudAllocator outperforms traditional rule-based allocation methods, achieving up to 30% improvement in resource utilization and 25% reduction in response time.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that involves assigning tasks to agents to maximize efficiency and minimize conflicts. This paper proposes a distributed task allocation framework using reinforcement learning, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on its local observations and interactions with other agents. We introduce a novel reward function that encourages cooperation and fairness among agents, and demonstrate its effectiveness in simulated environments. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and agent satisfaction.

title: Task-Oriented Dialogue Management using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Agents
paper_abstract: Developing autonomous agents that can engage in effective task-oriented dialogues remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for dialogue management, which leverages a two-level hierarchy to balance task completion and user engagement. The upper level learns a high-level policy to select the next dialogue act, while the lower level refines the policy by generating a specific response. We evaluate our approach on a popular dialogue dataset and demonstrate improved task success rates and user satisfaction compared to existing methods.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on manual input devices, limiting the immersion and accessibility of VR experiences. This paper proposes a novel gaze-based interaction framework, 'GazeVR', which leverages deep learning to infer user intentions from eye movement data. We introduce a multi-modal neural network architecture that combines convolutional and recurrent layers to process gaze patterns, head movements, and contextual information. Our evaluation on a VR gaming dataset shows that GazeVR achieves high accuracy and low latency in recognizing user commands, enabling more natural and efficient interaction in VR environments.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Agent Teams using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: We present a novel approach to task allocation for heterogeneous agent teams using multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL). Our framework, 'AgentTA', leverages a decentralized, communication-efficient architecture to enable agents with varying capabilities to learn joint policies for task allocation. We introduce a novel reward function that balances individual agent utility with global team performance, and demonstrate improved allocation efficiency and adaptability compared to traditional, centralized methods. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response domain show that AgentTA outperforms state-of-the-art MARL baselines in dynamic, real-world-inspired scenarios.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to bridge the vocabulary gap between queries and documents. This paper introduces a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'RL-QE', which learns to generate effective expansion terms by interacting with the retrieval environment. Our approach leverages a hierarchical policy network to select expansion terms based on their predicted relevance and coverage of the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of precision, recall, and NDCG.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly prevalent in modern data management systems. However, optimizing query execution in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning.
