We design a deep Q-network that learns to select the optimal query plan based on the database's current workload and system resources. Our experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query latency and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Urban traffic congestion is a major challenge for modern cities, and multi-agent systems have shown promise in optimizing traffic flow. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for coordinating autonomous agents in urban traffic control. Our approach combines a high-level planner that sets traffic signal timings with low-level controllers that adjust signal phases based on real-time traffic data. Experimental results using a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that our HRL framework outperforms traditional fixed-time signal control and model-based optimization methods in terms of reducing congestion and travel times.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Cognitive Biases on Human-AI Collaboration in Decision-Making
paper_abstract: As AI systems become increasingly integrated into decision-making processes, understanding the dynamics of human-AI collaboration is crucial. This paper investigates the role of cognitive biases in human-AI collaboration, focusing on the anchoring bias, confirmation bias, and availability heuristic. We conduct a user study with 120 participants, analyzing their decision-making behaviors when interacting with AI-driven recommendation systems. Our results show that cognitive biases significantly influence human trust in AI and decision outcomes, highlighting the need for bias-aware AI design and training strategies. We propose a framework for identifying and mitigating cognitive biases in human-AI collaboration, enabling more effective and trustworthy decision-making.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Document Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to suboptimal query results. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep learning-based document embeddings to effectively capture semantic relationships between terms. We demonstrate that incorporating contextualized embeddings from pre-trained language models can significantly improve retrieval performance, particularly for ambiguous or under-specified queries. Extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets show that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have revolutionized information retrieval by leveraging deep learning techniques to improve the accuracy of document retrieval. However, these models can be computationally expensive and require large amounts of training data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HierRank', which leverages a multi-level ranking strategy to efficiently retrieve relevant documents. HierRank combines the strengths of both lexical and semantic matching, and uses a novel attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant document regions. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HierRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models while reducing computational overhead by up to 40%.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the challenge lies in capturing the nuances of user queries. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks, which learns to identify and incorporate relevant contextual information from the query. Our proposed model, 'NeuroQE', leverages a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to capture both local and global dependencies in the query. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that NeuroQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Explainable Reasoning for Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) models often struggle to provide interpretable explanations for their predictions. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based approach, 'HAT-VQA', which leverages self-attention mechanisms to generate explanations at multiple levels of abstraction. Our framework consists of a question-aware visual encoder, a hierarchical attention network, and a reasoning module that predicts answers and explanations jointly. Experimental results on the VQA-X dataset demonstrate that HAT-VQA outperforms state-of-the-art VQA models while providing more accurate and informative explanations.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Older Adults: A Study on Age-Related Cognitive Decline
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve the lives of older adults, but its adoption is hindered by age-related cognitive decline. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive VR experiences for older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants aged 65-85, exploring the impact of cognitive decline on VR usability. Our results highlight the importance of simplified navigation, visual cues, and adaptable feedback mechanisms. We propose a set of design guidelines and a cognitive support framework to enhance the accessibility and engagement of VR systems for older adults.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Label Node Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-label node classification is a fundamental problem in graph-based learning, where each node can have multiple labels. Existing state-of-the-art methods, such as graph convolutional networks (GCNs) and graph attention networks (GATs), are limited in their ability to capture complex relationships between nodes and labels. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAN) architecture, which leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively aggregate features from different nodes and labels. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms existing methods in terms of micro-F1 score and label-wise accuracy, and provides better interpretability of node-label relationships.

title: Gaze-Based Human-Computer Interaction for Individuals with Severe Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with severe motor impairments face significant barriers to interacting with digital systems. This paper presents a novel gaze-based HCI system, 'EyeLink', which combines eye-tracking technology with machine learning-based gaze estimation to enable accurate and efficient communication. We evaluate EyeLink with a user study involving 20 participants with severe motor impairments, demonstrating a significant reduction in interaction time and error rate compared to existing gaze-based systems. Our approach has the potential to improve the quality of life for individuals with motor impairments, enabling them to engage more effectively with digital technologies.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Session-based Recommendation
paper_abstract: Session-based recommendation systems aim to predict the next item a user will interact with based on their recent behavior. Graph-based models have shown promise in this task, but they can be limited by their inability to capture complex item relationships and contextual information. We propose Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that combines hierarchical graph encoding with attention mechanisms to model both local and global dependencies in user-item interactions. Our experiments on two benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision and recall, while providing interpretable insights into user behavior.

title: Reducing Document Redundancy in Real-time Search Engines using Time-Aware Latent Semantic Analysis
paper_abstract: Real-time search engines often suffer from document redundancy, leading to decreased user satisfaction and increased computational costs. This paper proposes a novel time-aware latent semantic analysis (TALSA) approach to reduce redundancy in search results. By incorporating temporal features into the latent semantic space, TALSA captures the evolution of topics over time and identifies redundant documents more effectively. Experimental results on a large-scale news dataset demonstrate that TALSA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in reducing redundancy while maintaining search relevance.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Ranking Models using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in information retrieval tasks, but they often require extensive computational resources and large amounts of training data. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages knowledge graph embeddings to enrich the semantic representation of queries. Our method, called KGE-QE, uses a graph attention mechanism to select relevant entities and their relationships from a knowledge graph, and incorporates them into the query representation. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset show that KGE-QE improves the ranking performance of neural models, while reducing the computational overhead of query expansion.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus and extracting the answer. Existing passage retrieval methods rely on lexical matching or dense neural networks, which can be computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) architecture that models the relationships between passages, sentences, and entities. Our approach leverages graph-based attention mechanisms to identify the most relevant passages and reduce the search space. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset show that our method achieves state-of-the-art passage retrieval performance with significant computational savings.

title: HierarchicalAttentional Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification in Dynamic Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in dynamic graphs is a challenging task due to the complexity of node interactions and graph evolution. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attentional graph neural network (HAGNN) architecture, which leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and temporal information. Our model consists of a node-level attention module, a graph-level attention module, and a hierarchical fusion layer to capture both local and global graph structures. Experimental results on several real-world dynamic graph datasets demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in node classification tasks, particularly in scenarios with rapid graph changes.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Graph-Based Relevance Modeling for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval results. This paper proposes a novel neural graph-based relevance modeling approach, 'NeuGraph', to enhance query expansion for ad-hoc retrieval. NeuGraph represents the query and document graphs as neural networks, enabling the capture of complex semantic relationships and contextual dependencies. Our experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that NeuGraph outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Path Planning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, planning efficient paths for multiple agents is a challenging problem. Existing methods often rely on centralized approaches, which can be computationally expensive and brittle. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables decentralized, real-time path planning for multiple agents. By incorporating attention mechanisms at both local and global levels, our HAN model learns to prioritize relevant information and coordinate agent movements. Experimental results on a variety of scenarios demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of path efficiency, collision avoidance, and scalability.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning and Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems is a challenging problem in many applications, including robotics, smart cities, and autonomous vehicles. This paper proposes a novel approach that combines reinforcement learning with graph attention mechanisms to learn effective coordination strategies. Our method, called Graph Attention-based Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (GAMARL), represents the agents' communication graph as a neural network and learns to focus on the most relevant agents when making decisions. We evaluate GAMARL on several benchmark problems, including traffic signal control and robotic foraging, and show significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years due to their ability to provide transparent and trustworthy recommendations. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for ERS, which captures user preferences at multiple levels of abstraction. Our HAN model consists of a hierarchical encoder that learns to represent users and items as dense vectors, and a attention-based decoder that generates personalized explanations for recommended items. We evaluate our approach on a real-world e-commerce dataset and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of both recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face significant barriers when interacting with gesture-based systems. This paper presents a novel framework for designing accessible gesture-based interfaces that accommodate a wide range of motor abilities. We introduce a machine learning-based approach to recognize and adapt to individual users' gesture patterns, enabling more accurate and efficient interaction. Our user study with 20 participants reveals that our approach significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture recognition systems.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Deep Web Databases
paper_abstract: Deep web databases pose significant challenges for information retrieval (IR) systems due to their large scale, heterogeneity, and limited accessibility. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) framework that leverages both semantic and structural knowledge to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of retrieval in deep web databases. HQE incorporates a multi-layered representation of queries and documents, enabling the identification of relevant terms and phrases at different levels of abstraction. Experimental results on a large-scale deep web dataset demonstrate that HQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval accuracy and response time.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality Visualization of 3D Medical Data
paper_abstract: Effective visualization of 3D medical data is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning. This paper presents an innovative gaze-based interaction system for augmented reality (AR) visualization of 3D medical data. Our approach leverages eye-tracking technology to enable users to intuitively manipulate and explore 3D models of patient data in AR. We evaluate our system through a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional interaction methods. The results have implications for the development of more intuitive and accessible AR-based medical visualization tools.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Individuals with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder affecting articulation and intelligibility, face significant barriers when interacting with voice assistants. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop an inclusive voice assistant, 'EasySpeak', tailored to the needs of individuals with dysarthria. We conducted participatory design workshops and interviews with individuals with dysarthria, resulting in a set of design recommendations for speech recognition, error correction, and feedback mechanisms. A pilot study with 15 participants demonstrates that EasySpeak significantly improves speech recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel distributed task allocation framework for autonomous agents, leveraging auction-based mechanisms to optimize task assignments. We introduce a decentralized auction protocol, 'AgentAuction', which enables agents to bid on tasks based on their capabilities and availability. Our approach ensures efficient task allocation, minimizes communication overhead, and adapts to dynamic changes in the agent network. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced latency compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query performance remains a significant bottleneck, especially for complex queries. This paper presents an adaptive indexing approach that dynamically adjusts index structures based on query patterns and data distribution. Our approach, called 'AdapIndex', leverages machine learning-based prediction models to identify optimal index configurations for varying workloads. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that AdapIndex achieves significant improvements in query latency and throughput compared to traditional static indexing techniques.

title: Eye-Gaze Driven Adaptive Interfaces for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on manual input devices, leading to user fatigue and decreased immersion. This paper presents 'GazeAdapt', an innovative eye-gaze driven interface that dynamically adapts to user behavior in VR environments. Our approach utilizes machine learning-based gaze prediction and real-time pupillometry to detect user attention and intentions. We evaluate GazeAdapt in a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in task efficiency, user satisfaction, and reduced cognitive load. The proposed system has far-reaching implications for enhancing accessibility and overall user experience in VR applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning is a challenging problem in AI research, requiring agents to learn complex coordination strategies. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture, which enables agents to selectively focus on relevant teammates and tasks. HAN consists of a hierarchical attention mechanism and a novel ' teammate-aware' reward function. Our experiments show that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in several cooperative game environments, demonstrating its ability to learn effective coordination strategies in complex, dynamic scenarios.

title: Efficient Explainability for Deep Reinforcement Learning through Model-Agnostic Saliency Maps
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but the lack of transparency in decision-making processes hinders its adoption in high-stakes domains. This paper presents a novel, model-agnostic approach to explainability in DRL, dubbed 'SaliencyRL'. By generating saliency maps that highlight the most influential input features contributing to an agent's decisions, SaliencyRL provides actionable insights into the policy's behavior. We demonstrate the effectiveness of SaliencyRL on several Atari games and a real-world robotics task, showcasing its potential to facilitate trust and understanding in DRL systems.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems (MTDS) have become increasingly popular for cloud-based applications. However, optimizing query performance in MTDS remains a challenging problem due to the varying resource requirements of different tenants. This paper proposes a novel query optimization approach using reinforcement learning (RL). Our method, called QOptRL, learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the MTDS environment and receiving rewards based on query execution times. We evaluate QOptRL on a real-world MTDS dataset and show that it outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of average query response time.

title: Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection for Real-time Time Series Data Streams
paper_abstract: Real-time anomaly detection in time series data streams is crucial for various applications, including IoT, finance, and healthcare. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'TS-ADNet', which leverages a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to detect anomalies in real-time data streams. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively focuses on relevant features and time scales, enabling effective anomaly detection in high-dimensional and noisy data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that TS-ADNet outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but current VR interfaces often neglect the needs of users with visual impairments. This paper presents an inclusive VR interface design framework, VIIDE, which incorporates multimodal feedback and adaptive navigation mechanisms to facilitate independent exploration of virtual environments. We conducted a user study with 20 visually impaired participants, demonstrating significant improvements in navigation efficiency and user satisfaction compared to existing VR interfaces. Our work contributes to the development of more accessible and equitable VR experiences.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and vision, remains a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the heterogeneity of data sources. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages the strengths of graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to model the intricate relationships between modalities. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods on the CMU-MOSEI dataset, achieving an average F1-score of 0.83 across six emotions. We also provide insights into the learned attention patterns, revealing the importance of cross-modal interactions in emotion recognition.

title: Designing Inclusive Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Dementia
paper_abstract: Older adults with dementia face significant barriers when interacting with digital systems, leading to social isolation and decreased autonomy. This paper presents 'EasyGesture', a novel gestural interface designed to accommodate the cognitive and motor abilities of this population. We conducted a participatory design process with caregivers and individuals with dementia, resulting in a set of intuitive, error-tolerant gestures for common tasks. A user study yielded high engagement rates and improved task completion times compared to traditional touchscreen interfaces. EasyGesture has the potential to enable more inclusive and accessible digital interactions for older adults with dementia.

title: Efficient Zero-Shot Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Perception via Task-Conditioned Generative Models
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on accurate perception models to navigate complex scenarios. However, collecting and annotating data for every possible situation is impractical. This paper presents a novel zero-shot learning framework, 'TaskGen', which leverages task-conditioned generative models to synthesize novel scenarios and adapt perception models without additional labeled data. Our approach combines a conditional GAN with a task encoder, enabling the generation of realistic, task-specific scenes that improve the robustness of perception models. Experimental results on the KITTI and Waymo datasets demonstrate that TaskGen outperforms state-of-the-art zero-shot learning methods in object detection and semantic segmentation tasks.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Anthropomorphic Cues on User Trust and Satisfaction
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, yet their anthropomorphic design elements can have unintended consequences on user trust and satisfaction. This study investigates how varying levels of anthropomorphism in voice assistants influence user perceptions of trustworthiness, likability, and overall satisfaction. We conducted a between-subjects experiment with 120 participants, exposing them to either a highly anthropomorphized or a minimalist voice assistant. Our results show that users are more likely to trust and be satisfied with voice assistants that employ subtle, context-dependent anthropomorphic cues, rather than overtly human-like features. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of inclusive and trustworthy voice assistants.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Relational Databases using Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query performance remains a significant bottleneck in these systems. This paper presents a novel adaptive indexing approach that dynamically adjusts the indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distribution. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that our approach achieves an average query performance improvement of 35% compared to traditional indexing techniques, while reducing storage overhead by 25%. We also present a detailed analysis of the trade-offs between query performance, storage efficiency, and indexing overhead.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework using deep reinforcement learning, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on its local observations and interactions with neighboring agents. We introduce a novel auction-based mechanism that enables agents to bid for tasks and negotiate with each other to reach a mutually beneficial allocation. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and communication overhead.

title: Designing Personalized Accessibility Widgets for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents the design and evaluation of a novel accessibility widget framework tailored to the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a mixed-methods study, involving 30 participants with mild cognitive impairment, to identify key challenges and preferences in interacting with digital interfaces. Our framework, 'CognitiveEase', incorporates personalized adaptations, such as simplified layouts, enlarged icons, and audio cues, to facilitate intuitive navigation and reduce cognitive load. A usability evaluation demonstrates significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to standard interface designs.

title: Enhancing Query Reformulation via Neural Semantic Parsing for Conversational Search
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems rely heavily on accurate query understanding to provide relevant results. This paper proposes a novel neural semantic parsing approach, 'SemParse', to enhance query reformulation in conversational search. SemParse leverages a graph-based neural network to model the semantic relationships between entities, intent, and context in natural language queries. Our experiments on a large-scale conversational search dataset show that SemParse significantly improves query reformulation accuracy and reduces the need for manual intervention. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of SemParse in improving the overall search experience through a user study.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Coordination
paper_abstract: As autonomous vehicles (AVs) become increasingly prevalent, efficient coordination mechanisms are crucial for safe and efficient traffic flow. This paper presents MARL-COORD, a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that enables AVs to adaptively learn coordination strategies in dynamic environments. We propose a decentralized, graph-based Q-learning approach that leverages vehicle-to-vehicle communication and sparse rewards. Experimental results in a realistic simulation environment demonstrate that MARL-COORD outperforms existing methods in terms of reduced congestion, travel time, and fuel consumption.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Time-Series Anomaly Detection in IoT Sensor Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has generated vast amounts of sensor data, making anomaly detection a crucial task. Traditional methods often rely on manual feature engineering or shallow learning models, which are limited in capturing complex patterns. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for time-series anomaly detection in IoT sensor data. By incorporating both local and global attention mechanisms, HAN learns to selectively focus on relevant features and contextual information, improving detection accuracy and robustness. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in identifying anomalies, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Vehicles using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous vehicles using multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'MATRL', enables a team of autonomous vehicles to dynamically allocate tasks in real-time, taking into account their individual capabilities, resources, and environmental constraints. We formulate the task allocation problem as a decentralized Markov decision process and develop a novel multi-agent Q-learning algorithm that incorporates communication and coordination mechanisms. Experimental results in a simulated urban environment demonstrate that MATRL outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate, latency, and system scalability.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization with Gaussian Process Priors
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various machine learning tasks, but their success heavily relies on careful hyperparameter tuning. Bayesian optimization has emerged as a powerful approach to hyperparameter tuning, but its computational cost can be prohibitively high. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian optimization method that leverages Gaussian process priors to model the objective function. We introduce a sparse approximation scheme that reduces the computational cost of Gaussian process inference while maintaining its accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing Bayesian optimization methods and achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art methods with significantly reduced computational cost.

title: Decentralized Coordination of Autonomous Agents using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel framework for decentralized coordination of autonomous agents in complex, dynamic environments. We introduce a hierarchical reinforcement learning approach that enables agents to learn both individual and collaborative policies. The framework consists of a high-level coordination module that guides the agents' behavior and a low-level decision-making module that adapts to changing environmental conditions. Experimental evaluations in a simulated traffic management scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving efficient and scalable coordination of agents.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Decentralized resource allocation in complex systems necessitates the coordination of multiple autonomous agents. This paper presents a novel decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework, 'Distributed Q-Networks' (DQN), to optimize resource allocation in distributed systems. DQN leverages a decentralized Q-learning approach, where each agent learns to allocate resources based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DQN in a simulated cloud computing environment, showcasing improved resource utilization and reduced latency compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent systems have numerous applications in domains like robotics, smart cities, and IoT. However, efficient task allocation remains a challenging problem, especially in dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'Deep-Coop', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn distributed task allocation policies for cooperative multi-agent systems. Our method utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to make decisions based on local observations and communication with neighbors. Experimental results demonstrate that Deep-Coop outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion rate, latency, and adaptability to environmental changes.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and social media platforms has led to an exponential increase in data volumes, making real-time data warehousing a crucial aspect of modern data analytics. Traditional query optimization techniques often fail to provide optimal performance under such massive data influx. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using learned index structures, which can adapt to the underlying data distribution and workload patterns. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach, called 'LISA', achieves an average speedup of 3.5x over state-of-the-art query optimization techniques, while reducing memory footprint by 40%.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems struggle to efficiently retrieve relevant documents for complex queries. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that leverages both semantic and syntactic features to expand queries. HQE constructs a hierarchical representation of the query, where each level captures increasingly abstract concepts. We introduce a probabilistic model to estimate the relevance of expanded terms and a pruning strategy to reduce the search space. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HQE improves retrieval efficiency by 30% and mean average precision by 12% compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Neural search models have shown promising results in information retrieval tasks, but often rely on predefined query representations. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, dubbed 'ContrastiveQE', which leverages contrastive learning to generate semantically enriched query embeddings. Our method learns to distinguish relevant from non-relevant documents, enabling the model to capture nuanced query semantics and improve retrieval performance. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ContrastiveQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant gains in retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. One effective approach to improve retrieval performance is query expansion, which involves adding relevant terms to the original query. In this paper, we propose a neural query expansion framework that leverages pre-trained language models to learn dense embeddings for queries and documents. We introduce a novel attention-based mechanism to selectively expand the query, incorporating both local and global context. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Hybrid Indexing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a crucial component of modern business intelligence, but query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach, 'RT-Hybrid', that leverages the strengths of both column-store and row-store indexing techniques. We introduce a cost-based optimization framework that dynamically selects the most efficient indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distribution. Experimental results on a real-world data warehousing benchmark demonstrate that RT-Hybrid achieves an average query performance improvement of 3.2x compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems are essential for efficiently searching large-scale document collections. However, the query latency in such systems remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach, HI-DIR, which significantly reduces query processing time. HI-DIR partitions the document collection into a hierarchical structure, allowing for efficient query routing and reducing the number of nodes involved in query processing. Experimental results on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate that HI-DIR outperforms state-of-the-art DIR systems, achieving an average query latency reduction of 35% while maintaining retrieval accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained significant attention in recent years, but the lack of interpretability in deep learning models hinders their adoption in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates visual, textual, and acoustic features for multimodal sentiment analysis. Our HAN model employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant features and modalities, providing insights into the decision-making process. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and explainability, enabling more trustworthy AI systems.

title: Adaptive Negotiation Strategies for Autonomous Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments require effective negotiation strategies to achieve their goals. This paper presents a novel adaptive negotiation framework, 'AdaNeg', which utilizes reinforcement learning to adapt to changing environmental conditions and agent interactions. We introduce a hierarchical negotiation strategy that integrates game-theoretic analysis with machine learning-based opponent modeling. Experimental results in a simulated robotic soccer domain demonstrate that AdaNeg outperforms state-of-the-art negotiation strategies in terms of goal achievement and adaptability to environmental changes.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Neural Networks via Hierarchical Representation Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can have devastating consequences in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to improve the robustness of deep neural networks against adversarial attacks by learning hierarchical representations. Our method, Hierarchical Adversarial Training (HAT), leverages the idea of learning multiple levels of representations and using them to regularize the model's behavior. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAT on several benchmark datasets, including CIFAR-10 and ImageNet, and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art adversarial training methods.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Navigation
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient navigation strategies to handle complex scenarios. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'AV-Nav', that leverages a novel state-abstraction mechanism to reduce the curse of dimensionality. AV-Nav employs a higher-level policy to select sub-goals, while a lower-level policy focuses on executing the selected sub-goals. We demonstrate the effectiveness of AV-Nav in simulations and real-world experiments, showcasing improved navigation efficiency and reduced collision rates compared to flat reinforcement learning baselines.

title: Enhancing Query Reformulation with Hierarchical Graph Attention for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to poor query formulations. To address this, we propose a novel hierarchical graph attention model, 'HGA-QR', which refines query representations by modeling relationships between entities, keywords, and context. Our approach leverages graph convolutional networks to learn hierarchical representations of query components and attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant aspects. Experiments on the TREC ad-hoc search benchmark show that HGA-QR outperforms state-of-the-art query reformulation methods, achieving a 12.5% increase in mean average precision.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Resource allocation in multi-agent systems is a complex problem that requires efficient coordination among agents. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-MA', that enables agents to learn optimal resource allocation strategies in a decentralized manner. We introduce a novel hierarchical architecture that decomposes the global problem into smaller sub-problems, allowing agents to focus on local resource allocation while coordinating with other agents through a higher-level coordination layer. Experimental results on a simulated resource allocation scenario demonstrate that HRL-MA outperforms traditional reinforcement learning methods in terms of convergence speed and allocation efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Decomposition
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data. However, query optimization remains a major bottleneck in DDS, as it involves complex joins and subqueries across multiple nodes. This paper proposes a novel graph-based decomposition approach, called 'GraphOpt', which leverages the structural properties of query graphs to optimize query execution. GraphOpt first decomposes the query graph into smaller subgraphs, and then applies a dynamic programming-based approach to identify the optimal execution plan. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that GraphOpt outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time.

title: Designing Inclusive Chatbots: An Investigation of Emotional Support and Empathy in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Chatbots have become increasingly prevalent in various domains, including customer service, healthcare, and education. However, their ability to provide emotional support and empathy remains a significant concern. This study explores the role of emotional intelligence in chatbot design, examining how empathetic responses can improve user experience and trust. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 120 participants, analyzing their interactions with a chatbot designed to provide emotional support. Our results show that empathetic chatbots can significantly increase user satisfaction, reduce feelings of frustration, and enhance perceived emotional support. We provide design recommendations for creating inclusive chatbots that can effectively support users' emotional needs.

title: Exploiting Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Query Optimization in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component in distributed database systems, as it directly impacts query performance and resource utilization. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages knowledge graph embeddings to capture semantic relationships between database entities and optimize query plans. We introduce a graph neural network-based model that encodes database schemata and instance data into a low-dimensional vector space, enabling efficient similarity-based pruning of unnecessary join operations. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed database demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and CPU utilization compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Skeleton-Based Action Recognition
paper_abstract: Skeleton-based action recognition has gained popularity in recent years due to its ability to capture human movements. However, existing methods often fail to effectively model the complex relationships between body joints. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) that learns to focus on relevant joints and their relationships at multiple scales. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets, including NTU-RGBD and Kinetics-Skeleton. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in real-world applications, such as human-computer interaction and healthcare monitoring.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Decision Making
paper_abstract: Explainability is a crucial aspect of AI-driven decision-making systems, as it enables accountability and trust. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to provide transparent and interpretable explanations for AI-driven decisions. Our approach leverages attention weights to identify relevant input features and their contributions to the decision-making process. Experimental results on a real-world credit risk assessment dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in generating accurate and interpretable explanations, outperforming state-of-the-art explainability methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems increasingly rely on AI-driven decision-making, but the lack of transparency hinders trust and reliability. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HiGAT) architecture for explainable multi-agent cooperation. HiGAT integrates graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical reinforcement learning to learn interpretable policies for cooperative tasks. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HiGAT in a simulated multi-robot exploration scenario, achieving improved cooperation and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our approach provides a promising direction for explainable AI in real-world multi-agent applications.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In cooperative multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a decentralized approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to allocate tasks among agents in a distributed manner. Our method, called GNN-TA, represents the agent-task relationships as a graph and learns to predict the optimal task assignments based on agent capabilities, task requirements, and communication constraints. We evaluate GNN-TA on a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate its superiority over traditional centralized and decentralized methods in terms of task completion rate, communication overhead, and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Avatar Customization on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but the impact of avatar customization on user experience remains understudied. This paper investigates how customizing avatars affects user engagement, presence, and cognitive load in VR. We conducted a user study with 60 participants, who completed tasks in a VR environment with either a default or customized avatar. Our results show that customization significantly enhances user experience, particularly for females and gamers. We also found that customization reduces cognitive load, allowing users to focus on the task at hand. Our findings have implications for VR application designers and provide insights into the role of avatar customization in shaping user experience.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but existing systems often neglect the needs of users with disabilities. This paper presents a novel framework for designing embodied conversational agents (ECAs) that facilitate inclusive VR experiences. We develop a set of guidelines for creating ECAs that accommodate users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive impairments. Our approach involves a participatory design process, where users with disabilities co-create ECAs that cater to their specific needs. We evaluate our framework through a user study, demonstrating improved user engagement, satisfaction, and accessibility in VR environments.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms require efficient resource allocation to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'CloudAllocator', that allocates resources based on real-time usage patterns and provider constraints. Each agent learns to optimize its resource allocation policy using a novel hybrid Q-learning and graph neural network approach. Experimental results on a simulated cloud environment demonstrate that CloudAllocator outperforms traditional heuristic-based allocation methods, achieving up to 30% improvement in resource utilization and 25% reduction in request latency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Long-Tailed Classification
paper_abstract: Real-world classification tasks often exhibit long-tailed distributions, where a few dominant classes overshadow the remaining minority classes. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that tackles long-tailed classification by adaptively weighting class attention based on instance similarity. HAN consists of a feature extraction module, a hierarchical attention module, and a classification head. We demonstrate the efficacy of HAN on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational costs by up to 30%. Our approach is particularly effective for classes with limited training data, improving minority class accuracy by up to 15%.

title: Robustness-Aware Neural Architecture Search for Adversarial Defense
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly degrade their performance. This paper proposes a neural architecture search (NAS) framework, 'RobuNAS', that incorporates robustness awareness into the search process. We introduce a novel search objective that minimizes the expected loss under adversarial perturbations, while also considering the model's clean accuracy and computational cost. Experiments on benchmark datasets show that RobuNAS discovers architectures that are more robust to various types of attacks, outperforming state-of-the-art models trained with adversarial training and other defense mechanisms.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Neuroimaging Analysis
paper_abstract: Multi-modal neuroimaging datasets, combining structural and functional MRI with genetic data, offer a richer understanding of brain function and disease. However, existing analysis methods struggle to integrate these heterogeneous data types. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that models complex relationships between brain regions, genetic markers, and imaging features. HGAT leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant features and modalities, enabling the discovery of nuanced patterns and correlations. Our experiments on the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in predicting disease progression and identifying key biomarkers.

title: Optimizing Subquery Processing in Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular for large-scale data storage and querying. However, optimizing subquery processing in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize subquery execution plans. We design a rewards function that takes into account both query latency and resource utilization, and demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional rule-based and cost-based optimizers in terms of query performance and resource efficiency. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that our approach reduces average query latency by up to 35% and improves resource utilization by up to 25%.

title: Exploiting Query Reformulation Patterns for Enhanced Search Result Diversification
paper_abstract: Search result diversification is crucial for providing users with a comprehensive view of relevant information. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages query reformulation patterns to enhance search result diversification. We propose a probabilistic model that captures the relationships between query reformulations and their corresponding search results. Our approach is based on a graph-based ranking framework that incorporates both relevance and diversity metrics. Experimental results on a large-scale web search dataset demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art diversification techniques, leading to a significant improvement in search result novelty and coverage.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing more inclusive voice assistants for this population. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults, caregivers, and clinicians to identify key challenges and opportunities. Our findings inform the development of 'EASE', a novel voice assistant framework that incorporates adaptive dialog management, multimodal input support, and personalized cognitive assistance. We evaluate EASE through a usability study with 20 older adults, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Emotional State Recognition using Multimodal Fusion of Physiological and Facial Features
paper_abstract: Accurate recognition of human emotional states is crucial for developing empathetic human-computer interfaces. This paper presents a novel multimodal approach that combines physiological signals (heart rate, skin conductance) with facial features (facial action units, facial landmarks) to recognize emotional states. We propose a deep fusion framework that exploits the complementary strengths of each modality, resulting in improved recognition accuracy and robustness to noisy or incomplete data. Our experiments on a large, diverse dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in recognizing seven basic emotions, outperforming state-of-the-art unimodal and multimodal baselines.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) to learn effective assignment strategies. Our approach represents the agent-task interaction as a graph and uses GCNs to incorporate local and global information. We develop a distributed algorithm that enables agents to share knowledge and adapt to dynamic task requirements. Experimental results on a simulated rescue scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained significance in recent years, but existing approaches often rely on complex models that lack transparency. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates visual, textual, and acoustic features for sentiment analysis. Our HAN model employs a self-attention mechanism to identify relevant features and modalities, providing interpretable results. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and F1-score, while offering insights into the decision-making process.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Robust Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph analysis, but existing methods often struggle with noisy or incomplete graph structures. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that leverages multi-scale graph representations to improve node classification robustness. Our approach combines node and graph attention mechanisms to adaptively weigh node features and graph structures at different scales. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and robustness to graph perturbations.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Label Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-label classification is a fundamental problem in machine learning, where each instance can be associated with multiple labels. Existing approaches often suffer from high computational complexity and neglect label correlations. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages label hierarchies to improve model efficiency and accuracy. HAN employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant labels and capture label dependencies. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and inference time.

title: earable-based Gesture Recognition using Deep Learning and Sensor Fusion
paper_abstract: We present a novel wearable-based gesture recognition system that leverages the strengths of deep learning and sensor fusion. Our approach combines data from multiple sensors, including accelerometers, gyroscopes, and electromyography, to recognize a range of hand and finger gestures. We propose a multi-modal fusion architecture that integrates convolutional neural networks and recurrent neural networks to capture both spatial and temporal patterns in the sensor data. Experimental results demonstrate an average recognition accuracy of 95.2% across 12 different gestures, outperforming state-of-the-art approaches that rely on individual sensors or modalities.

title: Autonomous Agent Navigation in Dynamic Environments using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous agent navigation in dynamic environments using reinforcement learning. We propose a deep Q-network-based algorithm that enables agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions, such as moving obstacles or changing terrain, in real-time. Our approach leverages a combination of visual and sensorimotor inputs to learn a robust policy for navigation, and we demonstrate its effectiveness in a variety of simulated and real-world scenarios. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms traditional planning-based methods in terms of navigation efficiency and safety.

title: EyeTracking-based Adaptive Difficulty Adjustment for Intelligent Tutoring Systems
paper_abstract: Intelligent tutoring systems (ITS) aim to provide personalized learning experiences, but often struggle to adapt to individual students' needs. This paper proposes an eye-tracking-based approach to dynamically adjust the difficulty of instructional materials in real-time. Our system, 'EyeTutor', utilizes machine learning algorithms to analyze pupil dilation, fixation duration, and saccade patterns to infer a student's cognitive load and knowledge gaps. We evaluate EyeTutor in a controlled study with 120 students, demonstrating significant improvements in learning outcomes and user engagement compared to traditional, rule-based ITS.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in node classification tasks, but often struggle to capture complex relationships between nodes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN architecture, 'HAGNN', which leverages attention mechanisms at multiple scales to selectively focus on relevant node neighbors. We evaluate HAGNN on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in node classification accuracy compared to state-of-the-art GNN models. Further analysis reveals that HAGNN is particularly effective in handling graphs with heterogeneous node degrees and community structures.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable AI-driven recommendation systems aim to provide personalized suggestions while revealing the underlying decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that integrates graph-based user modeling with attention-based item embedding. HGAT learns to recursively attend to user-item interactions, capturing complex relationships and generating interpretable explanations. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate significant improvements in recommendation accuracy, diversity, and explainability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has created a need for efficient task allocation mechanisms to optimize resource utilization and minimize latency. This paper presents a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning to allocate tasks in IoT networks. Our approach, called 'MARL-TA', uses a decentralized, asynchronous learning strategy to train agent policies that adapt to dynamic network conditions. Experimental results on a simulated IoT network demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion time and network resource utilization.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but current interfaces often neglect the importance of embodied cognition. This paper investigates the role of gesture-based interaction in enhancing cognitive processing and user experience in VR. We designed an immersive VR environment that incorporates gesture recognition and haptic feedback, and conducted a user study to explore its effects on cognitive load, spatial awareness, and user engagement. Results show that gesture-based interaction significantly improves cognitive processing and user experience, suggesting a paradigm shift in VR interaction design.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short or ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'NEQE', which leverages neural embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. We explore the use of contextualized word representations and graph-based methods to generate a set of expanded queries that better match the user's information need. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that NEQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to enhance the lives of older adults, but existing interfaces often neglect their unique needs and abilities. This paper presents a novel, accessibility-focused VR interface design framework tailored to older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 older adults, combining user testing, surveys, and interviews to inform our design. The resulting framework emphasizes simplicity, intuitive navigation, and multimodal feedback. A prototype implementation of the framework was evaluated in a controlled experiment, demonstrating significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates compared to a baseline VR interface.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness against Backdoor Attacks in Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Backdoor attacks on deep neural networks (DNNs) have become a significant concern in machine learning. Existing defense methods often focus on detecting and removing backdoors, but these approaches can be evaded by sophisticated attackers. We propose a novel adversarial training framework, 'BackdoorGuard', which proactively injects artificial backdoors into the training data to enhance the model's robustness against such attacks. Our experiments demonstrate that BackdoorGuard significantly improves the resilience of DNNs to backdoor attacks, outperforming state-of-the-art defense methods in various scenarios.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Conversational agents are becoming increasingly prevalent in various applications, but accurately recognizing user emotions remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework that leverages multi-modal input (text, audio, and video) to improve emotion recognition. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant modalities and utterance segments, enabling more accurate emotion detection. Experimental results on a large-scale conversational dataset demonstrate that our HAN framework outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods, achieving an F1-score of 92.1% on the emotion recognition task.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Adaptive Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework using adaptive multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our approach, called Adaptive Task Allocation via Reinforcement Learning (ATAR), enables agents to learn from experience and adapt to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. We introduce a decentralized, asynchronous learning algorithm that allows agents to share knowledge and coordinate actions in real-time. Experimental results on a simulated logistics domain demonstrate that ATAR outperforms traditional task allocation methods in terms of task completion time, resource utilization, and adaptability to unexpected events.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Agents for Visually Impaired Users
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have become increasingly prevalent in various aspects of life, but their accessibility for visually impaired users remains a significant concern. This paper presents a novel framework for designing accessible conversational agents that cater to the needs of visually impaired users. Our approach integrates multimodal interaction techniques, including voice, tactile, and gesture-based inputs, to facilitate seamless communication. We evaluate our framework through a user study with 20 visually impaired participants, demonstrating improved usability and user satisfaction compared to existing conversational agents. Our findings provide valuable insights for designing inclusive conversational agents that can be effectively used by visually impaired users.

title: Understanding User Frustration in Voice-Based Virtual Assistants: A Multimodal Analysis
paper_abstract: Virtual voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but user frustration remains a significant obstacle to widespread adoption. This paper presents a multimodal approach to understanding user frustration in voice-based interactions. We collect a dataset of 100 users interacting with a popular virtual assistant, capturing audio, video, and physiological signals. Our analysis reveals that frustration is characterized by distinct patterns of speech, facial expressions, and physiological arousal. We develop a machine learning model that predicts user frustration with high accuracy, and demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving user experience through personalized feedback and error mitigation strategies.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Individuals with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of daily life, but individuals with disabilities often face significant barriers to accessing VR technology. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating accessible VR interfaces that cater to users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive disabilities. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops and usability studies to identify key accessibility challenges and developed a set of design guidelines and recommendations for inclusive VR interface design. Our results show that incorporating accessibility features into VR interfaces can significantly improve user experience and participation for individuals with disabilities.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of dynamically allocating resources to meet fluctuating workload demands. This paper presents a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'CloudOptimizer', that learns to adaptively allocate resources to minimize costs, reduce latency, and improve quality of service. Our approach leverages a novel combination of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and deep Q-networks (DQN) to learn a policy that optimizes resource allocation in complex, dynamic environments. Experimental results on a real-world cloud dataset demonstrate that CloudOptimizer outperforms traditional rule-based approaches and achieves significant cost savings and performance improvements.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Query Optimization in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial task in distributed databases, where the goal is to minimize query execution time and resource utilization. Traditional methods rely on heuristics and rule-based systems, which often fail to adapt to dynamic workloads. This paper proposes a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) framework, 'QueryOpt', that learns to optimize query plans in distributed databases. Our approach leverages a novel combination of graph neural networks and Deep Q-Networks to model the query optimization problem. Experimental results on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that QueryOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 40% in query execution time and 25% in resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-robot interaction, enabling robots to respond empathetically to users. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multimodal features from speech, text, and facial expressions to recognize emotions in real-time. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention layers that adaptively weigh feature importance, followed by a hierarchical fusion layer that captures inter-modal relationships. Experimental results on the SEMAINE dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in emotion recognition, achieving an average F1-score of 0.85. We also conduct a user study to validate the effectiveness of our system in a real-world human-robot interaction scenario.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Query Expansion on Deep Learning-based Retrieval Models for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Deep learning-based retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in ad-hoc search tasks. However, the role of query expansion in these models remains understudied. This paper investigates the effect of different query expansion techniques on the performance of BERT-based retrieval models. Our experiments on the TREC-2004 dataset show that a carefully designed query expansion strategy can improve the retrieval performance by up to 15%. We also analyze the limitations of existing query expansion methods and propose a novel approach that incorporates semantic role labeling to better capture the context of the query.

title: Latent Semantic Analysis for Improved Query Expansion in Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, where the goal is to reformulate the user's query to better capture their information need. This paper introduces a novel latent semantic analysis (LSA) approach for query expansion, which leverages word embeddings and semantic role labeling to identify context-dependent relationships between query terms. We propose a generative model that learns to predict plausible expansion terms based on the query context, and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness over state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for real-time traffic signal control. Our approach, dubbed 'Traffic Harmony', leverages a decentralized actor-critic architecture to optimize signal timing across multiple intersections. By incorporating domain knowledge of traffic flow dynamics into the policy learning process, we demonstrate substantial reductions in congestion and travel times compared to traditional fixed-time control strategies. We evaluate Traffic Harmony on a realistic simulation of the Pittsburgh city network, showcasing its potential for large-scale deployment.

title: Efficient Bayesian Neural Network Pruning via Hierarchical Masking
paper_abstract: Bayesian neural networks (BNNs) offer a promising approach to modeling uncertainty in deep learning, but their high computational cost hinders their adoption in real-world applications. This paper presents a novel pruning method for BNNs, leveraging hierarchical masking to identify and remove redundant weights. Our approach exploits the inherent structure of BNNs to efficiently prune entire sub-networks, resulting in significant reductions in computational cost and memory usage. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of accuracy and uncertainty estimation while maintaining a drastic reduction in model size.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Speech Disorders
paper_abstract: Individuals with speech disorders, such as apraxia or dysarthria, often face challenges when interacting with voice-based interfaces. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive voice-based interfaces that can accommodate diverse speech patterns. We propose a hybrid approach combining machine learning-based speech recognition with rule-based language processing to improve recognition accuracy for individuals with speech disorders.
