Our user study with 20 participants shows that our approach achieves a 35% reduction in error rate compared to commercial speech recognition systems, leading to improved user experience and accessibility.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Coordination
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, explaining the decision-making process of individual agents is crucial for trust and accountability. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that learns to coordinate agents while providing interpretable explanations. HGAT leverages hierarchical graph attention to model complex agent interactions and incorporates a novel explainability module that generates saliency maps highlighting influential agents and their relationships. Our experiments on a real-world traffic management dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both coordination efficiency and explanation quality.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Learning Environments
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent in educational settings, it is essential to investigate factors that influence user engagement. This study explores the effect of personalized avatars on learner motivation and self-efficacy in VR-based learning environments. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment involving 120 participants, who interacted with either a generic or personalized avatar in a VR simulation. Results show that users who interacted with personalized avatars reported higher levels of engagement, enjoyment, and perceived learning gains compared to those using generic avatars. Furthermore, thematic analysis of user feedback revealed that personalized avatars enhanced users' sense of presence and agency in the virtual environment.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Industrial Settings
paper_abstract: As robots are increasingly integrated into industrial workflows, understanding the role of embodiment in human-robot collaboration is crucial. This study investigates how the physical presence of a robot, as opposed to a virtual or screen-based interface, influences human trust, communication, and task performance. We conducted a series of user studies in a simulated industrial setting, comparing human-robot collaboration with embodied and non-embodied robots. Our results show that embodied robots lead to higher trust and improved communication, but also introduce new challenges related to spatial awareness and navigation. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future human-robot collaboration systems.

title: Reinforcing Query Expansion with Graph Attention for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to suboptimal retrieval results. Query expansion (QE) techniques can mitigate this issue, but existing methods rely on simplistic term weighting schemes. This paper proposes a novel QE approach, GraphAttention-QE, which leverages graph attention networks to model complex relationships between query terms and their contextual neighbors. Our method learns to focus on the most informative terms and their interactions, resulting in more effective query representations. Experimental evaluations on several TREC datasets demonstrate that GraphAttention-QE outperforms state-of-the-art QE techniques, leading to significant improvements in retrieval performance.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Users with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces, such as voice assistants and chatbots, are increasingly prevalent, but their interfaces often neglect the needs of users with dyslexia. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create accessible conversational interfaces for users with dyslexia. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with dyslexic users, identifying key challenges and preferences. Our proposed design framework, 'DyslexiaAwareCI', incorporates features such as phonetic-based error correction, personalized text summarization, and adaptive font sizes. A usability study with 20 dyslexic participants demonstrates that DyslexiaAwareCI significantly improves conversational interface usability and user experience.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Neural Networks via Hierarchical Mutual Information
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can be attributed to their limited robustness to input perturbations. This paper proposes a novel defense strategy based on hierarchical mutual information (HMI) to improve the robustness of DNNs. Our approach leverages the HMI metric to quantify the information flow between different layers of the network, allowing us to identify and regularize the most vulnerable components. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method significantly enhances the robustness of DNNs against various types of adversarial attacks, while maintaining their accuracy on clean data.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis tasks often involve processing heterogeneous data from multiple sources, such as text, images, and audio. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture that effectively integrates and leverages the strengths of multi-modal data. HGAN employs a hierarchical graph structure to model complex relationships between modalities, and attention mechanisms to selectively weight features from each modality. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in sentiment analysis tasks, particularly in scenarios with noisy or missing data.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed Information Retrieval (DIR) systems face significant scalability challenges when processing complex queries. This paper presents a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that reduces the dimensionality of query vectors while preserving semantic meaning. Our HQE method leverages a multi-layered neural network to learn hierarchical representations of query terms, enabling efficient document retrieval in large-scale DIR systems. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HQE outperforms existing query expansion techniques in terms of precision, recall, and query processing time.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of decentralized task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and preferences need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a novel approach based on deep reinforcement learning, where each agent learns to optimize its task allocation policy using a decentralized, asynchronous actor-critic framework. Our algorithm, called 'Dec-TAR', leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and achieves state-of-the-art performance in a variety of benchmark scenarios. We demonstrate the effectiveness of Dec-TAR in a simulated disaster response scenario, where agents need to coordinate to rescue victims and allocate resources.

title: Hierarchical Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Real-World Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Explainability is a crucial aspect of trustworthy AI, particularly in safety-critical autonomous systems. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HERO', which integrates model-based and model-free approaches to provide interpretable decision-making. HERO learns to decompose complex tasks into sub-goals, allowing for both global and local explanations of the agent's behavior. We demonstrate the efficacy of HERO in a real-world autonomous driving scenario, showcasing improved transparency and performance compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking Models for Conversational Search with Multi-Task Learning
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems require efficient ranking models that can effectively leverage context and user feedback. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking framework, 'ConvRank', which integrates multi-task learning to jointly optimize relevance, coherence, and user engagement. We design a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures contextual dependencies and user preferences, while a shared knowledge encoder facilitates knowledge sharing across tasks. Experiments on a large-scale conversational search dataset demonstrate that ConvRank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models in terms of nDCG, MRR, and user satisfaction metrics.

title: Efficient Indexing for Trajectory Data in Road Networks
paper_abstract: The increasing availability of trajectory data from various sources such as GPS, mobile devices, and sensors has created new opportunities for transportation and urban planning applications. However, indexing and querying trajectory data in road networks remain challenging due to their complex spatial and temporal relationships. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, TrajR-Tree, which leverages the road network topology to efficiently store and retrieve trajectory data. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that TrajR-Tree outperforms existing indexing methods in terms of query performance and storage efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Hierarchical Semantic Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of information retrieval systems, aiming to improve the retrieval accuracy by generating relevant expansion terms. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, termed 'HierExpan', which leverages hierarchical semantic embeddings to capture the nuanced relationships between query terms and expansion candidates. By modeling the semantic hierarchy of terms using a graph-based neural network, HierExpan generates a set of diverse and relevant expansion terms, leading to significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HierExpan over state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to coordinated task allocation for heterogeneous multi-agent systems using graph neural networks (GNNs). Our method, called Graph-based Task Allocation (GTA), leverages the expressive power of GNNs to learn effective task assignments in complex, dynamic environments. We introduce a hierarchical graph representation that captures both inter-agent dependencies and task-specific requirements, and develop a variant of the attention mechanism to facilitate efficient graph-based reasoning. Experimental results on a range of benchmark scenarios demonstrate the superiority of GTA over state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion efficiency, fairness, and robustness.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Density-based Clustering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems require efficient passage retrieval to reduce the search space for answer extraction. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical density-based clustering approach, called 'HDCluster', to index and retrieve relevant passages from a large corpus. HDCluster adaptively groups passages into clusters based on their semantic similarity, enabling fast and accurate retrieval of top-k passages. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HDCluster outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval methods, achieving a 25% improvement in mean average precision and a 3x speedup in retrieval time.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Feature Fusion in Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Multi-modal fusion of visual and textual features has become a crucial task in various computer vision applications. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that efficiently fuses features from different modalities. Our approach leverages self-attention mechanisms to capture intra-modal and inter-modal relationships, enabling the model to selectively focus on relevant features. We evaluate HAN on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in performance and computational efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-Time Time-Series Data in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and real-time data streams poses significant challenges for traditional database indexing techniques. This paper introduces 'TS-Tree', a novel indexing framework for distributed databases that efficiently handles high-volume time-series data. Our approach leverages a combination of hierarchical indexing and chunk-based storage to minimize query latency and optimize storage utilization. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that TS-Tree outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 3x in terms of query response time while maintaining comparable storage efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc information retrieval, but existing methods often rely on hand-crafted rules or simplistic models. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query expansion. Our method, called QERL, learns to select the most informative expansion terms by interacting with a simulated environment that mimics the retrieval process. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that QERL significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision and recall, while reducing the number of redundant expansion terms.

title: Gesture-Based Interface for Individuals with Motor Disabilities using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor disabilities face significant challenges interacting with digital devices. This paper presents a novel gesture-based interface that leverages machine learning to recognize and interpret user intentions. Our approach utilizes a convolutional neural network to classify hand and finger gestures captured by a low-cost, wrist-mounted camera. We evaluate our system with a user study involving 20 participants with motor disabilities, demonstrating an average accuracy of 92.5% in gesture recognition and a significant reduction in interaction time. Our findings suggest that machine learning-driven gesture recognition can greatly enhance the accessibility and usability of digital technologies for individuals with motor disabilities.

title: Robustifying Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks via Hierarchical Feature Importance
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can be detrimental in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel defense mechanism, 'HierFeat', that leverages hierarchical feature importance to robustify DNNs against adversarial attacks. HierFeat assigns importance scores to features at multiple scales, enabling the model to focus on robust features and ignore vulnerable ones. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierFeat on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in terms of adversarial robustness and clean accuracy. Our approach can be easily integrated into existing DNN architectures, providing a practical solution for real-world applications.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases
paper_abstract: As relational databases continue to grow in scale and complexity, query optimization remains a critical performance bottleneck. This paper presents a novel distributed query optimization framework, 'DQOpt', which leverages machine learning and graph-based methods to efficiently optimize queries across a cluster of nodes. DQOpt utilizes a hybrid approach that combines statistical modeling with cost-based optimization to minimize query latency and resource utilization. Experimental results on a large-scale relational database demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of User-Centered Co-Design Methods
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their design often neglects the needs of marginalized user groups, such as individuals with disabilities or non-native language speakers. This paper presents a user-centered co-design approach to create more inclusive voice assistants. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with diverse user groups, resulting in a set of design principles and recommendations for more accessible and usable voice assistants. Our evaluation demonstrates that these design principles improve user satisfaction and task completion rates for marginalized users, highlighting the importance of inclusive design in HCI.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents through Hierarchical Task Decomposition and Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating heterogeneous agents in complex environments is a fundamental challenge in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a novel framework that leverages hierarchical task decomposition and reinforcement learning to enable effective coordination among agents with diverse capabilities and goals. We introduce a hierarchical task graph that captures the relationships between high-level tasks and low-level actions, and a deep reinforcement learning algorithm that learns to allocate tasks to agents based on their strengths and weaknesses. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving global objectives while adapting to dynamic environments and agent failures.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management has emerged as a critical application domain for multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for adaptive traffic signal control. Our approach, 'TrafficMA', leverages graph neural networks to model complex traffic dynamics and enables agents to learn cooperative policies in a distributed manner. We demonstrate the effectiveness of TrafficMA in reducing congestion and improving travel times through extensive simulations on real-world traffic networks.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Graph Databases Using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing complex relationships between data entities. However, query performance remains a significant bottleneck, particularly for large-scale graphs. This paper presents a novel approach to optimizing query performance using learned index structures. We propose a deep learning-based method to predict the optimal index configuration for a given query workload, leveraging graph neural networks to capture structural patterns in the data. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate significant improvements in query response times, outperforming traditional indexing techniques by up to 3x.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising approach for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, existing methods often rely on costly and time-consuming evaluations of candidate architectures. This paper proposes a novel graph-based reinforcement learning framework, 'GraphNAS', which leverages the structural properties of neural networks to guide the search process. By representing architectures as graphs and learning a policy to traverse the graph space, GraphNAS achieves a significant reduction in search time and computational resources while maintaining competitive performance on several benchmark datasets.

title: Gaze-based Intention Recognition for Adaptive User Interfaces in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to intention recognition in virtual reality (VR) environments, leveraging gaze-tracking data to infer user goals and adapt the interface accordingly. We propose a hierarchical Bayesian model that integrates gaze patterns, head movements, and environmental cues to recognize user intentions in real-time. Our approach is evaluated in a VR-based puzzle game, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional, static interfaces. The proposed framework has implications for enhancing user experience and accessibility in VR applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multimodal fusion is a crucial component of Visual Question Answering (VQA) systems, but existing approaches often lack transparency and interpretability. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that integrates visual and textual features through a hierarchical attention mechanism. Our approach enables the model to focus on relevant regions of the image and corresponding question words, providing insight into the decision-making process. Experimental results on the VQA-CP v2 dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of accuracy and achieves better explainability through visualizations of attention weights.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Adaptive Color Schemes on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces often employ static color schemes, which can lead to user fatigue and decreased immersion. This paper investigates the effects of adaptive color schemes on user experience in VR. We propose a novel method, 'ChromaVR', which dynamically adjusts the color palette based on user behavior, gaze tracking, and environmental lighting conditions. A user study with 30 participants reveals that ChromaVR significantly improves user engagement, reduces visual discomfort, and enhances overall VR experience. Our findings have implications for the design of more user-centered and accessible VR systems.

title: Co-Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Experiences for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, it is essential to ensure that older adults with cognitive impairments can fully participate in and benefit from these experiences. This paper presents a co-design approach that involves older adults with cognitive impairments as active participants in the design process. We explore the use of participatory design methods, including contextual inquiry, co-creation workshops, and usability testing, to inform the development of accessible VR experiences. Our findings highlight the importance of simplicity, familiarity, and user control in designing VR interfaces that are intuitive and enjoyable for this population. We also discuss the implications of our research for the development of inclusive VR experiences that can promote social engagement, cognitive stimulation, and overall well-being for older adults.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Robotics with Transfer Learning
paper_abstract: Autonomous robotics requires agents to learn complex tasks in diverse environments. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HIRL-Transfer', that leverages transfer learning to adapt policies across tasks and domains. Our approach combines a high-level task encoder with a low-level motor controller, enabling the agent to transfer knowledge from simulation to real-world scenarios. Experimental results on a robotic arm platform demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced learning times compared to flat reinforcement learning methods.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Hierarchical Neural Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but existing approaches often rely on manual feature engineering or simplistic term weighting schemes. This paper proposes a hierarchical neural query expansion framework, 'HierQE', which learns to jointly model query-document relationships and term correlations. Our approach leverages a novel tree-structured attention mechanism to identify salient query terms and expand them into a hierarchical representation. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper proposes a novel auction-based mechanism, 'MASA', that enables agents to bid for tasks based on their capabilities and preferences. We introduce a novel bidding strategy that incorporates uncertainty and risk-aversion, leading to improved task allocation efficiency and fairness. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that MASA outperforms existing decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of task completion rate and agent satisfaction.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Multimodal Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Multimodal information retrieval (MMIR) systems struggle to effectively capture the semantic relationships between textual and visual features in queries. We propose a context-aware query expansion framework, CAQE, which leverages multimodal attention mechanisms to identify relevant contextual information. CAQE dynamically adapts to the query's semantic scope, enabling the incorporation of relevant visual and textual features to improve retrieval accuracy. Our experiments on a multimodal dataset show significant improvements in mean average precision and retrieval efficiency compared to state-of-the-art MMIR methods.

title: Coordinated Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Time-Dependent Rewards
paper_abstract: In many real-world applications, tasks need to be allocated to agents with varying capabilities and rewards that change over time. This paper proposes a novel decentralized task allocation algorithm, 'Tempo', which leverages a hybrid approach combining graph-based and reinforcement learning techniques. Tempo adapts to dynamic task rewards and agent capabilities, ensuring efficient and scalable coordination among agents. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that Tempo outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate and reward accumulation.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems by leveraging hierarchical graph attention networks (HGATs). Our proposed framework, 'CoorHGAT', enables agents to learn complex coordination strategies by aggregating information from neighboring agents and higher-level graph structures. We demonstrate the efficacy of CoorHGAT in a series of experiments involving decentralized traffic control and resource allocation problems, showcasing improved performance and scalability compared to existing methods. Theoretical analysis and ablation studies provide insights into the benefits of hierarchical graph attention in multi-agent coordination.

title: Optimizing Query Processing in Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial step in achieving efficient query processing in distributed database systems. Existing approaches rely on heuristics, rule-based systems, or statistical models, which may not adapt well to changing workloads and data distributions. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning-based approach, 'RL-QOPT', that learns to optimize query plans based on feedback from the database system. We design a reward function that balances query execution time, resource utilization, and data freshness. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that RL-QOPT outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Proximity-Aware Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for information retrieval often rely on computationally expensive pairwise comparison of documents. This paper presents a novel proximity-aware neural ranking model, 'ProxRank', which exploits the spatial proximity of documents in the latent space to reduce the number of required comparisons. By incorporating a proximity-aware attention mechanism and a hierarchical ranking strategy, ProxRank achieves significant speedups over existing methods while maintaining competitive retrieval performance on benchmark datasets. Our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of ProxRank in various retrieval scenarios, including ad-hoc retrieval and diversity-aware retrieval.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, optimizing queries on these systems remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of graph data and the distributed nature of the system. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages a combination of graph clustering, subquery decomposition, and adaptive join ordering to minimize query execution time. We evaluate GraphOpt on a real-world graph dataset and demonstrate significant performance improvements compared to existing query optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of relational database systems, as it directly impacts query performance and resource utilization. With the increasing popularity of distributed databases, the complexity of query optimization has grown significantly. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We design a DRL agent that learns to optimize queries by interacting with a distributed database environment, leveraging techniques from graph theory and probabilistic modeling. Experimental results on a realistic distributed database benchmark demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Column-Oriented Database Systems
paper_abstract: Column-oriented database systems have gained popularity in recent years due to their ability to efficiently process analytical workloads. However, query optimization in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages statistical models and machine learning techniques to predict optimal query plans. We introduce a cost-based optimization algorithm that takes into account the columnar storage layout and the query workload characteristics. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that ColOpt outperforms existing query optimizers in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in multi-modal sentiment analysis tasks, but their lack of transparency hinders their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that incorporates explainability mechanisms into the model architecture. Our HAN model learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and regions of interest, providing interpretable visualizations of the decision-making process. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal sentiment dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving improved performance and explainability over existing methods.

title: Hierarchical Few-Shot Learning with Self-Supervised Metric Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years, particularly in scenarios where labeled data is scarce. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical few-shot learning framework that leverages self-supervised metric learning to learn a robust feature representation. Our approach, dubbed 'HFS-SSL', learns a hierarchical representation by iteratively refining the feature space using episodic training. We demonstrate the efficacy of HFS-SSL on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance on mini-ImageNet and tiered-ImageNet. Our analysis reveals that the self-supervised metric learning component is crucial in adapting to new classes and improving overall model robustness.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Neural Networks for Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve the most relevant passage from a document given a query. While traditional methods rely on hand-crafted features and ranking models, we propose a deep neural network-based approach that learns to rank passages end-to-end. Our model, called PassageRank, employs a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural layers to capture both local and global contextual information in the passage. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that PassageRank outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Towards Efficient Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a critical problem in multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities must collaborate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning approach, 'TASKER', which learns to allocate tasks efficiently by modeling agent interactions and task dependencies. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to represent agent relationships and task graphs, and uses a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework to optimize task allocation. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation benchmarks demonstrate that TASKER outperforms existing approaches in terms of task completion time and agent utilization.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Contextualized Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, as it aims to reformulate the original query to better capture user intent. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach using deep contextualized embeddings, which leverages pre-trained language models to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms. Our method, called 'ConEx', generates a set of expanded queries by iteratively refining the original query based on the contextualized embeddings of its constituent terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ConEx significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving a 12% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has created a need for efficient task allocation mechanisms in decentralized networks. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARL-IoT', which enables autonomous task allocation in IoT networks. MARL-IoT utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on its local observations and communicates with neighboring agents to achieve global optimality. We evaluate MARL-IoT on a simulated IoT network and demonstrate improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing gesture-based interfaces that are accessible and usable by older adults with motor impairments. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 20 participants with varying levels of motor impairment, using a custom-built gesture recognition system. Our results show that a combination of machine learning-based gesture recognition and adaptive feedback mechanisms can significantly improve interaction accuracy and user satisfaction. We also identify key design recommendations for inclusive gesture-based interfaces, including the use of compensatory gestures and personalized feedback schemes.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multidimensional Data using GPU-Accelerated Indexing
paper_abstract: Multidimensional indexing is a crucial technique for efficient query processing in modern databases. However, existing indexing methods often struggle with high-dimensional data, leading to poor query performance. This paper proposes a novel GPU-accelerated indexing approach, 'GIDX', which leverages the parallel processing capabilities of modern graphics processing units (GPUs). Our approach uses a hybrid indexing scheme that combines a CPU-based filter with a GPU-accelerated refinement step, achieving significant speedups over traditional indexing methods. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that GIDX outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 5x for high-dimensional range queries.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-Driven Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: As AI systems increasingly influence decision-making, the need for explainable AI (XAI) has become paramount. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for sentiment analysis, which provides interpretable insights into the decision-making process. Our approach leverages both word-level and sentence-level attention to identify key phrases and sentences contributing to the sentiment classification. We evaluate our model on benchmark datasets and demonstrate improved accuracy and explainability compared to state-of-the-art XAI methods. The proposed HAN framework has far-reaching implications for trustworthy AI applications in customer service, marketing, and healthcare.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user engagement in virtual reality (VR) based learning environments. We designed and implemented a VR-based educational platform that utilizes machine learning-driven avatar personalization. Our user study involved 100 participants who interacted with either a personalized or non-personalized avatar in a VR learning scenario. Results show that users who interacted with personalized avatars demonstrated higher levels of engagement, motivation, and knowledge retention compared to those who interacted with non-personalized avatars. Our findings have implications for the design of VR-based learning systems and highlight the potential of personalized avatars in improving learning outcomes.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Query Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion is a widely used technique to improve retrieval performance. However, existing query expansion methods rely on manual feature engineering and may not capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a neural query embedding-based approach for query expansion, which learns to represent queries and documents in a shared semantic space. Our approach, termed NeuroXPand, leverages a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize query embedding and document ranking. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance over state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reasoning
paper_abstract: Real-world multi-agent systems often exhibit complex relationships and interactions. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel framework for explainable multi-agent reasoning. HGAT leverages hierarchical graph attention mechanisms to capture agent relationships at multiple scales, enabling the model to reason about both local and global interactions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in a real-world traffic scenario, showing significant improvements in prediction accuracy and interpretability compared to existing methods. Our approach has potential applications in various domains, including autonomous vehicles, smart cities, and social network analysis.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Vision Transformers against Real-World Attacks
paper_abstract: Vision Transformers (ViTs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various computer vision tasks. However, their robustness against real-world attacks remains under-explored. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of ViTs against a range of real-world attacks, including physical-world attacks, such as stickers, graffiti, and print-then-digitize attacks. We demonstrate that ViTs are vulnerable to these attacks, achieving accuracy drops of up to 30%. Furthermore, we propose a novel adversarial training method that incorporates real-world attack simulations, resulting in improved robustness against these attacks without compromising clean accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Large-Scale Document Collections
paper_abstract: Large-scale document retrieval systems often suffer from vocabulary mismatch between queries and documents, leading to poor retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural query expansion approach, HierNet, which leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively expand query terms based on their semantic importance. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierNet achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion methods. Furthermore, we show that HierNet can be effectively integrated with existing retrieval models, leading to further performance gains.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Evolutionary Game Theory
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel distributed task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, inspired by evolutionary game theory. Our approach, called EVO-MAS, models the task allocation problem as a repeated game between agents, where each agent learns to adapt its strategy to maximize its payoff. We introduce a new genetic algorithm-based mechanism to evolve the agents' strategies, which converges to a Nash equilibrium. Experimental results on a simulated robotics scenario demonstrate that EVO-MAS outperforms traditional auction-based methods in terms of task completion rate and system efficiency.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Traffic Management with Real-Time Adaptation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized, multi-agent system for real-time traffic management in urban environments. Our approach leverages autonomous agents to dynamically optimize traffic signal control, taking into account real-time traffic conditions, pedestrian, and cyclist activity. We propose a novel agent communication protocol that enables efficient information sharing and adapts to changing traffic patterns. Experimental results using real-world traffic data demonstrate that our approach reduces congestion, decreases travel times, and improves overall traffic flow by up to 25% compared to traditional, static traffic management systems.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Hierarchical Graph-based Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to handle complex queries, leading to suboptimal results. We propose a novel query expansion approach, 'HGEQE', which leverages hierarchical graph-based embeddings to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms. By recursively applying a graph attention mechanism, HGEQE identifies relevant expansion terms and weights them according to their importance. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval benchmark show that HGEQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 12.5% increase in mean average precision.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding human-robot collaboration in these environments is crucial. This study explores the effect of embodiment on human trust, communication, and task performance in VR-based human-robot collaboration. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, using a custom-built VR platform and a robotic arm. Our results show that embodied robots, which mimic human-like movements, lead to higher trust and better task performance compared to non-embodied robots. Furthermore, our findings suggest that the level of embodiment significantly influences the type and frequency of communication between humans and robots.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, but existing methods often rely on handcrafted rules or simplistic machine learning models. This paper proposes a novel QE approach, 'RL-QE', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize the expansion process. By formulating QE as a Markov decision process, our model learns to select the most informative expansion terms and adapt to varying query contexts. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Real-time Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. We propose a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to allocate tasks in real-time, taking into account the dynamic capabilities and availability of agents. Our method, called 'AgentDRL', uses a decentralized actor-critic framework to learn optimal task allocation policies. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that AgentDRL outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time and agent utilization, while adapting to changes in the environment and agent availability.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems have become ubiquitous in various applications, but their opacity hinders user trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that generates personalized recommendations while providing explicit explanations. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex item relationships and captures hierarchical representations of user preferences. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Design Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in many households, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a participatory design approach to create an inclusive voice assistant tailored to the requirements of older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with 20 older adults to identify their needs, preferences, and challenges when interacting with voice assistants. Our findings highlight the importance of clear and concise voice output, visual feedback, and customizable command structures. We developed a prototype incorporating these design principles and evaluated it with 15 older adults, resulting in significant improvements in user satisfaction and task completion rates.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Cloud-Native Database Systems using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Cloud-native database systems face significant performance challenges due to the shift towards distributed, scale-out architectures. Traditional indexing techniques often fall short in these environments, leading to suboptimal query performance. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages learned index structures to optimize query execution in cloud-native databases. By integrating machine learning models into the indexing layer, we demonstrate significant improvements in query latency and throughput. Our experiments on a real-world cloud database benchmark show that learned index structures can reduce query execution time by up to 3.5x compared to traditional indexing techniques.

title: Query Optimization for Real-time Data Warehousing using Column Stores and Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a crucial component of modern business intelligence. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge, particularly when dealing with large-scale column-store databases. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'RTOpt', which leverages machine learning to predict query execution times and optimize query plans in real-time. We demonstrate that RTOpt achieves significant performance improvements over traditional optimization techniques, with an average reduction of 35% in query latency on a benchmark dataset.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Improving Ad-hoc Retrieval in Domain-Specific Search
paper_abstract: Domain-specific search engines often struggle with ad-hoc queries that contain ambiguous or domain-specific terminology. This paper proposes a neural query expansion approach, 'NQE-DSS', which leverages a combination of word embeddings and domain knowledge graphs to generate more effective query representations. Our experiments on a large-scale dataset of biomedical queries show that NQE-DSS significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, resulting in a 23% increase in mean average precision and a 17% increase in mean reciprocal rank.

title: Hierarchical Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Self-Supervised Pre-Training
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, particularly when faced with limited labeled data. This paper proposes a hierarchical meta-learning approach, 'HierMeta', that leverages self-supervised pre-training to improve adaptability to new classes. We introduce a novel hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant task-specific features, while also utilizing contrastive self-supervised learning to enhance feature representations. Experimental results on benchmark datasets show that HierMeta outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot classification methods, achieving significant improvements in accuracy and robustness.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Zero-Shot Image Classification
paper_abstract: Zero-shot image classification (ZSIC) aims to recognize unseen classes without any labeled examples. Existing approaches rely on fixed, pre-defined class embeddings or complex generative models. We propose Hierarchical Contrastive Learning (HCL), a novel framework that learns a hierarchical representation space for ZSIC. HCL leverages contrastive learning to align seen and unseen class embeddings, and introduces a hierarchical clustering module to adaptively group semantically similar classes. Our experiments on the ImageNet-21K and COCO datasets demonstrate that HCL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in ZSIC, achieving significant improvements in accuracy and robustness.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Diverse Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, as it can significantly impact the relevance and diversity of retrieved documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'RL-EXPAND', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize the trade-off between relevance and diversity. We model the query expansion process as a Markov decision process and employ a deep Q-network to learn the optimal expansion strategy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-EXPAND outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and novelty metrics, while reducing the computational cost of query expansion.

title: Real-time Human Gesture Recognition using Graph Convolutional Networks and Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Human-computer interaction has seen significant advancements with the advent of gesture recognition. This paper presents a novel approach to real-time gesture recognition using graph convolutional networks (GCNs) and reinforcement learning. Our method, 'GesRec', represents gestures as graphs, leveraging spatial and temporal dependencies between joints. We introduce a reinforcement learning framework that optimizes GCN hyperparameters in real-time, adapting to varying user gestures and environments. Experimental results on a large-scale gesture dataset demonstrate GesRec's superiority in accuracy and latency compared to state-of-the-art methods, with applications in virtual reality, gaming, and healthcare.

title: Adaptive Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that significantly affects overall system performance. This paper proposes a novel adaptive task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments in dynamic environments. Our approach, called 'ATA-RL', uses a decentralized actor-critic architecture to learn agent-specific task preferences and adapt to changes in agent availability, task priority, and environmental conditions. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse management scenario demonstrate that ATA-RL outperforms traditional rule-based and optimization-based approaches in terms of task completion rate, agent utilization, and system responsiveness.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but the role of embodiment in shaping user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study examining the effects of embodiment on user presence, engagement, and cognitive load in VR. We designed and implemented an immersive VR environment that simulates real-world tasks, and conducted a within-subjects experiment with 30 participants. Results show that embodied interactions significantly enhance user presence and engagement, while reducing cognitive load. Furthermore, our qualitative analysis reveals that users' sense of embodiment influences their perception of agency and control in VR. Implications for the design of embodied VR experiences are discussed.

title: Hierarchical Attention for Explainable Deep Reinforcement Learning in Robotics
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in robotics, but its lack of interpretability hinders trust and adoptability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention mechanism, 'HierAttn', which selectively focuses on relevant state and action features to improve DRL explainability. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierAttn on a robotic arm grasping task, where it outperforms state-of-the-art DRL methods in terms of both performance and interpretability. Furthermore, we provide visualizations and feature importance analysis to illustrate the attention mechanism's decision-making process.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Distributed Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents, leveraging distributed reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize task assignments in dynamic environments. Our approach, called 'AgentDRL', enables agents to learn from local interactions and communicate with each other to achieve global optimality. We propose a novel DRL algorithm that incorporates graph neural networks to model agent relationships and a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture to balance exploration and exploitation. Experiments on a simulated multi-agent system demonstrate the effectiveness of AgentDRL in adapting to changing task requirements and outperforming traditional centralized task allocation methods.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Agents for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments. However, existing systems often fail to account for the unique needs and challenges of this population. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for developing accessible conversational agents that accommodate cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and caregivers to identify key design requirements, including simplified language processing, error tolerance, and personalized feedback mechanisms. Our prototype, 'CAREbot', was evaluated in a usability study with 20 older adults, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to a baseline agent.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework using multi-agent reinforcement learning. We consider a scenario where a team of agents must allocate tasks to maximize overall team performance, while communicating only with their local neighbors. We introduce a novel algorithm, 'MADRAL', which combines decentralized actor-critic methods with graph neural networks to learn task allocation policies. Experimental results in a simulated robotic search and rescue domain demonstrate that MADRAL outperforms existing decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of team performance and adaptability to changing task requirements.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Multimodal Approach to Mitigating Cognitive Biases
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their interfaces can perpetuate cognitive biases and exacerbate social inequalities. This paper presents a novel, multimodal framework for designing inclusive voice assistants that mitigate biases in speech recognition, natural language understanding, and response generation. We introduce a contextualized embedding approach that incorporates user demographics, language proficiency, and cultural background to adapt the assistant's behavior and language. A user study with 120 participants demonstrates significant reductions in biased responses and improved user satisfaction, particularly among underrepresented groups.

title: Deep Neural Networks for Anomaly Detection in Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in many applications, including finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. This paper proposes a novel deep learning approach, 'TS-Anomaly', which leverages the strengths of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks. TS-Anomaly uses a hierarchical architecture to capture both local and global patterns in time series data, enabling the detection of anomalies with high accuracy. We evaluate TS-Anomaly on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to accurately capture user intent, resulting in suboptimal query representations. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic query expansions. Our architecture combines a transformer-based query encoder with a dense passage retrieval module, enabling the model to identify relevant terms and phrases in the document collection. Experimental results on the TREC-8 and Robust04 datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Task Dialogue Management
paper_abstract: Multi-task dialogue management has become a crucial component of conversational AI systems. However, existing approaches often rely on black-box models, hindering transparency and interpretability. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that jointly learns multiple dialogue tasks while providing explainable results. Our HAN model employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant contextual information, enabling the generation of task-specific explanations. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of task performance while offering insights into the decision-making process.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become a cornerstone of modern data management, but optimizing query performance remains a complex challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'RL-Opt', which leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query execution plans in DDS. We design an RL agent that learns to select optimal plans by interacting with the database environment and receiving rewards based on query execution times. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that RL-Opt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving up to 30% reduction in query latency and 25% improvement in throughput.

title: Meta-Learning for Efficient Zero-Shot Learning in Real-World Image Classification
paper_abstract: Zero-shot learning (ZSL) enables models to recognize unseen classes without additional training data. However, existing ZSL methods often rely on auxiliary datasets or complex optimization procedures, limiting their applicability to real-world scenarios. This paper presents a meta-learning framework, 'MetaZSL', which tackles ZSL by learning to adapt to new classes from a few exemplar images. Our approach leverages a novel task-aware attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant feature dimensions, resulting in improved generalization to unseen classes. Experiments on popular image classification benchmarks demonstrate that MetaZSL outperforms state-of-the-art ZSL methods while requiring minimal additional computational resources.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Satisfaction
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require efficient task allocation to achieve common goals. We present a novel decentralized approach that leverages distributed constraint satisfaction (DisCSP) to allocate tasks in a flexible and scalable manner. Our algorithm, called D-MAP, enables agents to locally solve constraint satisfaction problems, reducing communication overhead and improving overall system performance. Experimental evaluations on a variety of multi-agent domains demonstrate that D-MAP outperforms existing decentralized task allocation methods, achieving up to 30% improvement in task completion rate and 25% reduction in communication costs.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Multi-Modal Event Extraction
paper_abstract: Event extraction from multi-modal data (e.g., text, images, videos) is a challenging task due to the complexity of capturing cross-modal relationships. This paper introduces HAGNet, a hierarchical attention graph neural network that jointly learns intra-modal and inter-modal representations. Our approach leverages self-attention mechanisms to model node interactions within each modality and across modalities. Experimental results on a large-scale event extraction benchmark demonstrate that HAGNet outperforms state-of-the-art methods by a significant margin, achieving an F1-score improvement of 12.5% on average.

title: Hierarchical Document Clustering using Deep Semantic Representations
paper_abstract: Document clustering is a fundamental task in Information Retrieval (IR) that enables efficient organization and retrieval of large document collections. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document clustering approach, 'DeepSemClus', which leverages deep semantic representations learned from pre-trained language models. Our method first extracts dense, contextualized embeddings for each document using a fine-tuned BERT model. Then, we employ a hierarchical agglomerative clustering algorithm to group documents based on their semantic similarity. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepSemClus outperforms state-of-the-art clustering methods, achieving higher purity and F1-scores. We also show that our approach is robust to varying cluster densities and noise levels.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for autonomous traffic signal control. We propose a novel communication protocol that enables agents to share local information and coordinate their actions in real-time. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model the complex interactions between agents and the dynamic traffic environment. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate improved traffic flow and reduced congestion compared to traditional, centralized control methods. We also analyze the robustness of our approach to varying agent densities and communication delays.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient control strategies to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for autonomous vehicle control, which decomposes the control problem into a hierarchy of tasks. Our approach leverages a high-level planner to select tasks, while a low-level controller executes the selected tasks using deep reinforcement learning. We evaluate our framework on a simulated urban driving environment and demonstrate improved efficiency and adaptability compared to flat reinforcement learning baselines. The proposed HRL framework has potential applications in real-world autonomous vehicle systems.

title: Hybrid Auction-Based Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive solutions. This paper proposes a hybrid auction-based task allocation framework that integrates combinatorial auctions with machine learning-based winner determination. The framework is designed to handle heterogeneous agents with diverse capabilities and preferences, and can effectively allocate tasks in dynamic environments. We evaluate the proposed framework through extensive simulations and demonstrate its superior performance compared to existing task allocation strategies in terms of system utility, fairness, and adaptability.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Hierarchical Neural Networks and Query-Document Interaction
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for information retrieval (IR) often rely on complex and computationally expensive architectures. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural network (HNN) architecture that leverages query-document interaction to improve ranking performance while reducing computational cost. Our HNN model consists of a query-aware document encoder and a hierarchical interaction module that captures multi-level relationships between query and document terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in ranking performance and computational efficiency compared to existing neural ranking models.

title: Efficient Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection for Industrial IoT Networks
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection is critical for ensuring the reliability and security of Industrial IoT (IIoT) networks. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'IoT-AD', which leverages a combination of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks to detect anomalies in IIoT sensor data. IoT-AD incorporates a transfer learning scheme to adapt to new devices and environments, and a robust feature selection mechanism to reduce the dimensionality of the data. Experimental results on a real-world IIoT dataset demonstrate that IoT-AD outperforms traditional machine learning-based methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Study
paper_abstract: The widespread adoption of voice assistants has transformed the way people interact with technology. However, older adults often face difficulties using these systems due to physical and cognitive limitations. This paper presents a multimodal interaction study that explores the design of inclusive voice assistants tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a series of user studies to identify key challenges and opportunities, and developed a novel interaction framework that integrates speech, gesture, and gaze-based inputs. Our results show that the proposed framework significantly improves the usability and accessibility of voice assistants for older adults, and provides insights for designing more inclusive and supportive systems.

title: Efficient Document Filtering with Hierarchical Neural Ranking for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (MIR) faces the challenge of efficiently filtering and ranking relevant documents from large collections. We propose a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'MedRank', which leverages domain-specific knowledge graphs and document embeddings to improve retrieval accuracy. MedRank employs a two-stage filtering approach, first pruning irrelevant documents using a coarse-grained neural filter, and then re-ranking the remaining documents using a fine-grained neural ranker. Experimental results on the TREC Medical Retrieval benchmark demonstrate that MedRank outperforms state-of-the-art MIR models in terms of precision, recall, and mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Multi-Modal Sensor Data Fusion
paper_abstract: Multi-modal sensor data fusion is crucial in various applications, including surveillance, healthcare, and robotics. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) to fuse and process multi-modal data from heterogeneous sensors. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between sensor modalities and captures hierarchical patterns in the data. Experiments on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy, robustness, and computational efficiency.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Improving Passage Retrieval in Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a fundamental task in many information retrieval (IR) systems. However, the effectiveness of passage retrieval models is often limited by the brevity and ambiguity of user queries. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach, 'QDE', which selectively expands relevant documents with contextual information to better match user queries. We design a neural ranking model that incorporates query-dependent document representations and demonstrate significant improvements in passage retrieval performance on several benchmark datasets. QDE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, particularly for short and ambiguous queries, and has potential applications in various IR systems, including search engines and question answering platforms.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents via Decentralized Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple heterogeneous agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent deep reinforcement learning framework, 'DMARL-COM', that enables agents to learn effective coordination strategies without relying on centralized controllers or communication. We introduce a novel attention-based agent representation that captures the heterogeneity of agents and their interactions. Experimental results on a real-world traffic management scenario demonstrate that DMARL-COM outperforms state-of-the-art decentralized methods in terms of coordination efficiency and scalability.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Social Media
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis in social media remains a challenging task due to the complexity of integrating textual, visual, and audio features. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant multimodal inputs and capture nuanced sentiment expressions. Our HAN model consists of a stacked attention mechanism that recursively aggregates features from multiple modalities, enabling the capture of both local and global contextual dependencies. Experimental results on a large-scale social media dataset demonstrate significant improvements in sentiment analysis accuracy compared to state-of-the-art multimodal fusion methods.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing query execution plans is crucial for the performance of distributed database systems. Traditional approaches rely on hand-crafted heuristics or exhaustive search, which can be suboptimal and computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepQOpt', that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn query optimization policies. We design a custom neural network architecture that incorporates database schema and query workload information to generate optimized execution plans. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that DeepQOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Clustering
paper_abstract: Node clustering is a fundamental task in graph analysis, but existing methods often struggle with scalability and accuracy. This paper proposes Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively aggregate node features at multiple scales. By hierarchically applying attention to graph neighborhoods, HGAT efficiently identifies densely connected clusters while preserving node-level information. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art clustering methods in terms of clustering quality and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column Stores
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become crucial for timely business insights, but query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', tailored for column-store databases. By leveraging column-level statistics and a cost-based optimization approach, ColOpt reduces query latency by up to 40% compared to traditional row-store optimization techniques. We also introduce a novel indexing scheme, 'ColIX', which further accelerates query execution by minimizing data access patterns. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate ColOpt's efficacy in supporting real-time analytics workloads.

title: Scalable Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases are increasingly used to store and query large amounts of multi-dimensional data. However, existing indexing techniques struggle to efficiently support range queries in these systems. This paper presents 'DIMS', a novel distributed indexing scheme that leverages a combination of hash-based and tree-based indexing to accelerate multi-dimensional range queries. DIMS employs a hierarchical indexing structure that adaptively partitions the data space and dynamically adjusts the indexing granularity based on query workload. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that DIMS outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of storage efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed RDF Graphs using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of RDF graphs in various domains has led to a growing need for efficient query optimization techniques. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans for distributed RDF graphs. Our method, called 'RL-Query', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal join order and indexing strategy based on the graph structure and query patterns. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that RL-Query outperforms traditional query optimization techniques, achieving up to 3x speedup and 2x reduction in memory usage.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, as it can significantly impact the accuracy of search results. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks. We design a multi-layer neural network that learns to generate context-aware query expansions from large-scale datasets. Our approach incorporates a hybrid attention mechanism that captures both semantic and syntactic relationships between query terms and document content.
