Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision and recall.

title: Exploring Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years, yet most existing approaches rely on complex and opaque neural networks. This paper proposes a novel graph attention network (GAT) architecture, 'ExplainGAT', which leverages attention mechanisms to provide transparent and interpretable recommendations. We demonstrate that ExplainGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models on benchmark datasets while providing visual explanations for recommended items. Furthermore, we introduce a novel evaluation metric, 'Explainability Score', to quantify the interpretability of recommendation models.

title: Deep Query Expansion for Retrieval of Sparse Entities in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph retrieval tasks often struggle with sparse entities, which lack sufficient descriptive information. This paper proposes a novel deep query expansion approach, 'DQE-KG', to enhance the retrieval of sparse entities. DQE-KG leverages a transformer-based architecture to generate semantically rich query expansions, incorporating entity relationships and type information. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate that DQE-KG outperforms state-of-the-art methods by up to 15% in terms of mean reciprocal rank, especially for sparse entities with limited context.

title: Efficient Indexing for Scalable Entity Disambiguation in Large-Scale Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph construction, but existing approaches are often computationally expensive and do not scale well to large datasets. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'EDIndex', which leverages a hierarchical clustering-based approach to efficiently identify and disambiguate entities. EDIndex utilizes a combination of lexical, semantic, and structural features to create a compact index that enables fast lookup and disambiguation. Experimental results on several large-scale knowledge graphs demonstrate that EDIndex achieves significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art methods, with an average speedup of 3.5x and a reduction in memory usage of 60%.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Progressive Pruning for Resource-Constrained Devices
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising technique for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, the computational overhead and memory requirements of NAS algorithms can be prohibitively expensive for resource-constrained devices. This paper proposes a novel NAS approach, 'ProgPrune', which leverages progressive pruning to reduce the search space and computational cost. Our method adaptively eliminates less promising architectures and focuses on the most promising candidates, resulting in significant speedups and memory savings. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ProgPrune discovers competitive architectures while requiring only a fraction of the computational resources compared to state-of-the-art NAS methods.

title: Intelligent Agent-Based Negotiation Framework for Multi-Stakeholder Decision Making
paper_abstract: In complex, dynamic environments, multi-stakeholder decision making often involves negotiation between autonomous entities with conflicting goals. This paper proposes a novel intelligent agent-based negotiation framework, 'AgentNegotiate', which leverages machine learning and game theory to facilitate efficient and effective agreements. AgentNegotiate incorporates a cognitive architecture that models stakeholders' preferences, uncertainty, and risk attitudes, enabling agents to adapt their negotiation strategies accordingly. Experimental results demonstrate that AgentNegotiate outperforms traditional negotiation protocols in terms of agreement quality and time-to-agreement, with potential applications in e-commerce, supply chain management, and smart cities.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Improving Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but traditional methods often suffer from the vocabulary mismatch problem. This paper proposes a novel context-aware embedding approach, CAQE, which leverages lexical and semantic relationships to generate expanded queries. CAQE incorporates a graph-based attention mechanism to capture contextual dependencies between query terms and documents, resulting in more accurate and diverse expanded queries. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art methods, with an average increase of 12.5% in mean average precision.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Resource allocation in cloud computing is a complex problem that requires efficient optimization of virtual machine placement, scaling, and migration. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'CloudOpt', that learns to optimize resource allocation policies in cloud environments. We design a modular DRL architecture that integrates a deep Q-network with a graph neural network to capture complex dependencies between VMs and physical resources. Experimental results on a real-world cloud dataset show that CloudOpt outperforms state-of-the-art heuristics and optimization techniques in terms of resource utilization, latency, and energy efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Real-time Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT
paper_abstract: Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) systems generate vast amounts of time-series data, making real-time anomaly detection crucial for ensuring system reliability and efficiency. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages graph-structured data and attention mechanisms to identify anomalies in IIoT systems. HGAT consists of a hierarchical encoder that aggregates features from multiple sensors and a graph attention-based decoder that captures complex dependencies between sensors. Experimental results on a real-world IIoT dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art anomaly detection methods in terms of accuracy and latency.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have gained popularity in recent years due to their ability to handle large-scale graph data. However, query optimization techniques for these systems are still in their infancy. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages graph partitioning, indexing, and caching to minimize query latency and improve throughput. We evaluate GraphOpt on a real-world social network dataset and demonstrate significant performance improvements compared to existing query optimization techniques.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but existing VR systems often exclude users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel framework for designing accessible VR experiences, focusing on auditory and tactile feedback. We introduce a set of guidelines and tools for developers to create inclusive VR environments, validated through user studies with visually impaired participants. Our approach enables users to navigate and interact with virtual objects using soundscapes and haptic feedback, demonstrating significant improvements in usability and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search for Resource-Constrained Edge Devices
paper_abstract: The proliferation of edge devices has created a pressing need for efficient neural networks that can operate within tight resource constraints. This paper proposes a novel neural architecture search (NAS) framework, 'EdgeNAS', designed specifically for resource-constrained edge devices. EdgeNAS employs a multi-objective search strategy that balances model accuracy, latency, and energy consumption. Our experiments on several edge datasets demonstrate that EdgeNAS discovers models that outperform state-of-the-art NAS methods while satisfying stringent resource constraints, making it an attractive solution for real-time edge AI applications.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic control systems require efficient coordination among multiple agents to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for coordinating multi-agent systems in autonomous traffic control. Our approach consists of two levels: a high-level coordinator that learns to allocate tasks to agents, and low-level agents that learn to execute tasks using deep reinforcement learning. We evaluate our framework in a simulated traffic scenario and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of traffic throughput and reduction in travel time.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Entity Disambiguation
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to identify the correct entity corresponding to a query. However, the performance of traditional methods degrades when dealing with ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel approach, HierGNN-QE, which leverages hierarchical graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn contextualized representations of entities and expand queries. Our model incorporates a two-level hierarchy of GNNs, where the first level captures local entity relationships and the second level aggregates global context. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HierGNN-QE in improving entity disambiguation accuracy and reducing computational overhead.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Multimodal Retrieval using Graph-based Embeddings
paper_abstract: Multimodal retrieval has gained significance with the increasing availability of multimedia data. Existing query expansion techniques struggle to capture the complex relationships between different modalities. This paper proposes a novel graph-based embedding approach, 'Multimodal Graph Embeddings' (MGE), to encode the interactions between text, image, and audio modalities. MGE leverages a graph neural network to learn joint representations, enabling effective query expansion for multimodal retrieval. Experimental results on the Wikipedia dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art methods, especially for queries with limited textual information.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Natural Language Processing with Hierarchical Adaptive Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot natural language processing (NLP) tasks require models to generalize to unseen tasks with limited labeled data. We propose a novel meta-learning approach, 'HATE', which employs hierarchical adaptive task embeddings to capture task relationships and transfer knowledge across tasks. Our method leverages a hierarchical neural network to learn task embeddings, which are then adapted to new tasks using a meta-learning objective. We evaluate HATE on several few-shot NLP benchmarks and demonstrate improved performance over state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average relative improvement of 12.5% in accuracy.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Distributed Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: As autonomous vehicles (AVs) become increasingly prevalent, coordinating their actions to ensure safe and efficient traffic flow is a crucial challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to distributed multi-agent reinforcement learning for coordinating AVs in complex scenarios. Our method, dubbed 'MARL-Co', leverages a decentralized actor-critic framework to enable AVs to learn cooperative policies in real-time. We demonstrate MARL-Co's effectiveness in reducing congestion and improving travel times in a simulated urban environment, outperforming traditional rule-based approaches.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics has become a crucial requirement in various industries, including finance, healthcare, and e-commerce. However, existing distributed database systems often struggle to provide low-latency query processing for complex analytical workloads. This paper proposes a novel optimization framework, 'Raptor', which leverages a combination of query rewriting, data partitioning, and parallel processing to accelerate query execution. We introduce a cost-based optimization algorithm that considers both data distribution and query patterns to minimize query latency. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that Raptor achieves up to 3x faster query processing compared to state-of-the-art distributed database systems.

title: Leveraging Deep Learning for Efficient Query Expansion in Ad-Hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc information retrieval, as it directly impacts the relevance and diversity of search results. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach for query expansion, which leverages a combination of word embeddings and recurrent neural networks to model query context and semantic relationships. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for ambiguous and underspecified queries, compared to traditional methods. We also investigate the impact of various neural architectures and training objectives on query expansion performance.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal inputs, such as speech, text, and facial expressions, is a crucial task in affective computing. Existing approaches often rely on fusion techniques, which can be computationally expensive and neglect the hierarchical relationships between modalities. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and fuse them in a hierarchical manner. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency, while providing interpretable attention weights for understanding emotion recognition.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Time-Series Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in industrial IoT time-series data is crucial for predictive maintenance and quality control. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that leverages both local and global patterns in the data. Our approach consists of a multi-scale feature extractor, a hierarchical attention module, and a probabilistic anomaly scoring function. Experimental results on three industrial datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and false alarm rate, especially in scenarios with limited labeled data.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on manual controllers or voice commands, which can be cumbersome and detract from the immersive experience. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system for VR, leveraging deep learning techniques to accurately predict user intent from eye movements. Our approach combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a recurrent neural network (RNN) to analyze gaze patterns and classify user actions. We evaluate our system using a custom-built VR platform and demonstrate significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user experience compared to traditional methods.

title: Enhancing Accessibility in Virtual Reality Environments through Adaptive Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, ensuring accessibility for users with disabilities remains a critical challenge. This paper presents 'AdaptGest', a machine learning-based framework that dynamically adjusts gesture recognition parameters to accommodate individual differences in motor abilities. Our approach leverages a novel combination of skeletal tracking and electromyography data to recognize gestures, achieving a 35% improvement in recognition accuracy for users with motor impairments compared to existing state-of-the-art methods. We evaluate AdaptGest through a user study with 20 participants, demonstrating its potential to enhance VR accessibility and usability.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Dialogue State Tracking
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a crucial component of task-oriented dialogue systems, where the goal is to accurately track user goals and preferences across multiple turns. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for DST, which leverages both local and global context to improve tracking performance. Our approach incorporates a multi-layer attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant dialogue history, enabling more accurate and interpretable state tracking. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate the efficacy of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art performance and providing insights into the decision-making process.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Clustering and Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in natural language processing and information retrieval, where the goal is to identify the correct entity reference in a given context. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages graph-based clustering and deep learning techniques to achieve scalable and accurate entity disambiguation. Our method first constructs a graph representation of the entities and their relationships, and then applies a deep clustering algorithm to group similar entities together. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalized Avatar Customization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: With the growing adoption of virtual reality (VR) technology, it is essential to understand the factors that influence user engagement. This study explores the impact of personalized avatar customization on user experience in VR environments. We designed a VR platform that allows users to create customized avatars using a combination of machine learning-based facial recognition and manual input. Our user study (N=100) reveals a significant increase in user engagement, measured through time spent in the VR environment and self-reported satisfaction, when users are able to create personalized avatars. We also identify key design factors that contribute to this effect, including avatar realism and controllability.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Explainable Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks that can mislead the model's predictions. Existing detection methods often rely on hand-crafted features or statistical analysis. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GraphAlert', which leverages explainable graph attention mechanisms to identify potential attacks. By analyzing the attention weights and graph structure, our method can detect adversarial samples with high accuracy. We evaluate GraphAlert on several image classification benchmarks and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting various types of attacks, including pixel-level and semantic-level perturbations.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Age-Related Differences in Voice Command Recognition
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their effectiveness for older adults is hindered by age-related declines in speech recognition. This study investigates the impact of age on voice command recognition, analyzing data from 100 participants aged 65-85. We identify significant differences in speech patterns, such as slower speech rates and increased variability, which affect recognition accuracy. We propose an age-aware voice assistant framework that incorporates acoustic models tailored to older adults' speech characteristics, resulting in improved recognition rates of up to 25%. Our findings have implications for designing more inclusive and accessible voice-based interfaces for aging populations.

title: Designing Adaptive Visualizations for Enhanced Multimodal Interaction in Augmented Reality
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) interfaces have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but existing visualization techniques often fail to effectively leverage multimodal input. This paper presents a novel framework for adaptive visualization in AR, which dynamically adjusts visual representations based on user behavior, context, and cognitive load. Our approach integrates machine learning-based user modeling with cognitive architectures to generate personalized, intuitive, and efficient visualizations. A user study demonstrates significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional visualization methods.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction and Cognitive Load
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed human-computer interaction, but the cognitive implications of embodied experiences remain understudied. This paper investigates the relationship between gesture-based interaction and cognitive load in VR. We designed a novel VR platform that tracks users' gestures and measures cognitive load through physiological signals. Our results show that embodied cognition in VR reduces cognitive load for complex tasks, while gesture-based interaction enhances spatial reasoning and memory recall. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of more intuitive and effective VR interfaces.

title: Efficient Few-Shot Learning with Meta-Learned Adaptive Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has emerged as a crucial challenge in AI, where models must adapt to new tasks with limited data. Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have shown promise in this setting, but their performance often hinges on manual tuning of hyperparameters. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning approach, 'MAGNET', which adaptively learns graph structures and neural network weights from a few examples. Our method leverages a hierarchical graph attention mechanism, enabling efficient knowledge transfer across tasks. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that MAGNET outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods, while requiring significantly fewer parameters and computations.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Autonomous Agent Teams
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in heterogeneous autonomous agent teams, where agents possess different capabilities and expertise. We propose a decentralized algorithm, 'Distributed Coalition Formation' (DCF), which leverages local communication and negotiation to form coalitions of agents that can effectively accomplish complex tasks. Our approach exploits agent heterogeneity to improve task allocation efficiency and adaptability in dynamic environments. Experimental results in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that DCF outperforms existing centralized and decentralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Hashing for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in distributed database systems, as it enables accurate data integration and querying. However, existing approaches suffer from scalability issues, particularly in large-scale systems. This paper proposes a novel graph-based hashing approach for entity disambiguation, which leverages the structural properties of entity relationships to efficiently disambiguate entities. Our approach uses a distributed hash table to store entity representations, enabling fast lookup and disambiguation. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and scalability.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Attention-based Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages attention-based graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn complex agent-agent and agent-task relationships. Our approach, called DAGAT, enables agents to adaptively allocate tasks based on their capabilities, resource constraints, and environmental dynamics. We evaluate DAGAT on a series of simulations, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized and distributed methods.

title: Robustifying Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Hierarchical Attention
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can mislead them into making incorrect predictions. This paper proposes a novel defense mechanism, Hierarchical Attention-based Adversarial Robustness (HAAR), which leverages attention mechanisms to identify and suppress adversarial perturbations. HAAR uses a hierarchical structure to adaptively focus on relevant features and regions of the input data, thereby improving the robustness of the network against diverse attack types. Our extensive experiments on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate that HAAR outperforms state-of-the-art defense methods in terms of both accuracy and robustness.

title: Designing Inclusive Accessibility Features for Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but existing VR interfaces often exclude users with disabilities. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for designing inclusive accessibility features in VR, focusing on users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive impairments. We propose a set of guidelines and heuristics for VR interface designers, based on a mixed-methods approach involving user studies, expert interviews, and iterative prototyping. Our evaluation shows that incorporating these accessibility features improves user experience and task performance for users with disabilities, while also enhancing overall usability for all users.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Platooning
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicle platooning has the potential to significantly improve highway safety and efficiency. However, coordinating the actions of multiple vehicles in real-time poses significant challenges. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARP', which enables autonomous vehicles to learn cooperative policies for platooning. MARP utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each vehicle learns to make decisions based on local observations and communication with its neighbors. We evaluate MARP in a simulated highway environment and demonstrate improved platooning stability and reduced fuel consumption compared to traditional rule-based approaches.

title: Optimizing Query Efficiency in Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly prevalent, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel graph-based indexing approach, 'GraphIndex', which leverages the structural properties of data graphs to optimize query execution. We propose a hierarchical indexing scheme that partitions the data graph into smaller subgraphs, enabling efficient query routing and parallel processing. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GraphIndex achieves up to 3x query performance improvement compared to traditional indexing methods, while reducing storage overhead by 20%.

title: Relevance Modeling with Deep Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to effectively capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper presents a novel relevance modeling approach that leverages deep semantic embeddings to enhance query understanding. We propose a neural network architecture that jointly learns term embeddings, document representations, and relevance scoring functions. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, with our approach outperforming state-of-the-art models by up to 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Stochastic Search
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of distributed task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and constraints need to collaborate to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a novel stochastic search algorithm, called 'AgentSearch', which leverages probabilistic modeling to efficiently explore the vast space of possible task allocations. Our approach incorporates a probabilistic graphical model to capture task dependencies and agent capabilities, enabling the identification of high-quality solutions. Experimental results on a suite of benchmark problems demonstrate the effectiveness of AgentSearch in achieving near-optimal task allocations, outperforming existing methods in terms of solution quality and computational efficiency.

title: Bayesian Neural Turing Machines for Efficient Meta-Learning
paper_abstract: Meta-learning has emerged as a promising approach to few-shot learning, but existing methods often suffer from poor computational efficiency and limited adaptability. This paper introduces Bayesian Neural Turing Machines (BNTMs), a new framework that combines the strengths of neural networks and probabilistic graphical models. BNTMs leverage a Bayesian inference mechanism to learn a meta-model that can adapt to new tasks with minimal data and computation. We demonstrate the effectiveness of BNTMs on several benchmarks, achieving state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational overhead by up to 75% compared to existing methods.

title: Adaptive Document Re-ranking with Deep Neural Networks for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to document re-ranking for information retrieval tasks. Our proposed method, 'DeepReRank', leverages deep neural networks to learn contextualized representations of documents and queries. By adaptively re-weighting the relevance scores based on the semantic similarity between the query and document, DeepReRank achieves significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that DeepReRank outperforms state-of-the-art models, while reducing the computational overhead by up to 30%.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning approach to tackle this challenge. We introduce a novel framework that combines a high-level policy for task allocation with low-level policies for individual agent control. The high-level policy is learned using a graph neural network, while the low-level policies are learned using deep reinforcement learning. We evaluate our approach in a simulated rescue scenario, demonstrating improved coordination and response times compared to traditional decentralized approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Reinforcement Learning in Partially Observable Environments
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (RL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its brittleness in partially observable environments remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces HAN-RL, a novel hierarchical attention network architecture that incorporates both spatial and temporal attention mechanisms to reason about uncertain state information. We demonstrate that HAN-RL improves the interpretability and performance of RL agents in several benchmark environments, including the Atari and MuJoCo suites. Furthermore, we provide a theoretical analysis of the attention mechanisms, showing that they facilitate more efficient exploration and improved policy convergence.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for distributed resource allocation in smart grids. We consider a scenario where multiple autonomous agents, each representing a microgrid, must negotiate and allocate resources to optimize energy efficiency and reduce peak demand. Our approach leverages deep Q-networks to learn cooperative policies that adapt to changing environmental conditions and agent interactions. We evaluate our method using a realistic simulation platform and demonstrate significant improvements in resource utilization and system stability compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but users with motor impairments often face significant barriers to accessing VR experiences. This paper presents a novel framework for designing accessible VR interfaces that accommodate users with motor impairments. We propose a set of guidelines and heuristics for designing intuitive and adaptive interfaces that can be controlled using alternative input methods, such as eye-tracking and voice commands. Our user study with 20 participants with motor impairments demonstrates that our approach can significantly improve the usability and accessibility of VR systems for this population.

title: Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but existing VR systems often neglect the needs of users with disabilities. This paper presents 'EmpathyBot', an embodied conversational agent (ECA) designed to facilitate inclusive VR experiences. EmpathyBot uses multimodal fusion and machine learning to recognize and respond to users' emotional states, providing personalized support and accommodations. We evaluate EmpathyBot in a user study with participants with disabilities, demonstrating significant improvements in user engagement, comfort, and accessibility.

title: Scalable Explainable AI for Real-time Traffic Flow Prediction
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic flow prediction is crucial for intelligent transportation systems, but existing AI models often lack interpretability, hindering trust and reliability. This paper presents 'TrafficLens', a novel framework that integrates scalable explainable AI techniques with graph neural networks for accurate traffic flow prediction. We propose a hierarchical attention mechanism that uncovers relevant spatial-temporal dependencies in traffic data, enabling transparent and interpretable predictions. Experimental results on a large-scale traffic dataset demonstrate that TrafficLens outperforms state-of-the-art models while providing meaningful explanations for its predictions.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for accessible interfaces that accommodate cognitive impairments. This paper presents a novel gesture-based interface framework, 'EasyGesture', designed specifically for older adults with mild cognitive impairments. EasyGesture utilizes machine learning-based gesture recognition and adaptively adjusts its sensitivity and feedback mechanism based on user performance. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional interfaces. We discuss the implications of our design principles for future HCI research in accessible interface design.

title: Enhancing Query Representation with Graph-Based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture the semantics of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach to enhance query representation by incorporating graph-based semantic embeddings. We leverage knowledge graphs to construct a query graph, which is then embedded into a dense vector space using a graph neural network. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly improves retrieval effectiveness, particularly for queries with complex semantics.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-time Entity Disambiguation in Large-Scale Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a critical task in knowledge graph construction, but existing approaches are often computationally expensive and unsuitable for real-time applications. This paper proposes a novel indexing method, 'EDIndex', which leverages a combination of graph-based and semantic-based features to efficiently disambiguate entities in large-scale knowledge graphs. We demonstrate the effectiveness of EDIndex on several benchmark datasets, achieving a 3x speedup over state-of-the-art methods while maintaining high disambiguation accuracy. Our approach enables real-time entity disambiguation in applications such as question answering and text analysis.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Planning with Hierarchical Task Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized multi-agent planning framework that leverages hierarchical task networks (HTNs) to coordinate complex tasks among agents. Our approach, called Dec-HTN, distributes planning responsibilities across agents, enabling them to reason about their local subtasks and communicate with neighboring agents to resolve dependencies. We prove the soundness and completeness of Dec-HTN and evaluate its performance in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved scalability and adaptability compared to centralized HTN-based planning.

title: Improving Query Efficiency with Hierarchical Indexing for Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval systems face significant challenges in efficiently processing complex queries. This paper presents a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'Distributed Hierarchical Indexing' (DHI), which leverages the concept of multi-level indexing to reduce query latency. DHI employs a two-tier indexing structure, comprising a global index and local indices, to facilitate efficient query routing and processing. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed testbed demonstrate that DHI achieves an average query latency reduction of 35% compared to existing indexing methods, while maintaining comparable retrieval effectiveness.

title: Adaptive Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is a crucial task that enables agents to achieve common goals. However, in real-world scenarios, agents often have incomplete information about each other's capabilities, preferences, and intentions. This paper proposes a novel adaptive coalition formation algorithm that leverages probabilistic graphical models to reason about uncertain agent information. Our approach iteratively updates coalition structures based on observed agent behaviors, enabling more effective and resilient collaboration. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the improved performance of our algorithm compared to existing methods that assume complete information.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems is a challenging problem in distributed artificial intelligence. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel framework that leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex interactions between agents. HGAT enables agents to learn hierarchical representations of their local neighborhoods, facilitating more effective coordination and decision-making. We evaluate HGAT on several multi-agent benchmarks, demonstrating significant improvements in coordination efficiency and task performance compared to existing approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice-based interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their accessibility for older adults with cognitive impairments remains a concern. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop inclusive voice-based interfaces tailored to the needs of this population. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults, caregivers, and clinicians to identify key challenges and opportunities. Our findings informed the development of a prototype system, 'EasyVoice', which incorporates features such as simplified syntax, personalized feedback, and cognitive support. A usability evaluation with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing voice-based interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Online Reviews
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis in online reviews has become crucial for businesses to understand customer opinions. However, existing approaches often struggle with handling multimodal data (e.g., text, images, and videos) and capturing complex sentiment relationships. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that integrates multimodal features and learns to focus on relevant segments of the input data. Our HAN model consists of three attention layers: modality-level, segment-level, and token-level attention, enabling it to capture sentiment patterns at different granularities. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal review dataset demonstrate improved sentiment analysis performance and robustness compared to state-of-the-art multimodal fusion methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Retrieval Models for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems struggle to effectively capture user intent, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion approach, 'NeuQE', that leverages the semantic capabilities of transformer-based retrieval models. By fine-tuning a pre-trained neural retriever on a large-scale dataset, we generate high-quality query expansions that capture nuanced relationships between terms. Our experiments on the TREC ad-hoc benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, outperforming state-of-the-art expansion methods. NeuQE's efficiency and scalability make it a promising solution for real-world search applications.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems for dynamic task allocation using reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'MA-RL-Allocator', which enables agents to learn optimal task allocation policies based on their local observations and interactions. Our approach integrates a deep Q-network with a graph neural network to model agent relationships and task dependencies. Experimental results on a simulated urban transportation scenario demonstrate that MA-RL-Allocator outperforms traditional planning-based methods in terms of task completion rate and agent utility.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual RealityInterfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but current interfaces often neglect the needs of users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel VR interface design that leverages audio-haptic feedback and gesture recognition to enable users with visual impairments to navigate and interact with virtual environments. We conducted a user study with 20 participants and found that our design significantly improved task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional visual-based interfaces. Our results inform the development of more inclusive and accessible VR systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable AI is crucial in multi-agent dialogue systems, where agents must understand and respond to user queries. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that generates interpretable responses while maintaining high task accuracy. Our approach incorporates a multi-level attention mechanism, which selectively focuses on relevant dialogue context, agent knowledge, and user preferences. We evaluate our HAN model on a large-scale dialogue dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in response quality and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Eye-Gaze Driven Interface for Enhancing Wheelchair Navigation
paper_abstract: Wheelchair navigation remains a significant challenge for individuals with mobility impairments. This paper presents an innovative, gaze-based interface designed to improve wheelchair control and navigation. Our system, 'GazeNav', utilizes a wearable eye-tracking device to detect and interpret user gaze patterns, translating them into wheelchair commands. We conducted a user study with 15 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in navigation accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional joystick-based interfaces. GazeNav's performance was further enhanced by integrating machine learning-based gaze prediction and path planning algorithms.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Deep learning models for sentiment analysis often struggle to provide interpretable results, especially when dealing with multi-modal inputs (e.g., text, images, and audio). This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that explicitly models the relationships between different modalities. Our approach learns to attend to relevant regions in each modality and fuses the representations using a hierarchical graph neural network. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method on a benchmark dataset, achieving state-of-the-art results in terms of both accuracy and explainability. We also provide visualizations of the learned attention patterns, offering insights into the decision-making process of the model.

title: EyeGesture: A Real-Time Eye Movement-Based Gesture Recognition System for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: This paper presents EyeGesture, a novel, real-time eye movement-based gesture recognition system designed to enhance user experience in human-computer interaction. EyeGesture leverages a deep neural network-based approach to classify eye movements into distinct gestures, achieving an accuracy of 95.2%. Our system is capable of detecting gestures in real-time, with a latency of 50ms, making it suitable for various applications, including gaming, virtual reality, and assistive technologies. We evaluate EyeGesture on a large-scale dataset of eye movement recordings and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving user engagement and interaction.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have become increasingly popular in cloud computing, but optimizing query performance for diverse workloads remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'DeepQuery', a novel query optimization framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to adapt to changing workload patterns. Our approach uses a hierarchical neural network to learn the optimal query plan from a large search space, considering various performance metrics and resource constraints. Experimental results on a real-world multi-tenant database system demonstrate that DeepQuery outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 3.5x in terms of average query response time.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Intelligent transportation systems can significantly reduce congestion and improve traffic flow. This paper presents a novel framework for coordinating traffic signal control using a hierarchical reinforcement learning approach. We model the traffic network as a multi-agent system, where each agent represents an intersection. Our algorithm, 'HierTraffic', learns a hierarchical policy that coordinates the agents to optimize traffic flow. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that HierTraffic outperforms traditional fixed-timing and adaptive signal control methods, reducing average travel time by 23% and increasing network throughput by 17%.

title: Real-Time Conjunctive Query Optimization using Column Stores and Indexing
paper_abstract: Traditional row-store databases struggle to efficiently execute conjunctive queries, which are common in data analytics and business intelligence applications. We present a novel optimization framework, 'Conjix', that leverages column stores and indexing to accelerate conjunctive query processing. Conjix employs a cost-based optimization strategy that adaptively selects the most efficient execution plan based on query patterns, data distributions, and system resources. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that Conjix outperforms state-of-the-art row-store and column-store databases by up to 5x in query response time and 3x in throughput.

title: Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection for Time Series Data in Industrial IoT
paper_abstract: The increasing use of Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) devices has led to a surge in time series data, making anomaly detection a critical task for ensuring system reliability and efficiency. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'TS-Autoencoder', which leverages the strengths of autoencoders and convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to detect anomalies in multivariate time series data. We evaluate TS-Autoencoder on a real-world dataset from a manufacturing plant and demonstrate its superiority over traditional methods in terms of detection accuracy and robustness to noise.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Decentralized Graph-Based Planning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel decentralized planning framework for coordinating multi-agent systems, leveraging graph-based representations to model agent interactions and objectives. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphPlan', enables agents to locally construct and exchange graph-based plans, facilitating efficient and scalable coordination in dynamic environments. We prove the correctness and completeness of GraphPlan and demonstrate its effectiveness in simulated urban traffic management and search-and-rescue scenarios, showcasing improved response times and reduced communication overhead.

title: Dynamic Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning-based approach, 'RL-TA', for dynamic task allocation in distributed environments. RL-TA leverages a decentralized Q-network to learn optimal task assignments for each agent, taking into account changing environment conditions and agent capabilities. We evaluate RL-TA in simulations of search-and-rescue and surveillance scenarios, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and agent utilization compared to traditional auction-based methods.

title: Real-time Human Emotion Recognition using Multimodal Fusion of EEG and Facial Expression Analysis
paper_abstract: Accurate human emotion recognition is crucial in various applications, including affective computing, human-computer interaction, and mental health monitoring. This paper proposes a multimodal fusion approach that combines electroencephalography (EEG) signals with facial expression analysis to recognize human emotions in real-time. We present a novel neural network architecture that integrates EEG-based affective state estimation with computer vision-based facial feature extraction. Experimental results on a large-scale emotion dataset demonstrate the superiority of our approach over unimodal methods, achieving an average emotion recognition accuracy of 92.5%.

title: Hierarchical Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Task-Aware Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, particularly when dealing with novel tasks. This paper proposes a hierarchical meta-learning framework, 'HMET', that leverages task-aware embeddings to adapt to new tasks with limited data. Our approach introduces a novel hierarchical structure that captures task relationships and incorporates a task-agnostic meta-learner to generate task-specific embeddings. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HMET outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot image classification, achieving an average accuracy improvement of 5.2% over existing methods.

title: Hierarchical Neural Retrieval Framework for Efficient Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering (QA) systems rely heavily on effective retrieval mechanisms to identify relevant passages. This paper presents a hierarchical neural retrieval framework, 'HNRF', which leverages a combination of semantic and syntactic features to retrieve top-ranked passages. We propose a novel attention-based neural ranking model that captures nuanced relationships between questions and passages, and integrate it with a hierarchical clustering algorithm to reduce the search space. Experimental results on the SQuAD dataset demonstrate that HNRF achieves a 15% improvement in retrieval accuracy and a 30% reduction in computational overhead compared to state-of-the-art QA systems.

title: EyeGazePath: A Novel Gaze-Based Navigation System for Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on manual controllers for navigation, which can be cumbersome and detract from the immersive experience. This paper presents EyeGazePath, a gaze-based navigation system that leverages machine learning-driven eye tracking to enable seamless movement in VR environments. Our approach combines convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with saliency maps to accurately predict user gaze targets, achieving a mean navigation error of 12.5° in a user study. We also introduce a novel gaze stabilization technique that reduces eye movement noise and enhances overall system performance.

title: Context-Aware Task Allocation in Decentralized Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel context-aware task allocation framework that leverages agent capabilities, task requirements, and environmental factors to optimize task assignments. We introduce a probabilistic ontology-based model to represent agent knowledge and context, and a distributed constraint optimization algorithm to allocate tasks. Experimental results on a real-world disaster response scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and overall system performance compared to existing approaches.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering Using Hierarchical Dense Representations
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) has gained significant attention in recent years. However, the passage retrieval step remains a major bottleneck, with most state-of-the-art models relying on inefficient and computationally expensive methods. This paper proposes a novel approach, Hierarchical Dense Passage Retrieval (HDPR), which leverages hierarchical dense representations to efficiently retrieve relevant passages from a large corpus. We demonstrate that HDPR achieves significant improvements in both retrieval efficiency and question answering accuracy on several benchmark datasets, including TriviaQA and Natural Questions.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have the potential to enhance the daily lives of older adults with cognitive impairments, but existing systems often fail to accommodate their unique needs. This paper presents 'EasyVoice', a novel voice assistant framework designed to improve accessibility and usability for this population. EasyVoice incorporates a range of adaptive features, including simplified language processing, personalized feedback mechanisms, and error correction strategies. A user study with 20 older adults with cognitive impairments demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has revolutionized the field of deep learning, but its computational cost remains a significant bottleneck. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention (HGA) framework that efficiently searches for optimal neural architectures. HGA leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture complex hierarchical relationships between architecture components, thereby reducing the search space and improving search efficiency. We demonstrate the efficacy of HGA on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in NAS tasks while reducing computational overhead by up to 50%.

title: Decentralized Trust Management for Autonomous Agent Systems using Blockchain
paper_abstract: As autonomous agents proliferate in various domains, trust management becomes a critical concern. This paper presents a decentralized trust management framework, 'BlockTrust', that leverages blockchain technology to establish and maintain trust relationships among agents. BlockTrust enables agents to autonomously evaluate and update trust ratings based on their interactions, while ensuring transparency, integrity, and accountability. We evaluate BlockTrust using a simulated smart grid scenario, demonstrating its effectiveness in detecting and mitigating malicious agent behavior.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Augmented Reality Displays: A Study on User Experience and Performance
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology advances, the need for intuitive and efficient interaction methods becomes increasingly important. This paper explores the use of gaze-based interaction with AR displays, focusing on user experience and performance. We designed and implemented a gaze-tracking system using a commercial eye-tracker and evaluated its accuracy and usability in a controlled study with 30 participants. Our results show that gaze-based interaction significantly reduces task completion time and improves user satisfaction compared to traditional touch-based input methods. Furthermore, we identify key factors influencing user performance, including visual attention, cognitive load, and individual differences in eye movement patterns.

title: Robustifying Deep Reinforcement Learning with Causal Graph-Based Intervention
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive results in various domains, but its brittleness to environment changes and interventions remains a significant concern. This paper introduces a novel causal graph-based approach, 'CausalIntervene', which integrates causal graph inference and graph-based intervention to improve the robustness of DRL policies. We demonstrate that CausalIntervene can effectively identify and intervene on causal factors affecting the environment, leading to more robust policy performance under changes and interventions. Experimental results on several benchmarks show that CausalIntervene outperforms state-of-the-art DRL methods in terms of robustness and adaptability.

title: Efficient Document Filtering for Real-time Information Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Real-time information retrieval (RTIR) systems require efficient document filtering to reduce latency and improve user experience. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural network (HNN) architecture for document filtering, which leverages semantic and syntactic features from documents and queries. Our approach outperforms traditional filtering methods by 23.1% in terms of precision and 17.5% in terms of recall on a benchmark dataset. We also demonstrate the scalability of our approach by evaluating it on a large-scale IR dataset, achieving an average filtering time of 12.6 ms per query.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems to improve the accuracy of document ranking. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural query expansion (HNQE) approach that leverages the semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our HNQE model consists of a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures the contextual importance of query terms and a neural ranking module that refines document scores based on the expanded query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HNQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural IR Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well to diverse query types. We propose a neural IR model, 'NeuroQE', which learns to expand queries by predicting relevant terms that capture the semantic intent of the original query. NeuroQE leverages a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query expansion and relevance ranking, thus improving the overall retrieval performance. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, especially for ambiguous and under-specified queries.

title: Scalable In-Memory Indexing for Real-Time Analytics on High-Throughput Data Streams
paper_abstract: The advent of IoT and sensor networks has led to an explosion of high-throughput data streams, necessitating efficient real-time analytics. Existing indexing techniques struggle to cope with the velocity and volume of these streams. This paper presents 'FlashIndex', a novel in-memory indexing framework that leverages multi-core processors and hybrid storage architectures to achieve high-throughput and low-latency query performance. We introduce a hybrid indexing strategy that adaptively switches between disk-based and memory-based indexing based on data velocity and query patterns. Experimental results on a simulated IoT dataset demonstrate that FlashIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 5x in terms of query throughput and response time.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Fraud Detection in Online Transactions
paper_abstract: Online transaction fraud poses significant financial risks to businesses and individuals alike. Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promise in fraud detection, but existing methods suffer from limitations in modeling complex transaction relationships. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN framework, 'HAGNN', which leverages multi-scale graph representations to capture both local and global patterns in transaction graphs. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weighs node importance at different scales, enabling more accurate fraud detection. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and false positive rates.

title: Distributed Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is crucial for achieving common goals. However, in real-world scenarios, agents often have incomplete information about each other's capabilities and preferences. This paper presents a novel distributed coalition formation algorithm, 'DCFA', which leverages probabilistic graphical models to reason about uncertain agent relationships. DCFA incorporates a decentralized negotiation protocol that enables agents to iteratively refine their coalition structures based on received information. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that DCFA outperforms existing methods in terms of coalition stability and overall system utility.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture Recognition Systems for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to enhance accessibility for individuals with motor impairments. However, current systems often fail to account for the diverse range of abilities and needs within this population. This paper presents a novel, inclusive gesture recognition framework that leverages machine learning and participatory design principles. We conducted a co-design study with 20 participants with motor impairments, resulting in a set of design recommendations for gesture recognition systems that prioritize flexibility, adaptability, and personalization. Our system, ' GestureFlex', is evaluated through a user study, demonstrating improved recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing systems.

title: Efficient Reinforcement Learning with Graph Neural Networks for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient and adaptive control systems to navigate complex environments. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn vehicle control policies. Our approach, 'GNN-RL', represents the vehicle's surroundings as a graph, enabling the incorporation of structural information and efficient learning of control policies. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GNN-RL in simulations of urban and highway driving scenarios, achieving improved performance and reduced computational overhead compared to traditional RL methods.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Efficient task allocation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities need to be assigned to tasks with varying requirements. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to model agent-task interactions. Our approach, called GraphAgent, uses a decentralized architecture where agents communicate with their neighbors to learn a shared representation of the task graph. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphAgent outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate, makespan, and communication overhead.

title: Deep Transfer Learning for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Social Media
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis in social media platforms has gained significance due to the increasing use of images, videos, and audio along with text. This paper proposes a deep transfer learning framework, 'MultimodalSent', which leverages pre-trained convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) for feature extraction from vision and language modalities, respectively. We introduce a novel multimodal attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of each modality based on the input data. Experimental results on a large-scale social media dataset demonstrate that MultimodalSent outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in sentiment classification tasks.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Deep Sparse Representations for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents from a massive corpus. This paper presents a novel approach, 'DeepSparse', which leverages deep sparse representations to encode passages and questions. Our method uses a hierarchical sparse encoder to capture semantic relationships between entities and concepts, enabling efficient similarity computation. Experimental results on the Natural Questions and TriviaQA datasets demonstrate that DeepSparse outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval methods, achieving a 15% improvement in top-1 accuracy while reducing computational cost by 30%.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to decentralized task allocation in multi-agent systems, leveraging distributed constraint optimization techniques. We propose a hierarchical framework that enables agents to negotiate and allocate tasks while respecting constraints on resource availability, communication bandwidth, and temporal dependencies. Our method, dubbed 'DCAgent', is shown to outperform existing decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of solution quality, convergence speed, and robustness to agent failures. We evaluate DCAgent in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating its effectiveness in coordinating autonomous vehicles and drones.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Multimodal Feedback in Virtual Reality-Based Stroke Rehabilitation
paper_abstract: This study investigates the impact of multimodal feedback on motor skill learning in virtual reality (VR)-based stroke rehabilitation. We designed a VR system that provides users with real-time auditory, visual, and haptic feedback on their movement performance. A user study with 24 stroke patients showed that the multimodal feedback condition resulted in significant improvements in movement accuracy and smoothness compared to a unimodal feedback condition. Our results suggest that incorporating multiple feedback modalities can enhance the effectiveness of VR-based rehabilitation and provide insights for the design of future VR systems.

title: Indexing and Querying Graph Data with Multi-Attribute Hashing
paper_abstract: Graph data has become increasingly prevalent in modern applications, but querying and indexing such data efficiently remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, `MAHGI` (Multi-Attribute Hashing Graph Index), which leverages multi-attribute hashing to facilitate fast query processing on large graph datasets. MAHGI uses a combination of vertex-centric and edge-centric indexing to enable efficient query execution, while also supporting various query types, including graph pattern matching and shortest path queries. Our experimental evaluation on real-world graph datasets demonstrates that MAHGI outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques in terms of query performance and storage efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion using Graph Convolutional Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle with lexical gaps between query terms and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel approach to hierarchical query expansion using Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs). Our model, dubbed 'GCN-Expander', learns to represent queries and documents as nodes in a graph, where edges capture semantic relationships between terms. By propagating query information through the graph, GCN-Expander generates context-aware expansion terms that improve retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant gains in precision and recall over state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Framework
paper_abstract: As voice assistants become increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need to design more inclusive interfaces that cater to the diverse needs of older adults. This paper presents a multimodal interaction framework that integrates speech, gesture, and visual cues to facilitate more effective and accessible interactions. Our user-centered design approach involves a series of co-design workshops and usability studies with older adults, revealing key challenges and opportunities for inclusive design. We evaluate our framework through a controlled experiment, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction. This work contributes to the development of more accessible and user-friendly voice assistants for older adults.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, cooperative task allocation is crucial for achieving efficient and effective collaboration. This paper presents a novel approach to this problem using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized, multi-agent Q-network (MAQN) that learns to allocate tasks based on the agents' capabilities, task requirements, and environmental constraints. The MAQN is trained using a modified Q-learning algorithm that incorporates a novel reward function, encouraging cooperative behavior and adaptability to changing environments. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion rate, resource utilization, and adaptability to dynamic environments.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but users with visual impairments are often excluded from these experiences. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR experiences that cater to users with visual impairments. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with visually impaired individuals to identify key accessibility barriers and developed a set of guidelines for VR interface design. Our framework incorporates audio-based navigation, tactile feedback, and personalized assistance to facilitate user engagement. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach in enhancing the overall VR experience for users with visual impairments.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its lack of transparency hinders trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel model-agnostic explainability framework, 'RL-Explain', which leverages attention mechanisms and feature importance scores to provide interpretable explanations for DRL policies. We demonstrate the effectiveness of RL-Explain on several Atari games and a real-world autonomous driving scenario, showcasing its ability to identify salient features and provide actionable insights for policy improvement.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively capture the semantic nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep semantic embeddings to enrich query representations. By injecting domain-specific knowledge into the embedding space, our method enables more accurate query expansion and improved retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the efficacy of DeepQE in enhancing retrieval precision and recall, particularly for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Coordination
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) promise to revolutionize urban transportation, but coordinating their actions in complex scenarios remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework, 'AV-CORD', which enables AVs to learn cooperative policies in real-time. We propose a novel, graph-based communication mechanism that facilitates information exchange between agents while respecting privacy and bandwidth constraints. Experimental results using a realistic simulation platform demonstrate that AV-CORD outperforms traditional, centralized approaches in terms of traffic efficiency, safety, and scalability.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Information Retrieval using Hierarchical Clustering
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems are increasingly used to index large-scale data repositories. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complex interactions between query terms, document indexing, and network topology. This paper presents a novel hierarchical clustering approach to optimize query processing in DIR systems. Our method, 'HCQO', leverages the clustering structure to prune irrelevant documents and reduce network communication. Experimental results on a large-scale DIR benchmark demonstrate that HCQO achieves significant improvements in query response time and throughput compared to existing optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-computer interaction (HCI) is crucial for developing empathetic systems. Existing approaches often rely on single modalities, neglecting the complementary information from multiple sources. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) for multimodal emotion recognition, integrating facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals.
