Our HAN architecture learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, outperforming state-of-the-art approaches on the EMOTIC dataset. We also explore the interpretability of HAN, providing insights into the emotional cues utilized by the model.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but users with visual impairments are often excluded from these experiences. This paper presents an accessible VR interface design framework, 'AccessibleVR', which incorporates assistive technologies and multimodal feedback to enable users with visual impairments to navigate and interact with virtual environments. We evaluate the usability and accessibility of our framework through a user study with visually impaired participants, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large-scale data and provide high availability. However, optimizing queries in such systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using graph neural networks (GNNs). We model the database as a graph, where nodes represent tables and edges represent joins. Our GNN-based optimizer, 'GQO', learns to predict the optimal execution plan for a given query by iteratively refining the graph representation. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate that GQO outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing with Skew Handling
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing (RTDW) enables timely insights into rapidly changing data, but query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents 'SkewOPT', a novel optimization framework that tackles data skew in RTDW. SkewOPT leverages a probabilistic data distribution model to identify and mitigate skew-induced performance bottlenecks. Our approach incorporates a lightweight, online skew detection mechanism and a dynamic query rewriting strategy to minimize query latency. Experimental results on a real-world RTDW benchmark demonstrate that SkewOPT outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3.5x in terms of query response time.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Models
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular, but optimizing queries in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach to query optimization, leveraging the structural properties of query plans to identify efficient execution strategies. We introduce a graph neural network (GNN) model that learns to predict optimal query plans from a large dataset of query executions. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving an average speedup of 2.5x while reducing query latency by 30%.

title: Hierarchical Explainability for Deep Reinforcement Learning in Partially Observable Environments
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its lack of transparency hinders trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical explainability framework, 'HERO', tailored to DRL in partially observable environments. HERO decomposes the agent's decision-making process into interpretable components, enabling the identification of influential observations, actions, and latent factors. We demonstrate HERO's effectiveness in Atari games and a real-world robotics task, showcasing improved interpretability without sacrificing performance.

title: Scalable Hierarchical Clustering for High-Dimensional Data via Deep Embeddings
paper_abstract: Hierarchical clustering is a fundamental task in data analysis, but traditional methods struggle with high-dimensional data. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepHier', which leverages deep neural networks to learn compact, hierarchical representations of data. We introduce a multi-resolution clustering objective that encourages the discovery of clusters at multiple scales, and develop an efficient optimization algorithm that scales to large datasets. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepHier outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of clustering quality and efficiency, particularly in high-dimensional regimes.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task due to the complexity of graph data and the need to minimize communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to select the optimal query plan based on the graph topology, query patterns, and system workload. Experimental results on a real-world graph dataset show that our approach outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces have become increasingly popular, but their adoption is hindered by user experience issues. This paper investigates the effect of haptic feedback on user experience in VR. We designed an experiment to compare user performance and satisfaction in two VR interfaces: one with haptic feedback and one without. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly improves user performance in tasks requiring spatial awareness and manipulation, while also reducing user frustration and fatigue. We also propose a novel metric, Haptic Experience Score (HES), to quantify the impact of haptic feedback on user experience.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for real-time traffic signal control. Our approach, dubbed 'TrafficMA', leverages a decentralized architecture to handle large-scale traffic networks, where each agent learns to optimize traffic signal timings based on local observations. We introduce a novel communication protocol that enables efficient information sharing among agents, reducing the need for centralized control. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network show that TrafficMA outperforms traditional optimization methods, achieving a 25% reduction in average travel time and a 30% decrease in congestion.

title: Multi-Task Learning for Hierarchical Sentiment Analysis with Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Hierarchical sentiment analysis is a complex task that involves identifying sentiment at multiple levels of granularity, from individual aspects to overall entities. This paper proposes a multi-task learning framework that leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to model the hierarchical relationships between aspects and entities. Our approach jointly learns sentiment analysis and aspect extraction tasks, leveraging the shared knowledge to improve performance on both tasks. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods on both aspect-level and entity-level sentiment analysis tasks.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Semantic Role Labeling for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a vital technique for improving the effectiveness of ad-hoc retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel QE approach that leverages deep semantic role labeling (SRL) to disambiguate query terms and identify salient entities. Our method, called SRL-QE, utilizes a pre-trained language model to generate contextualized representations of query terms, which are then fed into an SRL model to extract semantic roles. We demonstrate that SRL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various machine learning tasks, but their success highly depends on careful hyperparameter tuning. Bayesian optimization has emerged as a popular approach for hyperparameter tuning, but its computational cost can be prohibitive for large models. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian optimization algorithm, 'HyperBO', which leverages a probabilistic kernel-based surrogate model to efficiently explore the hyperparameter space. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HyperBO on several benchmark datasets, showing significant improvements in tuning efficiency and model performance compared to existing methods.

title: Deep Neural Ranking Models for Sparse and Noisy Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Relevance feedback is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it enables users to provide explicit judgments about the relevance of retrieved documents. However, in many real-world scenarios, the feedback is sparse and noisy, which can significantly degrade the performance of ranking models. In this paper, we propose a novel deep neural ranking model, 'NoiseRobustRank', that incorporates a denoising autoencoder to learns robust representations of user feedback. We also introduce a new loss function, 'SparseRankLoss', that adaptively weights the importance of each feedback instance based on its confidence score. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NoiseRobustRank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models in terms of both effectiveness and robustness.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where multiple agents with varying capabilities need to be assigned to tasks to optimize system performance. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework using deep reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'DRL-TA', enables agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to changing task requirements and agent capabilities. We evaluate DRL-TA on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario and demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized and distributed allocation strategies.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Virtual Agents in Augmented Reality
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, the need for more natural and intuitive interaction methods grows. This paper explores the potential of gaze-based interaction with virtual agents in AR environments. We propose a novel gaze-tracking algorithm that leverages machine learning-based eye movement classification and demonstrate its application in a virtual shopping assistant scenario. Our user study shows that gaze-based interaction can reduce task completion time and improve user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based input methods.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation in Uncertain Environments
paper_abstract: In many real-world applications, multiple agents must cooperate to achieve a common goal in uncertain and dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel framework for cooperative task allocation using multi-agent reinforcement learning. We formulate the problem as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process and develop a hierarchical policy gradient algorithm that leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability compared to existing methods, showcasing the potential of our approach for real-world applications.

title: Optimizing SQL Query Processing with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The ever-growing size and complexity of modern databases necessitate efficient query processing. This paper explores the application of deep reinforcement learning to optimize SQL query execution plans. We propose a novel framework, 'SQL-RL', which utilizes a decision-making agent to learn an optimal query plan policy from a large database workload. SQL-RL incorporates domain-specific knowledge, such as index selection and join ordering, into the agent's decision-making process. Experimental results on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that SQL-RL outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of execution time, while also adapting to changing workload patterns.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous multi-agent systems using graph neural networks (GNNs). Our approach, called DecGNN, leverages the graph structure of the agents' communication network to learn a distributed task allocation policy. DecGNN is capable of handling complex task dependencies and agent capabilities, and does not require a centralized controller. We evaluate DecGNN on a simulated urban search and rescue scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional decentralized allocation methods.

title: A Hierarchical Query Expansion Framework for Improving Search Engine Retrieval Effectiveness
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of modern search engines, as it enables users to retrieve relevant documents that may not contain the exact query terms. However, existing expansion techniques often suffer from the vocabulary mismatch problem, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion framework, 'HQEF', which leverages a multi-level representation of query semantics to generate expanded queries. HQEF incorporates a neural topic model to capture latent topics, and a graph-based method to identify semantic relationships between query terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HQEF significantly outperforms state-of-the-art expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly used in modern data-intensive applications, but query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes an adaptive indexing framework, 'AIx', that dynamically adjusts the indexing strategy based on query workloads and data distributions. We introduce a novel cost-based optimization algorithm that incorporates statistical models of query patterns and data correlations, enabling AIx to outperform existing indexing techniques by up to 30% in query response time. Experimental evaluations on a real-world DDS deployment demonstrate the effectiveness of AIx in improving query performance and reducing resource utilization.

title: Optimizing Join Order Enumeration with Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Query Processing
paper_abstract: Distributed query processing systems face the challenging problem of optimizing join order enumeration to minimize query execution time. Existing solutions rely on heuristics or exhaustive search, which can lead to suboptimal plans. This paper proposes 'RLJoin', a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize join order enumeration. RLJoin formulates the problem as a Markov decision process and employs a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy from a dataset of query executions. Experiments on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that RLJoin outperforms state-of-the-art methods by up to 30% in terms of query execution time, while adapting to diverse data distributions and query patterns.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Data Partitioning in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are increasingly used to manage large-scale data sets, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel adaptive data partitioning strategy, called ADAPT, which dynamically adjusts data distribution based on query patterns and workloads. ADAPT leverages a cost-based optimization framework to identify the most effective partitioning scheme, taking into account factors such as data locality, node capacity, and network latency. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that ADAPT outperforms existing static partitioning methods, achieving an average query performance improvement of 35%.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Learning-based Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it can significantly improve the retrieval accuracy. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based query expansion approach, which leverages a transformer-based architecture to learn the contextual relationships between query terms and relevant documents. Our approach, called DeepQE, integrates a sentence encoder and a graph-based attention mechanism to identify salient terms and phrases that can effectively expand the query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms traditional query expansion methods and achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of precision and recall.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) to optimize task assignments. Our approach decomposes the task allocation problem into hierarchical sub-problems, enabling agents to learn both high-level task selection policies and low-level action execution strategies. We demonstrate the efficacy of our method in a simulated robotics domain, showing significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional decentralized optimization methods.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Time-Series Data in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Time-series data has become increasingly prevalent in various domains, including IoT, finance, and healthcare. However, querying and indexing such data in distributed database systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'TS-Tree', which leverages a combination of spatial and temporal locality to efficiently store and query time-series data. We evaluate TS-Tree on a real-world IoT dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and storage efficiency compared to existing indexing methods. Our approach is highly scalable and can be easily integrated with existing distributed database systems.

title: Distributed Task Allocation and Scheduling for Heterogeneous Agent Teams
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems have been increasingly adopted in various applications, including search and rescue, surveillance, and environmental monitoring. However, task allocation and scheduling for heterogeneous agent teams remain a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel distributed algorithm, 'HATAS', which leverages graph theory and constraint programming to efficiently allocate tasks to agents with diverse capabilities and resource constraints. Our experiments demonstrate that HATAS outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate, latency, and robustness to agent failures. We also provide a thorough analysis of the algorithm's complexity and scalability.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization with Learned Index Structures for Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of modern database systems. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages learned index structures to accelerate query optimization for main-memory databases. Our framework, 'LIX', integrates a neural network-based index optimizer with a traditional query optimizer, enabling faster and more efficient query execution. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that LIX reduces query optimization time by up to 3x compared to state-of-the-art techniques, while maintaining comparable query performance.

title: Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Efficient Neural IR Systems
paper_abstract: Neural information retrieval (IR) models have achieved state-of-the-art results, but their computational requirements hinder their adoption in real-world applications. This paper presents a novel hierarchical document embedding approach, 'HiDE', which reduces the dimensionality of document representations while preserving their semantic meaning. Our method leverages a multi-level clustering strategy to group similar documents, and then learns compact embeddings for each cluster. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that HiDE achieves comparable retrieval performance to dense passage retrieval models while requiring significantly fewer computations and memory.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Multi-Agent Dialogue Management
paper_abstract: Multi-agent dialogue systems require effective dialogue management to generate coherent and context-dependent responses. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for explainable multi-agent dialogue management. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to select relevant context information and capture complex relationships between agents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in a real-world customer service scenario, achieving significant improvements in response accuracy and coherence compared to state-of-the-art baselines. Furthermore, our model provides interpretable attention weights, enabling explainability of dialogue flow and decision-making.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatar-Based Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in various domains, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the effect of personalized avatar-based feedback on user engagement in VR environments. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with a VR system that provided either generic or personalized avatar-based feedback. Our results show that personalized feedback significantly increases user engagement, measured through time spent in the VR environment, self-reported enjoyment, and physiological responses. We also explored the role of user embodiment and presence in mediating the feedback effect.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of people with disabilities. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive conversational interfaces, focusing on individuals with visual, hearing, motor, or cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of co-design workshops and usability studies, leading to the development of a novel framework that incorporates accessibility features, such as multimodal input, output customization, and real-time feedback. Our evaluation shows that the proposed framework significantly improves the interaction experience and satisfaction of users with disabilities, while also enhancing overall system usability.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various information retrieval tasks. However, they often suffer from the vocabulary mismatch problem, where the query and document vocabularies do not align. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively select expansion terms. Our method, called RLERank, learns to optimize the ranking metrics by interacting with a simulated environment. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RLERank outperforms traditional query expansion techniques and improves the overall retrieval performance of neural models.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Query Expansion Techniques in Multimodal Retrieval
paper_abstract: Multimodal retrieval systems have gained popularity in recent years, but the effectiveness of query expansion techniques in these systems remains understudied. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of various query expansion methods, including pseudo-relevance feedback, latent semantic analysis, and word embeddings, in the context of multimodal retrieval. We experiment with a large-scale dataset comprising images, videos, and text documents and analyze the impact of query expansion on retrieval performance. Our results show that a combination of query expansion techniques outperforms individual methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the effect of personalized avatars on user experience and engagement in VR. We propose a novel framework that leverages machine learning-based facial recognition and 3D modeling to generate personalized avatars that reflect users' physical appearance and personality traits. Our user study involving 100 participants reveals that personalized avatars lead to increased user engagement, improved self-presence, and enhanced overall VR experience. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of VR systems and applications.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Data Warehousing with Non-Volatile Memory
paper_abstract: The advent of non-volatile memory (NVM) technologies has transformed the landscape of data warehousing. However, existing indexing schemes are often optimized for traditional storage media, leading to suboptimal performance in NVM-based systems. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'NVMIndex', which leverages the unique characteristics of NVM to achieve efficient data retrieval and insertion in real-time data warehousing. We introduce a hybrid indexing strategy that combines the benefits of tree-based and hash-based indexing, and demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art indexing schemes.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, particularly in scenarios with complex dependencies and constraints. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph attention networks (GATs) to model the inter-agent relationships and allocate tasks efficiently. Our method, called GAT-Allocator, uses a hierarchical GAT architecture to learn the importance of each agent's local state and communication with neighbors. Experimental results on a variety of synthetic and real-world benchmarks demonstrate that GAT-Allocator outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system utility.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of autonomous vehicles (AVs) on public roads necessitates efficient coordination mechanisms to ensure smooth traffic flow and minimize congestion. This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework, called 'AV-Coord', that enables AVs to learn cooperative behaviors in real-time. AV-Coord leverages graph neural networks to model the interactions between AVs and their surroundings, and employs a novel credit assignment mechanism to incentivize cooperation. Experimental results using a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that AV-Coord outperforms traditional traffic signal control methods in reducing congestion and travel times.

title: Optimizing Join Order Selection for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular due to their ability to scale and handle large amounts of data. However, optimizing the join order selection in these systems remains a challenging problem. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that utilizes reinforcement learning to optimize the join order selection for distributed databases. Our method, called Distributed Join Optimizer (DJO), uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal join order based on the database schema, query patterns, and system workload. We evaluate DJO on a real-world distributed database system and demonstrate significant performance improvements compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis is a crucial task in natural language processing, but traditional methods often struggle to handle multi-modal data and provide inadequate explainability. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework that leverages both textual and visual features to perform sentiment analysis. Our approach uses multi-head attention to selectively focus on relevant input modalities and incorporates a gradient-based explanation technique to provide insights into the decision-making process. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate the superiority of our approach over state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and explainability.

title: Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval that involves adding relevant terms to the original query to improve retrieval performance. Existing methods rely on hand-crafted rules or statistical models, which may not capture the complexities of real-world queries. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning approach, 'RL-QE', that learns to expand queries by interactively exploring the search space. We define a reward function that balances retrieval accuracy and query efficiency, and train an agent to select optimal expansion terms. Experiments on the TREC dataset demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of MAP and NDCG metrics, while reducing query latency by up to 30%.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hyperbolic Geometry for AI-assisted Natural Language Processing
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial component in various AI-driven natural language processing (NLP) tasks. However, traditional KGE methods struggle to capture complex relationships and hierarchical structures in large-scale knowledge graphs. This paper proposes a novel KGE framework, 'HyperKGE', which leverages the expressive power of hyperbolic geometry to model complex relationships and scalable to large knowledge graphs. Experimental results on benchmarks such as WN18RR and FB15K-237 demonstrate that HyperKGE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods in link prediction and entity disambiguation tasks, while reducing computational costs.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing providers face the challenge of efficiently allocating resources to meet dynamic user demands. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'CloudOpt', that learns to optimize resource allocation in cloud data centers. CloudOpt employs a two-level hierarchy, where a high-level policy selects a subset of resources and a low-level policy allocates those resources to specific tasks. We introduce a novel reward function that incorporates both performance and energy efficiency metrics. Experimental results on a real-world cloud dataset demonstrate that CloudOpt outperforms existing approaches in terms of resource utilization, task completion time, and energy consumption.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal results. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'NeuroExpand', which leverages neural semantic embeddings to better capture query intent. Our method uses a pre-trained language model to generate a weighted set of expansion terms, which are then incorporated into the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroExpand significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving improvements of up to 15% in mean average precision.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of personalized avatars on user experience and behavior in VR environments. We designed and developed an avatar creation system that integrates facial recognition, machine learning-based personality analysis, and real-time animation. Our user study involving 120 participants reveals that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, presence, and enjoyment in VR, particularly among introverted individuals. We discuss the implications of these findings for VR-based applications in education, entertainment, and therapy.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-based Interfaces for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant barriers when interacting with digital systems. This paper presents a novel approach to designing adaptive gesture-based interfaces that accommodate diverse motor abilities. Our framework, ' GestureFit', utilizes machine learning-based gesture recognition and real-time adaptation to adjust interface parameters, such as gesture complexity and timing, to individual users' motor capabilities. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with motor impairments, demonstrating significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture-based interfaces.

title: Investigating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but users often report discomfort and disorientation due to the lack of haptic feedback. This paper presents a study examining the effect of haptic feedback on user experience in VR. We designed a custom VR system with haptic feedback and conducted a user study with 30 participants. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly improves user satisfaction, reduces cybersickness, and enhances spatial awareness. We also found that the type and intensity of haptic feedback influence user experience, with vibrotactile feedback being more effective than electroencephalography-based feedback.

title: Scalable Anomaly Detection in Time Series Data using Graph-based Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in many applications, including IoT, finance, and healthcare. However, existing methods often struggle to handle large-scale datasets and high-dimensional data. This paper proposes a novel graph-based contrastive learning approach, 'GraphCon', which leverages the structural properties of time series data to identify anomalies. By constructing a graph representation of the data and applying contrastive learning, GraphCon can efficiently detect anomalies in massive datasets. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and scalability of GraphCon compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Neural Document Ranking with Query Reformulation for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical neural document ranking model, HierRank, that leverages query reformulation to improve the efficiency of information retrieval systems. HierRank consists of a query reformulation module that generates a set of relevant sub-queries, and a hierarchical ranking module that learns to rank documents based on the original query and its sub-queries. We demonstrate that HierRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models on several benchmark datasets, while reducing the average query latency by 30%. Our analysis shows that the query reformulation module effectively captures the nuances of user queries, leading to improved ranking performance.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems to optimize resource allocation is a challenging problem in various domains, such as smart grids and traffic management. This paper proposes a novel framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn decentralized policies for agent coordination. We introduce a hierarchical architecture that combines a graph neural network with a deep Q-network, enabling agents to learn cooperative strategies that adapt to dynamic environment conditions. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional optimization methods and achieves near-optimal resource allocation.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Difficulty Adjustment for Virtual Reality Games
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) games often struggle to balance challenge and engagement, leading to player frustration or boredom. This paper presents 'GazeAdapt', a novel system that leverages eye-tracking and machine learning to adapt game difficulty in real-time based on the player's gaze behavior. Our approach detects cognitive load and emotional states from gaze patterns, adjusting game mechanics to optimize the player's experience. A user study with 30 participants shows that GazeAdapt significantly improves player satisfaction and reduces frustration compared to traditional, fixed-difficulty games.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving system-wide objectives. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework, 'AgentTA', that leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning to allocate tasks to autonomous agents. AgentTA utilizes a graph neural network to learn the communication patterns among agents and adapts to dynamic task arrivals and agent failures. We evaluate AgentTA on a simulated warehouse management scenario, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: As data scales and becomes increasingly distributed, query performance is a major bottleneck in modern database systems. In this paper, we propose an adaptive indexing framework, 'DynIx', which dynamically adjusts index structures based on query workload and data distribution. Our approach leverages machine learning to predict query patterns and identify optimal indexing strategies, reducing query latency by up to 30% compared to traditional static indexing methods. We evaluate DynIx on a real-world e-commerce dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving query performance and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Document Classification
paper_abstract: Document classification is a fundamental task in natural language processing, but it remains challenging due to the high dimensionality of document representations. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that selectively focuses on relevant sentences and words when classification. We introduce a two-stage attention mechanism that first identifies informative sentences and then extracts key phrases within those sentences. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency, making it suitable for real-world applications.

title: EyeGaze: A Machine Learning Approach to Enhance Eye-Tracking for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Eye-tracking has been increasingly used in human-computer interaction (HCI) to improve user experience. However, existing eye-tracking systems often suffer from low accuracy and high latency. This paper proposes EyeGaze, a machine learning-based approach that leverages convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and transfer learning to enhance eye-tracking accuracy. Our approach uses a multi-modal fusion of eye movement and facial features to improve gaze estimation. Experimental results demonstrate that EyeGaze outperforms state-of-the-art eye-tracking systems, achieving an average accuracy of 95.2% and latency of 50ms. We envision EyeGaze to have significant implications for HCI applications, including virtual reality, gaming, and assistive technologies.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot node classification in graph-structured data is a challenging task, particularly when only a few labeled nodes are available. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) model that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and subgraphs. HGAT consists of hierarchical layers that capture graph structural properties at multiple scales, enabling it to generalize well to unseen nodes and graphs. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot node classification tasks, showcasing its potential in real-world applications such as recommender systems and social network analysis.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents using Asynchronous Distributed Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating heterogeneous agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a novel asynchronous distributed reinforcement learning framework, 'ADRL-Het', that enables agents with different capabilities and goals to learn coordinated policies. We introduce a decentralized, asynchronous update mechanism that allows agents to learn from their local experiences while adapting to the changing behaviors of other agents. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate that ADRL-Het outperforms existing methods in terms of coordination, scalability, and robustness to agent failures.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Dialogue Management for Task-Oriented Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Task-oriented conversational agents require effective dialogue management to engage users and accomplish tasks efficiently. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention-based dialogue management framework, 'HATDM', which leverages contextual information and user intentions to generate context-dependent responses. We propose a two-stage attention mechanism that first identifies relevant task-related knowledge and then focuses on user-specific goals, enabling the agent to respond accurately and coherently. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that HATDM outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task success rate, response relevance, and user satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex decision-making tasks, but its lack of transparency hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. We introduce Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs), a novel architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to provide explanations for DRL policies. HANs disentangle the decision-making process into interpretable components, enabling the identification of relevant state features and action influences. Our experiments on Atari games and a real-world robotics task demonstrate that HANs achieve comparable performance to state-of-the-art DRL methods while providing insightful visualizations and feature importance scores.

title: Towards Inclusive Gesture Recognition: A Multimodal Approach for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have transformed human-computer interaction, but they often struggle to accommodate users with motor impairments. This paper presents a multimodal approach that combines computer vision, machine learning, and electromyography (EMG) to recognize gestures from users with diverse abilities. Our system, 'IncluGesture', leverages a novel feature fusion technique to integrate data from multiple sensors, enabling accurate recognition of gestures even in the presence of motor impairments. We evaluate IncluGesture with a diverse user group and demonstrate significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user experience compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Efficient Query Expansion in E-Commerce Search
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in e-commerce search systems, as it can significantly improve the relevance and diversity of search results. However, existing query expansion techniques often suffer from high computational costs and limited coverage of relevant terms. This paper proposes a hybrid retrieval model, 'HybEx', that combines the strengths of lexical and semantic query expansion methods. HybEx employs a two-stage approach, where a lightweight lexical expansion module generates an initial set of expansion terms, which are then refined and weighted using a semantic module based on a pre-trained language model. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that HybEx outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of precision, recall, and query latency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Short-Text Retrieval
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval is a challenging task due to the limited context and ambiguity in user queries. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages the strengths of deep neural networks to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our method, dubbed 'QNLP', uses a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to learn a dense representation of query terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QNLP outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Reinforcing Query Expansion with Neural Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel approach that integrates neural embeddings with traditional query expansion techniques. Our method, dubbed 'EmbEx', learns dense vector representations of query terms and documents, which are then used to identify latent semantic clusters. These clusters are subsequently leveraged to generate expanded query terms that better capture the information need. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that EmbEx outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Investigating the Impact of Anthropomorphic Design on User Trust in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: As conversational agents become increasingly prevalent in everyday life, it is crucial to understand how design factors influence user trust. This study explores the effect of anthropomorphic design on user trust in conversational agents. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment, combining a between-subjects design with semi-structured interviews, to examine how varying levels of anthropomorphism (human-like features, emotional expressions, and social cues) affect users' perceptions of trustworthiness. Our results show that moderate anthropomorphism enhances user trust, while excessive or minimal anthropomorphism can lead to decreased trust. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of conversational agents and suggest avenues for future research.

title: Efficient Zero-Shot Learning for Real-World Object Detection using Contrastive Language-Image Pre-training
paper_abstract: Zero-shot learning (ZSL) has gained significant attention in recent years, enabling object detection models to recognize unseen classes without additional training data. However, existing ZSL methods suffer from poor performance on real-world datasets due to the lack of robustness to noisy or limited training data. This paper proposes a novel contrastive language-image pre-training approach, dubbed 'CLIP-ZSL', which leverages large-scale language-image datasets to learn a shared representation space for both visual and linguistic inputs. Our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on several real-world object detection benchmarks, outperforming existing ZSL methods by up to 15% in mean average precision.

title: Exploiting Hierarchical Query Embeddings for Efficient Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has been shown to be highly effective in open-domain question answering. However, its computational cost remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel approach, Hierarchical Query Embeddings (HQE), which leverages the hierarchical structure of question representations to accelerate DPR. By decomposing query embeddings into coarse and fine-grained components, HQE enables efficient indexing and retrieval of relevant passages. Experiments on popular QA benchmarks demonstrate that HQE achieves significant speedups (up to 5x) while maintaining comparable retrieval accuracy to state-of-the-art DPR models.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, as it can significantly impact the retrieval performance. Traditional methods rely on term co-occurrence and statistical analysis, but they often fail to capture the semantic relationships between terms. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep learning-based semantic embeddings to model term relationships. We employ a neural network to learn dense vector representations of terms and their contexts, and then use these embeddings to expand the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, particularly for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Elderly Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gesture recognition system designed to accommodate elderly users with motor impairments. Our system leverages machine learning models to adapt to the unique movement patterns and abilities of individual users, improving recognition accuracy and usability. We conducted a user study with 20 elderly participants and demonstrated a 30% increase in gesture recognition accuracy compared to traditional machine learning approaches. Our system also incorporates real-time feedback mechanisms to facilitate user learning and adjustment, leading to improved user experience and overall system effectiveness.

title: Enhanced Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, as it enhances the retrieval performance by incorporating relevant terms. This paper proposes a novel context-aware embedding-based approach, 'CAQE', which captures the semantic relationships between query terms and the context in which they appear. CAQE leverages a graph-based neural network to model the query context and generates expanded queries that better reflect the user's intent. Experimental results on several standard benchmarks show that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Multi-Agent Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Explainability is a crucial aspect in multi-agent dialogue systems, as it enhances transparency and trust in decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms at both utterance and dialogue levels. Our approach enables the model to selectively focus on relevant contexts and generate interpretable explanations for its responses. Experimental results on the Multi-WOZ dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of dialogue coherence and explanation quality.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems Using Hybrid Auction Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages hybrid auction mechanisms to allocate tasks to agents. Our approach combines the benefits of combinatorial auctions and Vickrey-Clarke-Groves auctions to ensure efficient task allocation while minimizing communication overhead. We evaluate our approach through extensive simulations, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and system efficiency compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Deep Neural Networks for Improved Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: With the exponential growth of digital data, efficient document filtering has become a critical component of information retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach, 'DocFilter', which leverages the strengths of both traditional filtering methods and modern neural networks. Our model combines a hierarchical attention mechanism with a learned term weighting scheme, demonstrating significant improvements in filtering accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that DocFilter reduces the number of irrelevant documents by 30% while maintaining a high recall rate.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic signal control has the potential to significantly reduce congestion and emissions in urban areas. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'Hierarchical-MARL', which enables decentralized and adaptive traffic signal control. We model the traffic network as a hierarchical graph, where each intersection is represented by a local agent that coordinates with neighboring agents to optimize traffic flow. Our approach leverages a multi-agent Q-learning algorithm to learn optimal policies for each agent, and a hierarchical graph neural network to facilitate communication and coordination between agents. Simulation results on a real-world traffic dataset demonstrate that Hierarchical-MARL outperforms traditional fixed-time and adaptive signal control methods in terms of average travel time and traffic flow.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Indexing
paper_abstract: Traditional indexing techniques for document retrieval suffer from high memory requirements and slow query processing times. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural indexing approach, 'HierIndex', which leverages the strengths of both neural networks and traditional indexing methods. HierIndex uses a hierarchical structure of neural networks to learn a compact representation of documents, enabling efficient similarity search and retrieval. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierIndex achieves significant improvements in query processing time and memory usage compared to state-of-the-art methods, while maintaining competitive retrieval accuracy.

title: Adversarial Perturbation Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Uncertainty Estimation
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can be imperceptible to humans. Existing detection methods often rely on point estimates of model uncertainty, neglecting the inherent Bayesian nature of neural networks. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'BayesDefend', that leverages Bayesian uncertainty estimation to detect adversarial perturbations. By approximating the posterior distribution of model parameters, we can quantify the uncertainty of predictions and identify inputs with high uncertainty as potential attacks. Our experiments on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate that BayesDefend outperforms state-of-the-art detection methods, achieving an average detection rate of 95.2% with a false positive rate of 2.1%.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Learning Models using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their hyperparameter tuning remains a time-consuming and computationally expensive process. This paper proposes a Bayesian optimization approach, 'BOHB', which leverages a probabilistic search strategy to efficiently explore the hyperparameter space. We introduce a novel acquisition function that balances exploration and exploitation, and demonstrate its effectiveness in tuning hyperparameters for convolutional neural networks and recurrent neural networks. Experiments on several benchmark datasets show that BOHB outperforms popular hyperparameter tuning methods, including random search and grid search, in terms of both convergence speed and model performance.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Entity Disambiguation in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation in knowledge graphs is a challenging task, especially when dealing with ambiguous entity names. This paper presents a novel approach, Hierarchical Query Expansion (HQE), which leverages the hierarchical structure of knowledge graphs to generate context-aware queries for disambiguation. HQE uses a graph-based attention mechanism to select relevant entities and expand the query with related concepts, resulting in improved disambiguation accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HQE, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by up to 15% in terms of precision and recall.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Markov Decision Processes
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems using Markov decision processes (MDPs). We model each agent as an MDP, and propose a distributed value function approximation algorithm to learn optimal task allocations. Our approach leverages the agents' local observations and communication with neighboring agents to make decentralized decisions. We evaluate our framework on a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to centralized allocation methods. Our results have implications for large-scale multi-agent systems in real-world applications such as search and rescue, surveillance, and smart cities.

title: Self-Modifying Neural Networks for Real-Time Anomaly Detection in Cybersecurity
paper_abstract: Traditional neural networks rely on static architectures and weights, limiting their adaptability to evolving cyber threats. This paper introduces a novel self-modifying neural network (SMNN) framework that dynamically reconfigures its architecture and weights in response to real-time input data. Our approach leverages reinforcement learning to optimize the SMNN's modification policy, enabling it to detect anomalies more effectively and efficiently than state-of-the-art methods. Experimental results on a large-scale network intrusion dataset demonstrate the SMNN's superiority in detecting zero-day attacks and reducing false positives.

title: Evaluating the Effects of Personalized Avatar Embodiment on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown immense potential in various domains, but user experience remains a crucial aspect to be improved. This study investigates the impact of personalized avatar embodiment on user experience in VR environments. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with a VR system using either a generic or personalized avatar. Our results show that personalized avatars led to increased user engagement, self-presence, and enjoyment, while reducing cybersickness symptoms. We also found that the effects of personalized embodiment varied across different age groups and personality traits. The findings of this study have significant implications for the design of VR systems that aim to enhance user experience and promote long-term user engagement.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Multi-Agent Systems with Dynamic Resource Constraints
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task planning for multi-agent systems in dynamic environments with resource constraints. We propose a hierarchical task network (HTN) planning framework that integrates both symbolic and geometric planning to generate efficient and feasible plans. Our approach leverages a novel resource-aware task decomposition strategy that adapts to changing resource availability and agent capabilities. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a variety of scenarios, including search and rescue, environmental monitoring, and surveillance.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Stores using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing query execution in distributed column-stores is crucial for high-performance analytics. This paper presents an innovative approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans. Our framework, 'RL-QO', learns to adapt to workload patterns and data distributions, selecting the most efficient query plan for a given query. We demonstrate that RL-QO outperforms traditional cost-based optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization, achieving speedups of up to 3.5x on TPC-H benchmarks. Our results highlight the potential of reinforcement learning in database query optimization and pave the way for further research in this area.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Anomaly Detection in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential increase in network traffic, making anomaly detection a critical task. Existing approaches suffer from scalability issues, particularly when dealing with massive IoT networks. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages graph attention mechanisms to identify anomalies in IoT networks. HGAT hierarchically represents IoT devices as nodes in a graph, enabling efficient processing of large-scale networks. Experimental results on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks for Explainable AI-driven Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) has become a crucial aspect of modern recommendation systems, as users increasingly demand transparency into the decision-making process. This paper introduces a novel heterogeneous graph neural network (HGNN) framework, 'ExplainRec', which integrates node-level explanations into the recommendation workflow. By modeling complex item relationships and user behaviors as a heterogeneous graph, ExplainRec leverages graph attention and hierarchical reasoning to generate personalized recommendations with accompanying explanations. Our experiments on a real-world e-commerce dataset demonstrate improved recommendation accuracy and enhanced user trust through explainable AI.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention for Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering (QA) over knowledge graphs (KGs) relies on effective KG embeddings that capture complex relationships between entities. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention mechanism, 'HAT', which selectively focuses on relevant subgraphs and entity properties when learning KG embeddings. Our approach leverages a combination of graph attention and hierarchical clustering to reduce dimensionality and improve embedding quality. Experimental results on benchmark QA datasets demonstrate that HAT outperforms state-of-the-art KG embedding methods, achieving higher accuracy and better generalizability to unseen entities and relations.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Adaptive Relation Attention
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) models have shown promise in various AI applications, but their performance is often hindered by the complexity of relation semantics. This paper presents a novel KGE approach, 'RelAttn', which leverages adaptive attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant relations during training. Our method dynamically adjusts attention weights based on the local neighborhood of each entity, enabling more effective capture of relation patterns. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RelAttn outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods in link prediction and triple classification tasks while reducing computational overhead.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Real-Time Analytics in Main-Memory Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory column-store databases have become increasingly popular for real-time analytics due to their exceptional performance and low latency. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in these systems. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'RT(Column)', which leverages advanced statistical models and machine learning techniques to predict query execution times and optimize query plans. We also introduce a novel cost model that takes into account the unique characteristics of main-memory column-store databases. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that RT(Column) outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Unsupervised Query Intent Detection using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Accurate query intent detection is crucial for effective information retrieval. This paper presents a novel unsupervised approach, Hierarchical Graph Query Intent Detector (HGQID), which leverages graph neural networks to capture complex relationships between query tokens and their intent. Our method first constructs a hierarchical graph representation of the query, and then applies a graph attention mechanism to identify key intent-related tokens. Experimental results on a large-scale query log dataset demonstrate that HGQID outperforms state-of-the-art unsupervised methods by 12.5% in terms of intent detection accuracy, while also providing interpretable results.

title: Deconfliction Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, conflicts between agents can lead to suboptimal performance and instability. This paper proposes a novel graph-based reinforcement learning approach to deconfliction, where agents learn to negotiate and resolve conflicts in a decentralized manner. We model the conflict resolution process as a graph-based Markov decision process and develop a reinforcement learning algorithm that leverages graph neural networks to learn effective deconfliction strategies. Experimental results on a simulated air traffic control scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing conflicts and improving overall system performance.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Retrieval of Short Text Documents
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, particularly for short text documents where the query context is limited. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach, 'NeuroExpan', which learns to expand queries by modeling the semantic relationships between words and documents. Our approach leverages pre-trained language models and fine-tunes them on a large corpus of text data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroExpan significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, resulting in improved retrieval precision and recall.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by limitations in speech recognition, language comprehension, and cognitive load. This paper presents a novel multimodal interaction framework for inclusive voice assistants, incorporating visual and tactile cues to facilitate understanding and reduce user frustration. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults, demonstrating improved task completion rates and user satisfaction with our approach compared to traditional voice-only interfaces. Our findings inform the design of more accessible and supportive voice assistants for older adults.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to learn task allocation policies. We formulate task allocation as a graph-based optimization problem, where agents are nodes, and tasks are edges. Our GCN-based algorithm, 'AgentGCN', learns to allocate tasks by capturing complex relationships between agents and tasks. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate that AgentGCN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on User Experience and Error Recovery Strategies
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but users with disabilities often face significant barriers to adoption. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the user experience of individuals with hearing, speech, and cognitive impairments interacting with voice assistants. We identify key challenges and propose a novel error recovery strategy, 'ReSpeak', which leverages multimodal feedback and adaptive prompting to improve user understanding and reduce frustration. Our results show significant improvements in user satisfaction and task completion rates, highlighting the importance of inclusive design in voice assistant development.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to gesture recognition that adapts to the unique abilities and needs of individuals with motor disabilities. We propose a machine learning-based framework that leverages a small set of calibration gestures to personalize the recognition model for each user. Our approach integrates computer vision and machine learning techniques to identify the most informative features of gestures, even in the presence of motor variability and noise. Evaluation results with 20 participants with motor disabilities demonstrate significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing, one-size-fits-all approaches.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: The increasing demand for real-time analytics in modern applications has led to a surge in distributed database systems. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of data distribution, network latency, and dynamic workloads. This paper presents 'Aurora', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and online learning techniques to adapt to changing system conditions. Aurora uses a multi-armed bandit approach to dynamically select the most efficient query plan, taking into account query patterns, data locality, and system resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that Aurora achieves up to 3x improvement in query response times compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Multimodal Retrieval in Large-Scale Datasets
paper_abstract: Multimodal retrieval has become increasingly important in various applications, such as image and video search. However, the efficiency and effectiveness of retrieval models are often hindered by the complexity of user queries and the scale of the datasets. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, which leverages both semantic and visual features to expand user queries. Our method employs a graph-based clustering algorithm to group semantically similar queries and then uses a deep learning-based model to learn visual representations of the expanded queries. Experimental results on several large-scale datasets show that our approach significantly improves the retrieval performance and reduces the computational cost compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Context-Aware Embedding for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, as it helps to disambiguate user queries and improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel context-aware embedding approach, 'CAQE', that leverages both semantic and syntactic features to generate high-quality expansion terms. By incorporating contextual information from the query and document collection, CAQE can capture nuanced relationships between terms and improve retrieval performance. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, particularly in scenarios where the original query is ambiguous or underspecified.

title: Query Expansion via Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle with vocabulary mismatch between queries and documents. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach, HDE-QE, which leverages hierarchical document embeddings to capture nuanced semantic relationships between terms. By recursively applying a graph-based clustering algorithm to the document embedding space, HDE-QE generates a hierarchical representation of the vocabulary. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that HDE-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 12.3% increase in mean average precision.

title: Rank-Biased Precision: A Novel Evaluation Metric for Diversified Search Results
paper_abstract: Traditional evaluation metrics for search engines, such as precision and recall, often fail to capture the diversity of search results. This paper introduces Rank-Biased Precision (RBP), a novel metric that incorporates both relevance and diversity into a single score. RBP is designed to reward search engines that return diverse results while maintaining high relevance. We conduct an extensive evaluation of RBP on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness in promoting diversified search results. Our analysis also reveals that RBP is more robust to query ambiguity and user intent variability compared to traditional metrics.

title: Context-Aware Agent Communication Strategies for Efficient Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, effective task allocation is crucial for achieving global goals. However, agents' communication strategies significantly impact the allocation efficiency. This paper proposes a novel context-aware communication framework, 'CACOM', which adapts to the dynamic environment and agent capabilities. CACOM integrates a probabilistic task modeling approach with a reinforcement learning-based communication strategy, enabling agents to selectively share information and reduce unnecessary communication overhead. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that CACOM outperforms existing communication strategies, resulting in faster task completion and improved system resilience.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Long-Tail Classification
paper_abstract: Long-tail classification problems, where class distributions are heavily skewed, remain a significant challenge in machine learning. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that adaptively focuses on relevant features and instances to improve classification accuracy. Our HAN model consists of two stages: a feature attention module that weights important input features and a instance attention module that selects informative samples. We evaluate our approach on several long-tail image classification benchmarks, demonstrating significant performance gains over state-of-the-art methods, including resampling and reweighting techniques.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in these systems. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach for query optimization in distributed databases. We model the query plan as a graph and employ graph neural networks to learn the optimal query execution plan. Our approach considers various factors such as data distribution, network latency, and node capacities to minimize query execution time.
