Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Understanding sentiment from multi-modal inputs (e.g., text, images, audio) is crucial for AI-driven decision-making. However, existing methods often rely on complex neural networks with opaque decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates attention mechanisms across modalities and layers, enabling explainable sentiment analysis. Our approach leverages modality-specific attention to weigh feature importance and provides visualizations of attention weights for interpretability. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate improved sentiment accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art models.

title: Efficient Indexing for Distributed Database Systems using Hierarchical Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face significant challenges in indexing large datasets across multiple nodes. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, Hierarchical Bloom Filter Indexing (HBFI), which leverages probabilistic data structures to efficiently manage distributed data. HBFI employs a hierarchical approach, combining Bloom filters withskip lists to achieve fast query performance and low memory overhead. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HBFI outperforms existing indexing techniques in terms of query latency and storage efficiency, making it a promising solution for large-scale distributed database systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Relational Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Knowledge graphs (KGs) have become a crucial component in various AI applications, but their symbolic nature limits their ability to capture complex relationships and uncertainty. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for multi-relational KG embedding, which learns to selectively focus on relevant entities and relations at different abstraction levels. We evaluate HGAT on several popular KG benchmarks and demonstrate its superior performance in link prediction and entity classification tasks compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Integrating Entity Disambiguation and Query Expansion for Enhanced Search Result Diversification
paper_abstract: Modern search engines often struggle to provide diverse search results, particularly when dealing with ambiguous queries. This paper presents a novel approach that jointly addresses entity disambiguation and query expansion to improve search result diversification. Our proposed framework, 'DivEx', leverages a graph-based entity disambiguation method to identify relevant entities and then expands the query using a contextualized language model. Experimental results on the TREC 2020 dataset show that DivEx significantly outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of search result diversity and relevance.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, vision) remains a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the heterogeneity of modalities. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that adaptively integrates and weights features from different modalities. Our HAN consists of multiple attention levels, each focusing on a specific modality or interaction between modalities. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs, achieving a 12.1% improvement in F1-score.

title: Joint Entity Disambiguation and Link Prediction for Knowledge Graphs using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graphs (KGs) suffer from scalability issues due to entity ambiguity and incomplete links. We propose a novel framework, 'GraphAmbiLink', which jointly tackles entity disambiguation and link prediction using graph attention networks (GATs). Our approach leverages KG-specific attention mechanisms to weigh the importance of neighboring entities and relationships, enabling more accurate disambiguation and link prediction. Experimental results on the YAGO3-10 and DBpedia datasets demonstrate significant improvements in both tasks, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by up to 12% in entity disambiguation F1-score and 8% in link prediction AUC.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual learning environments (VLEs) have become increasingly popular, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the effect of personalized feedback on user engagement in VLEs. We designed and implemented a novel feedback system that incorporates machine learning-based user modeling and adaptive difficulty adjustment. Our user study with 120 participants shows that personalized feedback significantly improves user engagement, as measured by time spent on tasks, self-reported motivation, and objective performance metrics. We also identify key factors influencing the effectiveness of personalized feedback, including user personality traits and prior experience with VLEs.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Users with Dysarthria: An Empirical Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but users with dysarthria, a speech disorder characterized by impaired articulation and pronunciation, often struggle to interact with these systems effectively. This paper presents an empirical study investigating the challenges faced by individuals with dysarthria when using commercial voice assistants. We report on a user-centered design approach to develop an inclusive voice assistant prototype that incorporates acoustic models tailored to dysarthric speech patterns. Our results show significant improvements in speech recognition accuracy and user experience, highlighting the importance of inclusive design in HCI.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a novel auction-based mechanism for distributed task allocation, where agents bid for tasks based on their capabilities and preferences. We introduce a truthful bidding strategy that incentivizes agents to reveal their true valuations, and develop a distributed auction protocol that converges to a near-optimal allocation. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving system-wide utility and reducing communication overhead.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Hierarchical Agent Clustering in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In dynamic multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper introduces a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages hierarchical agent clustering to adapt to changing environmental conditions. We propose a clustering algorithm that groups agents based on their capabilities, spatial proximity, and task requirements. Our framework enables agents to dynamically adjust their cluster membership and allocate tasks using a decentralized, auction-based mechanism. Experimental results demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized task allocation approaches.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval using Hierarchical Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems face scalability challenges due to the high volume of query traffic. This paper proposes a novel approach to optimize query processing in DIR systems using hierarchical Bloom filters (HBFs). Our method leverages the hierarchical structure of the filter to reduce the number of nodes involved in query processing, resulting in significant improvements in query response time and throughput. We evaluate our approach on a large-scale DIR system and demonstrate a 30% reduction in query latency and a 25% increase in system throughput compared to existing methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sensor Fusion in Human Activity Recognition
paper_abstract: Human activity recognition (HAR) using multi-modal sensors requires effective fusion of heterogeneous data streams. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (H-GAT) architecture that adaptively integrates feature representations from various sensor modalities. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between sensor readings and activity labels, while hierarchical fusion enables the capture of both local and global contextual information. Experiments on a large-scale HAR dataset demonstrate that H-GAT achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming existing fusion techniques by up to 12% in terms of activity recognition accuracy.

title: Towards Efficient Passage Retrieval with Multi-Modal Embeddings for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) models rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. This paper proposes a novel multi-modal embedding approach, 'MMEmb', which jointly learns dense representations of passages and questions from both textual and visual features. We demonstrate that MMEmb outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval methods on the Natural Questions dataset, achieving a 12.5% improvement in top-1 passage retrieval accuracy. Furthermore, we analyze the effectiveness of MMEmb in various ODQA pipelines, showcasing its potential to improve overall question answering performance.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require sophisticated control systems to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning (DHRL) framework for autonomous vehicle control. Our approach combines a high-level policy network with a low-level control network, enabling the vehicle to adapt to diverse driving situations. We introduce a hierarchical exploration strategy that balances short-term and long-term rewards, leading to improved learning efficiency and stability. Experimental results on a realistic simulation platform demonstrate that our DHRL approach outperforms state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods in terms of safety, efficiency, and adaptability.

title: Entity Disambiguation in Knowledge Graph Embeddings using Attention-based Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings (KGEs) have shown promising results in various NLP tasks, but often struggle with entity disambiguation due to the complexity of real-world graphs. This paper proposes an attention-based graph neural network (GNN) approach to disambiguate entities in KGEs. Our model, AttentiveKG, learns to focus on relevant neighboring entities and relations when computing entity representations, thereby improving disambiguation accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of AttentiveKG in reducing entity ambiguity and enhancing overall KGE performance.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Decentralized Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems (MAS) in complex, dynamic environments remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a decentralized reinforcement learning framework, 'Dec-MAS', which enables heterogeneous agents to learn cooperative policies without relying on centralized controllers or explicit communication. We introduce a novel, graph-based neural network architecture that incorporates local observations and neighbor information to facilitate decentralized decision-making. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that Dec-MAS achieves improved coordination and adaptability compared to traditional, model-based approaches.

title: Gaze-Based Stress Detection in Virtual Reality Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Stress detection in virtual reality (VR) environments is crucial for providing personalized experiences. This paper proposes a novel gaze-based stress detection approach using deep learning. We develop a convolutional neural network (CNN) that extracts features from gaze patterns and predicts stress levels. Our approach leverages a large-scale dataset of gaze patterns collected from VR users experiencing stressful and relaxing scenarios. Experimental results show that our approach achieves an accuracy of 87.2% in detecting stress, outperforming traditional machine learning methods. We envision our approach being integrated into VR systems to provide real-time stress monitoring and personalized interventions.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Database Systems with Heterogeneous Data Sources
paper_abstract: The increasing prevalence of distributed database systems (DDBS) integrating heterogeneous data sources has introduced new challenges in query optimization. This paper proposes a novel cost-based optimization framework, 'HetOpt', which leverages machine learning and data profiling to efficiently optimize queries in DDBS. We introduce a probabilistic modeling approach to capture data distribution and correlation across different data sources, enabling more accurate cost estimation and optimization. Experimental results on a real-world DDBS benchmark demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing optimization techniques.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-time Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT Systems
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in Industrial IoT (IIoT) systems is crucial for ensuring the reliability and safety of industrial processes. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework for real-time anomaly detection in IIoT systems. Our approach leverages a hierarchical DRL architecture that integrates a deep autoencoder for feature learning and a reinforcement learning module for adaptive thresholding. We evaluate our method on a real-world IIoT dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting anomalies in real-time, outperforming traditional machine learning and rule-based approaches.

title: EyeGazeDirector: A Gaze-Based Interface for Autonomous Camera Control in Virtual Meetings
paper_abstract: Virtual meetings have become an essential tool for remote collaboration, but often suffer from poor camera angles and limited user engagement. This paper presents EyeGazeDirector, a novel gaze-based interface for autonomous camera control in virtual meetings. Our system uses machine learning-based gaze estimation to infer user attention and control camera movements, creating a more immersive and engaging experience. We evaluate EyeGazeDirector in a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in user satisfaction and engagement compared to traditional manual camera control.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Learning Models against Adversarial Attacks on Graph-Structured Data
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance on various graph-structured data tasks, but their robustness against adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. In this paper, we present a comprehensive analysis of the robustness of graph neural networks (GNNs) against different types of adversarial attacks, including node injection, edge perturbation, and feature manipulation. We propose a novel attack-agnostic defense mechanism, 'GraphShield', which leverages graph autoencoders to detect and correct adversarial perturbations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphShield in improving the robustness of GNNs against various adversarial attacks.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly popular, but their accessibility for people with disabilities remains a significant concern. This paper presents an empirical study on the design of accessible conversational interfaces for individuals with visual, hearing, motor, and cognitive disabilities. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with participants from diverse disability groups, identifying key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our findings inform the development of a novel framework, 'AccessibleChat', which incorporates personalized accommodations, multimodal input/output, and adaptive error correction. We evaluate the effectiveness of AccessibleChat through a usability study, demonstrating significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates for participants with disabilities.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but its accessibility remains a significant concern for users with disabilities. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for designing inclusive VR interfaces that cater to users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of user studies to identify key accessibility barriers and developed a set of guidelines for creating adaptable VR interfaces. Our proposed framework is evaluated through a case study of a VR-based educational application, demonstrating improved usability and user experience for users with disabilities.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is critical for achieving cooperative goals. This paper proposes a novel graph neural network (GNN) based approach for coordinated task allocation. Our method, called 'GNN-TA', represents the agent-task relationships as a graph and learns to predict the optimal task assignments through a graph-based attention mechanism. We evaluate GNN-TA on a simulated search and rescue scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our approach is scalable, flexible, and can be applied to a wide range of multi-agent domains.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Network-based Document Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on manual feature engineering and may not fully capture the semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep neural network-based document embeddings to improve retrieval performance. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of different document terms and phrases, enabling more accurate identification of relevant documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important in various applications, including financial analysis and IoT monitoring. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the high volume and velocity of incoming data. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning to optimize query execution plans in real-time data warehousing. We present a framework that uses a graph neural network to learn the query execution patterns and predict the optimal plan based on the workload characteristics. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate significant performance improvements compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Query Expansion via Adaptive Contextualized Embeddings for Improving Search Result Diversity
paper_abstract: Search engines often struggle to provide diverse results, particularly for ambiguous queries. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages adaptive contextualized embeddings to capture nuanced semantic relationships between terms. Our method, 'ACE-Expander', dynamically updates the embedding space based on the search context, enabling more effective identification of relevant and diverse documents. Experimental results on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate significant improvements in search result diversity and relevance, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multimodal Dialogue State Tracking
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a crucial component of multimodal conversational systems. Existing approaches struggle to effectively integrate visual and linguistic cues, leading to suboptimal performance. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HiGAT) that leverages both modalities to learn a comprehensive representation of the conversation state. HiGAT exploits the graph structure of the dialogue to model relationships between entities, intent, and slots, and incorporates multimodal attention to selectively focus on relevant input features. Experimental results on the DSTC8 benchmark demonstrate state-of-the-art performance, with significant gains over existing multimodal DST models.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Existing gesture recognition systems often neglect the needs of older adults with motor impairments, leading to decreased accessibility and user experience. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive gesture recognition systems, incorporating insights from gerontology, psychology, and human-computer interaction. We develop a set of guidelines for adapting gesture recognition algorithms to accommodate motor impairments, and evaluate our approach through a user study with 20 older adults with varying levels of mobility. Results show significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction, highlighting the potential for more inclusive and supportive interfaces.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Language Models for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems rely on effective query expansion techniques to improve retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages neural language models to generate high-quality expansion terms. Our method, dubbed NeuroQE, utilizes a masked language modeling objective to learn a dense representation of the query context. We demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms traditional query expansion methods, such as Rocchio and KL-divergence, on several benchmark datasets. Furthermore, we show that NeuroQE can be seamlessly integrated into existing search architectures, resulting in significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency with Hierarchical Indexing in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval systems face the challenge of efficiently processing complex queries across large-scale document collections. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical indexing approach, dubbed 'HierIndex', which leverages a combination of term frequency and document frequency to prune the search space. Our technique partitions the index into multiple layers, each optimized for a specific query type, enabling more efficient query routing and reducing the number of network hops. Experimental results on a large-scale web dataset demonstrate that HierIndex achieves a significant reduction in query latency and improves overall system throughput compared to traditional indexing methods.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus to answer a given question. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) architecture, 'PassageNet', for efficient passage retrieval. PassageNet represents the corpus as a hierarchical graph, where each node corresponds to a passage, and edges capture semantic relationships between them. We develop a neural ranking model that learns to traverse the graph, identifying the most relevant passages for a given question. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that PassageNet outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval methods, achieving a 12% improvement in passage retrieval accuracy while reducing computational cost by 30%.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Ranking Models using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in information retrieval tasks, but they often struggle with limited training data. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method that leverages pseudo-relevance feedback to improve the effectiveness of neural ranking models. Our approach, called 'PRF-Net', uses a neural network to predict the relevance of expansion terms and integrates them into the original query. We evaluate PRF-Net on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in ranking quality compared to traditional query expansion methods. Our analysis shows that PRF-Net is particularly effective in scenarios with limited training data, making it a promising approach for real-world IR applications.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents using Hierarchical Task Networks in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments face the challenge of coordinating their actions to achieve complex tasks. This paper presents a novel approach using Hierarchical Task Networks (HTNs) to coordinate multiple agents. We introduce a decentralized HTN framework that allows agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions and task requirements. Our approach leverages a hybrid planning technique that combines symbolic and geometric reasoning to generate coordinated plans. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving task completion rates and reducing agent collisions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years due to the need for transparency and trust in AI-driven decision-making. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention graph neural network (HAGNN) architecture that incorporates both item-level and user-level attention mechanisms to generate personalized explanations for recommended items. Our approach leverages graph-based representation learning to capture complex relationships between users and items, while the hierarchical attention module enables the identification of influential factors driving recommendation decisions. Experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in improving recommendation accuracy and providing insightful explanations.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Few-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has witnessed significant progress with the advent of meta-learning and attention mechanisms. However, the lack of explainability in these models hinders their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that integrates self-attention and class-attention mechanisms to provide interpretable few-shot classification. Our approach learns to selectively focus on relevant features and instances, generating attention maps that explain the model's predictions. Experimental results on mini-ImageNet and tiered-ImageNet datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in achieving state-of-the-art performance while providing transparent decision-making processes.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and vision, remains a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the need to model intricate relationships between modalities. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) architecture that leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture both intra- and inter-modality relationships. Experiments on the benchmark CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs, achieving a significant improvement in F1-score and correlation coefficient.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Neural Networks and Query Reformulation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to document ranking in information retrieval, leveraging the power of deep neural networks and query reformulation. Our proposed model, DeepRank, incorporates a query reformulation module that generates semantically similar queries to the original query, thereby expanding the search space and improving retrieval accuracy. We also introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of different query terms and document segments. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepRank significantly outperforms traditional ranking models and state-of-the-art neural ranking approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (MIR) systems often struggle to accurately capture the nuances of medical queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'MedExpan', which leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic relationships between medical concepts. MedExpan uses a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to learn a dense representation of medical queries and expand them with relevant terms. Experimental results on the TREC Medical Retrieval dataset show that MedExpan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, improving retrieval precision by up to 15% and recall by up to 20%.

title: Hierarchical Clustering-based Anomaly Detection for Time Series Data using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'HierarchicalGraphAD', which leverages the strengths of hierarchical clustering and graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to identify anomalies in time series data. We represent time series data as graphs and employ a hierarchical clustering algorithm to identify dense regions. Then, we use GCNs to learn a robust representation of the graph structure, which enables us to detect anomalies more effectively. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority of HierarchicalGraphAD over state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and efficiency.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Neural Networks for Knowledge Graph Construction
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph construction, as it resolves ambiguity in entity references. This paper proposes a novel graph-based neural network approach, 'GED-GNN', that leverages both local and global structural information to disambiguate entities efficiently. Our model combines a graph attention mechanism with a hierarchical clustering algorithm to identify clusters of similar entities. Experimental results on benchmark datasets show that GED-GNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and scalability, making it suitable for large-scale knowledge graph construction.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks: A Comprehensive Evaluation of Node Embedding Robustness
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have become increasingly popular for node classification tasks, but their robustness to adversarial attacks remains largely unexplored. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of the robustness of popular node embedding techniques, including GraphSAGE, GCN, and GIN, against various adversarial attack strategies. Our experiments on multiple benchmark datasets reveal that GNNs are vulnerable to targeted attacks, which can significantly degrade their performance. We also propose a novel defense mechanism based on adversarial training and graph purification, which demonstrates improved robustness against such attacks.

title: EyeGaze+: Enhancing Gaze-Based Interaction with Machine Learning-based Gaze Correction
paper_abstract: Gaze-based interaction has emerged as a promising modality for human-computer interaction, but accurate gaze estimation remains a significant challenge. This paper presents EyeGaze+, a novel framework that leverages machine learning to correct gaze errors in real-time. Our approach combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a Kalman filter to refine gaze estimates, achieving a mean absolute error reduction of 35% compared to state-of-the-art methods. We evaluate EyeGaze+ in a user study, demonstrating improved performance in gaze-based typing and selection tasks. The proposed framework has implications for enhancing accessibility and usability in various HCI applications.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Multimodal Approach for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their interaction modalities often exclude users with disabilities. This paper presents a novel, multimodal framework for designing inclusive voice assistants that accommodate diverse abilities. We combine computer vision, natural language processing, and gesture recognition to enable users to interact with voice assistants through a range of modalities, including speech, sign language, and gestures. Our user study with 30 participants with disabilities shows that our approach significantly improves interaction accuracy, efficiency, and overall user experience compared to traditional voice-only assistants.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of distributed database systems, as it directly impacts query performance and system scalability. This paper presents an adaptive query optimization framework, 'RL-Optimizer', that leverages reinforcement learning to dynamically adjust query plans based on real-time system metrics and query characteristics. Our approach integrates a deep Q-network with a novel reward function that balances query latency, resource utilization, and data freshness. Experimental results on a distributed database benchmark demonstrate that RL-Optimizer outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving up to 30% reduction in query latency and 25% improvement in system throughput.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to coordinate autonomous agents in task allocation. Our method, called 'Agent-Q', uses a decentralized, model-free Q-learning algorithm to enable agents to learn optimal task assignments based on their individual capabilities and environmental dynamics. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse management scenario demonstrate that Agent-Q significantly outperforms traditional, centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Gaze-based Adaptive Feedback for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has revolutionized various fields, but users often struggle with cognitive and motor skill demands. This paper introduces 'GazeGuide', a novel gaze-based adaptive feedback system that dynamically adjusts VR interactions to individual user needs. Our system utilizes machine learning-based gaze tracking and real-time performance assessment to provide personalized feedback, reducing user frustration and improving overall experience. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant gains in task completion speed and user satisfaction when using GazeGuide. The results have implications for VR-based training, education, and entertainment applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable success in node classification tasks, but often struggle with scalability and capturing complex graph structures. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN framework, 'HAGNet', which leverages a hierarchical clustering approach to decompose large graphs into smaller subgraphs. Our model employs attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant subgraphs and nodes, enabling more efficient learning and improved classification performance. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNet in node classification tasks, particularly in scenarios with large and complex graphs.

title: Decentralized Consensus Protocol for Multi-Agent Systems with Byzantine Fault Tolerance
paper_abstract: Distributed multi-agent systems require robust consensus protocols to ensure reliable decision-making in the presence of faulty or malicious agents. This paper proposes a novel decentralized consensus protocol, 'Byzantine-Resilient Consensus' (BRC), which achieves Byzantine fault tolerance without relying on a centralized authority. BRC employs a combination of digital signatures, threshold cryptography, and a probabilistic voting mechanism to detect and correct malicious behavior. We demonstrate the protocol's effectiveness through simulations on a large-scale agent network, showcasing its ability to maintain consensus even when up to 30% of agents are Byzantine faulty.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Task Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for distributed task allocation in smart grids. We model the problem as a decentralized Markov decision process, where each agent represents a microgrid and learns to allocate tasks to maximize overall efficiency and minimize energy losses. Our approach utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns its own policy and shares knowledge with neighbors to improve global performance. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid environment demonstrate significant improvements in task allocation efficiency and reduced energy losses compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Short-Text Retrieval using Neural Language Models
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval is a challenging task due to the limited context and ambiguity of user queries. This paper explores the application of neural language models to query expansion for improving retrieval effectiveness. We propose a novel approach, 'NeuroQE', which leverages the semantic capabilities of BERT to generate high-quality expansion terms. Our method adaptively selects relevant terms based on their contextual relevance and semantic similarity to the original query. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in precision and recall.

title: Emotional Intelligence-Based Affective Modeling for Personalized Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper presents an affective modeling framework that leverages emotional intelligence to enhance personalized human-computer interaction. Our approach combines multimodal sensing and machine learning to recognize users' emotional states and adapt the interaction accordingly. We conducted a user study with 50 participants and demonstrated that our framework improves user satisfaction and reduces frustration in emotionally charged tasks. The proposed model can be integrated into various HCI applications, such as virtual assistants, gaming, and mental health support systems.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous task allocation using graph-based reinforcement learning. We model the agent-task assignment as a graph, where agents and tasks are nodes, and edges represent compatibility and resource constraints. Our proposed algorithm, GraphAgent, leverages the graph structure to learn a policy that maximizes task completion while minimizing resource utilization. Experimental results on a set of simulated scenarios demonstrate that GraphAgent outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate and resource efficiency.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Relation Extraction with Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot relation extraction (FSRE) is a challenging task in natural language processing, where a model must learn to extract relevant relations from a few examples. This paper proposes a meta-learning approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn a relational representation space. Our model, MetaRel, uses episodic training to simulate FSRE tasks and adapt to new relations. We demonstrate that MetaRel outperforms state-of-the-art FSRE methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 12.5%. Our analysis shows that MetaRel's performance gain is attributed to its ability to capture complex relational patterns and generalize to unseen relations.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management systems require efficient decision-making in complex, dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARL-ATM', which leverages graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to facilitate cooperation among agents. We introduce a hierarchical reward structure that balances individual agent objectives with global system-level goals, enabling the framework to adapt to diverse traffic scenarios. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that MARL-ATM outperforms traditional reinforcement learning approaches in terms of traffic flow efficiency and reduced congestion.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Graph-based models have shown promise in information retrieval tasks, but scaling to large document collections remains a challenge. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Convolutional Networks (HGCN) for efficient document retrieval. HGCN leverages a hierarchical graph structure to capture semantic relationships between documents at multiple levels of abstraction. We propose a novel graph pooling mechanism that adaptively selects relevant nodes, reducing computational complexity while preserving retrieval accuracy. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HGCN outperforms state-of-the-art graph-based models in terms of mean average precision and query processing time.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Planning and Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems by integrating hierarchical planning and reinforcement learning. We propose a two-layer framework, where a high-level planner generates abstract plans that are then refined by a lower-level reinforcement learning agent. The hierarchical structure enables the agents to reason about long-term goals while adapting to dynamic environments. We evaluate our approach in a simulated robotic soccer domain, demonstrating improved coordination and task completion rates compared to existing methods. The proposed framework has applications in various multi-agent domains, such as autonomous vehicles, smart homes, and disaster response.

title: Hybrid Attention Network for Efficient Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) combines computer vision and natural language processing to analyze user opinions from images, text, and audio. Existing approaches often rely on separate modality-specific models, leading to increased computational costs and reduced accuracy. We propose a novel Hybrid Attention Network (HAN) that integrates modality-agnostic and modality-specific attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant inputs. HAN achieves state-of-the-art performance on three benchmark MSA datasets while reducing inference time by up to 30%. Our approach has significant implications for real-world applications, such as opinion mining and customer feedback analysis.

title: Deep Anomaly Detection in Time-Series Data using Graph-Based Attention Mechanisms
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is crucial in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. Existing methods often struggle with complex temporal dependencies and non-linear relationships. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach, 'GTAD', which leverages attention mechanisms to identify anomalies in time-series data. GTAD represents time-series data as graphs, enabling the capture of intricate relationships between data points. Our attention mechanism adaptively focuses on the most informative nodes, reducing false positives and improving detection accuracy. Experiments on three real-world datasets demonstrate GTAD's superiority over state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 12.5%.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Hop Reasoning
paper_abstract: Multi-hop reasoning is a fundamental aspect of human cognition, but existing AI models struggle to provide transparent and explainable reasoning processes. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel framework that leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between entities and reasoning paths. HGAT utilizes a hierarchical architecture to progressively refine attention weights, enabling the model to focus on relevant entities and relationships while ignoring irrelevant ones. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate HGAT's improved performance and interpretability in multi-hop reasoning tasks, making it a promising approach for building more transparent and trustworthy AI systems.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems via Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems face the challenge of efficiently processing queries across multiple nodes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'HiDir', which leverages a two-tiered index structure to reduce query latency and improve system scalability. We introduce a dynamic indexing scheme that adaptively partitions the index based on query workload patterns, resulting in significant reductions in query processing time and network communication overhead. Experimental evaluation on a large-scale DIR testbed demonstrates the effectiveness of HiDir in enhancing query efficiency and system throughput.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Multimodal Conversational AI using Graph-based Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of multimodal conversational AI systems has raised concerns about their vulnerability to adversarial attacks. This paper proposes a novel graph-based anomaly detection approach, 'GraphGuard', to identify suspicious input patterns in multimodal inputs. We leverage graph convolutional networks to model the relationships between modalities and detect anomalies in the graph structure. Experimental results on a dataset of conversational AI interactions demonstrate that GraphGuard achieves a detection accuracy of 95.2% and outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in identifying adversarial attacks.

title: Scalable Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Learning Models using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Hyperparameter tuning is a critical step in deep learning model development, but it can be computationally expensive and time-consuming. This paper proposes a scalable Bayesian optimization approach for hyperparameter tuning, leveraging a novel acquisition function that balances exploration and exploitation. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results in terms of model performance and tuning efficiency. Our method is particularly suitable for large-scale deep learning models and can be easily parallelized, making it an attractive solution for real-world applications.

title: Hybrid Agent-Based Framework for Real-Time Traffic Congestion Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hybrid agent-based framework for real-time traffic congestion management. Our approach integrates macroscopic traffic flow modeling with microscopic agent-based simulation, enabling the optimization of traffic signal control and routing decisions. We propose a decentralized coordination mechanism that leverages autonomous vehicle-to-infrastructure communication to adapt to changing traffic conditions. Experimental results using a large-scale traffic simulator demonstrate the effectiveness of our framework in reducing congestion and travel times, while improving overall network efficiency.

title: Scalable and Efficient Indexing for High-Dimensional Data in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases have revolutionized data processing by providing low-latency and high-throughput performance. However, indexing high-dimensional data in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel indexing approach, 'HDTree', which leverages the properties of main-memory databases to achieve scalable and efficient indexing for high-dimensional data. HDTree uses a hybrid indexing structure that combines the benefits of tree-based and hash-based indexing, resulting in improved query performance and reduced memory usage. Experimental evaluation on real-world datasets demonstrates that HDTree outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques in terms of query efficiency and scalability.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Haptic Feedback on Virtual Reality User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems have seen rapid advancements in recent years, but the impact of personalized haptic feedback on user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of a novel haptic feedback framework that incorporates user preferences, task requirements, and environmental factors. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, analyzing the effects of personalized haptic feedback on user engagement, task performance, and perceived realism. Results show that our framework significantly enhances user experience, with participants reporting higher levels of immersion and satisfaction compared to traditional, one-size-fits-all haptic feedback approaches.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) to understand agent interactions and decision-making processes. This paper introduces HGAT, a hierarchical graph attention network that learns to represent complex agent relationships and their impact on joint policy learning. HGAT leverages a novel hierarchical graph structure to capture both local and global dependencies among agents, and incorporates an attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions. Experimental results on a variety of MARL benchmarks demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both policy performance and explainability.

title: EyeGaze+: A Deep Learning-based Framework for Enhancing Eye-Tracking Accuracy in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Eye-tracking technology is crucial for immersive virtual reality (VR) experiences, but current systems suffer from accuracy limitations. This paper presents EyeGaze+, a novel deep learning-based framework that enhances eye-tracking accuracy in VR by leveraging multimodal fusion of eye movement, head pose, and scene context. We propose a hierarchical attention network that adaptively weighs the contributions of each modality to improve gaze estimation. Experimental evaluation on a large-scale VR dataset shows that EyeGaze+ outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 25% reduction in gaze error and enabling more precise foveated rendering.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has been widely employed in various AI applications, but existing methods suffer from limitations in handling complex graph structures and scalability issues. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for efficient KGE. HGAT leverages a hierarchical clustering approach to group entities into clusters, reducing the graph size while preserving critical structural information. We also introduce a graph attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant entities and relations during embedding. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Route Planning
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on efficient route planning to minimize travel time and energy consumption. This paper introduces a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, HRL-Route, that learns to optimize route planning by decomposing the problem into a hierarchical structure of tasks and sub-tasks. Our approach leverages a high-level task encoder to identify critical route segments and a low-level action decoder to generate optimal vehicle control signals. Experimental results on a large-scale traffic simulation dataset demonstrate that HRL-Route outperforms state-of-the-art route planning methods in terms of travel time, energy efficiency, and safety.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving system-level objectives. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) to optimize task assignments. Our approach, dubbed 'HierTask', enables agents to learn hierarchical policies that balance local and global objectives. We introduce a novel attention mechanism that facilitates information sharing among agents, leading to improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability. Experimental results on a simulated smart city scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of HierTask in reducing task completion times and increasing overall system utility.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular in modern data management systems. However, query optimization in such systems remains a challenging task due to the complexity of data distribution and communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach for query optimization in distributed databases. We model the database as a graph and leverage graph algorithms to identify optimal query execution plans. Our approach reduces the query optimization time by up to 50% compared to traditional methods, while maintaining comparable query performance. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in various distributed database settings.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents through Decentralized Multi-Objective Optimization
paper_abstract: Coordinating heterogeneous agents is a crucial challenge in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a decentralized optimization framework, 'DMAgent', that tackles this problem by formulating it as a decentralized multi-objective optimization problem. DMAgent employs a novel combination of distributed constraint optimization and multi-objective evolutionary algorithms to find Pareto-optimal solutions that balance individual agent objectives with global system performance. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of DMAgent in coordinating heterogeneous agents in a simulated smart grid scenario, achieving improved system efficiency and scalability compared to centralized optimization approaches.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we address the problem of distributed task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents have varying capabilities and task requirements. We propose a novel reinforcement learning-based approach, called HRL-TA, which learns to allocate tasks effectively by considering the agents' strengths, weaknesses, and task dependencies. Our approach leverages a hierarchical Q-network architecture to handle the complexities of large-scale systems. Experimental results on a variety of robotic task allocation scenarios demonstrate that HRL-TA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion efficiency and system adaptability.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Hierarchical Task Network Planning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems using Hierarchical Task Network (HTN) planning. We introduce a decentralized HTN framework, where each agent maintains a local plan and communicates with neighboring agents to resolve conflicts and achieve global goals. Our approach leverages a hierarchical representation of tasks to reduce the complexity of planning and improve scalability. Experimental results demonstrate that our method outperforms traditional centralized planning approaches in terms of planning time and solution quality, particularly in large-scale multi-agent systems.

title: Scalable Graph Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Graph query optimization is a crucial problem in modern database systems, particularly for large-scale graph databases. This paper introduces GRAphQL, a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize graph query execution plans. GRAphQL uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal join order and indexing strategy for a given query, taking into account the graph structure, data distribution, and query workload. Our experiments on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that GRAphQL outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of execution time and 2x in terms of memory usage.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of coordinated task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities need to be assigned to tasks with diverse requirements. We propose a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model the interaction between agents and tasks. Our method, called GraphAgent, learns a latent representation of the agent-task graph and optimizes task assignments using a decentralized, iterative refinement process. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that GraphAgent outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Large-scale Time Series Data using Deep Metric Learning
paper_abstract: Time series data has become increasingly prevalent in various domains, including IoT, finance, and healthcare. However, traditional clustering algorithms struggle to handle large-scale time series data due to high dimensionality and complexity. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering approach, 'DeepHCT', which leverages deep metric learning to learn a hierarchical representation of time series data. We introduce a novel triplet loss function that encourages the clustering model to learn a hierarchical structure, resulting in improved clustering quality and scalability. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of DeepHCT in comparison to state-of-the-art clustering algorithms.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Agent Teams using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous agent teams, where agents possess different capabilities and preferences. We propose a multi-agent reinforcement learning approach, called HAT-MARL, that learns to allocate tasks by minimizing a global objective function while respecting individual agent constraints. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and incorporates a novel attention-based mechanism to focus on the most critical agents in the team. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that HAT-MARL outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods and adapts to changing team compositions.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Interfaces for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder characterized by difficulty articulating words, often face significant barriers when interacting with voice-based interfaces. This paper presents a novel approach to designing accessible voice interfaces that accommodates the unique needs of users with dysarthria. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 20 participants with dysarthria, combining qualitative interviews with quantitative usability testing of a custom-built voice assistant. Our findings highlight the importance of adaptive speech recognition, personalized error correction, and multimodal feedback in enhancing the accessibility and user experience of voice interfaces for this population.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding for Multi-Modal Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-modal question answering (MMQA) has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing models often struggle to effectively integrate knowledge from diverse sources. We propose a novel knowledge graph embedding (KGE) method, 'MM-KGE', which jointly learns entity and relation representations from visual, textual, and structural modalities. Our approach leverages a multi-task learning framework to optimize KGE objectives across multiple datasets, resulting in improved MMQA performance. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of MM-KGE in capturing complex relationships between entities and answering multi-modal questions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Decision-Making in Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Autonomous systems increasingly rely on AI-driven decision-making, yet the lack of transparency and interpretability hinders trust and accountability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates attention mechanisms with explainability techniques to provide insights into the decision-making process. Our approach enables the identification of critical input features and their contributions to the output, facilitating the detection of biases and errors. Experimental evaluations on a real-world autonomous driving dataset demonstrate improved accuracy and explainability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in these systems. This paper presents a novel query optimization technique that leverages hierarchical indexing to reduce the number of data transfers between nodes. Our approach, called HiQO, uses a combination of vertical and horizontal partitioning to create a hierarchical index structure that enables efficient query processing. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HiQO achieves an average query latency reduction of 35% compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: Context-Aware Agent-based Framework for Adaptive Resource Allocation in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: Resource allocation is a crucial task in distributed systems, where agents must adapt to changing environmental conditions to optimize resource utilization. This paper proposes a novel context-aware agent-based framework, 'CAAR', which incorporates machine learning-based decision-making to allocate resources dynamically. CAAR agents learn from historical data and real-time sensor inputs to predict task demands, identify bottlenecks, and adjust resource allocations accordingly. Experimental results on a simulated distributed system demonstrate that CAAR achieves up to 30% improvement in resource utilization and 25% reduction in response time compared to traditional static allocation methods.

title: Designing Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Recognition and Cognitive Load
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, designing accessible interfaces for older adults becomes increasingly important. This paper investigates the impact of speech recognition technology on cognitive load in voice-based interfaces for older adults. We conducted a user study with 30 participants aged 65-85, comparing three interface designs: manual text input, speech-to-text with error correction, and speech-to-text without error correction. Our results show that speech recognition technology can significantly reduce cognitive load, but error correction mechanisms can introduce additional cognitive demands. We propose design guidelines for voice-based interfaces that balance speech recognition accuracy with cognitive load reduction.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Autonomous Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In complex dynamic environments, autonomous agents must adapt and collaborate to achieve shared goals. This paper presents a novel decentralized coalition formation algorithm, DCFA, which enables agents to form coalitions and allocate tasks efficiently. DCFA combines graph-based clustering with multi-agent reinforcement learning to optimize coalition structures and task assignments. We evaluate DCFA in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing centralized approaches. Our framework has applications in real-world domains such as search and rescue, smart cities, and autonomous transportation.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Conversational agents require accurate emotion recognition to provide empathetic and personalized responses. Existing approaches often rely on a single modality, such as speech or text, which can be limiting. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multimodal features from speech, text, and vision to recognize emotions in conversational agents. Our HAN model learns to attend to relevant modalities and time steps, improving emotion recognition accuracy and robustness. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by 12.5% in terms of F1-score.

title: Real-time Human-Robot Collaboration using Attention-based Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly interact with humans in shared workspaces, there is a growing need for efficient and safe collaboration strategies. This paper presents a novel attention-based multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'Attn-MARL', which enables real-time human-robot collaboration in complex tasks. By incorporating attention mechanisms to model human-robot interactions, our approach improves the efficiency and adaptability of collaboration policies. Experimental results on a robotic assembly task demonstrate that Attn-MARL outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion time and human satisfaction.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of relational databases, as it significantly impacts query performance. With the increasing adoption of distributed databases, traditional query optimization techniques are no longer effective. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning to optimize query plans in distributed relational databases. Our approach, called 'DistOpt', uses a graph neural network to model the query optimization problem and a reinforcement learning framework to learn an optimal query plan. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DistOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of distributed task allocation for autonomous agents in dynamic environments. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that enables agents to learn task allocation policies in a decentralized manner. The framework consists of a high-level planner that assigns tasks to agents and a low-level executor that adapts to changes in the environment. We evaluate our approach using a simulated search-and-rescue scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and agent utilization compared to traditional methods. Our results have implications for the deployment of autonomous agents in real-world applications.

title: Efficient Document Indexing with Hierarchical Clustering for Scalable Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Large-scale information retrieval (IR) systems require efficient document indexing methods to facilitate fast query processing. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering approach, 'HierIndex', which leverages the inherent structure of document collections to reduce indexing time and memory requirements. By recursively applying a density-based clustering algorithm, HierIndex creates a hierarchical index that adapts to the varying densities of the document space. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierIndex achieves significant speedups over traditional indexing methods while maintaining retrieval accuracy.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Learning Models using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Deep learning models are increasingly vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can have devastating consequences in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks using graph attention networks (GATs). By modeling the relationships between input features as a graph, our method leverages GATs to identify suspicious patterns in the input data. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting both white-box and black-box attacks. Our results show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art detection methods, achieving a high detection accuracy of 95.2% on the CIFAR-10 dataset.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for cooperative task allocation in dynamic environments. We propose a decentralized, communication-efficient approach that enables agents to learn task allocation strategies based on local observations and sparse rewards. Our method, called 'CoopTask', incorporates a hierarchical graph neural network to model agent interactions and a curriculum learning mechanism to adapt to changing environment conditions. Experimental results on a simulated Search-and-Rescue scenario demonstrate that CoopTask outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate and average reward.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Materialized Views in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Materialized views are crucial for real-time data analytics in distributed databases. However, maintaining up-to-date views in the presence of frequent updates and inserts poses significant performance challenges. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'HyperTree', which exploits the hierarchical structure of distributed databases to efficiently maintain materialized views. HyperTree leverages a combination of in-memory caching and disk-based storage to minimize query latency and reduce update overhead. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database setup demonstrate that HyperTree outperforms existing indexing approaches by up to 30% in terms of query response time and 25% in terms of update throughput.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Decentralized Edge Computing
paper_abstract: Decentralized edge computing has emerged as a promising paradigm for reducing latency and improving quality of service in IoT applications. However, efficient resource allocation remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes an autonomous agent-based framework, 'EdgeAgent', which leverages multi-agent systems and distributed constraint optimization to dynamically allocate resources in decentralized edge computing environments. We demonstrate the efficacy of EdgeAgent in reducing latency and improving resource utilization through simulations on a real-world smart city scenario.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Partitioning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query performance remains a significant bottleneck in DDS. This paper proposes an adaptive partitioning strategy, 'APart', which dynamically re-partitions data based on query patterns and workload changes. APart leverages a novel cost model that considers both data distribution and query access patterns to optimize query performance. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that APart achieves an average query performance improvement of 30% compared to traditional fixed-partitioning schemes.

title: Autonomous Agent Coordination for Real-time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a distributed multi-agent system for real-time traffic management in smart cities. We propose a novel coordination mechanism based on decentralized partially observable Markov decision processes (DEC-POMDPs), which enables autonomous agents to adapt to dynamic traffic conditions and optimize traffic flow. Our approach integrates real-time data from various sources, including sensor networks, traffic cameras, and social media, to improve traffic signal control and reduce congestion. Experimental results using a simulated traffic network demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing travel times and increasing traffic throughput.

title: Autonomous Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often involve autonomous agents negotiating with each other to achieve mutually beneficial outcomes. This paper explores the application of deep reinforcement learning to develop negotiation strategies for autonomous agents. We propose a novel framework, 'DeepNegotiate', which utilizes a deep Q-network to learn effective negotiation policies. Experimental results demonstrate that DeepNegotiate outperforms traditional negotiation strategies in various scenarios, including auctions and bilateral negotiations. We also analyze the robustness of our approach against different opponent types and negotiation protocols.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has transformed the way we interact with virtual objects, but current input methods, such as voice commands or manual gestures, have limitations. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system for AR using deep learning. Our approach leverages convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to classify gaze patterns and detect user intentions. We introduce a new gaze dataset and demonstrate the effectiveness of our system in various AR scenarios, including object selection and manipulation. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and user experience.

title: Designing Gamified Interfaces for Enhancing User Engagement in Smart Home Systems
paper_abstract: Smart home systems have become increasingly popular, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a gamification framework, 'SmartPlay', that leverages persuasive design principles to encourage users to adopt energy-efficient behaviors. We conducted a 6-week user study with 30 participants, demonstrating that SmartPlay increases user interaction by 35% and energy savings by 22% compared to traditional interfaces. Our results also show that personalized feedback and social norms-based incentives are key factors in promoting sustained user engagement.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines face the challenge of retrieving relevant products from vast catalogs. Query expansion techniques can improve retrieval effectiveness, but often incur significant computational costs. This paper proposes a hierarchical query expansion framework, 'HQE', which leverages product category hierarchies to selectively expand queries. HQE combines a category-based query expansion method with a relevance-based filtering approach, reducing the number of expanded queries while maintaining retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that HQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of both retrieval effectiveness and computational efficiency.

title: Gaze-Guided Adaptive Difficulty Adjustment for Intelligent Tutoring Systems
paper_abstract: Intelligent tutoring systems (ITSs) have been shown to be effective in personalized learning, but often struggle to adapt to individual students' abilities.
