This paper presents a novel gaze-guided approach to adaptive difficulty adjustment in ITSs. We develop a machine learning model that leverages gaze data from eye-tracking devices to infer a student's confidence and comprehension, and adjusts the difficulty of subsequent questions accordingly. Our user study with 40 students demonstrates that the proposed approach leads to improved learning outcomes, increased engagement, and reduced frustration. The results have implications for the design of more effective and human-centered ITSs.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Anthropomorphic Design on User Trust in Conversational Interfaces
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces are increasingly prevalent, but their anthropomorphic design can influence user trust. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the effects of anthropomorphic design elements (e.g., avatars, personas) on user trust in conversational interfaces. We conducted a between-subjects experiment with 120 participants, analyzing their interactions with and perceptions of two chatbot prototypes: a minimalist, functional design and an anthropomorphized design. Results show that users perceive anthropomorphized chatbots as more trustworthy, but this effect is mitigated by users' prior experience with conversational interfaces. We discuss implications for HCI designers and provide recommendations for balancing anthropomorphism with user trust.

title: Hierarchical Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Explainable reinforcement learning (XRL) is crucial for trustworthy autonomous vehicle decision-making. This paper proposes 'HierXRL', a hierarchical framework that integrates XRL with deep reinforcement learning to improve transparency and interpretability in complex driving scenarios. Our approach involves (1) feature importance-based attention, (2) hierarchical abstraction of state and action spaces, and (3) model-based reinforcement learning. We evaluate HierXRL on a realistic driving simulator and demonstrate improved explainability, safety, and overall performance compared to state-of-the-art XRL methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: An Empirical Study on Dialogue Flow and Cognition
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents an empirical study examining the impact of dialogue flow and cognition on the usability of conversational systems for older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants aged 65+, exploring the effects of varying dialogue structures and cognitive load on task completion rates, user satisfaction, and mental workload. Our results highlight the importance of designing conversational interfaces that accommodate age-related cognitive changes, and provide guidelines for improving the accessibility and inclusivity of these systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly used in modern data-intensive applications, but optimizing queries in these systems remains a complex task. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query execution times. Our approach, called 'RL-QO', uses a combination of exploration-exploitation strategies to adapt to changing database workloads and optimize query performance. Experimental results on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that RL-QO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning with graph neural networks (GNNs) has shown great promise in various applications. However, the vulnerability of these systems to adversarial attacks remains largely unexplored. This paper investigates targeted attacks on multi-agent systems, where an adversary manipulates the graph structure or node features to compromise the learning process. We propose a novel attack method, 'GraphFool', which leverages the graph topology to identify influential agents and craft customized perturbations. Our results demonstrate that GraphFool can significantly degrade the performance of the victim agents, highlighting the need for robustness measures in multi-agent reinforcement learning.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Large-Scale Social Networks
paper_abstract: Node classification in large-scale social networks is a challenging task due to the complexity of graph structures and the scarcity of labeled data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that leverages both local and global graph features to improve node classification accuracy. Our approach employs a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively selects relevant nodes and graph features at multiple scales, enabling the model to capture complex dependencies and relationships in the graph. Experimental results on several real-world social network datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAN in achieving state-of-the-art performance on node classification tasks.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Reasoning for Multi-Agent Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems have made significant strides with the integration of AI models, but their lack of transparency hinders human trust. This paper proposes 'HARE', a novel hierarchical attention-based framework for explainable reasoning in multi-agent dialogue systems. HARE employs a cognitive graph-based architecture to model agent interactions, incorporating attention mechanisms to identify salient context elements. We demonstrate that HARE outperforms state-of-the-art models in generating coherent and interpretable dialogue responses, while providing explicit explanations for its reasoning process. Our approach has far-reaching implications for deploying trustworthy AI systems in real-world applications.

title: EmoTract: Affective State Modeling for Personalized Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper introduces EmoTract, a novel affective state modeling framework for human-computer interaction. EmoTract leverages multimodal sensor data from physiological and facial expression sensors to infer users' emotional states in real-time. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical Bayesian network that captures the dynamics of affective states and their influence on user behavior. We evaluate EmoTract in a user study, demonstrating its ability to accurately predict user frustration and adapt the interaction to mitigate negative emotional responses. The results show improved user experience and task performance, highlighting the potential of EmoTract for personalized HCI.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents using deep reinforcement learning. We formulate the task allocation problem as a Markov decision process and employ a multi-agent deep Q-network (MA-DQN) to learn optimal allocation strategies. Our approach enables agents to adapt to changing task requirements and agent capabilities in real-time, without relying on a centralized controller. Experimental results on a simulated robotics environment demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized allocation methods.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in ad-hoc retrieval, but its effectiveness is often hindered by the ambiguity of query terms. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages context-aware embeddings to disambiguate query terms and generate more informative expansion terms. Our method, ContextExp, incorporates a graph-based attention mechanism to capture the contextual relationships between query terms and their surrounding words. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that ContextExp significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving an average improvement of 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Adaptive Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. We propose a novel adaptive auction-based mechanism, 'AdaAuction', which enables agents to dynamically adjust their bidding strategies based on real-time observations of the environment. Our approach leverages a probabilistic graphical model to capture agent interactions and incorporates a feedback loop to refine task assignments. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that AdaAuction outperforms existing decentralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and system adaptability.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI-based Malware Detection
paper_abstract: The increasing sophistication of malware has rendered traditional detection methods ineffective. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) for explainable AI-based malware detection. HGAT leverages graph neural networks to model the complex relationships between system calls and API calls, and incorporates attention mechanisms to focus on relevant features. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art detection performance on the Malware Benchmark dataset, while providing interpretable explanations for the detected malware. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in identifying novel, zero-day malware samples.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Recognition and Error Mitigation
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but their adoption among older adults is hindered by difficulties in speech recognition and error mitigation. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop an inclusive voice assistant tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a series of interviews and usability studies to identify the key challenges and preferences of this demographic. Our proposed system incorporates a novel speech recognition algorithm that leverages acoustic models adapted to the speech patterns of older adults. We also introduce an error mitigation strategy that utilizes visual and tactile feedback to facilitate corrections. Our evaluation results show significant improvements in speech recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel auction-based mechanism for cooperative task allocation in multi-agent systems. Our approach leverages the concept of combinatorial auctions to efficiently allocate tasks to agents while minimizing communication overhead and ensuring system-wide optimality. We introduce a decentralized auction protocol that allows agents to bid on tasks based on their capabilities and preferences, and develop a novel pricing scheme to incentivize truthful bidding. Experimental results demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in various multi-agent domains, including search and rescue, and surveillance tasks.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Multimodal Interaction for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their accessibility for users with disabilities remains a significant concern. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop multimodal interfaces for voice assistants that cater to diverse abilities. We conducted co-design workshops with users with visual, hearing, motor, and cognitive disabilities to identify key interaction challenges and opportunities. Our findings inform the design of an inclusive voice assistant prototype that incorporates text-based input, gesture recognition, and personalized accessibility features. A usability study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in user satisfaction and task completion rates compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coordinated exploration is crucial for efficient task allocation and planning. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical graph attention mechanism, 'HGA-MAS', which enables agents to selectively focus on relevant nodes in the environment graph. HGA-MAS combines graph convolutional neural networks with attention weights learned through reinforcement learning. Experimental results in a simulated warehouse robotics scenario demonstrate that HGA-MAS outperforms existing methods in terms of exploration efficiency and task completion rate, especially in large-scale and dynamic environments.

title: Multi-Modal Retrieval with Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Efficient Image-Text Search
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art image-text search systems rely on computationally expensive cross-modal embeddings, limiting their scalability. This paper proposes a novel multi-modal retrieval framework, 'HiGRMN', which leverages hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs) to efficiently capture fine-grained relationships between images and text. By modeling visual and textual features as interconnected graphs, HiGRMN achieves significant improvements in retrieval accuracy while reducing computational overhead by 30%. Experimental results on the COCO dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in real-world image-text search applications.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies in Partially Observable Environments
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive results in various domains, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its reliability in safety-critical applications. This paper investigates the robustness of DRL policies in partially observable environments, where the agent observes only a subset of the true state. We propose a novel attack framework, 'POE-Attack', which crafts perturbations to the observation space, misleading the agent into taking suboptimal actions. Our experiments on several benchmark domains demonstrate that POE-Attack significantly degrades the performance of state-of-the-art DRL algorithms, highlighting the need for robustification techniques in real-world deployments.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Context-Aware Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but traditional methods often struggle to capture the nuanced semantics of user queries. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages context-aware semantic embeddings to enrich query representations. We introduce a graph-based model that incorporates both local and global context, enabling more accurate identification of relevant terms and expansion of the query scope. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, particularly for complex, multi-faceted queries.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems (MTDS) have become increasingly popular in cloud-based services, but optimizing query performance across multiple tenants remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize query plans in MTDS. We design a DRL agent that learns to navigate the complex query optimization space, taking into account tenant-specific workload characteristics and system resource constraints. Experimental results on a real-world MTDS benchmark show that our approach achieves an average query latency reduction of 35% compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers.

title: Dynamic Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving system-level goals. This paper proposes a novel approach to dynamic task allocation using Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs). Our method, 'AgentGCN', models agent interactions as a graph and learns to allocate tasks by predicting the optimal assignment of agents to tasks based on their capabilities, availability, and communication constraints. We evaluate AgentGCN on a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional optimization-based approaches.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system for virtual reality (VR) applications, leveraging deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to predict user intentions. Our approach, dubbed 'GazeRL', uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to process raw gaze data and a DRL agent to learn a policy for selecting interactions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GazeRL in a VR game environment, achieving a 32% reduction in interaction time and a 25% increase in user satisfaction compared to traditional gaze-based methods. The proposed system has far-reaching implications for VR applications in gaming, education, and healthcare.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Scalable Unsupervised Representation Learning
paper_abstract: Unsupervised representation learning has become a crucial component of many machine learning pipelines. However, existing methods often struggle with scalability, particularly when dealing with high-dimensional data. This paper presents 'Hierarchical ClusterNet', a novel approach that leverages hierarchical clustering to efficiently learn representations from large datasets. Our method iteratively applies k-means clustering to subspaces of the input data, generating a hierarchical representation that captures complex patterns and structures. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that Hierarchical ClusterNet outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of representation quality, while reducing computational overhead by up to 75%.

title: Scalable Explanations for Deep Reinforcement Learning via Model-agnostic Attribution
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) models have achieved remarkable successes in complex decision-making tasks, but their opacity hinders trust and understanding. This paper presents 'AttribuRL', a model-agnostic attribution framework for explaining DRL policies. By recursively applying feature importance measures, AttribuRL generates human-interpretable explanations for state-action pairs, facilitating error analysis and policy improvement. We evaluate AttribuRL on several Atari games and a real-world robotics task, demonstrating its scalability and ability to identify actionable insights.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Urban traffic management is a complex problem that requires coordinating multiple agents, such as traffic lights and autonomous vehicles, to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to train a decentralized multi-agent system. We design a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that enables agents to learn cooperative policies and adapt to changing traffic conditions. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional traffic signal control methods, achieving a 25% reduction in travel time and a 30% decrease in congestion.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decision-making often involves complex interactions and dependencies among agents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture to enable explainable decision-making in such systems. Our approach learns to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions, generating interpretable attention weights that reveal the underlying causal relationships. We evaluate our method on a variety of multi-agent domains, demonstrating improved decision-making performance and providing insights into the decision-making process. Our framework has potential applications in autonomous systems, smart grids, and other real-world domains.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Learning Models using Bayesian Optimization with Transfer Learning
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their hyperparameter tuning remains a challenging and time-consuming task. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian optimization framework that leverages transfer learning to adapt the search space of hyperparameters. Our approach, 'HyperTL', uses a surrogate model pre-trained on a large dataset to warm-start the search process, reducing the number of evaluations required to find optimal hyperparameters. We demonstrate the efficacy of HyperTL on several benchmark datasets, showing significant speedups and improved model performance compared to existing Bayesian optimization methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: Column-oriented NoSQL databases have gained popularity in big data analytics due to their ability to handle high-dimensional data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in these systems. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework that leverages statistical modeling and machine learning techniques to identify optimal query plans. Our approach, called COOP, uses a combination of histogram-based statistical modeling and reinforcement learning to learn from query patterns and adapt to changing data distributions. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that COOP achieves up to 3x performance improvement over state-of-the-art query optimizers.

title: Optimizing Query Workloads with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are critical for modern data-intensive applications, but optimizing query workloads remains a challenging problem. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize query execution plans in DDS. Our proposed framework, 'QueryOpt', uses a hybrid DRL architecture that combines a graph neural network with a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query execution strategy. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that QueryOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, reducing query latency by up to 35% and improving resource utilization by up to 25%

title: Designing Visuospatial Tactile Feedback for Enhanced Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on gesture recognition to enable immersive interactions. However, the lack of tactile feedback can lead to reduced accuracy and user frustration. This paper explores the design of visuospatial tactile feedback to enhance gesture recognition in VR. We propose a novel framework that integrates vibrotactile cues with visual and auditory feedback to improve gesture recognition. Our user study shows that the proposed framework increases gesture recognition accuracy by 23% compared to traditional visual-based recognition methods. Furthermore, participants reported a significant reduction in cognitive load and improved overall VR experience.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalization on User Experience in Voice-Based Interfaces
paper_abstract: The proliferation of voice-based interfaces (VBIs) has led to a growing interest in personalization techniques that tailor the interaction experience to individual users. This paper presents a comprehensive study investigating the effects of personalization on user experience in VBIs. We designed a controlled experiment with 120 participants, exposing them to either personalized or non-personalized VBI interactions. Our results show that personalization significantly improves user satisfaction, reduces error rates, and enhances overall usability. We also identify key factors influencing personalization effectiveness, including user familiarity with VBIs and individual differences in communication styles.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Context-Aware Embedding for Search Engines
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique to improve the retrieval effectiveness of search engines. However, traditional methods often rely on manual rules or simplistic statistical models, which may not capture the semantic relationships between query terms and documents. This paper proposes a novel context-aware embedding approach, dubbed 'CAQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to learn dense vector representations of query terms and documents. By incorporating contextual information from the query and document collections, CAQE can adaptively generate expansion terms that better match the user's search intent. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that CAQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval precision and recall.

title: Indexing Techniques for Efficient Query Processing in Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex data relationships. However, query processing remains a significant bottleneck due to the inherent complexity of graph traversals. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, GraphAxis, which leverages a combination of graph summarization and axis-based partitioning to accelerate query execution. We introduce a cost-based optimization framework that adaptively selects the most efficient indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distributions. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that GraphAxis outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 3x in query response time.

title: Designing Adaptive Feedback Mechanisms for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various domains, but its adoption is often hindered by accessibility barriers. This paper presents a novel framework for designing adaptive feedback mechanisms that cater to diverse user needs and abilities in VR environments. We introduce a machine learning-based approach that integrates physiological and behavioral metrics to detect user discomfort, anxiety, or fatigue, and subsequently adjusts the feedback modalities to ensure a more inclusive and comfortable experience. Our user study involving participants with varying abilities demonstrates the efficacy of our approach in enhancing user satisfaction and reducing simulator sickness.

title: Hierarchical Task Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Planning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent planning has numerous applications in real-world domains, but the lack of transparency in decision-making processes hinders trust and adoption. This paper presents a novel approach to explainable multi-agent planning using Hierarchical Task Networks (HTNs). We introduce a new HTN framework that integrates symbolic planning with probabilistic reasoning, enabling agents to generate hierarchical plans with explicit justifications. Our approach is evaluated on a set of benchmark problems, demonstrating improved explainability and plan quality compared to existing methods. The proposed framework has significant implications for the development of transparent and trustworthy AI systems in multi-agent settings.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion is a crucial step in this process, as it aims to reformulate the original query to better capture the user's intent. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach to query expansion, dubbed 'QNexus', which leverages the strengths of neural networks in learning semantic relationships between words. QNexus uses a dual-encoder architecture to learn query and document representations, and then generates an expanded query through a generative process. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QNexus outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness.

title: Optimizing Join Order Enumeration with Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of distributed database systems. However, the join order enumeration problem remains a significant bottleneck due to its inherent complexity. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize join order enumeration. We design a deep Q-network that learns to navigate the exponentially large search space of possible join orders, guided by a reward function that balances query execution time and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving an average speedup of 2.5x on complex queries.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Hierarchical Indexing in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems are increasingly used to index and query large-scale document collections. However, query performance remains a major bottleneck due to the high latency and bandwidth requirements of traditional indexing methods. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'HierIndex', which leverages a multi-level tree structure to efficiently prune the search space and reduce query latency. Our experimental evaluation on a large-scale text corpus demonstrates that HierIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 30% in terms of query throughput and 25% in terms of average query latency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Convolutional Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained increasing attention in recent years, as they provide transparency into the decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention graph convolutional network (HAGCN) model that leverages both user-item interactions and item attributes to generate personalized explanations. Our approach utilizes a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant user and item features, and a graph convolutional network to capture complex relationships between items. Experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate that HAGCN outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cyber-Physical Systems
paper_abstract: Cyber-physical systems (CPS) require efficient task allocation to ensure real-time performance and reliability. This paper proposes a multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for distributed task allocation in CPS. Our approach, called MARL-TA, leverages decentralized decision-making and coordination among agents to optimize task assignment. We introduce a novel reward function that incorporates system-level performance metrics, such as latency and energy consumption. Experimental results on a case study of a smart manufacturing system demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of adaptability and scalability.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents with Emotion Regulation for Mental Health Support
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have shown promise in mental health support, but their emotional expressions can significantly impact user trust and engagement. This paper presents an ECA framework that incorporates emotion regulation mechanisms, enabling the agent to recognize and adapt to users' emotional states. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, demonstrating that our ECA's empathetic responses and emotional regulation strategies improve user self-disclosure and perceived support. The findings have implications for the design of ECAs in mental health interventions, highlighting the importance of emotional intelligence in human-agent interaction.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Gamification in Reducing Cognitive Load for Elderly Users
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, designing accessible and user-friendly interfaces for elderly users becomes increasingly important. This study investigates the role of gamification in reducing cognitive load for older adults when interacting with digital systems. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment with 30 participants aged 65-85, examining the impact of gamification elements on cognitive load, user engagement, and task performance. Our results show that gamification significantly decreases cognitive load and improves user experience, particularly for tasks requiring working memory and attention. We discuss the implications for HCI design principles and guidelines tailored to the needs of elderly users.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Gesture-Based Authentication in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, ensuring secure authentication mechanisms is crucial. This paper investigates the efficacy of gesture-based authentication in VR environments. We designed a user study to evaluate the performance of a gesture-recognition system using a custom-built VR platform. Our results show that gesture-based authentication can achieve high accuracy (>90%) and robustness against spoofing attacks. We also identify key factors influencing user performance, including gesture complexity and feedback modalities. The findings of this study have implications for the development of secure and user-friendly authentication systems in VR applications.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column-Store Indexing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important in today's fast-paced business environment. However, optimizing queries for low-latency execution remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using column-store indexing, tailored to the specific needs of real-time data warehousing. Our method, 'RTOpt', efficiently identifies the most critical columns and leverages a hybrid indexing strategy to minimize query execution time. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that RTOpt reduces query latency by up to 75% compared to traditional row-store indexing, making it suitable for real-time analytics and reporting applications.

title: Designing Accessible Conversation Agents for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, designing conversation agents that cater to older adults with cognitive impairments is crucial. This paper presents a user-centered approach to developing accessible conversation agents, focusing on individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI). We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults with MCI, identifying key design requirements and preferences. Our findings inform the development of a novel conversation agent, 'CareChat', which incorporates cognitive support features, such as visual cues, simplified language, and memory aids. A pilot evaluation of CareChat with 20 participants shows significant improvements in user engagement and comprehension compared to traditional conversation agents.

title: AdaBoost-Enhanced Deep Reinforcement Learning for Robotics
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to deep reinforcement learning (DRL) for robotics, leveraging AdaBoost to improve exploration and exploitation in complex, high-dimensional state spaces. Our method, dubbed 'AdaRL', adaptively combines the strengths of multiple DRL agents, each with distinct exploration strategies, to achieve better overall performance and robustness. Experimental results on a robotic arm manipulation task demonstrate that AdaRL outperforms state-of-the-art DRL methods, achieving higher success rates and faster learning convergence.

title: Designing Emotion-Aware Conversational Interfaces for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but their accessibility for people with disabilities remains a significant concern. This paper presents an emotion-aware conversational interface, 'EmpathyChat', designed to accommodate users with disabilities. We incorporate affective computing techniques to detect and respond to users' emotions, and develop a personalized interaction model that adapts to individual communication preferences. A user study with 30 participants with disabilities demonstrates that EmpathyChat significantly improves user satisfaction and reduces anxiety compared to traditional conversational interfaces.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Enhancing User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the potential of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in enhancing user experience in VR. We present 'VR-Chatty', a novel ECA framework that leverages multimodal sensing and machine learning to recognize and respond to user emotions, gestures, and voice commands. Our user study (N=60) demonstrates that VR-Chatty significantly increases user engagement, sense of presence, and overall satisfaction in VR applications compared to traditional text-based interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Convolutional Networks for Skeleton-Based Action Recognition
paper_abstract: Skeleton-based action recognition has garnered significant attention in recent years due to its applications in healthcare, surveillance, and human-computer interaction. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Graph Convolutional Network (HAGCN) architecture that leverages the hierarchical structure of skeleton data to improve action recognition performance. Our approach incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to capture informative joint interactions and contextual relationships. Experimental results on the NTU-RGB+D and PKU-MMD datasets demonstrate that HAGCN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average accuracy of 95.2% and 92.5%, respectively.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Semi-Supervised Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in node classification tasks, but often rely on abundant labeled data. In this paper, we propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for semi-supervised node classification. HGAT leverages attention mechanisms to selectively aggregate features from neighboring nodes and captures hierarchical graph structures through a recursive attention framework. We evaluate HGAT on several real-world graph datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in node classification accuracy compared to state-of-the-art semi-supervised GNNs.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Neural Ranking Models with Adaptive Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems rely on hand-crafted features and ranking models, which often struggle to capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel deep neural ranking model, 'ADAPTQR', which leverages adaptive query expansion to improve document retrieval performance. Our approach integrates a query-aware document encoder with a hierarchical attention mechanism, allowing the model to focus on relevant contextual information and iteratively refine the query representation. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of ADAPTQR, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Older adults with motor impairments face significant barriers when interacting with modern computing systems. This paper presents a novel gesture-based interface designed to improve accessibility for this demographic. We conducted a participatory design process with 15 older adults, resulting in a set of intuitive gestures that accommodate motor limitations. Our interface, 'EasyReach', utilizes machine learning-based gesture recognition and provides real-time feedback to assist users. A usability study with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional mouse-based interactions.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Dense Passage Representations
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant passages from a large corpus that contain the answer to a given question. This paper presents a novel approach to passage retrieval using dense passage representations, which enables fast and accurate similarity search. We propose a hierarchical clustering-based method to index passages and a neural ranking model to re-rank the retrieved passages. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent systems have numerous applications in real-world domains such as robotics, smart cities, and disaster response. However, efficient task allocation in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel decentralized task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to enable agents to learn optimal allocation strategies. Our approach, 'MA-RL-TA', uses a multi-agent Q-learning algorithm to adapt to dynamic task requirements and agent capabilities. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that MA-RL-TA outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Designing Emotionally Expressive Avatars for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize social interactions, but current avatar designs often lack emotional expressiveness, limiting users' sense of presence and connection. This paper presents a novel approach to designing emotionally expressive avatars that incorporate subtle, culturally-informed facial cues and body language. We conducted a user study with 120 participants from diverse cultural backgrounds, demonstrating that our avatars enhance emotional understanding, empathy, and social bonding in VR interactions. Our findings have implications for the design of inclusive, culturally-sensitive VR experiences that promote social connection and well-being.

title: Accelerating SQL Query Optimization with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing SQL queries is a crucial task in relational databases, as it significantly impacts query performance. Existing optimization techniques rely on hand-crafted heuristics or exhaustive search, which can be inefficient and suboptimal. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepQOpt', that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn an optimal query optimization policy. Our method uses a graph neural network to represent the query plan space and a deep Q-network to learn the optimal policy. Experimental results on a diverse set of benchmark queries demonstrate that DeepQOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers, achieving an average speedup of 2.5x over the baseline.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) remains a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotional expressions. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that leverages both local and global attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. Our approach enables explainable emotion recognition by generating attention-based visualizations of the decision-making process. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in achieving state-of-the-art performance while providing insights into the emotional cues utilized by the model.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search for Real-time Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Real-time object detection is a critical component of autonomous vehicle systems. However, the computational requirements of state-of-the-art detectors hinder their deployment on resource-constrained embedded platforms. This paper proposes a novel neural architecture search (NAS) framework, 'AutoDet', which leverages reinforcement learning to efficiently search for detector architectures that optimize accuracy and latency. We introduce a hierarchical search space that incorporates domain knowledge from computer vision and a novel reward function that balances accuracy and computational cost. Experimental results on the KITTI object detection benchmark demonstrate that AutoDet discovers detectors that achieve superior accuracy to hand-crafted models while meeting real-time latency constraints.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings with Hierarchical Relation Attention
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have become a crucial component in various AI applications, but existing methods often struggle to capture complex relational structures. In this paper, we propose a novel hierarchical relation attention mechanism, 'HieraRel', which learns to selectively focus on relevant relations at different abstraction levels. Our approach leverages a graph neural network to encode entity representations and a hierarchical attention module to weigh relation importance. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HieraRel outperforms state-of-the-art methods in link prediction, entity classification, and question answering tasks.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gestural Interfaces for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles in virtual reality (VR) to design more intuitive and engaging gestural interfaces. We conducted a user study to investigate how embodied cognition affects user experience and performance in VR-based tasks. Our results show that incorporating embodied cognition principles in VR interfaces leads to improved user satisfaction, reduced cognitive load, and enhanced overall experience. We propose a framework for designing embodied cognition-based VR interfaces and discuss the implications for HCI research and applications.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Transactional Support for Real-Time Analytics in Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics on large-scale datasets necessitate low-latency and high-throughput processing. Modern main-memory database systems (MMDBs) offer promising solutions, but their transactional support remains a bottleneck. This paper presents 'RTTx', a novel transactional framework for MMDBs that leverages adaptive concurrency control and speculative execution to minimize latency and abort rates. Our evaluation on a real-world financial dataset demonstrates that RTTx outperforms state-of-the-art MMDB systems by up to 3x in transactional throughput while maintaining strong consistency and durability guarantees.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Document-Oriented Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed document-oriented databases (DDODBs) have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large amounts of semi-structured data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in these systems. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'DocOpt', which leverages a combination of statistical analysis and machine learning techniques to efficiently optimize queries in DDODBs. Our approach utilizes a cost-based model to estimate the execution time of alternative query plans and selects the most efficient one. Experimental results on a large-scale DDODB benchmark demonstrate that DocOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Neural Embeddings for Scientific Literature Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it directly affects the quality of retrieved documents. This paper proposes a novel neural embedding-based approach to query expansion, specifically designed for scientific literature retrieval. Our method, NEQE, leverages a combination of word and document embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms and expand the query with relevant synonyms and related concepts. Experimental results on the CiteSeerX dataset demonstrate that NEQE outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, improving retrieval precision by 15% and recall by 20%.

title: Exploring Embodiment in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction in Collaborative Design
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent in design and collaboration, it is essential to understand the role of embodiment in shaping user experience. This paper presents a study on gesture-based interaction in collaborative design, examining how users' bodily gestures influence their perception of virtual objects and interaction with co-designers. Our findings suggest that embodied interaction enhances spatial awareness, reduces cognitive load, and fosters more effective collaboration. We propose a novel framework for integrating embodiment into VR-based design tools, highlighting the potential for more immersive and effective design experiences.

title: Gaze-based Interaction for Virtual Reality: A Study on User Experience and Performance
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has seen significant advancements in recent years, but user interaction remains a major bottleneck. This paper explores the use of gaze-based interaction as a novel modality for VR. We designed and implemented a gaze-driven interface for manipulating virtual objects and conducted a user study to evaluate its effectiveness. Our results show that gaze-based interaction can improve user experience and performance in VR tasks, particularly for users with motor impairments. We also identify key challenges and opportunities for future research in this area, including the need for more accurate and robust gaze-tracking algorithms.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: With the exponential growth of digital data, efficient document retrieval has become a critical component of modern search engines. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach that leverages semantic knowledge graphs to disambiguate query terms and identify relevant documents. Our method, 'HQE-Graph', incorporates a two-stage expansion process that first identifies relevant entities and then generates a weighted set of expansion terms. Experimental results on the TREC dataset demonstrate that HQE-Graph outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency, particularly for complex, multi-entity queries.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: Investigating Gesture-Based Interaction for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but the potential of embodied cognition in VR remains under-explored. This paper presents a novel gesture-based interaction framework that leverages embodied cognition principles to enhance user experience in VR. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, comparing our framework to traditional controller-based interaction. Results show that our approach improves user engagement, reduces cognitive load, and increases overall satisfaction. We discuss implications for VR interaction design and highlight avenues for future research.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a distributed task allocation framework, 'RL-Allocator', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments for autonomous agents. We model the task allocation problem as a Markov decision process and employ a decentralized, actor-critic architecture to learn agent-specific policies. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that RL-Allocator outperforms traditional, centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and agent satisfaction.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities need to collaborate to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a novel distributed constraint optimization approach that enables agents to coordinate their actions and allocate tasks efficiently. Our method, called Distributed Constraint-based Task Allocation (DCTA), leverages local search and constraint propagation to find a feasible task assignment that satisfies individual agent constraints and global system objectives. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that DCTA outperforms existing approaches in terms of task completion rate, latency, and overall system utility.

title: EyeGaze-Based Cognitive Load Detection using Deep Learning for Adaptive User Interfaces
paper_abstract: Cognitive load detection is crucial for adaptive user interfaces that aim to optimize user performance and experience. This paper proposes a novel approach using eye-gaze features and deep learning to detect cognitive load in real-time. Our approach leverages a convolutional neural network (CNN) to extract features from eye-gaze data and a recurrent neural network (RNN) to model the temporal dynamics of cognitive load. We evaluate our approach on a dataset of 30 participants performing a complex problem-solving task and demonstrate an accuracy of 92.5% in detecting cognitive load. The results have implications for the design of adaptive interfaces that can adjust their complexity and feedback to match the user's cognitive abilities.

title: Real-time Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT Systems using Graph-based Deep Learning
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of Industrial IoT (IIoT) systems has led to a surge in sensor data, making it challenging to detect anomalies in real-time. This paper proposes a novel graph-based deep learning approach, 'GAD-IoT', which leverages the structural relationships between sensors to identify anomalies more accurately. GAD-IoT combines graph convolutional networks with a attention-based mechanism to capture complex patterns in sensor data. Experimental results on a real-world IIoT dataset demonstrate that GAD-IoT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and latency.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval using Hierarchical Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when queries are short and ambiguous. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion approach, 'HQE', which leverages hierarchical document embeddings to capture latent semantic relationships between terms and documents. HQE uses a graph neural network to learn expanded query representations, incorporating both local and global contextual information. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, particularly for difficult queries, and outperform state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Explainable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems are crucial for building trust with users. However, existing methods often sacrifice efficiency for model interpretability. This work proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that balances recommendation accuracy with explainability. Our HAN model employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant user and item features, generating personalized explanations for each recommendation. Experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing transparent and actionable explanations.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the challenging problem of cooperative task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents must work together to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a novel distributed reinforcement learning framework, 'CoRAL', that enables agents to learn cooperative policies in a decentralized manner. CoRAL combines Q-learning with a consensus-based protocol to ensure that agents converge to a common optimal policy. We evaluate CoRAL in a simulated environment and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving task completion rates and reducing communication overhead compared to existing approaches.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval Models
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) models have shown promising results in open-domain question answering tasks. However, they often suffer from high computational costs and slow inference speeds, making them impractical for large-scale applications. This paper proposes a hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that reduces the number of passages to be scored by the DPR model, resulting in significant speedups. HQE leverages a two-stage framework, where the first stage uses a lightweight neural retriever to select a subset of relevant passages, and the second stage applies DPR to the selected passages. Experimental results on the NQ and Trivia datasets demonstrate that HQE achieves comparable retrieval performance to state-of-the-art DPR models while reducing inference time by up to 75%.

title: Efficient Query Optimization with Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of distributed database systems, as it directly impacts performance and scalability. Traditional query optimizers rely on hand-crafted heuristics and rule-based systems, which often fall short in complex scenarios. This paper presents 'QOptRL', a novel query optimization framework that leverages reinforcement learning to learn efficient query plans from experience. We formulate query optimization as a Markov decision process and employ a deep Q-network to learn optimal query plans. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database demonstrate that QOptRL outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Scalable RDF Graph Partitioning for Distributed Query Processing
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of RDF data has led to a growing need for scalable and efficient query processing techniques. In this paper, we propose a novel RDF graph partitioning approach, termed 'RDFPart', which leverages graph structural properties to distribute query workload across a cluster of machines. RDFPart incorporates a cost-based partitioning strategy that minimizes data replication, reduces network communication, and optimizes query execution times. Our experimental evaluation on real-world RDF datasets demonstrates significant performance improvements over existing graph partitioning methods, making RDFPart a promising solution for large-scale RDF data processing.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Query Graph Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely heavily on effective query expansion techniques to improve retrieval performance. In this paper, we propose a novel neural query graph embedding approach, dubbed 'NQGE', which learns to represent queries as dense vectors in a high-dimensional space. By leveraging graph convolutional networks and self-attention mechanisms, NQGE captures complex relationships between query terms and their contextual dependencies. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NQGE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Malware Detection
paper_abstract: Malware detection is a critical task in cybersecurity, but existing methods often struggle with the complexity of modern malware variants. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAT-GNN) for malware detection. Our approach leverages graph-based representations of system call sequences to capture the structural patterns of malicious behavior. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant graph nodes and edges, improving the model's ability to generalize across diverse malware families. Experimental results on a large-scale malware dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HAT-GNN in detecting unknown malware, outperforming state-of-the-art baseline models.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Query Expansion on Neural Ranking Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in ad-hoc retrieval tasks, but their effectiveness can be limited by the quality of the input queries. This paper investigates the impact of query expansion on neural ranking models, exploring the use of different expansion techniques and their effects on retrieval performance. Our experiments on the TREC Robust04 dataset show that query expansion can significantly improve the performance of neural ranking models, but the choice of expansion technique and hyperparameters can have a significant impact on the results. We also analyze the effects of query expansion on the robustness of neural ranking models to out-of-vocabulary queries.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Armed Bandits
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework, 'MAB-Agents', which leverages multi-armed bandits (MAB) to adaptively assign tasks to autonomous agents. We propose a novel MAB algorithm that incorporates agent-specific rewards, exploration-exploitation trade-offs, and communication constraints. Simulation results demonstrate that MAB-Agents outperforms traditional assignment methods in terms of task completion rate and agent utility, while tolerating agent failures and network partitions.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation with Adaptive Reputation Systems for Multi-Agent Teams
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse skills and reliability levels need to collaborate to achieve common goals. We propose a decentralized framework that incorporates adaptive reputation systems to evaluate agent performance and reliability in real-time. Our approach enables agents to dynamically adjust their task assignments based on the reputation scores, leading to improved team efficiency and robustness. Experimental results using simulated disaster response scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing task completion times and enhancing overall system resilience.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In this paper, we investigate the application of deep reinforcement learning to task allocation in multi-agent systems. We propose a novel framework, 'MADQN', that leverages a decentralized, actor-critic architecture to learn coordination strategies for allocating tasks to agents. MADQN utilizes a novel attention mechanism to capture the complex dependencies between agents and tasks, and is shown to outperform existing methods in several benchmark scenarios. Our results demonstrate the potential of deep reinforcement learning for scalable, adaptive, and efficient task allocation in real-world multi-agent systems.

title: Designing Adaptive Haptic Feedback for Enhanced Virtual Reality Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but existing haptic feedback systems often fail to provide a realistic and engaging experience. This paper presents an adaptive haptic feedback framework that leverages machine learning-based user modeling and real-time biomechanical simulation. Our approach dynamically adjusts the feedback intensity, frequency, and texture to individual users' preferences and VR environments, resulting in improved user satisfaction and immersion. We conduct a comprehensive user study to evaluate the effectiveness of our framework and demonstrate its potential applications in VR gaming, education, and therapy.

title: Enhancing Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in information retrieval (IR) to improve the recall of relevant documents. However, traditional query expansion methods often suffer from noise and ambiguity. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach that leverages neural embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our method, called HQE-NE, employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively expand the query terms based on their relevance and context. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HQE-NE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval performance and robustness.

title: Efficient Data Retrieval in Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Query Optimization
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in recent years, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach to query optimization, which leverages the structural properties of the database schema to minimize data retrieval times. Our approach, called 'GraphOpt', represents the database schema as a graph and uses graph algorithms to identify optimal query plans. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Semantics for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines often struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to poor search results. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'GraphExpan', which leverages graph-based semantics to better understand user queries. By modeling query terms as nodes in a graph and incorporating semantic relationships, we can identify relevant expansion terms that improve search result relevance. Our experiments on a large e-commerce dataset show that GraphExpan outperforms traditional query expansion methods, resulting in a 15% increase in search result quality and a 20% reduction in search latency.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Contextualized Word Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component of ad-hoc retrieval systems, but traditional QE methods often struggle to capture nuanced semantic relationships between words. This paper proposes a novel QE approach that leverages deep contextualized word embeddings (CWE) to better model word meanings in context. Our method, CWE-QE, integrates CWE into a neural ranking model, allowing the system to adaptively expand queries based on the semantic relationships between words. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that CWE-QE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, particularly for ambiguous and rare query terms.

title: Explainable Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-World Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has shown remarkable success in various autonomous systems, but its lack of explainability hinders trust and wide adoption. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'ExplainDRL', which integrates model-based and model-free reinforcement learning to provide interpretable policies for real-world autonomous systems. We introduce a attention-based explanation module that visualizes the decision-making process of the DRL agent, enabling humans to understand and correct its behavior. Experimental results on a real-world autonomous driving dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of ExplainDRL in improving transparency, safety, and performance.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Robust Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Object detection is a critical component of autonomous vehicle systems, but current state-of-the-art models are vulnerable to adversarial attacks and environmental variations. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between objects and scenes. HGAT integrates a hierarchical feature extractor with a graph attention module, enabling robust object detection in diverse scenarios. Experimental results on the KITTI and Cityscapes datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms existing object detection models in terms of accuracy, robustness, and resilience to attacks.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Graph Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems to improve search accuracy. Traditional methods rely on manual feature engineering and suffer from limited expressive power. This paper introduces a novel approach, GraphQE, which leverages deep graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn rich query representations from graph-structured data. We propose a query-graph attention mechanism to selectively incorporate relevant context and a graph-based semantic similarity measure to identify informative expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention Networks for Question Answering
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has been widely adopted in question answering (QA) tasks to capture semantic relationships between entities. However, existing KGE methods often suffer from limited scalability and neglect the hierarchical structure inherent in knowledge graphs. This paper proposes a novel KGE approach, 'HierAttention', which leverages hierarchical attention networks to selectively focus on relevant entities and relations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierAttention on several QA benchmarks, achieving state-of-the-art results with significant improvements over existing KGE methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explanations for Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but the lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes domains. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention mechanism, 'HAT', to provide explanations for DRL policies. HAT generates attention weights at multiple levels of abstraction, enabling the identification of key state features and their relationships that contribute to the policy's decisions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAT on several Atari games and a real-world autonomous driving scenario, showing that it improves the transparency and trustworthiness of DRL agents.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Multi-Modal Search
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques rely solely on textual features, neglecting the rich contextual information available in multi-modal search scenarios. This paper presents a novel context-aware query expansion framework, 'CAQE', which incorporates visual and acoustic features to disambiguate user queries. By leveraging a multi-modal graph neural network, CAQE captures intricate relationships between query terms, visual objects, and audio patterns. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate significant improvements in search accuracy and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Large-Scale Document Collections
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but its computational cost can be prohibitive for large document collections. This paper presents a novel hierarchical query expansion approach that leverages the inherent structure of document clusters to reduce the number of expansion terms. Our method, dubbed 'HQE', uses a two-stage clustering process to identify relevant terms at multiple granularities, resulting in more accurate and efficient retrieval. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HQE outperforms state-of-the-art expansion techniques in terms of both recall and query processing time.

title: Adversarial Perturbation Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Hierarchical Temporal Attention
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are increasingly vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their performance and reliability. Existing detection methods often rely on hand-crafted features or complex models, leading to limited generalizability and interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical temporal attention (HTA) mechanism that detects adversarial perturbations in DNNs by modeling the temporal dependencies between input sequences. Our approach leverages attention weights to highlight suspicious regions and adaptively adjusts the detection threshold based on the input complexity. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HTA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in detecting both white-box and black-box attacks, while providing insightful visualizations into the perturbation detection process.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing Environments
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of efficiently allocating resources to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper presents a novel approach to resource allocation using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We propose a multi-agent DRL framework that leverages graph neural networks to model complex relationships between cloud resources and workloads. Our approach learns to adaptively allocate resources based on real-time workload patterns, achieving improved resource utilization and reduced latency compared to traditional rule-based methods. Experimental results on a large-scale cloud simulator demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing costs and improving quality of service.

title: Query-Aware Document Ranking with BERT-Based Dense Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional retrieval models often rely on sparse vector representations, which can be limited in capturing nuanced semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel query-aware document ranking approach that leverages BERT-based dense retrieval. Our method, 'QADR', jointly learns a dense query encoder and a document encoder, enabling more accurate matching of query-document pairs. We demonstrate the effectiveness of QADR on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements over state-of-the-art sparse retrieval models in terms of recall and precision.

title: Adaptive Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) often require effective negotiation strategies to achieve mutually beneficial agreements in dynamic environments. This paper introduces a novel adaptive negotiation framework, 'DynaNeg', which leverages reinforcement learning and graph-based modeling to optimize negotiation outcomes. DynaNeg integrates a dynamic graph structure to represent agent relationships, and a Q-learning algorithm to adapt negotiation strategies based on environment feedback. Experimental results on a supply chain management scenario demonstrate that DynaNeg outperforms traditional negotiation strategies in terms of agreement quality and negotiation efficiency.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Autonomous Driving
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require rapid decision-making in complex environments. We propose a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'HierAct', which leverages a dual-agent architecture to optimize action selection and planning in real-time. Our approach integrates a high-level, model-based agent with a low-level, model-free agent, enabling efficient exploration-exploitation trade-offs and improved adaptability to dynamic scenarios. Experimental results on a high-fidelity driving simulator demonstrate HierAct's superiority over flat RL baselines in terms of task completion rate and safety metrics.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-Hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc information retrieval (IR) systems rely heavily on effective query expansion techniques to improve retrieval accuracy. This paper presents a novel approach, 'DeepQuery', which leverages deep reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query expansion. Our method employs a Markov decision process to model the query expansion process, where an RL agent learns to select the most informative expansion terms based on user feedback.
