Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQuery outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in both precision and recall.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Data warehousing has become a crucial component of modern business intelligence, but the rapid growth of real-time data demands efficient indexing techniques to support fast query performance. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'RTIndex', which leverages a combination of column-store indexing and in-memory caching to accelerate query execution. We also introduce a cost-based optimization algorithm that adaptively selects the most effective indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distribution. Experimental results on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that RTIndex outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Adaptive Reward Shaping
paper_abstract: In large-scale multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive solutions. This paper presents a novel approach to task allocation that leverages adaptive reward shaping to improve the overall system performance. We propose a decentralized algorithm that allows agents to learn and adapt to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. Our approach is evaluated on a simulated logistics domain, where we demonstrate improved task allocation efficiency and robustness compared to traditional methods. Theoretical analysis and empirical results show that our algorithm scales well with the number of agents and tasks, making it suitable for real-world applications.

title: Neural Ranking Models for Efficient Document Retrieval in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems struggle to effectively retrieve documents from heterogeneous networks, where documents and queries exhibit diverse structures and relationships. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'HetRank', that leverages graph neural networks to learn representations of documents and queries in a unified vector space. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HetRank on a large-scale dataset of academic papers, showing significant improvements in retrieval performance and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Query Optimization for Complex Event Processing over Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of distributed databases, optimizing query processing for complex event processing (CEP) has become a critical challenge. In this paper, we propose a novel query optimization framework, 'DistributedCEP', which leverages graph-based query decomposition and parallel processing to minimize latency and improve throughput. Our approach utilizes a cost-based optimizer that considers both data locality and communication costs to generate efficient query plans. Experimental results on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that DistributedCEP outperforms existing CEP systems by up to 3x in terms of query response time and scales to handle high-volume event streams.

title: EyeTracking-Based Adaptive Interaction for Enhanced Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but current interaction methods can be cumbersome for users with disabilities. This paper presents 'EyeGuide', an adaptive VR interaction system that leverages eye-tracking to enable users to navigate and interact with virtual environments using gaze-based commands. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, including individuals with mobility and visual impairments, to evaluate the effectiveness of EyeGuide. Results show that EyeGuide significantly improves interaction accuracy and speed, while reducing user fatigue and discomfort. Our approach has implications for enhancing accessibility in VR-based applications, including gaming, education, and healthcare.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Reinforcement Learning for Diverse Search Results
paper_abstract: Conventional learning-to-rank models for information retrieval often prioritize relevance over diversity, leading to redundant search results. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning framework, 'DIVERSE', that optimizes document ranking to balance relevance and diversity. Our approach employs a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture, where a high-level policy learns to select a diverse set of documents, and a low-level policy refines the ranking within each selected set. Experimental results on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in both relevance and diversity metrics compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Skeleton-Based Action Recognition
paper_abstract: Skeleton-based action recognition has gained popularity in human-computer interaction applications. However, existing methods struggle to capture complex spatial-temporal relationships between joints. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture, which leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant joints and their interactions. We introduce a hierarchical graph representation that captures both local and global dependencies, enabling the model to recognize actions more accurately. Experiments on the NTU RGB+D and Kinetics datasets demonstrate the superiority of HGAT over state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average accuracy improvement of 3.5%.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommendation systems often rely on graph-based models to capture complex user-item relationships. However, these models can be computationally expensive and scale poorly with large graphs. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant graph regions. We introduce a hierarchical pooling scheme that adaptively reduces graph sizes, allowing for efficient processing of large-scale recommendation datasets. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art graph-based models while reducing computational costs by up to 50%.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Modal Database Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of multi-modal data, including images, videos, and sensor readings, has led to a surge in the development of multi-modal database systems. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a significant challenge due to the diverse characteristics of each modality. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'MMO', which leverages a hybrid approach combining machine learning-based cost estimation with traditional optimization techniques. Our experiments on a real-world multi-modal dataset demonstrate that MMO achieves an average query performance improvement of 3.5x compared to state-of-the-art optimization methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Semi-supervised Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-based data analysis, but it often suffers from limited labeled data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for semi-supervised node classification. HGAT learns to represent nodes at multiple scales by recursively applying graph attention mechanisms, capturing both local and global structural patterns. We also develop a new self-supervised loss function that leverages the node's neighborhood information to regularize the learning process. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of classification accuracy and robustness to noisy labels.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalization on User Experience in Voice-Assisted Interfaces
paper_abstract: Voice-assisted interfaces (VAIs) have become ubiquitous in modern computing, but the role of personalization in shaping user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study that explores how personalized features in VAIs influence user satisfaction, trust, and behavioral adaptation. Our results show that personalized VAIs can lead to increased user engagement and perceived usefulness, but also raise concerns about privacy and transparency. We identify key design implications for VAI systems that balance personalization with user autonomy and agency.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must coordinate to accomplish complex tasks without a central authority. This paper proposes a novel approach using hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs) to learn decentralized task allocation policies. Our method leverages the hierarchical structure of task graphs to learn both local and global dependencies between tasks, enabling agents to make informed decisions in a distributed manner. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving near-optimal solutions while minimizing communication overhead.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agents are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can manipulate the state and action spaces to compromise the learning process. We propose a novel approach to detect such attacks using graph convolutional networks (GCNs). Our method, 'AdvGuard', constructs a graph representation of the agent's experience and applies GCNs to identify anomalous patterns indicative of adversarial behavior. We evaluate AdvGuard on a range of DRL environments and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting both white-box and black-box attacks, outperforming existing detection methods.

title: Accelerating Query Processing on Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases with GPU-Aware Indexing
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of NoSQL databases in big data analytics has led to a growing need for efficient query processing. This paper presents a novel GPU-accelerated indexing approach for column-oriented NoSQL databases, dubbed 'GPU-ColIx'. By leveraging the massively parallel architecture of modern GPUs, GPU-ColIx achieves significant performance gains for range queries and aggregations. We propose a dynamic indexing strategy that adapts to query patterns and data distributions, minimizing indexing overhead and optimizing query execution. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GPU-ColIx outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 5x for certain query types.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Empirical Study on Accessibility Features for Older Adults
paper_abstract: As voice assistants become increasingly prevalent, ensuring their accessibility for older adults is crucial. This study examines the impact of various accessibility features on the usability of voice assistants for older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants aged 65+, evaluating the effectiveness of features such as speech rate adjustment, audio cues, and personalized vocabulary. Our results show that participants with accessibility features experienced significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction. We provide design recommendations for inclusive voice assistants and highlight areas for future research.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents through Hierarchical Task Networks for Disaster Response
paper_abstract: Effective disaster response relies on the coordination of multiple autonomous agents, such as drones and robots, to perform complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel framework for coordinating agents through hierarchical task networks (HTNs), which enable the decomposition of high-level goals into lower-level tasks. We introduce a task allocation algorithm that considers the capabilities and availability of agents, as well as the dynamic environment. Experimental results using a realistic disaster response scenario show that our approach achieves significant improvements in task completion time and resource efficiency compared to existing methods.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for People with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to improve the quality of life for people with motor impairments. However, current systems often rely on able-bodied users' data, leading to poor performance and user experience for individuals with motor impairments. This paper presents a novel framework for designing adaptive gesture recognition systems that can accommodate diverse motor abilities. Our approach combines machine learning with participatory design, involving users with motor impairments in the design process. We evaluate our system with a case study involving users with cerebral palsy and demonstrate significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Word Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely on query expansion techniques to improve retrieval accuracy. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method, 'EmbExpan', which leverages word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and expansion candidates. We introduce a new embedding-based similarity metric that incorporates both local and global context information. Experimental results on the TREC ad-hoc retrieval benchmark show that EmbExpan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Proximity Graphs for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of ad-hoc retrieval systems, but traditional methods often struggle with vocabulary mismatch and term ambiguity. This paper proposes a novel neural approach, 'NeuroXPand', which leverages proximity graphs to model semantic relationships between queries and documents. By learning a dense representation of the query-document graph, NeuroXPand effectively captures nuanced context and improves retrieval performance. We evaluate our approach on several standard benchmarks, demonstrating significant gains in mean average precision and NDCG@10 compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Real-Time Query Expansion using Neural Document Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural document embeddings to improve retrieval performance. We introduce a real-time query expansion framework, 'NeuroXE', which uses a combination of semantic and syntactic features to generate high-quality expansion terms. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that NeuroXE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Data Placement for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing. However, efficient data placement remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize data placement in DDS. We formulate the data placement problem as a Markov decision process and develop an RL-based algorithm that learns to place data chunks in a way that minimizes data retrieval latency and improves system throughput. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing data placement strategies by up to 30% in terms of latency reduction.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gesture-based interface design approach tailored to older adults with motor impairments. Our system, called 'EasyGesture', utilizes machine learning-based gesture recognition to adapt to individual users' abilities and compensate for motor variability. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture-based interfaces. EasyGesture's adaptive nature enables older adults to interact with technology more effectively, promoting digital inclusion and independence.

title: Efficient Indexing for Scalable Graph Pattern Matching
paper_abstract: Graph pattern matching is a fundamental problem in graph databases, with applications in social network analysis, recommendation systems, and knowledge graphs. However, as graph sizes continue to grow, existing indexing techniques struggle to provide efficient query performance. This paper presents 'GraphSprint', a novel indexing framework that leverages a combination of graph summarization, hierarchical indexing, and caching to accelerate graph pattern matching. Our experiments on large-scale graph datasets demonstrate that GraphSprint outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 5x in query response time while maintaining a competitive storage footprint.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Traffic Flow
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning approach to coordinate autonomous vehicles in urban traffic networks. We formulate the problem as a Markov game, where each agent learns to optimize its actions based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Our method, dubbed 'MARL-Traffic', incorporates a novel attention mechanism to prioritize critical intersections and adapt to changing traffic conditions. Simulation results demonstrate a significant reduction in travel time and increased traffic flow compared to traditional traffic signal control methods.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Graph-based Keyword Extraction and Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Traditional keyword extraction methods for document retrieval often rely on shallow term frequency analysis, leading to suboptimal query representations. This paper presents a novel graph-based approach, 'GraphKE', which leverages document- keyword co-occurrence networks to extract relevant keywords and expand user queries. We propose a scalable algorithm for graph-based keyword ranking and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving retrieval performance on several benchmark datasets. Experimental results show that GraphKE outperforms state-of-the-art keyword extraction methods, achieving a 12% increase in mean average precision.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalization on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As Virtual Reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding the effects of personalization on user experience is crucial. This study investigates how personalized VR environments, tailored to individual users' preferences and behaviors, influence user engagement, satisfaction, and cognitive workload. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment with 120 participants, analyzing quantitative metrics (e.g., task completion time, user ratings) and qualitative feedback (e.g., think-aloud protocols, post-experiment interviews). Our results show that personalized VR environments lead to significant improvements in user experience, particularly for users with prior VR experience. We discuss the implications of these findings for VR system design and provide recommendations for future research.

title: Context-Aware Neural Ranking Models for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal ranking performance. This paper proposes a novel context-aware neural ranking model, 'CARMA', which integrates user behavior and query context into the ranking pipeline. CARMA employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively weigh term importance based on user interactions and query intent. Experimental results on the TREC Web Track dataset demonstrate significant improvements in ranking accuracy and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art neural ranking models.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to scalable multi-agent task allocation using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'MAgent', which enables agents to learn efficient task allocation strategies through self-play. Our method leverages a graph neural network to model agent interactions and a deep Q-network to learn optimal task assignment policies. Experimental results on a large-scale logistics scenario demonstrate that MAgent achieves significant improvements in task completion time and resource utilization compared to traditional optimization-based methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Social Network Analysis
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for multi-modal social network analysis. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between users, and hierarchical representations to integrate multiple modalities, such as text, images, and graphs. We evaluate HGAT on a large-scale social media dataset, demonstrating its effectiveness in predicting user engagement and identifying influential individuals. Experimental results show that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: EmotionAware: Affective State Recognition using Multi-modal Fusion of Physiological and Behavioral Cues
paper_abstract: Continuous affective state recognition is crucial for human-computer interaction, mental health monitoring, and personalized systems. This paper introduces EmotionAware, a novel framework that leverages multi-modal fusion of physiological (EEG, ECG) and behavioral (facial expressions, speech) cues to recognize emotions in real-time. We propose a deep learning architecture that integrates convolutional and recurrent neural networks to handle the heterogeneous data streams. Experimental results on a dataset of 50 participants demonstrate that EmotionAware achieves an average recognition accuracy of 87.2% for seven emotions, outperforming state-of-the-art systems that rely on single modalities.

title: Query Expansion using Graph-based Embeddings for Improving Retrieval Effectiveness
paper_abstract: Query expansion techniques are crucial for enhancing the retrieval effectiveness of search engines. This paper proposes a novel graph-based embedding approach, 'GraphExpan', which leverages the structural relationships between query terms to generate more informative and diverse expansions. We represent the query context as a graph and learn node embeddings that capture semantic similarities between terms. Experimental results on several TREC datasets demonstrate that GraphExpan outperforms state-of-the-art expansion methods, leading to significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: Node classification in heterogeneous information networks (HINs) is a challenging task due to the complexity of node relationships and diverse node types. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that leverages both local and global graph structures to improve node classification performance. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant nodes and edges at different levels of abstraction, enabling the model to capture complex node relationships and contextual dependencies. Experimental results on several real-world HIN datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in achieving state-of-the-art node classification performance.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Dialogue Generation
paper_abstract: Generating coherent and engaging dialogue responses remains a challenging task in conversational AI. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that models dialogue context and user preferences to produce more relevant and explainable responses. Our HAN framework consists of a dialogue encoder, a user preference encoder, and a response generator, which jointly learn to identify salient context and preference features. We evaluate our approach on the OpenSubtitles and Ubuntu Dialogue datasets, demonstrating improved response quality and explainability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Efficient Cross-Modal Fusion for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) has gained increasing attention due to the proliferation of multimodal data on social media. Existing MSA approaches often rely on early or late fusion methods, which neglect the complex interactions between modalities. To address this, we propose a novel cross-modal fusion framework based on graph attention networks (GATs). Our approach models the relationships between modalities as a graph, allowing for adaptive and selective information exchange. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI and ICT-MMM datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming existing fusion methods by up to 5.2% in terms of F1-score.

title: Unsupervised Query Expansion using Neural Dense Retrieval for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to effectively capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel unsupervised query expansion framework, 'NeuroQE', which leverages the power of neural dense retrieval models. NeuroQE generates a set of relevant expansion terms by analyzing the dense vector representations of the query and the top-retrieved documents. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE consistently outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness.

title: Efficient Query Reformulation using Reinforcement Learning for Improving Search Engine Ranking
paper_abstract: Search engines rely on query reformulation to improve the relevance of search results. However, existing methods often rely on hand-crafted rules or supervised learning, which may not generalize well to diverse user queries. This paper proposes a novel approach, QRLR, which leverages reinforcement learning to learn an optimal query reformulation policy. Our method uses a deep Q-network to learn from user interactions and adapts to changing user behavior. Experimental results on a large-scale search engine dataset show that QRLR significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of ranking improvement and user satisfaction.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and preferences need to allocate tasks efficiently. We propose an auction-based mechanism that exploits the agents' local knowledge to determine task assignments, thereby improving overall system performance. Our approach incorporates a novel bidding strategy that takes into account the agents' capabilities, task dependencies, and communication constraints. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving efficient task allocation and improved system performance.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Display Type on Gestural Interaction in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly prevalent, but the effects of display type on user experience are not well understood. This study investigates how different display types (OLED, LCD, and MicroLED) influence gestural interaction in VR. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, analyzing their performance and subjective feedback on a series of gestural tasks. Our results show that OLED displays lead to faster and more accurate gestural interactions, while MicroLED displays result in reduced fatigue and eye strain. We discuss the implications of our findings for VR system design and provide recommendations for optimizing gestural interaction across different display types.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Recognition and Accessibility
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by limitations in speech recognition and accessibility. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating an inclusive voice assistant for older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants aged 65+, examining the impact of speech recognition errors, cognitive load, and visual feedback on user experience. Our results reveal that older adults prefer a hybrid interaction model that combines voice and visual inputs, and that personalized speech recognition models can significantly improve recognition accuracy. We discuss the implications of our findings for designing more accessible and usable voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and energy. While graph neural networks have shown promise in this area, they often struggle to capture long-term dependencies and hierarchical relationships in the data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HiGAT) that leverages a multi-scale graph representation to model complex temporal dependencies. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HiGAT on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in long-term forecasting tasks.

title: Adaptive Agent Coordination for Dynamic Task Allocation in Multi-Robot Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-robot systems, task allocation and coordination are critical challenges, particularly in dynamic environments. This paper presents a novel adaptive agent coordination framework, 'DynaAgent', which leverages a decentralized Markov decision process (MDP) to optimize task allocation and resource utilization. DynaAgent utilizes a probabilistic graph model to represent agent capabilities and task dependencies, enabling efficient and flexible coordination. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and resource utilization compared to existing centralized and decentralized approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have revolutionized the field of information retrieval, but their reliance on exact keyword matching can lead to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method, 'ContraQE', which leverages contrastive learning to capture semantic relationships between query terms and documents. By generating negative samples that are semantically distant from the query, ContraQE encourages the model to focus on relevant contexts and expands the query space more effectively. Experimental results on the TREC-COVID dataset demonstrate that ContraQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% increase in retrieval accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in modern data-intensive applications. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of data distribution and the need to minimize communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep reinforcement learning model that learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database system and receiving feedback in the form of execution times. Our approach is able to adapt to changing data distributions and workloads, and outperforms traditional optimization techniques in terms of query execution time and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Dementia
paper_abstract: This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop accessible gestural interfaces for older adults with dementia. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with caregivers and individuals with dementia to identify key challenges and opportunities in gestural interaction. Our findings inform the design of 'EasyGest', a novel interface that incorporates simplification, consistency, and feedback mechanisms to facilitate intuitive gestural input. A usability evaluation with 15 older adults with dementia demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing gestural interfaces.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Massive Graph Databases using GPU-Accelerated Indexing
paper_abstract: As graph databases continue to grow in size and complexity, query performance becomes a major bottleneck. This paper presents a novel approach to accelerate graph query execution by leveraging GPU-accelerated indexing. We introduce a hybrid indexing scheme that combines traditional CPU-based indexing with GPU-based indexing, allowing for efficient querying of massive graph datasets. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing indexing schemes, with query execution times reduced by up to 75%. Our approach is particularly effective for queries involving complex graph patterns and large datasets.

title: Eye-tracking-based Gaze-aware Interface for Enhanced User Engagement
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gaze-aware interface system that leverages eye-tracking technology to improve user engagement and interaction with digital content. Our approach uses a machine learning-based gaze prediction model to anticipate user attention and dynamically adapt the interface layout, font sizes, and color schemes to optimize visual appeal and readability. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates a significant increase in user engagement, as measured by time spent on task and self-reported satisfaction, when compared to traditional interface designs. The proposed system has potential applications in various domains, including e-learning, advertising, and gaming.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Coordination for Efficient Resource Allocation in Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized multi-agent coordination framework for efficient resource allocation in autonomous systems. Our approach leverages a hybrid of distributed constraint optimization and deep reinforcement learning to enable agents to adaptively allocate resources in real-time. We introduce a novel communication protocol that enables agents to share information and coordinate their actions without reliance on a centralized controller. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach achieves significant improvements in resource utilization and overall system efficiency compared to traditional centralized methods.

title: Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection for Time Series Data in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosion of time series data, necessitating efficient anomaly detection methods to ensure network reliability and security. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'TS-Anomaly', which leverages a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to identify anomalies in IoT time series data. We introduce a novel loss function that incorporates domain knowledge to improve detection accuracy and reduce false positives. Experimental results on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that TS-Anomaly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of F1-score and detection latency.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Social Cues in Virtual Reality Avatars
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) avatars are increasingly used in social interactions, but their design often neglects the role of embodiment in conveying social cues. This paper presents a study investigating how varying levels of embodiment in VR avatars affect users' perception of social cues, such as gaze and proximity. We developed a novel VR platform that manipulates embodiment through customizable avatar representations and conducted a user study with 40 participants. Our results show that avatars with higher embodiment lead to more accurate social cue recognition, but also increase feelings of anxiety and self-consciousness. We discuss implications for VR avatar design and future research directions.

title: Embodied Cognition in Human-Robot Collaboration: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly enter human-centric environments, effective human-robot collaboration (HRC) is crucial. This paper explores the role of embodied cognition in HRC, focusing on gesture-based interaction. We design and evaluate a novel gestureset for robot control, incorporating insights from cognitive linguistics and human-computer interaction. Our user study reveals that embodied cognition principles can significantly improve task performance, user experience, and robot anthropomorphism. The results have implications for the design of intuitive and efficient HRC systems in various applications, such as manufacturing, healthcare, and home assistance.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become crucial for businesses to make timely decisions. However, optimizing queries for low-latency execution remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize query plans for real-time data warehousing. Our method, called 'DRL-QOpt', uses a DRL agent to learn an optimal query plan policy from a large dataset of query executions. We evaluate DRL-QOpt on a real-world data warehousing benchmark and demonstrate significant improvements in query latency and system throughput compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Indexing and Query Optimization for Time-Series Data in Main-Memory Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of IoT devices and real-time analytics has led to a surge in time-series data storage and querying demands. In this paper, we propose a novel indexing scheme, 'TS-Index', designed for main-memory column-store databases. TS-Index combines a compact, adaptive-bit-width encoding with a hierarchical indexing structure to minimize storage overhead and improve query performance. We also develop an optimized query engine that leverages the index to accelerate range and aggregation queries. Experimental evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrate that TS-Index outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 3.5x in storage efficiency and 2.2x in query performance.

title: Gaze-Based Authentication for Augmented Reality Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly pervasive, securing AR experiences against unauthorized access is crucial. This paper presents a novel gaze-based authentication system utilizing deep learning techniques. Our approach leverages convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to analyze users' gaze patterns, achieving high accuracy in distinguishing legitimate users from impostors. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our system in various AR scenarios, highlighting its potential for seamless and secure authentication in AR applications.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning has been increasingly applied to autonomous systems, such as autonomous vehicles and drones. However, the robustness of these systems to adversarial attacks remains largely unexplored. This paper investigates the vulnerability of multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithms to targeted attacks, which can manipulate the behavior of individual agents to compromise the overall system. We propose a novel attack framework, 'MAARA', which leverages the interaction between agents to amplify the adversarial effect. Our experiments demonstrate the efficacy of MAARA in compromising the performance of state-of-the-art multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithms, highlighting the need for robustness testing in these systems.

title: Eliciting User Preferences for Personalized Accessibility in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology holds great promise for individuals with disabilities, but existing VR interfaces often fail to account for diverse user needs and preferences. This paper presents a novel approach to eliciting user preferences for personalized accessibility in VR, leveraging a mixed-methods design that combines user surveys, think-aloud protocols, and statistical modeling. Our results identify key factors influencing user preferences for accessibility features in VR, including visual, auditory, and motor impairments. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving user experience and accessibility in a VR-based educational application.

title: Decentralized Agent Coordination for Dynamic Task Allocation in Smart Cities
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel decentralized agent coordination framework for dynamic task allocation in smart city applications. Our approach leverages a multi-agent system where agents represent autonomous entities, such as drones or robots, that can perform tasks like waste collection, surveillance, or package delivery. We introduce a distributed auction-based mechanism that enables agents to bid for tasks based on their capabilities, schedules, and preferences. Experiments in a simulated smart city environment demonstrate that our approach outperforms centralized task allocation methods in terms of response time, resource utilization, and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval with Sparse Adaptive Hashing
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to document retrieval using sparse adaptive hashing (SAH). We propose a hashing framework that leverages the sparsity of document-term matrices to reduce the dimensionality of the feature space. Our approach adaptively adjusts the hash functions based on the query distribution, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval efficiency. Experimental evaluations on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that SAH outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision and recall, while reducing the computational overhead by up to 50%.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Deep Semantic Hashing
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in information retrieval tasks, but still suffer from the vocabulary mismatch problem. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method, DeepHash, which leverages deep semantic hashing to generate latent semantic representations of query terms. Our approach learns to capture nuanced semantic relationships between terms and documents, enabling more effective query expansion. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that DeepHash significantly improves retrieval performance compared to traditional query expansion methods, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-hop question answering (QA) models have achieved impressive results, but their lack of transparency hinders their reliability in real-world applications. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that provides interpretable reasoning for multi-hop QA tasks. Our model employs a stacked attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant context sentences, entities, and relationships, allowing for explicit tracking of the reasoning process. Experimental results on the HotPotQA dataset demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art approaches while offering enhanced explainability and transparency.

title: Neural Re-ranking with Document Expansion for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires retrieving relevant documents and accurately identifying the answer span. This paper proposes a novel neural re-ranking approach that incorporates document expansion, leveraging both local and global contextual information. Our method, called 'DocExpan', expands each document by generating synthetic paragraphs that capture latent semantic relationships. The re-ranker then leverages these expanded documents to better distinguish between relevant and irrelevant passages. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that DocExpan significantly outperforms state-of-the-art models in both retrieval and answer accuracy.

title: Designing Emotionally Intelligent Virtual Assistants for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) have transformed the way people interact with technology, but their lack of emotional intelligence (EI) can lead to frustration and abandonment, particularly for individuals with disabilities. This paper presents an EI framework for VAs that incorporates empathy, self-awareness, and social skills. We develop a multimodal affect recognition system that detects users' emotional states from speech, facial expressions, and physiological signals. Our user study with 30 participants with disabilities shows that our EI-VA significantly improves user satisfaction, reduces anxiety, and increases task completion rates compared to a traditional VA. We discuss the implications of our work for designing more inclusive and supportive interfaces.

title: Designing Inclusive Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for accessible interfaces that cater to the diverse needs of older adults, particularly those with motor impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for developing gestural interfaces that accommodate the physical and cognitive abilities of older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and caregivers to identify key design requirements, including adaptable gesture recognition, personalized feedback, and error tolerance. Our evaluation results show that the proposed interface significantly improves the interaction experience and reduces user frustration for older adults with motor impairments.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Graph Databases using Adaptive Caching
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, query performance remains a significant bottleneck due to the high latency and overhead of distributed query execution. This paper proposes an adaptive caching framework, GraphCache, which dynamically adjusts the cache size and content based on query patterns and graph topology. We experimentally evaluate GraphCache on a real-world social network dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in query response time and throughput compared to existing caching strategies.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, optimizing query performance in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning techniques to predict and optimize query execution plans. Our approach, called 'QueryOpt', uses a graph neural network to model the distributed database system and predict the optimal query plan based on historical query patterns and system workload. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system show that QueryOpt achieves an average query performance improvement of 23% compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodied Cognition on Gesture-Based Interaction in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding user behavior and experience is crucial. This study explores the role of embodied cognition in gesture-based interaction in VR, examining how users' bodily experiences influence their performance and perception. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment, combining behavioral and physiological measures with user surveys, to investigate the impact of embodied cognition on gesture recognition, user satisfaction, and cognitive load. Our results show that participants who were encouraged to adopt an embodied approach to gesture-based interaction demonstrated improved performance, reduced cognitive load, and higher user satisfaction. The findings have implications for the design of more intuitive and effective VR interfaces.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: As autonomous vehicles increasingly rely on deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to make critical decisions, it is essential to develop explainability techniques that provide insights into their decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel method, 'RL-Explain', which leverages attention mechanisms and feature importance to generate interpretable explanations for DRL policies in real-time. We demonstrate the effectiveness of RL-Explain on a variety of autonomous driving scenarios, showcasing its ability to identify salient features and provide actionable explanations for human operators. Our results highlight the potential of RL-Explain to increase trust and transparency in autonomous vehicle systems.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Agent Teams using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to coordinated task allocation for heterogeneous agent teams using deep reinforcement learning. We formulate the task allocation problem as a decentralized, partially observable Markov decision process and develop a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that leverages both global and local observations. Our approach enables efficient and adaptive task allocation in real-time, even in the presence of uncertain and dynamic task requirements. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in team performance and scalability compared to traditional, centralized optimization methods.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing answers. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document representation (HDR) framework that captures semantic relationships between passages, paragraphs, and documents. Our approach leverages a combination of dense and sparse embeddings, enabling efficient indexing and retrieval of passages. Experimental results on several ODQA benchmarks demonstrate that HDR outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval methods, achieving a 15% increase in accuracy while reducing computational overhead by 30%.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) is a crucial task in human-computer interaction, as it enables computers to understand user emotions and opinions from various modalities. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) for MSA, which integrates visual, acoustic, and textual features. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention modules that learn to weight features based on their importance, followed by a hierarchical fusion module that combines the weighted features. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in MSA, achieving an accuracy of 83.2% and a F1-score of 85.1%. We also conduct an ablation study to analyze the effectiveness of each attention module.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Databases using Adaptive Workload-Aware Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed databases are increasingly used in modern data-intensive applications, but query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper presents an adaptive workload-aware replication strategy, 'AWARE', which dynamically adjusts data replication based on changing workload patterns. AWARE leverages machine learning-based workload prediction and optimization techniques to minimize query latency and maximize system throughput. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world distributed database setup demonstrates that AWARE outperforms existing static replication schemes by up to 35% in terms of query response time, while reducing overall system resource utilization by 20%.

title: Co-Designing AI-Powered Virtual Assistants with Older Adults: A Participatory HCI Approach
paper_abstract: The proliferation of virtual assistants has transformed the way people interact with technology. However, older adults often struggle to adopt these systems due to inadequate accessibility and usability. This paper presents a participatory Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) approach to co-designing AI-powered virtual assistants with older adults. Our methodology involves a series of workshops, interviews, and usability testing sessions with 25 older adults to identify their needs, preferences, and pain points. We develop a set of design guidelines and recommendations for creating more inclusive and supportive virtual assistants, highlighting the importance of transparent AI decision-making, personalized feedback, and multimodal interaction.

title: Boosting Query Efficiency with Hybrid Indexing for Large-Scale Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: The proliferation of big data has led to a surge in large-scale document retrieval systems. However, traditional indexing techniques struggle to efficiently process complex queries. This paper presents a novel hybrid indexing approach, 'HybridIX', which combines the strengths of inverted indexing and caching. HybridIX adaptively allocates index resources based on query patterns and document popularity, resulting in significant improvements in query latency and throughput. Experimental evaluations on a 100-million-document corpus demonstrate that HybridIX outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 3.5x.

title: Deep Anomaly Detection in Time Series Data using Multi-Scale Temporal Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. This paper proposes a novel deep learning approach, 'Multi-Scale Temporal Convolutional Networks' (MSTCN), which leverages multi-scale temporal dependencies to identify anomalies. MSTCN uses a hierarchical architecture to capture patterns at different time scales, and a novel loss function that encourages the model to focus on anomaly detection. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that MSTCN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and False Positive Rate.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Error Handling and Recovery Strategies
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their error handling and recovery mechanisms often fail to accommodate users with disabilities. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the impact of error handling strategies on user experience and accessibility. We developed a novel framework, 'VoiceCare', which integrates proactive error prevention, personalized recovery prompts, and real-time feedback. Our evaluation with 30 participants, including individuals with visual and motor impairments, shows that VoiceCare significantly reduces user frustration and improves task completion rates compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of autonomous vehicles (AVs) on public roads demands efficient coordination mechanisms to ensure safety and traffic efficiency. This paper proposes a hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework, 'AV-Coord', to facilitate real-time decision-making among AVs in complex traffic scenarios. AV-Coord combines a high-level coordinator agent with distributed low-level agents, each responsible for controlling an individual AV. We evaluate AV-Coord in a simulated urban environment, demonstrating improved traffic flow and reduced congestion compared to traditional decentralized AV control strategies.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed column-store databases have emerged as a prominent solution for big data analytics, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', that leverages column-store statistics and parallel processing to improve query execution times. We propose a cost-based optimization algorithm that takes into account data distribution, column correlations, and available computational resources. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query response time, while maintaining a low optimization overhead.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing query execution plans in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to adaptive query optimization using reinforcement learning. Our method, called 'RL-Optimizer', learns to select the optimal execution plan based on the system's current workload and resource utilization. We evaluate RL-Optimizer on a real-world distributed database and show that it outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Neural Relevance Feedback for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in modern information retrieval systems, aiming to bridge the gap between user queries and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel deep neural relevance feedback framework, 'DeepRF', to enhance query expansion by incorporating user feedback and document semantics. Our model leverages a multi-task learning approach, jointly optimizing query expansion and relevance prediction tasks. Experimental results on the TREC datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Real-time Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles using Efficient YOLOv5 Variants
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on efficient and accurate object detection systems to ensure safety and reliability. This paper presents an in-depth analysis of YOLOv5 variants for real-time object detection in autonomous vehicles. We propose a novel approach, 'YOLOv5-Lite+', which reduces computational complexity by 30% while maintaining a high detection accuracy of 95.2% on the KITTI dataset. Our approach combines knowledge distillation, channel pruning, and spatial attention to optimize the model for real-time performance. We evaluate our approach on a diverse set of scenarios, including daytime, nighttime, and adverse weather conditions, and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving the overall safety and reliability of autonomous vehicles.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperation in Complex Environments
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems are increasingly being used to tackle complex tasks in various domains. However, cooperation among agents in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that enables effective cooperation among agents in complex environments. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to model agent relationships at multiple scales, allowing agents to selectively focus on relevant peers and share knowledge. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmarks and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and overall system efficiency compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation using Self-Organizing Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, which leverages self-organizing principles to adapt to dynamic environments. Our approach, called 'SOmA', uses a distributed, auction-based mechanism to allocate tasks to agents, taking into account their capabilities, workload, and communication constraints. Simulation results demonstrate that SOmA outperforms existing decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of task completion time, agent utilization, and system resilience. We also provide a theoretical analysis of the algorithm's convergence properties and communication complexity.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents have different capabilities and task requirements. We propose a decentralized approach based on distributed constraint optimization, which allows agents to negotiate and allocate tasks in a distributed manner. Our approach is resistant to single-point failures and can handle dynamic changes in the system. We evaluate our approach using a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to centralized allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, interpretable decision-making is crucial for safety, trust, and accountability. This paper presents HAT-MAD, a novel hierarchical attention network architecture that enables explainable decision-making in multi-agent scenarios. HAT-MAD learns to focus on relevant agents, their relationships, and context-dependent features, generating attention weights that provide insights into the decision-making process. We evaluate HAT-MAD on a variety of multi-agent tasks, demonstrating improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.
